webTitle: RAC plans cradle to grave service

fields.headline: RAC plans cradle to grave service
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lex, the business and motoring services group, yesterday pinned its hopes on the RAC's becoming a "cradle-to-grave" service for car-owners and the engine of earnings growth.
fields.body:
Lex, the business and motoring services group, yesterday pinned its hopes on the RAC's becoming a "cradle-to-grave" service for car-owners and the engine of earnings growth.

The RAC, for which Lex paid £437m last year, now has 5.4m members, including 3.5m corporates, or about 4m fewer than the rival AA, part of Centrica. But Andy Harrison, Lex's chief executive, said it was winning half of all new motoring organisations' members.

"We promised a £30m profit improvement and we are on course to do that and more. What we intend doing is develop it as a cradle-to-grave motor services brand in the £50bn auto after-market," Mr Harrison said.

But, unlike the AA, which is the spearhead of Centrica's drive into a range of home as well as roadside services, the RAC will remain a purely motoring service, including financial products.

"It's all about motoring and it will stay in motoring and we are not going to take it into the household," said Mr Harrison.

He promised a continuing improvement in the quality of earnings but the cost of transforming the group from a car dealership took its toll with pre-tax profits down 18% in the first half to £29.2m and, after exceptionals, down even further to £19.3m. Underlying profits were up £1m at £35.5m.

The company blamed the pound, consumer uncertainty and falling car prices for its profits decline but pointed to a 43% rise in the RAC's earnings to £14.3m pre-tax or half the overall total as the strongest pointer to the future.

Lex has bought 140 car service centres for all makes and offers assistance from the roadside breakdown via a tow to repairs in some areas. Its aim is to persuade motorists to access this network, including the BSM learner-driver schools, via the web or a smart card.

It sold its car dealership business to Pendragon (and Royal Sun Alliance) for a net £83m in March, a "particularly well-timed move," according to Mr Harrison.

webTitle: MFI plans 1,500 new jobs in expansion programme

fields.headline: MFI plans 1,500 new jobs in expansion programme
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: MFI, Britain's biggest bathroom and kitchen retailer, is to create 1,500 jobs as part of a three-year, £100m programme of new store openings and refurbishments.
fields.body:
MFI, Britain's biggest bathroom and kitchen retailer, is to create 1,500 jobs as part of a three-year, £100m programme of new store openings and refurbishments.

The group has brought in Conran Design to help develop a new look for its stores but says the move is in response to increasing customer sophistication and is not an attempt to move upmarket.

MFI, which includes the Hygena and Schreiber brands as well as the Howden Joinery business, is planning 20 out-of-town stores and could open more than 40 more of the smaller, high street stores of the type piloted in Chiswick.

This week the group also tied up a deal to sell its Hygena and kitchen ranges through a number of Currys stores.

"With a 30% share of the [bedroom and kitchen] market we are dealing with the market as a whole. We don't want to be dealing with a particular part of the market to the detriment of another part of the market," according to chief executive John Hancock.

Mark Horgan, MFI's customer and service director said that MFI's top of the range kitchen sold for £12,000.

Customers were becoming "more design conscious and fashion aware," he said.

MFI has undergone significant restructuring since profits reported last year fell 70%. Yesterday the group reported pre-tax profits of £34.7m in the 24 weeks to June 17. Though there is no direct comparison because MFI has changed its year end, the group said the results showed a 37.2% increase on a pro forma basis.

"The position is that we have more opportunities than we can resource," Mr Hancock said. He was "reasonably optimistic" for the second half of the year, though he warned against expecting the same level of improvement as in the first half.

Interim dividend has been increased 29% to 0.9p a share and on the stock exchange MFI shares closed down 1.25p at 61p.

webTitle: Halifax fights for business customers

fields.headline: Halifax fights for business customers
fields.standfirst: Mortgage bank tries to stop clients deserting Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Halifax used its half-yearly results presentation yesterday to pledge an aggressive fight for new business and current account customers, while cranking up efforts to prevent mortgage customers defecting to rivals.
fields.body:
Halifax used its half-yearly results presentation yesterday to pledge an aggressive fight for new business and current account customers, while cranking up efforts to prevent mortgage customers defecting to rivals.

The country's biggest home loan provider, which has delayed the start of its Intelligent Finance telephone and internet bank to next month, has already contacted 500,000 of its 2.5m mortgage customers and intends to reach the rest of them at the rate of 225,000 a month.

The fight to retain customers, however, will take its toll on its profit margins in the coming year. The bank said moves to retain customers were working, with 10% transferring to better products and the bank boosting its share of new mortgage lending to 12%, above its target but still below its historic share.

The move reflects the competition in the mortgage market and the pain that new entrants such as Standard Life bank have inflicted on the leading lenders.

"Customer retention is our line in the sand. We do not expect to see more customers leaving us than joining us," said James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax.

Mr Crosby admitted that the bank had been "guilty of sitting back" by letting its mortgage business be stolen by new entrants.

He said Halifax intended to turn the tables on the clearing banks - Lloyds TSB, HSBC, NatWest (Royal Bank of Scotland) and Barclays - which dominate the current account, credit card and small business banking market and face competition investigations.

He refused to set specific targets for boosting its share of the current account market - it has about 2m customers - or its non-existent share of small business customers. The delayed Intelligent Finance operation is expected to be main conduit for new customers, however, with a current account that offers a 5% rate of interest.

Halifax, which yesterday reported a record pre-tax interim profit of £885m, suffered another 25p fall in its shares to 512p as investors ex pressed anxiety about its scope for profits growth in the future. The shares were floated at 774p three years ago.

The pressure on profit margins was also highlighted by its closest rival, Abbey National, this week, and comes amid a general negative sentiment towards bank shares.

Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro, said Halifax's strategy to retain customers would put pressure on the new entrants. "This is amply reflected in Egg's share price," Mr Coleman said. Egg, in which Prudential owns a majority stake, was floated at 160p last month but slumped another 10p yesterday to 118p.

Halifax is already generating 38% of its profits outside its core mortgage business, in life products - where its sales in the first six months were higher than Legal & General - and through its treasury operation.

In addition to setting up Intelligent Finance, Halifax is to establish own-brand internet products, an online insurance business and has bought a stake in the private banking group St James' Place.

Halifax will pay a dividend of 8.5p, up 13%.

webTitle: Pop review: A beguiling cat's cradle

fields.headline: A beguiling cat's cradle
fields.standfirst: Fonda 500 Notting Hill Arts Club, London ***
fields.trailText: Fonda 500 Notting Hill Arts Club, London ***
fields.body:
"Is that the right beat?" A faintly perplexed singer and keyboardist Simon Stone is gazing up at his guitarist, improbably named Nick 500. Nick shrugs. A few minutes later, Stone asks: "Any musicians in tonight? Am I out of tune?"

Meanwhile, Nick battles with his new keyboard, which, for no apparent reason, is precariously balanced on a stand designed for an instrument at least a foot wider. From anyone else, this kind of behaviour would signal a disaster of a show. And yet, not only do Fonda 500 perform with aplomb, they make their audience grin from the first off-key note to the last.

Fonda 500's music is a cat's cradle of exuberance and incompetence, punk vigour and hamfisted - but always enjoyable - attempts at breezy, harmonious pop.

The Hull quintet's albums - January's playful debut Eight Track Sound System and its speedy follow-up, Autumn: Winter Collection - are fun to listen to, but not half as entertaining as the live show. There's one very good reason for this: Stone is clearly bonkers.

He spends the show tapping kiddie rattles against his head, daring the audience to steal from his packets of cookies, breaking randomly into Duran Duran's The Reflex and reciting snatches of dialogue from the film Wild Geese in a ridiculous gnarled accent.

As he sings Betamax, he twists the bobbles on his woolly hat as if they're picking up radar signals. Each note on his keyboard is named but that doesn't seem to make a great deal of difference; delightfully, when he hits a wrong key, his vocals follow suit without a trace of embarrassment.

It's not that the band are without ambition; more that their sense of fun sometimes speeds ahead, leaving their musicianship panting in the dust behind. Each song has its momentary flashes of inspiration - the rollicking guitar riff that kicks off The Glen Mcaffrey All Star Singularity, the quivering melody line in Interstella Invitation.

They flicker, are almost extinguished, then suddenly flare up again. Contrary though it may seem, it is precisely this imperfect quality that makes Fonda 500 so beguiling. And, of course, the fact that their frontman knows that a gimmick or two can go a long way.

webTitle: Theatre review: A jagged journey

fields.headline: A jagged journey
fields.trailText: Mr Peter's Connections Almeida Theatre, London **
fields.body:
Memory has always been a key feature of Arthur Miller's work: either the collective memory of a nation or the haphazard one of an individual. But in this free-floating 80-minute piece, here getting its British premiere, it becomes the entire theme.

The action takes place in the mind of Harry Peters: an ex-Pan Am pilot and Princeton lecturer who, in a derelict New York nightclub, conjures up figures from his past and present. We get to meet, in an echo of Death of a Salesman, his globe-trotting, wise-cracking brother and a blonde, voluptuous ex-lover called Cathy-May - a name that reminds you of Marilyn Monroe, christened Norma Jean.

We watch, bemused and disengaged, as Miller's hero ruminates on the social upheavals of the American century, and searches for "the subject", the single idea that will make sense of his life. At last he seems to find it, through the character of a pregnant woman called Rose, in the love of a father for his child.

Miller undeniably captures the discontinuous nature of aged memory. He also shows his gift for distilled aphorism: "How like sex the trumpet is," mutters Harry at one point, "it always leaves you kind of sad when it's finished." And Miller evokes an American past in which you never locked your front door and American presidents were morally righteous, "rather than just entertaining".

The problem with the play lies in its form. The characters have no objective existence: they simply become figures in Harry's dream, which rules out external conflict or internal development. A black bag lady seated in the corner may symbolise Harry's marginalisation of a whole race: we never, however, get to hear her story. Equally, Cathy-May is simply seen as a sex-object used and abused by men. How, one wonders, does she see herself? Running throughout the play is a vein of bullish locker-room sexism which Miller may record rather than endorse - but it is none the less dramatically limiting.

Miller, at his best, documented the failure of the American Dream; here he is simply charting the time-bending dreams of an individual. The result, while psychologically accurate, is stubbornly undramatic. Not even Michael Blakemore's atmospheric production or Peter J Davison's set, which turns Manhattan's concrete canyons into a dissolving hall of mirrors, can compensate for the absence of internal tension. One is left admiring John Cullum's craggy, intransigent selfhood as this latterday Prospero, the dutiful support of Nicholas Woodeson as the Grouchoesque brother and of Jan Waters as Harry's ex-Rockette wife. But what you finally get is a jagged journey through Miller's psyche rather than an authentic dramatic event.

 Until September 2. Box office: 020-7359 4404.

webTitle: Expansion and price cuts cause slump in BT profits

fields.headline: Expansion and price cuts cause slump in BT profits
fields.standfirst: Forcing the pace: Fierce competition prompts restructuring
fields.trailText: BT might consider a flotation of its wholesale fixed-line business - selling services to other businesses - after yesterday reporting a 27% slump in the group's first-quarter pre-tax profit from £772 to £561m.
fields.body:
BT might consider a flotation of its wholesale fixed-line business - selling services to other businesses - after yesterday reporting a 27% slump in the group's first-quarter pre-tax profit from £772 to £561m.

Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive, said the company was still in discussions with telecoms watchdog Oftel and the Department of Trade over plans to split the retail and wholesale fixed-line businesses.

He wants the wholesale business to remain under Oftel's regulation with the retail arm possibly governed by the competition commission.

Asked if he would consider selling the wholesale arm, Sir Peter said: "We haven't ruled anything in or out."

In April, BT announced it had restructured the company into four main divisions: Ignite, BT Openworld, BT Wireless and Yell. It was also planning to separate its fixed-line wholesale and retail businesses.

Deutsche Telekom, another former state-owned monopoly, added to the sombre mood for the telecommunications sector by reporting that its first-half net profit slid 26% to €700m (£420m). The German firm blamed its decline on the the cost of acquiring 7m new mobile phone customers.

BT said the fall in its pre-tax earnings was caused by fierce competition on prices in Britain and a rising interest bill. Its net interest bill quadrupled to £239m.

BT has spent heavily on third generation licences in Britain and Holland and bought out the shareholdings in Telfort and Esat it did not own. Those moves meant the company's debt has almost doubled to £15.4bn in that period.

Robert Brace, finance director, said the company might consider asset sales as one way of reducing debt in the future.

BT expects its debt to in crease to £20bn by March next year. Group turnover rose 36% to £6.8bn, benefiting from solid growth in its Concert joint venture with AT&T and its Japanese operations.

Analysts said the solid turnover growth supported BT's shares, however, which fell only 3p to 866p.

"These are a sound set of results and certainly the top-line change for BT is now the growth in turnover which has accelerated as we move the company away from the traditional core business in the UK," Sir Peter said.

The company's investors were also reassured by the improvement in BT Cellnet. Mobile communications turnover for BT jumped from £508m to £620m.

Sir Peter admitted that "BT Cellnet has significantly underperformed Vodafone in the UK in terms of profitability". He said BT was committed to doubling Cellnet's profit this year.

However, BT's biggest division - the fixed-line wholesale and retail business - suffered severe price competition from resellers in that market, which saw turnover from calls fall 5.4% to £1.4bn.

The company expects that fall to continue but said it would match the fierce competition in the fixed-line business with production innovation.

BT managers said in April that they would restructure the group and consider floating parts of the business to unlock value and bolster the flagging share price.

However, no time frame was given for the potential sale or flotation of the various divisions.

Yell, the company's Yellow Pages directory service, is expected to be listed by the year-end.

BT yesterday appointed ABN Amro Rothschild and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to manage Yell's sale which analysts have estimated is worth as much as £5bn.

webTitle: Pru wins TUC pension scheme

fields.headline: Pru wins TUC pension scheme
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Prudential is to run the TUC stakeholder pension scheme.
fields.body:
Prudential is to run the TUC stakeholder pension scheme.

The move is part of the insurer's aim to achieve "scale" in the stakeholder pension market, which officially gets under way in April.

Providers will not be allowed to charge fees greater than 1%, which is considered to be low in comparison with existing pension products.

The deal with the TUC will give the Pru access to 5.5m union members. Many insurers are looking for stakeholder clients.

The announcement came as the Pru reported a fall in its sales in Britain, where it is reducing costs by cutting 5,000 jobs in its sales force.

Jonathan Bloomer, chief executive, predicted the stakeholder pension and shifting demand for products would lead to takeovers and mergers in the sector.

While the Pru was considering whether to bid for Equitable Life, which put itself up for sale this month, the group might also look outside Britain.

He held out little hope for a quick distribution of its £7bn-£9bn "orphan" estate - untraceable assets in its funds - following this week's news of Axa's £400 offer to policyholders.

The Pru is now generating half of its sales outside Britain, particularly from the US where it owns Jackson Life and in Asia.

Overall, the Pru reported a 14% rise in first half profits to £425m but its shares fell 39p to 917p, in part because of disappointment about the 6% rise in the dividend to the 8.2p.

Mr Bloomer said investors were mistaken in treating the Pru, which recently floated on the US stock market, as a British life insurance company. "We're very much an international financial services group."

Jonathan Bloomer, chief executive, predicted the stakeholder pension and shifting demand for products would lead to takeovers and mergers in the sector. While the Pru was considering whether to bid for Equitable Life, which put itself up for sale this month, the group might also look outside Britain. He held out little hope for a quick distribution of its £7bn-£9bn "orphan" estate - untraceable assets in its funds - following this week's news of Axa's £400 offer to policyholders. The Pru is now generating half of its sales outside Britain, particularly from the US where it owns Jackson Life and in Asia. Overall, the Pru reported a 14% rise in first half profits to £425m but its shares fell 39p to 917p, in part because of disappointment about the 6% rise in the dividend to the 8.2p. Mr Bloomer said investors were mistaken in treating the Pru, which recently floated on the US stock market, as a British life insurance company. "We're very much an international financial services group."

webTitle: Investors dump Amazon shares

fields.headline: Investors dump Amazon shares
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Shares in online retailer Amazon.com fell sharply yesterday as investors lost patience after a second-quarter revenue shortfall.
fields.body:
Shares in online retailer Amazon.com fell sharply yesterday as investors lost patience after a second-quarter revenue shortfall.

Shares in Amazon, which is seen as a bellwether for the entire online retailing sector, fell in heavy trade on Nasdaq.

"It was a disappointing quarter, leading some we spoke with to say the conference call 'was like attending a wake'," Dain Rauscher Wessels analyst George Sutton told clients. "It was painful to listen to this top-tier internet brand admit it does have issues maintaining its growth, given its size."

Mr Sutton, who maintained a "buy-aggressive" rating for Amazon, lowered his price target to $50 (£33) from $85.

On Wednesday, Amazon reported that second-quarter revenues rose to $578m, short of the $600m some analysts had hoped for, even as the company posted a quarterly loss that beat Wall Street's per share estimate by two cents.

Amazon had an initial target for 90% revenue growth. The results reported by the company on Wednesday showed only 84% revenue growth.

It was the latest in a string of bad news for the company. This week, its share price dropped 10% after its president Joseph Galli abruptly quit, its stock was downgraded by two analysts ahead of earnings and its website crashed.

Amazon said, for its second quarter to June 30 it recorded a pro forma net loss of $115.7m, or 33 cents per share, excluding special items, against a loss of $82.7m, or 26 cents a share, in the same period last year.

The company was expected to lose 35 cents a share, according to the consensus analyst estimate compiled by First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks brokerage estimates.

Amazon stock has fallen from a 52-week high of $113 set in December.

webTitle: Proms review: Charismatic debut

fields.headline: Charismatic debut
fields.standfirst: BBC Philharmonic/Jarvi Royal Albert Hall, London *****
fields.trailText: BBC Philharmonic/Jarvi Royal Albert Hall, London *****
fields.body:
Like father, like son, so they say. The Estonian-born conductor Paavo Jarvi - son of Neemi - has been causing a stir of late as the result of his performances with the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra and the BBC Philharmonic, as well as a series of powerful recordings for Virgin Classics.

A pupil of Leonard Bernstein, he has much of the latter's charisma and a similar ability to galvanise an orchestra into playing with furious intensity and bravura panache. This was his Proms debut, and a packed Albert Hall was buzzing with excitement before he even stepped on to the platform. Huge cheers greeted his appearance and what followed was outstanding.

His programme consisted of Beethoven's First Piano Concerto (with Lars Vogt as soloist) and Mahler's Sixth Symphony, both works subjected to a radical re-examination, their emotional content unforgettably exposed. Classicism slides into Romanticism in Beethoven's pivotal concerto. Jarvi and Vogt cover the widest stylistic and expressive range that I've ever heard in the work, kicking off with skittish, Mozartian elegance rather than the usual militaristic stiffness, then deepening and darkening the music as they go.

The weighty limpidity of Vogt's playing brings with it a sudden, shocking pre-echo of Chopinesque chromaticism in the slow movement. The Dionysiac elation of the finale peers forward to Beethoven's own Fourth Symphony, then further on to Brahms.

Jarvi's Mahler (like his father's) is powerhouse stuff, his version of the Sixth not so much a noble, tragic statement as a terrifying portrait of a world floundering on the edge of a void. The whole seems to reek of decay and rot. This is the last gasp of the Romantic revolution that Beethoven instigated. The symphony's so-called "motto theme", all pulverising brass and drums, first sneers at the rapturous emotions that surround it, then crushes them with ferocious brutality.

The ludicrous minuet that forms the central section of the scherzo comes over as an obscene memory of imperial Vienna in its glory days. There's no peace anywhere, not even in the slow movement; its central theme is riddled with chromatic unease and never quite follows the melodic contours you expect. An overwhelming achievement: one of the great conducting careers of the 21st century is now, unquestionably, under way.

webTitle: Brown's spree will force up interest rates, says Niesr

fields.headline: Brown's spree will force up interest rates, says Niesr
fields.trailText: Interest rates will need to rise by half a percentage point to quell the inflationary impact of Gordon Brown's bumper increase for public spending, a leading independent economic thinktank warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Interest rates will need to rise by half a percentage point to quell the inflationary impact of Gordon Brown's bumper increase for public spending, a leading independent economic thinktank warned yesterday.

Experts at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said the chancellor's 6.7% real terms increase in public spending this year was "awkwardly timed" because the economy was already running at close to full speed.

"Inflationary pressures will build up because the economy will be growing faster than its potential trend rate of growth at a time when there is little spare capacity," the institute said in its quarterly report on the economy.

The Niesr experts predict that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee will be forced to increase the cost of borrowing by 0.25% by the end of the summer, to 6.25% and to 6.5% by the beginning of next year to damp down inflationary pressures.

US interest rates also look set to rise after new figures showed that employment costs and orders to factories for high-pric ed durable goods surged in June.

Manufacturing orders rose by 10%, led by a record increase in demand for aircraft, the largest monthly increase in nine years. The market had been expecting a rise of just 0.1%. Meanwhile, wage and benefits costs rose by 4.4% over the 12 months to June, also a nine-year high.

Analysts said the figures called into question the widely held view that the economy was beginning to slow. "Today's numbers keep the Fed very much in the picture," said Anthony Karydakis, senior economist at Banc One Capital Markets in Chicago.

Despite the threat of higher interest rates, the Niesr report said the British economy was set for a period of relatively high growth, with output expected to rise by over 3% this year and next.

Stronger productivity growth would allow earnings to rise as well, the institute noted, although it warned that if the productivity improvements did not materialise, borrowing costs would need to be higher still.

Niesr's economists believe that Britain could enter the single currency with the pound valued at around €1.55 - equivalent to DM3, well above most previous estimates of the sustainable rate.

webTitle: United draw a blank with Blanc

fields.headline: United draw a blank with Blanc
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has failed with a surprise attempt to entice Laurent Blanc to Manchester United from Internazionale.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has failed with a surprise attempt to entice Laurent Blanc to Manchester United from Internazionale.

The Italian club were willing to allow Blanc to join the Premiership champions, but the 34-year-old French central defender rejected the move yesterday after a series of talks with United that followed France's European Championship triumph this month.

"We have made three bids for Blanc but he has turned them down," Ferguson explained last night. "Other than that we have not bid for any other player apart from Fabien Barthez."

Internazionale confirmed the news Coventry City's fans were dreading last night by declaring an official interest in Robbie Keane. The Serie A club are confident of enticing the 20-year-old Republic of Ireland striker for £11m before bolstering their attacking options by trying to sign Marcelo Salas from Lazio for £15m. "First it will be Keane and then, eventually, the Chilean [Salas]," said Inter's managing director Gabriele Oriali.

The fears of Arsenal and Chelsea were also realised yesterday when Nwankwo Kanu and Celestine Babayaro were named in Nigeria's provisional squad for the Olympics. The Gunners' manager Arsène Wenger had said that Kanu would not be going to the Olympics as he might miss five Premiership games and three Champions League ties.

Arsenal are becoming resigned to losing Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit. The new Barcelona president Joan Gaspart hopes to conclude a deal worth around £25m for the pair before the weekend.

Barcelona have confirmed Llorenc Serra Ferrer as their new coach on a one-year contract. He was in charge of the youth team for three years.

The coach immediately made his mark by telling six players - Vitor Baia, Frédéric Dehu, Winston Bogarde, Samuel Okunowo and Jari Litmanen - they can go.

Parma have bought the former Aston Villa striker Savo Milosevic from Real Zaragoza for about £15m on a four-year deal. George Weah has been granted a free transfer by Milan, giving Fulham renewed hope of signing the former world player of the year.

webTitle: South Africa fights cup vote

fields.headline: South Africa fights cup vote
fields.trailText: South Africa has appealed to Fifa over the controversial vote that gave Germany the 2006 World Cup.
fields.body:
South Africa has appealed to Fifa over the controversial vote that gave Germany the 2006 World Cup.

Although the world governing body's president Sepp Blatter has already stated that the vote will stand, South Africa believes it has a valid case after consulting the New Zealand Football Association, the Oceania Football Confederation and a lawyer in Brussels.

Senior South African officials last week met the lawyer, an expert in Swiss law, who advised them that their association might have legal grounds to call for the Fifa vote to be conducted again.

The appeal to Fifa asks for arbitration on last month's vote in Zurich, which South Africa lost 12-11 when the New Zealander Charles Dempsey, who had a mandate from Oceania to vote for South Africa once England were out of the running, instead alleged intolerable pressure and abstained from the final round.

Irvin Khoza, chairman of South Africa's 2006 bid committee, said the South Africa Football Association had sent a letter to Fifa "asking them to set the process in motion".

He said it was hoped the association would be able to present the information gathered by himself and its senior official Danny Jordaan in the past three weeks.

The association's executive had instructed Khoza and Jordaan to establish whether there were legal or constitutional grounds for challenging Fifa's decision, and the decision to approach the governing body for arbitration came after extensive information gathering by the pair.

Khoza said the appeal had been made under article 59 of the Fifa statute, which deals with the right of any member to arbitration. Jordaan said: "We have a moral and legal obligation to our people, our supporters and the African continent to proceed with this matter."

Dempsey resigned as president of the Oceania Football Confederation and quit as a member of the Fifa executive committee.

webTitle: Bradford suffer mettle fatigue

fields.headline: Bradford suffer mettle fatigue
fields.standfirst: Tarassov 16
fields.trailText: Chris Hutchings' prediction that his team's task would become harder as they progressed through the rounds of the Intertoto Cup was proved right here in last night's semi-final first leg. The Bradford manager's side, looking tired from their recent excursions to Lithuania and Holland, were beaten in a manner more comfortable than the scoreline suggests.
fields.body:
Chris Hutchings' prediction that his team's task would become harder as they progressed through the rounds of the Intertoto Cup was proved right here in last night's semi-final first leg. The Bradford manager's side, looking tired from their recent excursions to Lithuania and Holland, were beaten in a manner more comfortable than the scoreline suggests.

Bradford were forced to make changes to the side that won against RKC Waalwijk in the previous round with David Wetherall missing through injury and Aidan Davison preferred to Gary Walsh in goal. Zenit meanwhile came in to the match on the back of eight straight wins, including four in this competition.

The game, played inside a packed Petrovsky stadium - any English side being a big draw to Russian football fans - produced a hectic opening 10 minutes with St Petersburg taking the lead after 16 minutes with their first serious chance.

Andrei Kobelev was allowed space to tee up a shot from outside the area which beat Davison before coming back off his left-hand post. Yevgeny Tarassov got to the rebound first to score his first goal for the club.

Zenit then took the initiative, with Alexander Gorshkov on the left and Sergei Osipov on the right looking particularly dangerous. All the real chances were going to the Russians, and they hit both bar and post half-way through the first period.

Bradford, on the other hand, were having difficulty putting anything of note together. David Hopkin was put in a good position by Stuart McCall but his cross came to nothing.

Bradford started the second half with more purpose as both Lee Sharpe and Dean Saunders managed to get in to the game. Saunders was unlucky to see his header from a Sharpe corner go wide on the hour. Bradford's best chance, however, fell to Lee Mills, put through after good work by the tireless Mc Call. His shot was well blocked by the goalkeeper Vyatcheslav Malafeev, as was Hopkin's follow-up.

Zenit, though, kept creating and wasting their own chances, with Tarassov being particularly guilty. A second goal would have left Bradford with an extremely difficult task for the return leg next week. As it stands, Hutchings and his men can look forward to the second leg in the knowledge that it could have been much worse.

Zenit St Petersburg (4-4-2): Malafeev; Igonin, Tsvetkov, Katulsky, Nedorezov; Gorshkov (Gorovoy, 70), Kobelev (Ugarov, 66), Spivak, Osipov; Popovich, Tarassov.

Bradford City (5-3-2): Davison; O'Brien, Atherton, Nolan, Myers, Sharpe; McCall, Windass, Hopkin (Whalley, 86); Saunders, Mills.

Referee: B Coue (Fr).

webTitle: Hancock stakes higher claim as holders mock doubters

fields.headline: Hancock stakes higher claim as holders mock doubters
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 280
Northants 218
Gloucestershire win by 62 runs
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 280
Northants 218
Gloucestershire win by 62 runs.
fields.body:
The mean-spirited have been tempted to call Gloucestershire escapologists and winners by default, because of their contentious though legitimate second chance against Worcestershire and then, 24 hours later, their resilience to scrape a win against Leicestershire in the fourth round.

But yet again, at a convivial Nevil Road yesterday, they mocked their indeterminate championship form to prove themselves beyond question the best-equipped one-day side in the country.

They beat Northamptonshire by 62 runs to earn a home semi-final against Lancashire. Their immediate regret, however, is that Ian Harvey, who took four wickets, will be missing. He has been called away to join the Australia squad.

Gloucestershire, the NatWest Trophy holders, win matches not by feats of individual brilliance but by balanced efficiency. That is especially true of their energetic fielding. The little, inexperienced Chris Taylor chased in at midwicket to catch David Sales; James Averis stretched up his arms to avert a six and hold on to a straight-driven catch from Mal Loye.

Tim Hancock was stumped for 110 and had no serious challenger for the man-of-the-match award. He has emerged as an important, intelligent and alert batsman. Soon he may have to be considered for higher stature.

Diffident by nature, at one time appearing to be destined for that permanent label of unfulfilment known vaguely as "promising", he has grown in assurance, as has his range of shots. And he can easily adjust to the needs of limited-over cricket. In the field he moves with loping strides; at the wicket he chases with the short single-minded steps of a sprinter.

Here he straight-drove with a handsome sweep of the bat, daringly judged dangerous singles, manifested the occasional late cut into unoccupied territory and effortlessly whacked a midwicket six beyond the long boundary and into the crowd.

He might have been caught at deep square-leg on 83 but he was not inhibited by the solitary lapse and walked out to Graeme Swann to reach his hundred with a flamboyant six over long-on.

Gloucestershire like to bat first in these games. They are brisk practitioners, devouring runs with the morning coffee, hoping to fill opponents with apprehension. Apart from Hancock, there were Dominic Hewson and Kim Barnett to construct an innings with mostly untroubled intent.

Northants looked short of bowlers. Hewson, a young batsman in form, to the exclusion here of Matt Windows, set the mood until caught at the wicket after a drinks break. Barnett made his half-century, in the process undergoing an impromptu medical test on his injured ankle as he responded to a succession of sharp runs; he did not look like a 40-year-old with a limp.

Gloucestershire lost six wickets in their final six overs in the ritual slog. Darren Cousins was Northants' most successful bowler but they knew going into the match that they had to rely on their batsmen.

Just fleetingly it seemed as though the target might be within reach. Much depended on Matthew Hayden but he drove submissively into the covers. His fellow Australian Jeff Cook was altogether more positive, belting Mark Alleyne for six and taking four boundaries in an over from Averis.

Yet he was out to a weak lunge, and after that Tony Penberthy's 50 was no more than a gesture. Harvey, shuffling swing, pace and kidology, took four wickets and the off-spinner Martyn Ball three. The obligatory streaker earned a good deal less attention than the girl steward who chased him unavailingly for 100 yards.

webTitle: Fabulous Flintoff weighs in with a ton

fields.headline: Fabulous Flintoff weighs in with a ton
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 210
Lancashire 214-2
Lancashire win by eight wickets
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
Surrey 210
Lancashire 214-2
Lancashire win by eight wickets.
fields.body:
The most attractive of the NatWest quarter-finals turned out to be even more one-sided than the other three, with Lancashire swaggering past Surrey with eight wickets and 14 overs to spare.

Andrew Flintoff, who has recently been compared with Lennox Lewis but whose blows yesterday had some of the terminal quality more readily associated with Mike Tyson, knocked Surrey out with a breathtaking innings.

Lancashire's jolly white giant, omitted from the England squad for next week's third Test, smote 19 fours and four sixes in an unbeaten innings of 135 that occupied only 110 deliveries.

With Sourav Ganguly he added 190 for the second wicket in only 29 overs, a competition record for Lancashire. Flintoff's share was 123. Ganguly was no slouch with an 84-ball fifty. But he was lapped several times by his partner.

Surrey already knew what Flintoff was capable of. In a championship match at Old Trafford two years ago he scored 61 from 24 balls, including 34 off one Alex Tudor over. And against Essex in Chelmsford last year he cudgelled 143 from 66 deliveries.

Yesterday's innings was more measured, but it was still brutal stuff. Those who argue, with some justification, that he is a mighty hitter and no more might have been surprised by the way his feet twinkled. There were also some sensible singles.

Most memorably, though, he reached his half-century with successive straight sixes off Jason Ratcliffe, the second off the back foot. Ratcliffe, in for the dropped Mark Butcher, had relieved Carl Greenidge, who coming in for the injured Martin Bicknell had been savaged for 33 in only four overs. Flintoff hit him for three fours in four balls.

He also pulled Tudor for six over midwicket and drove Ben Hollioake for another over long-off. Surrey, who had won their previous 11 matches in all cricket, were simply blown away.

John Crawley, Flintoff's captain, said that it was "one of the greatest innings ever played in domestic one-day cricket". David Gower said: "We have just seen one of the most awesome displays on a cricket field."

We had something of a convention of false gods here yesterday. Everywhere you cared to look there was a saviour of English cricket. The Hollioake brothers, Ian Salisbury, Chris Schofield, Alex Tudor...

Now Flintoff took the role. George Sharp should have given him out lbw to Saqlain Mushtaq's googly when he was 67, and Alistair Brown dropped him at slip one run later. But on a turning pitch he played Saqlain and Salisbury with some assurance.

Surrey were burned by their own Bunsen. The championship leaders, who also lead the National League Second Division, prepared another turning pitch for Saqlain and Salisbury. But Lancashire, in Schofield, Gary Yates and Gary Keedy, picked three twirly men.

The off-spinner Yates, not considered a big turner of the ball, made it hum here and so did Keedy. But Schofield was the pick, taking four wickets for the second time in successive NatWest matches.

Surrey's batting, however, was inept after Alec Stewart and Ian Ward had put on 80 for the first wicket. Brown was out reverse-sweeping against the spin before his eye was in and Ben Hollioake, brainlessly, jumped down the wicket to his fourth ball and was stumped immediately after just surviving a similar fate.

Graham Thorpe promised to revive them with a 64-ball fifty but then he swung a Schofield full toss straight to midwicket.

Surrey's 210 never looked enough. Tudor plucked out Michael Atherton's off stump with his third ball but in view of what followed he probably wishes he had not bothered.

webTitle: On their general's secret service: Pakistan to spy on their own players

fields.headline: On their general's secret service: Pakistan to spy on their own players
fields.trailText: The Pakistan Cricket Board is to counter corruption by snooping on its own players. According to the Dawn newspaper yesterday, an undercover agent will be appointed to spy on the team at home and on tour.
fields.body:
The Pakistan Cricket Board is to counter corruption by snooping on its own players. According to the Dawn newspaper yesterday, an undercover agent will be appointed to spy on the team at home and on tour.

The international man of mystery is expected to begin monitoring the players during Pakistan's visit to Singapore next month for a triangular one-day series also involving New Zealand and South Africa. He will continue to operate during England's tour of Pakistan from October to December this year.

"The spy will shadow the team, stay in the same hotel and keep an eye on the cricketers, like who they meet, where they go and when they return to the hotel," Dawn reported.

Dawn said the spy would be responsible only to Lieutenant General Tauqir Zia, the chairman of the Pakistan board. "A person would be appointed who would work undercover and report only to me," Zia said. "His identity would be known only to me and he would be answerable to me.

"The cricketers will be briefed about the appointment of the official and his job description. But nothing more."

Pakistan cricket has been overshadowed by allegations of match-rigging for years. The Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum report released in May resulted in life suspensions for the former captain Salim Malik and the pace bowler Ata-ur-Rehman. It added that "doubts of varying intensity have been cast on the integrity of some members of the team in their individual capacity".

The Qayyum report sug gested that the board should appoint a private eye to investigate allegations of match-rigging and collusion with bookmakers.

Dawn also said that the board had added a clause to the players' contracts by which they could be fined or suspended even if they were merely "found socialising with people of suspected characters".

"The board has to safeguard the reputation of the country and the team," one of Dawn's sources explained. "If the players are not involved in corruption they have no business to be associating with bookies."

webTitle: Warne's refusal to sign hat sparks punches in pub

fields.headline: Warne's refusal to sign hat sparks punches in pub
fields.trailText: Shane Warne seems to be fated for a colourful existence while serving out his summer contract with Hampshire.
fields.body:
Shane Warne seems to be fated for a colourful existence while serving out his summer contract with Hampshire.

Police were called to a celebration involving the Australian and his county colleagues this week when Warne refused to sign an autograph for an apparently drunken supporter after Hampshire's victory over Middlesex in the quarter-final of the NatWest Trophy .

Players, including Warne and England's Alan Mullally, were heckled while drinking in the Lord's Tavern in London on Tuesday. Police were called by the pub's manager Julie Stewart as the incident turned nasty some three hours after Hampshire completed their seven-wicket win.

Stewart said: "There was a bit of a scuffle but nothing serious and it was quickly sorted out."

A spokesman for the Metropolitan police confirmed they had been summoned. "Several customers were involved. Our inquiries are continuing."

Hampshire are conducting their own inquiry into the latest incident involving their expensive Australian import. Two months ago the Australia vice-captain admitted making suggestive phone calls to a girl he met in a Leicester nightclub.

But an onlooker said Warne was not at fault in the current incident. The eye-witness, who refused to be named, said: "This supporter was obviously drunk and asked Warne to sign the rim of his hat. Warne said he would when he finished his own drink. But this guy persisted and kept shouting and taunting him about the Leicester nightclub thing, so Warne said he would not sign the hat.

"This just made it worse and before long a couple of punches flew in, though Shane was not involved in any way. One of his friends did get hit."

A man was ejected from the pub and Warne and some team-mates remained.

Meanwhile, Warne's international team-mate Mark Waugh says he is willing to have his financial records scrutinised to prove he has told the truth about his dealings with an Indian bookmaker. He and Warne were fined by the Australian Cricket Board after admitting accepting money from a bookie in 1994 in return for weather and pitch information.

webTitle: FA cracks down on abusive players

fields.headline: FA cracks down on abusive players
fields.standfirst:
Crime and punishment: the measures
Players' union wants a total exclusion zone
fields.trailText: The Football Association yesterday announced some of the toughest disciplinary measures in the history of the game, including lengthy bans and heavy fines, to combat the rising tide of verbal and physical abuse being directed towards match officials by players and managers.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday announced some of the toughest disciplinary measures in the history of the game, including lengthy bans and heavy fines, to combat the rising tide of verbal and physical abuse being directed towards match officials by players and managers.

Under the new rules, if a group of players try to intimidate a referee, as Manchester United's were accused of doing last season against Middlesbrough, the guilty club could be fined up to £250,000 and deducted two points.

The FA has defined mass intimidation of a referee as an incident involving three players or more. If any club was to be found guilty of the same offence within the same season then it could be fined up to £750,000 with another two points deducted.

The FA was criticised last season for not taking any action against United or Keane, the captain who led the charge against the referee Andy D'Urso.

The new rules are also stricter about individual players who try to verbally intimidate referees.

Those found guilty will be liable to a minimum three-match ban plus a fine of one week's salary.

Disciplinary panels will be able to take into account the rank of a player and could increase the punishment if it is the team or club captain.

Managers who abuse referees or match officials from the touchline or dug-out will be liable to a minimum three- match suspension from the side of the pitch plus a fine of a week's wages.

The new rules are strictest over the striking or assaulting of referees. Under the new measures, a player found guilty of such an offence will be liable to a minimum 12-match suspension and a fine of one month's salary.

When the former Sheffield Wednesday striker Paolo Di Canio shoved the referee Paul Alcock to the ground during a Premiership match against Arsenal at Hillsborough in September 1998 he was banned for a maximum of 11 games and fined £10,000.

Under the new rules, Di Canio would have been banned for a minimum of 12 games but would also be liable to a year-long suspension if he was to repeat the offence at any time.

The FA's chief executive, Adam Crozier, said: "We have come up with a system that is fair, transparent and consistent. All players and clubs now know where they stand. It does not matter which club you play for because everyone will be treated in the same way.

"What happens in the Theatre of Dreams or anywhere else is replicated around the country.

Players have to understand they are role-models. We are trying to make the system more consistent and saying to people that from hereon in, everyone is on an equal footing. I don't care if it's Manchester United or Macclesfield, everyone will be treated the same."

The new rules also go some way towards formalising the use of video evidence. From the start of the new season, three-member panels will study video evidence of incidents that might have been missed by the referee.

The panels will comprise a representative from the playing side, perhaps a former professional player or manager, somebody from the referees' side and an independent legal expert. There will be a pool of up to 12 members.

The FA has ruled, however, that the video panel will only be able to make decisions on cases of mistaken identity or wrongful dismissal where the player has been served with a three-match ban.

A speedier disciplinary process is also being put in place. The FA said that it will aim to make decisions on whether charges are to be brought against a player within four days of any match.

The disciplinary panels will also contain a legal expert and the FA is recruiting lawyers.

Crozier said that all clubs would be notified of the new rules, which were drawn up in conjunction with the Premier League, players' and managers' representatives and referees.

He added: "There was a feeling that last season there was more indiscipline towards referees.

There was more jostling of officials. Everyone within the game agreed that something had to be done about this. We want players to think at least three or four times before they actually do anything."

fields.headline: Crime and punishment: the measures
fields.standfirst:

fields.trailText: • Players or managers manhandling match officials to be banned for a minimum of 12-matches and fined four weeks' wages. At least a one-year suspension for any repetition.
fields.body:
 Players or managers manhandling match officials to be banned for a minimum of 12-matches and fined four weeks' wages. At least a one-year suspension for any repetition.

 Penalties between a fine of one week's wages and a three-match ban for threatening or abusive behaviour to officials, players or spectators.

 Clubs to be fined if a match official is intimidated or harassed by three or more players. In serious cases, two points to be deducted.

 Clubs to be fined if six or more players are booked in a game.

 Fines and possible points deductions for clubs with fans involved in crowd trouble.

 Any offence of discrimination to result in double the normal penalty.

 Players with five bookings by the end of February will receive a one-match ban; with 10 by the second Sunday in April a further two match ban. There is a three-match ban for 15 yellow cards and four for 20.

 Advisory panel, made up of former managers, referees, players or administrators to investigate incidents requiring video evidence in cases of mistaken identity or wrongful dismissal.

 Lifetime ticket ban for anyone involved in the game found selling or offering tickets for sale at more than face value.

 Fine and/or suspension for anyone found guilty of betting.

 All charges to be brought within a maximum of four days after a match and often sooner. Hearing dates to be set within three weeks.

fields.trailText: The Professional Footballers' Association yesterday proposed a "five-yard no-go zone" to be introduced around referees to prevent them being intimidated by players.
fields.body:
The Professional Footballers' Association yesterday proposed a "five-yard no-go zone" to be introduced around referees to prevent them being intimidated by players.

After new regulations were announced yesterday that will see players suspended for 12 matches if they are found guilty of manhandling officials, the PFA is urging its members to help improve the game's tarnished image by avoiding any confrontation with referees and their assistants.

"We believe the officials should be allowed a five-yard no-go zone that players should not encroach, so they can get on with their jobs to the best of their ability," the chief executive Gordon Taylor said last night. "If the players have that in their minds and treat the referees with the respect they deserve, it will be for the better of the game.

"There were a number of isolated incidents when referees were intimidated last season, the like of which we don't want to see again, and it is only right that they receive the proper protection, especially at a time when the game is so high profile.

"We need to set as high standards as we can and the players have to take it upon themselves that intimidation of referees will not be tolerated.

"The main responsibility lies with the players but the clubs should not duck this issue. As employers, they are responsible for their workers so this is a joint matter for them, the managers and the players.

"The main thing is that these guidelines have sent out the warning signs before the start of the new season so everyone knows exactly where they stand."

The Football Association's efforts to protect the welfare of match officials were welcomed by the Premier League referees' officer Philip Don.

"This has to be seen as a positive step," he said. "There have been a few isolated incidents in recent seasons and we don't like to see those. But there is such a lot at stake for everybody in the game today.

"We sat down with the various bodies earlier this year and discussed ways of improving the game's image. Everybody in the game is looking for proper punishments for players who break the law and these would appear to fit the bill."

webTitle: Housing benefit system 'in meltdown'

fields.headline: Housing benefit system 'in meltdown'
fields.standfirst: MPs in broadside against £12bn service after flood of complaints
fields.trailText: The £12bn housing benefit system was "in meltdown" last night after a storm of criticism from MPs, housing association chiefs and the local government ombudsman who disclosed that he was deluged with complaints from aggrieved claimants.
fields.body:
The £12bn housing benefit system was "in meltdown" last night after a storm of criticism from MPs, housing association chiefs and the local government ombudsman who disclosed that he was deluged with complaints from aggrieved claimants.

The Commons social services committee told the Department for Social Security it must act urgently to simplify rules that are confusing claimants in nearly 5m households and causing administrative chaos in many areas.

"The complexity and constant changes to the current scheme present fundamental barriers to efficient administration," the Labour-dominated committee said.

It instructed the DSS to "display greater self-discipline" and take responsibility for improving the quality of service instead of blaming poor local authority administration in some areas.

In a separate initiative, the chief executives of 15 of London's largest housing associations said administration of the benefit should be removed from local authorities and given to a national agency that could be consistent. "We are experiencing meltdown in some areas. Councils have been given an unfair task by government. The system cannot work as it stands," said Peter Redman, chief executive of the Notting Hill Housing Group.

Edward Osmotherley, the local government ombudsman, summoned the chief executives of four London boroughs to a meeting earlier this week to explain the huge volume of complaints from housing benefit claimants in their authorities.

A spokesman said there were 1,669 complaints of maladministration of housing benefit in the London region over the 12 months to the end of March and 60% of these were from people in the boroughs of Lambeth, Islington, Hackney and Southwark where the service is run by private contractors.

Housing aid workers have reported increasing delays in payment of benefit in many parts of the country, particularly where the service had been contracted out to private contractors. This is causing tenants to fall into arrears, leading to evictions and the withdrawal of rented property from the market by landlords seeking to avoid complications.

Housing benefit is the main plank of a programme that started more than 50 years ago to help low income families stay in decent and affordable accommodation. The cost of the programme quadrupled over the past 20 years as local authorities and housing associations were encouraged to push up rents.

According to the most recent official estimates from 1997-98, incorrect housing benefit payments cost the taxpayer £840m a year, of which £600m was attributed by the DSS to fraud. However, only £180m of that total was confirmed as fraud.

"We urge the department to evaluate and consider the costs to the public purse of fraud and error, and the potential for indirect savings to be achieved by making the scheme easier to administer, easier for claimants to understand and less susceptible to fraud," the MPs said.

A DSS spokesman said the department would reply in due course once there had been an opportunity "to give the report the just consideration it deserves".

webTitle: Jobs go as Murdoch rethinks web strategy

fields.headline: Jobs go as Murdoch rethinks web strategy
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News International has broken up its troubled new media division, made dozens of staff redundant and is thought to be ready to abandon its high profile online entertainment auction brand FiredUp.com.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News International has broken up its troubled new media division, made dozens of staff redundant and is thought to be ready to abandon its high profile online entertainment auction brand FiredUp.com.

It is understood that around 30 staff have either been made redundant or left voluntarily after the closure of News Networks, NI's internet division run by Mr Murdoch's son-in-law Alasdair MacLeod.

Most were working on FiredUp.com, the auction site launched last year with an expensive television advertising campaign fronted by actor Bruce Willis. The others came from jobs site revolver.com.

News Networks was set up at the start of this year and given responsibility for the online editions of the Sun, News of the World, Page3.com, The Times and The Sunday Times. Control of those sites is being handed back to the individual newspapers.

Susan Boster, a senior executive with responsibility for managing NI's growing stable of new media investments and co-ordinating alliances with parent company News Corporation, has left the group. Other executives are understood to be working their notices.

Remaining staff, who were told about the changes earlier this week, are unsure about the full extent of the reorganisation.

A spokeswoman for News International last night refused to comment. "We have nothing to say on this," she said. Ms Boster and Mr MacLeod could not be reached for comment.

However, an internal memo from NI chief executive Les Hinton seen by The Guardian, says that News Network, which was only set up at the start of this year, is being merged with News International Ventures, the existing reader offer and brand extensions business, to create New Commercial Ventures (NCV).

It will be headed by FiredUp.com general manager Brett Miller, with Alex Stitt, a director of News International Ventures, acting as his deputy.

FiredUp.com has struggled to find its niche in the fiercely competitive online auction market while NI as a group has had difficulty transferring the commercial success of its core newspapers like The Sun and The Times, into the online arena.

In common with many newspaper groups it has been looking for a way to take its brands online without cannibalising too much of its existing, and cash generative, newspaper sales.

CurrantBun.com, a free ISP based around the Sun, was set up last year, quickly rebranded Bun.com and then after a heavy TV advertising campaign sold to pan-European ISP World Online for an undisclosed sum.

Lineone, an ISP and portal, was launched in partnership with BT but NI pulled out and several of Lineone's technical team departed for the BBC. Lineone's media partner is now United News & Media.

In March, webzine theregister.co.uk got hold of a leaked NI memo from Mr MacLeod that suggested that employee morale at the new media company was low and employees were dissatisfied with management.

Mr Hinton has previously emphasised the importance of digital media to NI. In May, while outlining a series of new divisions aimed at accelerating development of NI's digital franchise, he said: "News Network has been the catalyst in developing an expertise and culture which we can now adopt throughout the company to take full advantage of the potential presented by the new economy."

webTitle: How to write a sitcom

fields.headline: How to write a sitcom
fields.standfirst: Adam Evans   finds himself in a desperate situation and turns to the net for some light relief
fields.trailText: Adam Evans finds himself in a desperate situation and turns to the net for some light relief
fields.body:
Have you ever sat through a turgid half hour of humourless television and thought to yourself, I could write a better sitcom with my eyes closed, one hand behind my back and a colony of vicious drone ants living in my underwear? Have you?

Well, of course you have. And if you've ever had a go at writing your own comedic masterpiece, you'll have found that it's a whole lot harder than it looks. Characterisation, pacing, timing and - above all - being hilarious is tough. The internet is not an obvious place to look for help in writing a sitcom.

Being funny is, after all, a creative process, not something that can be searched for or bought on an auction site. Or so I thought, until I took a long hard look at my own half-written pilot episode. It had decent characterisation and reasonable plot development but - at the end of it all - not a single funny line.

In desperation, I headed to the web and discovered a wealth of resources. The Write Stuff is the official website of the BBC's comedy script unit, which receives between 1,200 and 1,500 scripts each year.

It is essential reading: the writers' guidelines tell you everything you need to know about submitting your script, including formatting pages, tips on concepts and, importantly, what the Beeb is really looking for in a sitcom. At the other end of the scale is www.hahabonk.com, a website that develops and produces original animated sketches and sitcoms. They are actively looking for new concepts and scripts for online animated short films - the only criterion, they say, is that "it has to make us laugh".

Unfortunately, most production companies aren't very good at supplying online submission details for would-be sitcom writers. This is where insider contacts and friends of friends come into their own but, of course, you're just starting out, so you don't have any industry chums.

Fear not, there are ways around this: the UK Sitcom Writing List is an online discussion forum for sitcom writers. Recent topics include Steve Coogan's new production company and tips on how to behave when meeting the new ITV head of comedy, Sioned William. A great place for advice, discussion and insider information.

Another excellent site with a community feel is Situations Vacant, which "works with new writers and performers to devise, develop and test on stage sitcoms and comedy concepts for television and radio". It also organises London-based sitcom trials (next show in September), has an archive of original scripts and supplies a comprehensive top 10 of sitcom dos and don'ts.

If it's advice you're after, don't miss out on Sitcom Writing http://members.aol.com/dsimon9874. It features interviews with professional comedians, tips on how to structure your sitcom and sample sketches from Smack The Pony.

Another invaluable resource is Writing for Performance www.kelly.mcmail.com. This is the most comprehensive sitcom site I've seen, offering an excellent guide to sitcom basics, transcripts of interviews with television producers, and contact details for 20 comedy production companies.

If you're not sure that your script is ready to be sent to a producer, the Screenwriters' Workshop at www.lsw.org.uk may be the place for you. It has links to writing groups and offers a professional, paid-for, script evaluation service. If you think you'd benefit from taking an online course, take a look at TV Comedy College. For £100 you can buy six foundation units in comedy writing, taught by three experienced sitcom writers with impressive pedigrees. (A free sample module is available on request.)

Finally, when you're working on your script and the words just won't flow, pay a visit to Tom's Comedy Quotes at http://tomsquotes.amhosting.net. This has inspirational quotes by the bucketful from those greats of the sitcom world, Cheers and Seinfeld. Another good place for kick-starting your creative juice pump is the TV Comedy Database, which has cast, production and episode details for more than 600 British sitcoms. Browsing through these programmes can be both depressing and invigorating.

The chances of you coming up with something even half as wonderful as Fawlty Towers on your first attempt are extremely slim. But at least you'll be able to manage something funnier than Heartburn Hotel and Up Rising (two of the direst sitcoms it has ever been my misfortune to endure) simply by persuading a city gent to fall into a manhole when distracted by an attractive young lady. Oh, my sides.

webTitle: Blair unveils NHS plan for 21st century

fields.headline: Blair unveils NHS plan for 21st century
fields.trailText: More than 20,000 extra nurses, 7,500 more consultants and 2,000 GPs are to be employed in the NHS as the cornerstone of the government's national plan for reform of the health service, the prime minister promised today.
fields.body:
More than 20,000 extra nurses, 7,500 more consultants and 2,000 GPs are to be employed in the NHS as the cornerstone of the government's national plan for reform of the health service, the prime minister promised today.

An extra 7,000 NHS beds - including 5,000 intermediate care places to look after elderly people and stop so-called "bed-blocking" - will also be funded.

As part of the shake-up, unveiled by Tony Blair in the House of Commons, ministers aim to cut the maximum waiting time for an operation from 18 months to six months by 2005. By 2008, no patient will wait more than three months for treatment on the NHS, according to the plan.

And from 2002, any patient whose operation is cancelled for non-medical reasons will have their surgery within 28 days - even if it means the NHS paying for them to go to a private hospital, the government promised.

The blueprint - The NHS Plan: A Plan for Investment. A Plan for Reform - is being billed as the most radical reform of the health service since it was founded in 1948.

It includes proposals for 100 new hospital schemes over the next decade, an overhaul of consultants' contracts and the creation of new "senior sister" posts for nurses - a modern-day matron.

As part of modernisation of primary care services, 500 one-stop centres will be established, combining GPs, dentists, opticians and other health and social care professionals under one roof.

By 2002, all patients will be able to see a primary care professional within 24 hours and a GP within two days, under the plan.

By 2004, all patients arriving at hospital casualty departments will be seen within four hours, the plan pledges.

Millions of outpatients who are currently seen in hospitals will instead be referred to 1,000 "specialist GPs" in areas such as eye treatment, skin diseases and ear, nose and throat problems.

Contracts for family doctors are to be overhauled so that they are paid if they meet set standards and quality targets.

Under the plan, more than 20,000 extra nurses and 5,500 more training places will be established to boost staff numbers.

Senior sisters will be put in charge of ward cleanliness and being given greater powers to discharge patients.

A new grade of "therapist consultant" will be established by 2004 to end traditional demarcations between nurses and doctors.

It also pledges that new diagnostic and treatment centres will be built to ease the burden on hospitals and specialise in particular areas of surgery which can be performed in a single day or with a short stay.

But older people are set to be disappointed by the government's refusal to accept the recommendations of a Royal Commission that all nursing and personal care should be free. Instead, nursing care in homes will be free from 2001 - currently people pay for this. But personal care, which can include changing dressings and catheters, will still be charged for.

Cottage hospitals and specially designated wards in hospitals will have intermediate care beds in a bid to stop "bed-blocking" by elderly patients who do not need acute care.

A nationwide "clean up" campaign of hospitals is also to be launched under the plan. Hospitals will be inspected by undercover teams, including patients, every six months. National standards for cleanliness are to be set down and every NHS Trust will have to appoint a board member who will be responsible for monitoring standards.

A new Modernisation Agency is to be set up to implement the changes and cut waiting times to meet the ambitious new targets set out in the plan. And a new "traffic light" system will show how different hospitals and trusts are performing.

Trusts which meet all their targets and are in the top 25% of well performing organisations will be give the "green light" - and rewarded with greater powers, extra cash from a new Performance Fund and less inspections.

"Yellow light" trusts will meeting most of their targets will have to draw up plans with regional bosses before they can get their hands on the Performance Fund.

Failing trusts will be shown the red light. They will have to draw up a "recovery plan", will only be able to get extra money by applying to the Modernisation Agency and could be taken over by managers from "green light" trusts.

Sharon Holder, national officer of the GMB union, said: "This represents a real improvement in the delivery of care to patients and is what those who work and rely upon the NHS have been crying out for."

In a bid to tie doctors more closely to the NHS, newly-qualified hospital consultants will have to work exclusively for the health service for the first seven years of their careers before they can undertake private work.

Consultants will have to work at least seven "fixed sessions" in the NHS a week in a bid to cut the amount of time they can spend doing private work. And a new "concordat" between the NHS and the private sector will mean NHS doctors and nurses will be able to use beds and operating theatres in the independent sector to treat patients.

Nigel Edwards, policy director of the NHS confederation, which represents health authorities, said: "The government has been brave to address head-on the really difficult problems facing the NHS, particularly: changing the relationships between government, the professions and patients; how to move to common standards of performance; and how to persuade clinicians to do the most effective things not what they have always done.

"This makes it truly radical and presents NHS staff, particularly its managers, with a huge change agenda."

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "The BMA supports the national plan's aspirations to build a stronger NHS."

A spokesman for the Patients' Association said: "There are some very good ideas in this plan but now these things have really got to happen and the money has got to be there."

The boost will mean that in five years time there should be nearly 349,000 nurses working in the NHS. A spokeswoman for the Royal College of Nursing said: "We do believe these are new nurses."

An extra 7,500 consultants and 2,000 GPs are also pledged to be in place by 2005. There are currently 35,000 consultants and 25,000 GPs.

But a spokesman for the British Medical Association said: "It is very difficult to unravel all of the figures. Some of those consultants are already in the pipeline and would have been brought on-stream anyway."

National standards for cleanliness are to be set down and every NHS Trust will have to appoint a board member who will be responsible for monitoring standards. A new Modernisation Agency is to be set up to implement the changes and cut waiting times to meet the ambitious new targets set out in the plan. And a new "traffic light" system will show how different hospitals and trusts are performing. Trusts which meet all their targets and are in the top 25% of well performing organisations will be give the "green light" - and rewarded with greater powers, extra cash from a new Performance Fund and less inspections. "Yellow light" trusts will meeting most of their targets will have to draw up plans with regional bosses before they can get their hands on the Performance Fund. Failing trusts will be shown the red light. They will have to draw up a "recovery plan", will only be able to get extra money by applying to the Modernisation Agency and could be taken over by managers from "green light" trusts. Sharon Holder, national officer of the GMB union, said: "This represents a real improvement in the delivery of care to patients and is what those who work and rely upon the NHS have been crying out for." In a bid to tie doctors more closely to the NHS, newly-qualified hospital consultants will have to work exclusively for the health service for the first seven years of their careers before they can undertake private work. Consultants will have to work at least seven "fixed sessions" in the NHS a week in a bid to cut the amount of time they can spend doing private work. And a new "concordat" between the NHS and the private sector will mean NHS doctors and nurses will be able to use beds and operating theatres in the independent sector to treat patients. Nigel Edwards, policy director of the NHS confederation, which represents health authorities, said: "The government has been brave to address head-on the really difficult problems facing the NHS, particularly: changing the relationships between government, the professions and patients; how to move to common standards of performance; and how to persuade clinicians to do the most effective things not what they have always done. "This makes it truly radical and presents NHS staff, particularly its managers, with a huge change agenda." Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "The BMA supports the national plan's aspirations to build a stronger NHS." A spokesman for the Patients' Association said: "There are some very good ideas in this plan but now these things have really got to happen and the money has got to be there." The boost will mean that in five years time there should be nearly 349,000 nurses working in the NHS. A spokeswoman for the Royal College of Nursing said: "We do believe these are new nurses." An extra 7,500 consultants and 2,000 GPs are also pledged to be in place by 2005. There are currently 35,000 consultants and 25,000 GPs. But a spokesman for the British Medical Association said: "It is very difficult to unravel all of the figures. Some of those consultants are already in the pipeline and would have been brought on-stream anyway."
