fields.body:
ROBBO ROBBED

We really want to leave Bryan Robson alone, we really do. After suggesting that he lived in a parallel universe, or that he had been trained by MI6 to become 00Robbo, we really thought that we had done enough. But sadly, we haven't, so here is the latest instalment in his continuing adventures.

Last night, Christian Ziege failed to turn up at the Rockcliffe training ground for talks which, according to Robson, weren't "clearing the air talks". Which they weren't, because Ziege didn't turn up. Robson did learn something that evening though, when he found out that the clause in Ziege's contract allowing him to talk to clubs that bid £5m or more for him did exist, after Robbo had spent the last couple of months denying it. Then Robbo admitted he had received a bid from Liverpool (which the rest of us have known about since Monday) but said that: "I have not responded to it yet."

The response of a beleaguered man, the Fiver reckons, and one who had probably already heard of Ziege's interview in this week's Kicker (like Shoot! with lots of umlauts) in which he says: "Liverpool interest me greatly, especially as they will be playing in Europe next season." Or the remarks from his agent, which suggest a move from the North East to Merseyside is imminent.

But never mind, that won't stop Robbo in his improbable quest to buy himself a good side. The latest rumours, following on from those linking him with Dani, Boksic, Hasselbaink and Jesus suggest that he wants to spend as much money as he possibly can on signing, wait for it, Steve McManaman. The man who left Liverpool to sample the continental lifestyle and, more importantly, win some trophies. Oh dear.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Win a fantasy night for you and 5 of your friends courtesy of www.e-street.com - the essential new service for planning your shopping, eating and drinking in London.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FOLLOW THAT FERG (PT 2)

Still struggling to keep up with the whinging of the Imperial Lord Ferg? Don't worry, the Fiver's back with our cut-out-and-keep guide.

No 3: The World Club championship

"The tournament had very much the atmosphere of an inaugural event. A motley crew of competitors had been assembled by invitation and there was little of the buzz and crackle of a major championship. But I am not trying to use that as an excuse"

Don't forget to collect the set!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SEAT ON THIS!

The Fiver has never been a big fan of PR. You need a degree to be able to cast a vote under porpoise-enal repres repr, that election thing. Pot Rice will often be too soggy. Peter Reid has a monkey's heed, and as for that job that basically involves throwing parties for a living, well the mere mention of it usually brings us out in spots. But today, as Newcastle United decide to take their own fans to court in order to pursue missing costs from the Save Our Seats affair, the Fiver advises them to get some good public relations going. And quickly.

The six Newcastle fans who lost an appeal against having their seats, which were guaranteed by club bonds, moved across St James's Park to make way for executive boxes have, like most losers, been asked to pay the legal costs for both sides. This total is estimated at £198,000, a whole £80,000 more than the six were insured for. They claim they took out a policy based on estimates provided by the club, estimates that now prove to have been a little bit under. So naturally the only way for the club to get their money back (money which would pay Duncan Ferguson's wages for all of, ooh, a fortnight) is to head back to court.

"The board believes that the most appropriate way forward is to allow the matter to proceed to a costs hearing where the costs of the action payable by the claimants can be independently assessed by the court," read a heartfelt club statement today. "Subsequent to this assessment the board of Newcastle United plc will then consider the determination of the court and consider what further actions, if any, should be taken." Jane Duffy, leader of the six, agreed at least in part: "We believe that the final bill will be significantly less than £80,000, but to be honest it could have been written off and that would have been the end of it. But now it just drags on and on." Anyone got a number for Max Clifford?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I was wrong and I think the team were wrong. It is a passionate game, especially in the Premiership, but we were definitely bang out of order. The manager said that and hopefully it will never happen again."

Roy Keane finally apologises for his verbal assault on Andy D'Urso (about six months late). And we're sure it won't happen again either.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE YEAR OF THE FOX

"Money, money, money, always honey. In a rich man's world!" And which rich man's world is the Fiver talking about? San Tropez? Old Trafford? Anfield? Try Filbert Street. Because today Leicester chairman (or should that be foxy playboy?) John Elsom splashed out a club record £5m on Wolves' Ade Akinbiyi, to take his total spending this summer over the £10m mark.

It may not sound like a lot in these days of £37m transfers, but it is more than the parsimonious Peter Kenyon at Manchester United or David Moores at Liverpool have given their managers this pre-season. And the good news for Foxes fans (and other first division managers) is that he's ready to offload more dosh! "It does not necessarily mean an end to the spending. We are going seriously into this season to be a very successful team," Elsom said in a fit of extravagance. The spendthrift!

Or maybe not. Because Leicester manager Peter Taylor has obviously seen something in the 25 year-old Akinbiyi that Norwich, Hereford, Brighton, Gillingham, Bristol City and Wolves fans have all missed, claiming that the Nigerian international has been his prime target since ever since he became Leicester manager. "I had a look at the players as soon as I got here and I wanted some pace and power - somebody who would score goals," Taylor said, conveniently forgetting about Akinbiyi's complete lack of a first touch. "Ade fits the bill. He was always top of my list."

The Fiver has certainly noticed his pace and power, but a look at Akinbiyi's goalscoring record in lower division football (207 appearances, 74 goals) doesn't exactly mark him out as a marksman on the Steve Bull scale. So until he proves us otherwise we reckon Taylor is probably only two-thirds right - although, as Meatloaf once pointed out, two out of three ain't bad.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Barcelona coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer has admitted that "grave problems" are threatening Boudewijn Zenden's proposed £8m transfer to Lazio - although he hasn't said what they are. And Serra Ferrer added: "I wouldn't have a problem if the deal collapsed and Zenden stayed here. He is still an interesting player."

George Weah has left AC Milan and is expected to move to AS Roma in the next few days.

Celtic manager Martin O'Neill wants to sign Manchester United goalkeeper Mark Bosnich on loan. United have turned down a permanent deal but Celtic are still waiting to see whether Sir Alex Ferguson will allow Bosnich to sign a three-month loan agreement.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The FA are seeking talks with the government to try and persuade them to limit the number of non-EU players in the English game. "We believe a quota system is the right way forward," said FA spokesman Steve Double. "Our proposal is that there should be a limit of two non-European Union players in the Premier League and one in the First Division." The news comes after the government said it was unlikely that a quota system on all foreign players being brought into Britain would be possible under the Treaty of Rome.

Sunderland manager Peter Reid has signed Slovakian international Stanislav Varga for £875,000.

Good news for Manchester City fans. Striker Shaun Goater's hopes of being fit for the start of the new season have increased with the news that his knee operation has been a success.

Chelsea have blocked a request by the Nigerian FA for Celestine Babayaro to join a pre-Olympics training camp next month, but will not attempt to prevent him competing in the tournament.

Arsenal defender Brian McGovern, a Republic of Ireland Under-21 international, has joined First Division Norwich on a month's loan with a view to a permanent transfer.

Yugoslavia defender Sinisa Mihajlovic has retired from international football, telling Belgrade daily Sportski: "The time has come to say goodbye and give young players a chance."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World football: Get hottest CONCACAF scoops here first. Or maybe second (depending on whether Futbol Mondial get there first).

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (4.30am) LA luminous tropical fish v Tampa Bay marinated tuna steaks.

Sky Sports 1: Beach soccer (6.30, 10.15pm) An evening of top-drawer sports kicks off with fat men.

Fifa TV (7.30, 11.15pm) Then moves seamlessly into fat bureaucrats.

Futbol Mondial (9pm) Before coming to rest at the top transfer news from Burundi.

webTitle: Sisters of mercy

fields.headline: Sisters of mercy
fields.standfirst:
For 21 years, Southall Black Sisters have campaigned in defence of women jailed for killing violent men. Melissa Benn pays tribute

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: For 21 years, Southall Black Sisters have campaigned in defence of women jailed for killing violent men.  Melissa Benn  pays tribute.
fields.body:
You wouldn't give it a second glance, this drab shop front in a silent suburban street. Press a buzzer on the side of the red door and you are in a dark but homely house, a warren of meeting rooms and offices. There are toys out for visiting children, cake in the fridge. But the curtains of the front room are permanently drawn to deter brick throwers, death threats or irate husbands with sawn-off shotguns.

Welcome to a unique institution in British radical life, black life, feminist life. This month, Southall Black Sisters celebrated their 21st anniversary. "Oh yes," said a friend in instant recognition. "They save women, don't they?"

It's easy to see what she means. Over the past two decades, Southall Black Sisters have mobilised some of the most public and poignant campaigns in defence of women jailed for killing violent or abusive men. When Kiranjit Ahluwalia was released from prison in 1992, after the court agreed she had killed her violent husband in a final act of survival, she came to SBS to say thank you. She couldn't believe her eyes, says Pragna Patel. "When she saw that we were so few, she said, how do you do it? How does an organisation with such a big persona operate on such small reserves?"

One answer is commitment, sheer hard work. Southall Black Sisters have four full-time workers, three of whom are funded by Ealing Council, the fourth by a group of charities. Their small offices are cramped, the phone rings constantly. A thousand women a year come knocking on their door, many fleeing domestic violence and the problems it throws up: homelessness, benefits, racial violence, difficulties with immigration status.

"This is no ordinary nine to five job," Patel says. "The workers are so busy dealing with women during the day, the only time they can do their paperwork and administration is in the evenings or at weekends."

In addition Patel, who has recently completed the academic stage of a solicitor's qualification, reckons she and the other committee members give to Southall Black Sisters "between 50% and 70% of our working time, mostly unpaid". What motivates these women is "a sense of belonging, of confidence, a sense that here we are our true selves".

Patel, 39, has been involved with Southall Black Sisters since 1982, but there is a younger generation coming up now, among them Anita Johal, 30. "I came to Southall Black Sisters because I wanted to put in a wider context what had happened to me. I had done a masters in law in relation to race and immigration, yet I had been in a violent relationship myself. That was a cruel irony, to be theoretically studying the issues and yet, in reality, facing them. This job has politicised me, no doubt."

Southall Black Sisters emerged from the 1979 clashes between anti-racist youth and fascists in Southall, the ferment that killed the white teacher Blair Peach. Black women's groups were springing up in many cities but according to Nira Yuval-Davis, professor in gender and ethnic studies at the University of Greenwich, SBS never drowned in what was once fashionable identity politics. "They had enough of a grounding in their own position to be open to other feminists and to work towards shared goals and visions."

As an example of this, she cites a 1984 demonstration outside the house of a young woman driven to suicide by her violent husband. Patel recalls how, after the first ever march through Southall against domestic violence, "we adopted the methods of the Indian women's movement, by standing silently outside. A lot of the women were disguised as they had left the area already because of domestic violence. They were incredibly brave." A white socialist feminist academic ran the crèche.

Since then, Southall Black Sisters have worked with an array of groups to secure the freedom of women like Kiranjit Ahluwalia or Zoora Shah, the non-literate Muslim woman who, in 1992, murdered the man who had waged a campaign of physical and sexual terror against her. Shah remains in prison; Rahila Gupta, a member of Southall Black Sisters since 1989, is writing a play about her.

According to Gupta: "We have always been under attack for washing our dirty linen in public, not just from traditional conservatives but from the black left in general. We are accused of fuelling racist stereotypes." She pauses. "This is the big question we are always asking ourselves - how to present a public face without being considered counterproductive."

The question was particularly pertinent in both the Rushdie and Tyson affairs. Southall Black Sisters tried to find a political way, often at great personal risk, between what they saw as white racist stereotypes and a failure in the black community to examine honestly its attitudes towards women.

But public success and a changed political climate have brought new difficulties, Patel says. "We were used to oppositional politics under Thatcher and Major. With Blair, there's a feeling that we should seize the moment and see if we can have a positive influence on the institutions." One of their biggest recent successes was to get the government to drop the notorious one year rule, which left women newly arrived in this country, who had fled violent marriages, with no immigration status. Now such women are allowed to stay indefinitely.

The group is also often asked to talk to senior police officers about race and domestic violence. At one seminar, Johal says: "They had to sit and listen to us for a whole day. Wonderful!"

The price of inclusion is not always so pleasurable. Having lobbied hard to make sure the working party on forced marriages consulted a wider range of women's groups, Southall Black Sisters member Hannana Siddiqui resigned from the working party last month in protest at its support for mediation as a viable option for women in forced marriages.

Yuval-Davis says: "Southall Black Sisters have come to represent some kind of ideal to black feminist activists. But I don't see them as unique so much as the better expression of a wider trend, a trend of self-assertion that has taken root in both the urban centres of Britain and globally. It is the kind of politics that was evident at Beijing where often the best organised groups were not led by western white feminists."

Think global, act local. In their own community, 21 years may not have brought respectability but they have finally brought a measure of acceptance to this extraordinary group of women. "In the early stages," Patel says, "the community was much more hostile. We would be hassled in the street, called prostitutes, home-wreckers and lesbians. But the community has had to acknowledge that we exist. They may or may not like us but they can no longer deny us."

One of their biggest recent successes was to get the government to drop the notorious one year rule, which left women newly arrived in this country, who had fled violent marriages, with no immigration status. Now such women are allowed to stay indefinitely. The group is also often asked to talk to senior police officers about race and domestic violence. At one seminar, Johal says: "They had to sit and listen to us for a whole day. Wonderful!" The price of inclusion is not always so pleasurable. Having lobbied hard to make sure the working party on forced marriages consulted a wider range of women's groups, Southall Black Sisters member Hannana Siddiqui resigned from the working party last month in protest at its support for mediation as a viable option for women in forced marriages. Yuval-Davis says: "Southall Black Sisters have come to represent some kind of ideal to black feminist activists. But I don't see them as unique so much as the better expression of a wider trend, a trend of self-assertion that has taken root in both the urban centres of Britain and globally. It is the kind of politics that was evident at Beijing where often the best organised groups were not led by western white feminists." Think global, act local. In their own community, 21 years may not have brought respectability but they have finally brought a measure of acceptance to this extraordinary group of women. "In the early stages," Patel says, "the community was much more hostile. We would be hassled in the street, called prostitutes, home-wreckers and lesbians. But the community has had to acknowledge that we exist. They may or may not like us but they can no longer deny us."

webTitle: Brazil bounce back

fields.headline: Brazil bounce back
fields.trailText: Just as the vultures were circling around coach Wanderley Luxemburgo and his seemingly slack and disinterested side, Brazil finally came to life to beat in-form Argentina 3-1 in a rousing World Cup qualifying match last night.
fields.body:
Just as the vultures were circling around coach Wanderley Luxemburgo and his seemingly slack and disinterested side, Brazil finally came to life to beat in-form Argentina 3-1 in a rousing World Cup qualifying match last night.

Last week Brazil had slumped to defeat in Paraguay and fallen to fifth in the South American qualifying group. But inspired by 80,000 fanatical fans in the Morumbi Stadium in Sao Paulo, the doubts and lethargy which had characterised their recent play evaporated. They became more like the Brazil of old.

It helped that they got off to the perfect start. The game was barely six minutes old when a corner found Antonio Carlos on the edge of the area and his perfectly flighted chip was headed home by an unmarked Alex at the back post.

But Argentina came right back, and missed several chances to equalise. In the 12th minute Claudio Lopez found Ariel Ortega in space at the far post but his limp header didn't trouble Dida. And minutes later Ortega set up Hernan Crespo with an even better opportunity. But his woeful finish was more like an occasional parks player than a feared £36m striker.

Aregentina were made to rue this sloppiness when Brazil, who had enjoyed the majority of possession, finally took advantage just before half time through a brilliantly worked goal from Vampeta.

The central midfielder started the move on the edge of his own penalty area, exchanged a one-two with Ronaldinho and then fed Alex, who fired in a powerful 20 yard shot which the Argentine keeper Bonano could only parry - leaving Vampeta to slot the loose ball home.

The crowd went wild, but immediately from the restart Argentina hit back. Crespo cleverly flicked the ball into the path of Matias Almeida, and his screamer from the edge of the area thumped past Dida.

The pulsating rhythm continued after the break: Brazil doing all the pressing, but Argentinian always looking dangerous on the break: the visitors very nearly making it 2-2 through Crespo. But in the 54th minute Vampeta killed the game when he finished of a sublime pass by Ronalindho.

Indeed Ronaldinho was a constant thorn in Argentina's side, with most of Brazil's best work going through him. Diego Simeone summed up his side's frustration at one point, by putting his hand around the Brazilian's neck.

But Brazil certainly gave as good as they got in the fouls department. The hotly contested match produced nearly 50 fouls, most of them committed by the home side.

Despite losing their unbeaten record, Argentina stay top of the group with 15 points, while Brazil move into second place on 11 points, ahead of Uruguay on goals scored.

Brazil: Dida, Evanilson, Antonio Carlos, Roque Junior, Roberto Carlos, Vampeta, Emerson, Rivaldo, Ze Roberto (Marques 60), Alex (Cesar Sampaio 75), Ronaldinho

Argentina: Bonano, Sensini, Ayala, Samuel, Zanetti (Almeyda 39), Simeone, Veron, Gonzalez (Sorin 72), Ortega (Gustavo Lopez 72), Crespo, Lopez

Booked: Lopez, Almeyda, Sorin (Argentina); Ronaldinho, Vampeta (Brazil)

Referee: Gustavo Mendez (Uruguay

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... cigarettes
fields.trailText: ... cigarettes
fields.body:
The Chancellor Tobacco Company probably doesn't care much for a bargain ... wanton extravagance is more its kind of thing. And clearly convinced that there are plenty of like-minded customers out there with money to burn, it has launched what it claims is the "most expensive cigarette in the world". At £18 for a packet of 20, Treasurer cigarettes are great if expense is your reason to quit.

In the quest to create the "utmost smoking pleasure" no expense has been spared. From the aluminium/silver tip, to the watermarked paper, this is a very exclusive cigarette indeed. While the tobacco connoisseur will no doubt appreciate the "nutty ... fulsome flavour" achieved through a blend of Virginia tobacco with a small percentage of Burley, the doyen of good taste will be slightly less enamoured with the choice of silver packaging. To describe it as "tacky" would be harsh, but the ultimate in sophistication? I don't think so. Harrods, Selfridges, The Davidoff Shop, St James's. Call 01626 866 422 for stockist information.

webTitle: Cybershopping

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Interiors
fields.body:
Interiors

Cancel your subscription to Wallpaper and Elle Decoration and, while you're at it, get rid of that Ikea catalogue. Everything you need to transform your interiors into loft-conversion cool can be found at www.i4orm.com. Launched earlier this month, i4orm aims to become the "Yellow Pages for the design community" but anyone interested in modern design should take a look at the range of beds, lighting, seating, storage and accessories. The DS 150 Chaise Longue, made from leather and designed around the shape of the human body (£31,000) may be out of your league but 10 'least priced items' - including tumblers and place mats - are proof that modernism isn't just for the mega rich.

Making designer furniture and accessories affordable is what www.europebynet.com have set out to do. The site features over 3,000 products and claims to be up to 60% cheaper than the high street. If you can't find what you're looking for online, send them an e-mail and they'll do their best to find it for you.

Fans of Mufti - the homewares range created by Michael D'Souza - no longer need travel to London's Fulham Road, for his Burmese teak beds and leather letter racks which are now available from www.mufti.co.uk Browse for hand-crafted furnishings and accessories.

webTitle: Welcome to Wal-Mart

fields.headline: Welcome to Wal-Mart
fields.standfirst: Tim Dowling samples a brand new,  all-American shopping experience ... in Bristol
fields.trailText: Tim Dowling samples a brand new, all-American shopping experience ... in Bristol
fields.body:
Britain's very first Wal-Mart, which opened on Monday, is just one of a sprawl of shed-like superstores in an area known as The Mall in Bristol's Patchway district. At three in the afternoon yesterday, the two-acre site is crowded (60,000 customers are expected this week), but as with Tate Modern, there is the sense that the space could accommodate many more visitors.

An American comedian once said of K-Mart, a much-maligned Wal-Mart precursor, that it was the place you went when you had four dollars and you needed snow tires. The Asda Wal-Mart Supercentre Patchway, to give it its fully merged name, appears to be the place to go when you have £15.98 and you need a gazebo. The Wal-Mart concept, like the joke, does not translate perfectly.

Visitors hoping to find a treasure trove of genuine American rubbish - confections of celebratory disgustingness, perhaps, or Confederate flag windscreen stickers - will be disappointed. The "Taste of America" range is actually rather cautious: outsize doughnuts, ribs, some chocolate muffins, a slim selection of baseball mitts (no lefties) and a few bags of Fireside marshmallows. Even the Wal-Mart name keeps a low profile, apart from the gigantic banner lashed to the side of the building.

"Greeters" guard the two entrances, their attentions difficult, if not impossible, to avoid. Once inside, it's difficult to take in the expanse: 100,000 square feet of shopping prairie, with a cafe at one end, clothing (and fitting rooms) at the other, and everything else in between. The staff even use scooters to get around the site.

One feature of the new Wal-Mart experience gets old very quickly: the PA system. Every 10 minutes or so, Neil the greeter grabs the microphone, introduces himself and welcomes you to the store. Dumbly worded customer announcements point out bargains and reunite families: "Could David Norris, currently shopping in the store, please return to your car where your wife is waiting." Mr Norris may have misplaced his Mrs, but presumably even he knows that he is shopping in the store.

At one point a "colleague", as staff are known, uses the PA to sing Happy Birthday to someone called Jemma. It seems strange that British customers have been so quick to make use of this horrible facility, although it must be admitted that it provided a convenient way to reunite Guardian reporter with Guardian photographer.

In its attempt to distance itself from Wal-Mart's downmarket image, Asda-Wal-Mart has largely succeeded. The wine section is particularly impressive, with bottles of Australian white which might set you back £5 in a late-night off licence selling for £2.29, alongside reds in the £20 to £30 range. The expensive wines are laid out in wooden cases, which is a nice surprise, given that in my local Sainsbury they're kept under lock and key. Elsewhere there is posh balsamic vinegar and grand olive oils with price tags to match, as well as bargain vegetable oils in unfeasibly large containers. Sometimes the mix is uncomfortable: a rather cosmopolitan variety of Chinese and Indian takeaways are available in ready-packed sacks at the front of the store, but the ingredients to make such dishes are tucked away in an aisle unappetisingly marked "foreign food".

The eye tends to strays to signs advertising absurd bargains - this is a Wal-Mart, after all. Basic sliced white is a mere 15p a loaf, the new Harry Potter is £9.87 (list price £14.99, although Amazon has it for £8.99) and butter can be had for as little as 45p.

The store aims to undercut its rivals by an average of 10% - 15%, but some of the reductions are a little stingy - organic wild rocket: was 77p, now 76p - and with the overwhelming selection before you (there are dozens of varieties of everything) it becomes impossible to recall what one normally pays for anything.

Food is only half the story of the Asda-Wal-Mart experience. Just one aisle past the middle you suddenly find yourself surrounded by camping equipment, mobile phones, CDs, vacuum cleaners, toys, toasters, microwaves, bicycles, a pharmacy, an optician, prams, shoes, paint, video cameras and power tools. This half is where the crowds tend to form, looking at the exercise treadmills and music systems on display. This is where parents pushing "Bobby Buggies" - two-seater toy cars mounted on flat-bed trolleys, with the shopping basket at the back - tend to pull over and block traffic so they can shout at their children.

There's no doubt that everything is cheaper, some of it a lot cheaper, but the quality can vary alarmingly. The half-price scooters are but a flimsy imitation of the best-selling model. The non-Black and Decker workbench, which costs £9.98, is suspicious, although the real McCoy sits on a higher shelf, conspicuously unpriced (they normally go for about £89). Is Wal-Mart really the place to buy golf clubs, or a swimming costume, or a circular saw?

Cheap or not, if you're an impulse shopper, things could get very expensive very quickly. Just under £500 may be a very reasonable price for an exercise treadmill, but will it fit in the back of the Volvo?

After an hour or so the novelty of the place begins to wear off, as one succumbs to selection fatigue. There is just too much stuff, spread over too many square feet.

The prices are undoubtedly low, in some cases the lowest in the land. The "colleagues" are preposterously helpful and the Asda-Wal-Mart hybrid is nowhere near as charmless as its American cousin, but for the customer the sheer size of the place is a nuisance.

Over the course of the afternoon I was bewitched, bothered and bewildered, not necessarily in that order, but by the end I was longing for a nice little high street.

webTitle: Fiji plunged into chaos as Speight faces treason charges

fields.headline: Fiji plunged into chaos as Speight faces treason charges
fields.trailText: Armed gangs took to the streets today after Fiji's military threatened to charge the coup leader, George Speight, with treason for threatening the life of the country's new president.
fields.body:
Armed gangs took to the streets today after Fiji's military threatened to charge the coup leader, George Speight, with treason for threatening the life of the country's new president.

Mr Speight was arrested along with three key advisers and a bodyguard at a military checkpoint overnight, the first step in a crackdown on the rebels who plunged the country into crisis two months ago when they seized the entire government hostage.

Hours after Mr Speight's arrest, heavily armed troops fired tear gas as they stormed a school in the capital, Suva, where more than 350 Speight supporters were encamped, military spokesman Lieutenant Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini said. One man died and 39 others were injured, seven seriously, in the clash, Tarakinikini said. Hundreds were arrested.

In another incident, gunmen briefly took some 40 ethnic Indians hostage and kidnapped two New Zealand pilots. Police said some ethnic Indians were rounded up in trucks and taken by gunmen to Labasa's rebel-held military barracks until the military negotiated their release a few hours later.

Police in Labasa on Vanua Levu, Fiji's second largest island, warned residents to stay indoors as 50 gunmen roamed the streets, shooting indiscriminately and looting shops.

At Savusavu airport on Vanua Levu, the New Zealanders working as Air Fiji pilots were kidnapped by gunmen and taken to a nearby village, airport officials said. The pilots are still being held.

"It is completely unsatisfactory for the citizens of another country to be caught up in Fiji's internal problems," New Zealand's prime minister, Helen Clark, told Radio New Zealand. Air New Zealand said it had cancelled flight stopovers in Fiji because of the civil unrest, sparked by Mr Speight's arrest.

Fiji has been in turmoil since Mr Speight and his gunmen stormed parliament in May in the name of indigenous rights and held the ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and most of his multiracial cabinet hostage for 56 days.

Fiji's military said it was in full control and was conducting a "mopping up operation" to arrest more rebels. But troops stepped up security around the main military barracks in the capital Suva, where Mr Speight was being held, and erected razor-wire roadblocks on streets leading to the barracks.

Mobile police units were bussed to locations around Suva on Thursday night. The latest unrest is confined to Vanua Levu island and has not spread to Fiji's main island, Viti Levu.

Police in the west of Viti Levu, home to the majority of Fiji's Indians who work the nation's key sugar farms, said all was quiet tonight. Extra security had been placed at the main international airport at Nadi in the west. Australia issued a new travel advisory on Thursday calling on its nationals to leave.

webTitle: Future of dome 'secure' as theme park

fields.headline: Future of dome 'secure' as theme park
fields.trailText: Dome Europe, a Japanese-led consortium, has won the competition to take over the troubled Millennium Dome, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Dome Europe, a Japanese-led consortium, has won the competition to take over the troubled Millennium Dome, it was announced today.

Making the announcement, Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer of Thoroton said the dome had secured its future. Lord Falconer praised the dome as a "model for future regeneration schemes" that had created 30,000 jobs, although the project has been pilloried ever since its opening at the end of last year.

Dome Europe wants to retain the venue as a tourist attraction featuring virtual reality computer games, a Beatles' "Yellow Submarine" and interactive art galleries. Dome Europe believes it could attract 6m visitors a year - the same number as is now estimated will visit the current exhibition before the end of the year.

Dome Europe said that it planned to continue with the dome's current price structure, which means a single adult ticket will cost £20 and five-person family tickets will cost £57.

But the company added that there will be a one-year season ticket, priced initially at £30. Dome Europe said Nomura, the Japanese financial group, had underwritten about £400m to support the plans and that Dome Europe's development partners would spend a further £400m on the site.

"This is a great day," said Guy Hands, managing director of Nomura International's principal finance group.

The consortium is taking over a troubled venture. The dome has failed to meet projections for visitors and the £800m project has had to ask for extra government cash to keep going. It has raised only £85m in commercial income so far this year - less than half a predicted income revenue of £194m - because total spending by visitors is now expected to be less than half what was originally forecast.

In its third annual report, the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the Greenwich site, blamed the financial difficulties on the strong pound and "negative media coverage".

The report predicted that without a change in circumstances the dome was likely to need extra funding to remain open until the end of the year.

The warning came despite the award of £29m from the National Lottery in May, which came on top of the £496m of lottery funds already committed to the dome.

The NMEC's 74-page report released earlier this month revealed that the dome's total income over this year is now estimated to be £761m, with another £3m set aside to promote and market the attraction.

The significant reduction in the estimates of commercial income reflect the halving of the paying visitor target from 12m to 6m. The accounts indicate that the original £399m of lottery money received by NMEC had now risen to a net figure of £525m, including the additional grants of £60m in February and £29m in May.

The company report, which covers the last nine months of 1999, also revealed details of the pay deals of senior staff. fields.bodyText: Dome Europe, a Japanese-led consortium, has won the competition to take over the troubled Millennium Dome, it was announced today. Making the announcement, Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer of Thoroton said the dome had secured its future. Lord Falconer praised the dome as a "model for future regeneration schemes" that had created 30,000 jobs, although the project has been pilloried ever since its opening at the end of last year. Dome Europe wants to retain the venue as a tourist attraction featuring virtual reality computer games, a Beatles' "Yellow Submarine" and interactive art galleries. Dome Europe believes it could attract 6m visitors a year - the same number as is now estimated will visit the current exhibition before the end of the year. Dome Europe said that it planned to continue with the dome's current price structure, which means a single adult ticket will cost £20 and five-person family tickets will cost £57. But the company added that there will be a one-year season ticket, priced initially at £30. Dome Europe said Nomura, the Japanese financial group, had underwritten about £400m to support the plans and that Dome Europe's development partners would spend a further £400m on the site. "This is a great day," said Guy Hands, managing director of Nomura International's principal finance group. The consortium is taking over a troubled venture. The dome has failed to meet projections for visitors and the £800m project has had to ask for extra government cash to keep going. It has raised only £85m in commercial income so far this year - less than half a predicted income revenue of £194m - because total spending by visitors is now expected to be less than half what was originally forecast. The report predicted that without a change in circumstances the dome was likely to need extra funding to remain open until the end of the year. The warning came despite the award of £29m from the National Lottery in May, which came on top of the £496m of lottery funds already committed to the dome. webTitle: Leaks can be embarrassing but convenient

fields.headline: Leaks can be embarrassing but convenient
fields.standfirst: As the hunt for the leaker at No 10 goes on, Westminster correspondent David Hencke thinks at least this latest leaked memo shows the prime minister as willing to lead - if only Philip Gould will let him
fields.trailText: Thursday, 3.45pm: As the hunt for the leaker at No 10 goes on, Westminster correspondent David Hencke thinks at least this latest leaked memo shows the prime minister as willing to lead - if only Philip Gould will let him.
fields.body:
The latest leak to hit Tony Blair over the euro could be strangely beneficial to him. Contrary to what William Hague and Rupert Murdoch might want to make out of Britain scrapping the pound, it shows that the PM is for once prepared to lead rather than follow.

Indeed it shows that one of Tony's problems is having to put up with the endless witterings from adviser Philip Gould and his overactive focus groups continually giving instant public opinion polls.

Nobody would be surprised that Tony Blair would want a robust debate on joining the Euro or that when it happens he will want to take a strong line. What is gratifying to know from the leak is that already last spring he was laying down the groundrules.

The most interesting thing about the latest stream of leaks to News International papers must be the motive of the leaker. All the issues raised seems to either show the PM afraid of William Hague or worried about the Hague agenda.

The worst part of them show the PM worried about public presentation and wanting easy eye catching quick fixes on issues like crime to take on the Tories. The leaks also seem timed for maximum embarrassment - either just before the big public spending statement from Gordon Brown or in today's leak on the day the government announces its ten year plan for the NHS.

How convenient for the Conservatives. The fun part of the leak story is definitely the role of Benji the Binman, who obviously supplied at least the early drafts of the Philip Gould memos. More worryingly for Sir Richard Wilson, the unfortunate Cabinet secretary, left running a leak inquiry - is where the information from No 10 is coming from.

Nobody knows whether there is store of them - no doubt the next one will come out on the day of Tony's big speech at Labour party conference in September.

webTitle: ITV takes News at Ten case to high court

fields.headline: ITV takes News at Ten case to high court
fields.trailText: ITV announced today that it is applying for a high court judicial review of a decision by the Independent Television Commission to order it to reschedule its late evening news bulletin.
fields.body:
ITV announced today that it is applying for a high court judicial review of a decision by the Independent Television Commission to order it to reschedule its late evening news bulletin.

The announcement comes just over a week after the ITC issued a "legally-binding" direction aimed at forcing the network to bring forward its 11pm ITV Nightly News.

ITV has been told to change the slot after viewing figures slumped for its news programmes following last year's axing of long-running flagship News at Ten.

webTitle: Swiss rollicking for timid Oasis

fields.headline: Swiss rollicking for timid Oasis
fields.trailText: Oasis's credibility as a major rock group has taken a further battering after they left a Swiss stage amidst a hail of missiles - and were later denounced as arrogant and paranoid by the furious festival organisers.
fields.body:
Oasis's credibility as a major rock group has taken a further battering after they left a Swiss stage amidst a hail of missiles - and were later denounced as arrogant and paranoid by the furious festival organisers.

Just 20 minutes into last night's performance at the Paleo festival in Nyon, Switzerland, frontman Liam Gallagher and drummer Alan White were reportedly hit by a hail of bottles and cans thrown by the audience.

Already minus one Gallagher - songwriter and guitarist Noel Gallagher having left the European tour after falling out with Liam - Oasis were no doubt wary of losing their remaining bushy-eyebrowed attraction when they were pelted with debris by a small group of spectators.

After leaving the stage for a short period, they returned but decided to scrap their headline set - for which they were paid at least £66,000 - after just two more songs.

A spokeswoman for the band claimed: "Oasis were forced to stop short their concert due to a handful of festival-goers.

"An announcement was made to the audience advising them that the band wanted to return, but only if nothing more was thrown on the stage.

"The band returned to the stage for two more songs, but were once again forced off when Liam Gallagher and drummer Alan White were hit with debris."

However, Paleo organisers have quickly dismissed these reports, saying that the missiles "consisted of a few empty plastic bottles none of which hit either group member."

Further, the organisers accused Liam Gallagher of provoking the trouble with his "arrogant attitude" and by "insulting the spectators". Oasis's decision was, they said, "totally irrational and a paranoid reflex reaction".

Oasis's spokeswoman apologised to the majority of the festival-goers, who were, she said, unfortunately robbed of "what started out as a fantastic show". In a desperate attempt at damage limitation, she hinted that those responsible for hurling objects might not be legitimate festival-goers but gatecrashers.

The Foreign Office meanwhile confirmed that both the British Consulate and Swiss police were called in by festival security staff after Oasis said they were afraid to leave with the audience still on site. While Swiss police judged that it was safe, it was not enough to allay the fears of the once-swaggering group, who waited for the crowds to clear before making their way out.

Oasis were today on their way back home to Britain, where they are due to play to hopefully more appreciative crowds in Edinburgh.

webTitle: Speaker warns of cynicism in farewell to MPs

fields.headline: Speaker warns of cynicism in farewell to MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Speaker of the House of Commons, Betty Boothroyd, yesterday used her valedictory speech to MPs to warn them against growing public cynicism and to condemn the enemies of parliament - arrogant or long-winded ministers, spin doctors and young MPs demanding shorter working hours.
fields.body:
The Speaker of the House of Commons, Betty Boothroyd, yesterday used her valedictory speech to MPs to warn them against growing public cynicism and to condemn the enemies of parliament - arrogant or long-winded ministers, spin doctors and young MPs demanding shorter working hours.

As she spoke backbench Labour MPs were circulating motions critical of the arcane voting method under which the father of the Commons, Sir Edward Heath, will conduct the election for her successor in three months' time - the rules of which he published yesterday.

Up to 10 names are being floated with Labour's deputy speaker, Michael Martin, an approachable Glaswegian teetotaller this week showing signs of pulling ahead. Whoever wins will have a hard task acquiring Ms Boothroyd's reputation for style, firmness and championing backbenchers' right.

The 70-year-old Labour MP for West Bromwich West, who became the first woman Speaker among the 155 holders of the office, received lavish praise, led by Tony Blair and William Hague. "A passionate parliamentarian" whose judgment was "unerringly sound and fair," said Mr Blair.

Ms Boothroyd coupled her own reproach with an emotional display of gratitude for a job which had never given her a "boring" day. "I have enjoyed the job. I was about to say I enjoyed every minute of it - I enjoyed almost every minute of it," she told a crowded house.

But there was no mistaking her underlying message which brought louder cheers - and rare clapping - from the Conservative benches and smaller opposition parties than it did on the Labour side where some new Blair "babes and boys" took her strictures personally.

"Our Betty" as several MPs called her, will stand down before the Commons resumes on October 24. Yesterday she told MPs it was their duty to rebuild the confidence of their electors. "I know from my postbag how much disillusion about the political process exists among the general public. The level of cynicism about parliament and the accompanying alienation of many of the young from the democratic process is troubling," she said.

During eight years in the chair she has often expressed concern about government spin and the pre-leaking of official statements in newspapers and on BBC Radio's Today programme.

So she reminded MPs that the primary "function of parliament is to hold the executive to account ... It is in parliament in the first instance that ministers must explain and justify their policies".

In a Commons where Labour enjoys a near-record 177-seat majority this has often proved difficult, especially when some MPs have been active cheerleaders for the government. Ms Boothroyd, who started her Commons life as a secretary and was elected an MP in 1973 at her sixth attempt, has often been tough on the 1997 beneficiaries of Labour's all-women shortlists. Without the distractions of a family in the constituency she has thus been criticised for being insensitive to the campaign for family friendly hours. But yesterday she did not back down.

Ms Boothroyd said that most colleagues agreed effective scrutiny of legislation was an area "ripe for improvement. "If long hours or shorter holidays prove necessary for effective scrutiny of the government, then MPs must make that effort," she told them.

MPs campaigning for a straight ballot among aspiring candidates to succeed Ms Boothroyd realise there is little or no time to change the rules this time round. That means Sir Edward will call for nominations one at a time and MPs will vote openly until a candidate clinches a clear majority - as Ms Boothroyd easily did in 1992.

webTitle: Sketch: Simon Hoggart

fields.headline: Graceful goodbye with home truths for Blair babes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Graceful goodbye from Betty with home truths for Blair babes.
fields.body:
Betty Boothroyd said goodbye to the Commons yesterday in a speech which was fairly critical of the government. For Mr Blair, it must have been like being kicked in the goolies by a Tiller girl - he couldn't know if it was deliberate, accidental, or even affectionate, but at least it was done with great style.

It was, all in all, a graceful and nicely judged farewell. She even finished with her favourite catchphrase, as well loved by her fans as "can I do yer now sir?" or "where's me washboard?"

"Time's up!" she said, and the place once again erupted in that strictly out of order applause. Even a few people in the public gallery dared to join in. I wondered if she might have thought the effect wasn't quite ecstatic enough; should we in the press have hurled bouquets down on to her throne? And will there be souvenir tea towels?

She began by thanking her helpers, secretaries and clerks, though not the naughty boys of the Commons - the Skinners and the Bercows - who have given her job so much relish. Then she jigged menacingly towards the audience and started kicking out in her stiletto heels. She was troubled, she said, by the cynicism people felt about parliament, and the "troubling" alienation of young people from politics.

"Let us make a start by remembering that the function of parliament is to hold the executive to account. It is in parliament, in the first instance, that ministers must explain and justify their policies ... I have made my views known about this both publicly and behind the scenes."

Workaday stuff it might seem, but in context it was astringent, the valedictory hug concealing the paper knife aimed at the back. It translated as "I am sick and tired of ministers leaking everything beforehand and going behind MPs' backs."

So she was being critical, but at least her animadversions were mild enough to stop the prime minister from flashing us his scary Jack Nicholson-is-the-Joker rictus grin which we last saw at the Women's Institute, the grin which says: "I'm not really hurt, gosh no, but I do know where you live."

Then MPs who had been looking forward to a real lambasting of the government (including all Tory MPs and quite a few Labour too) suddenly realised she was talking about them. She was fed up, she said, with people who spent ages complaining that they didn't get to spend enough time at home.

"Of course I recognise the importance of enabling parliamentarians to enjoy a domestic life, and it shouldn't be impossible to meet both objectives. But where they may be a clash, the requirements of effective scrutiny and the democratic process must take priority over the convenience of members."

Blair babes, from the you-can-have-it-all generation, didn't like that one bit, especially coming from someone who has never had her own family and who banned the suckling of their infants during the scrutinising process.

Tony Blair was up next and reminded us of the "legendary stifled yawn" she used to indicate someone had gone on too long. From my seat I could never see this phenomenon, but I thought, why did she bother to stifle it? Why not an enormous gaping yawn, like the mouth of the Marabar caves? They couldn't ignore that.

And then to Ted Heath, who as father of the house will have to run the election for the next speaker. He would, he said, be happy to offer advice to MPs. "I shall be available over the next three months [long, well-timed pause] in some part of the world or other. Provided you pay the telephone charges."

webTitle: Leader: Need for a contest to determine Speaker's successor

fields.headline: Betty bows out
fields.standfirst:
We need a robust contest for her successor
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It may have been all cosy consensus yesterday as MPs bade a teary farewell to Betty Boothroyd, but behind the scenes there has been no such unanimity
fields.body:
It may have been all cosy consensus yesterday as MPs bade a teary farewell to Betty Boothroyd, but behind the scenes there has been no such unanimity. Privately, there is muttered dissent from the now-cliched view of Madam Speaker as national treasure. Some Tories say she never quite shelved her old Labour instincts; a few Labourites say she worked so hard to be fair, she ended up helping the Conservatives. Perhaps attacks like that, from both sides of the house, are a good sign that the departing Ms Boothroyd got it about right.

Still the current debate is not so much about speakers past as speakers future. Who should take over Ms Boothroyd's chair? The bookies think the contest is over before it has started: more than £10,000 placed on Michael Martin, the Scottish Labour MP and current deputy speaker, has convinced William Hill to close its book. But this contest is too important to be a fait accompli, decided on a tribal Labour vote, fixed in the tea-room. As Tony Benn argued on these pages yesterday, the speaker should be the champion of parliamentary democracy: MPs have to choose wisely.

Mr Martin may have some compelling qualities, but he hardly has the clout to reassert the Commons' status in an era when that body has seen its power erode. The Lib Dem Menzies Campell cuts a more distinguished figure, but his popularity with Downing Street - and therefore his proximity to the executive - surely counts as a liability rather than an asset. A clutch of Tory applicants fails to inspire. No, the Commons should look for a speaker with a proven record of independence and even bolshieness. Two names spring to mind: Gwyneth Dunwoody, a redoubtable Labour backbencher, and that stout defender of parliament's rights, Mr Benn himself. There may be others yet to come forward. But the Commons needs a robustly independent speaker and the country deserves a real contest to find one.

webTitle: Paddington train crash survivors blast rail bosses

fields.headline: Paddington train crash survivors blast rail bosses
fields.trailText: Survivors and people bereaved by the Paddington rail crash today fought back tears as they criticised the management of the railway industry. They spoke out as part one of the inquiry into the disaster neared its conclusion.
fields.body:
Survivors and people bereaved by the Paddington rail crash today fought back tears as they criticised the management of the railway industry. They spoke out as part one of the inquiry into the disaster neared its conclusion.

Thirty-one people were killed when a Thames Trains turbo train crashed into a London-bound Great Western high-speed train at Ladbroke Grove, two miles from Paddington station, west London, on October 5 last year.

Birgit Andersen, who lost her daughter Charlotte, 32, in the accident, told a news conference: "I thought that one of the most disappointing things I have heard during the inquiry so far was the cavalier attitude of Railtrack regarding safety. I go away from this inquiry wondering how much impact it has made on the people making decisions at Railtrack.

"It is disappointing that no party will be brought to account for this tragedy. After so many were injured - and 31 have died - I don't know of anybody who has been relieved of their duty or made redundant."

As with others who spoke, she did not criticise Michael Hodder, 31, the driver of the Thames train. He drove the train 700 yards through signal 109, which was at red, before colliding with the Great Western train.

She said: "It was very irresponsible of the managers to put an inexperienced driver in a rush-hour train in that two-mile area. I think it was inexcusable to put a man in that position."

Pam Warren, a survivor, said: "We are not campaigning for ourselves. There are many of us that will never catch a train again. We know now how shabby the system is. But we need to protect the people who are still catching the trains, they are in as much danger as we were on October 5 1999."

Louise Christian, a solicitor representing bereaved and survivors, said: "The evidence has been particularly shocking. We have heard that Railtrack knew that the signals at Paddington station were dangerous five years before this happened.

"They knew that it was only a matter of time before there was going to be a terrible collision. They had meeting after meeting - and in the meantime drivers were continuing to pass signals at danger in the Paddington area. They discussed it, but they did nothing."

She added: "My clients do not blame Michael Hodder. He went past a red signal at danger as many other drivers had done."

Railtrack could not be trusted with the railway network and rail safety, she said. Those responsibilities should lie with an independent, publicly accountable body.

Catherine Wood, of Liss, Hampshire, whose husband Simon died in the crash, said: "I have been horrified by what I have heard. I have sat and listened to people passing the buck.

"There had been previous accidents, with recommendations put forward, that could have prevented this crash. I would like Railtrack to tell me what I can say to my two daughters, when in a few years time they say, 'Why did Daddy have to die?'"

Relatives and survivors now knew that signal 109 was non-compliant with regulations, he said, adding: "We know that Thames Trains had an inadequate training programme, had hardly explained any of the dangers to the drivers, and Thames Trains used very weak excuses not to fit protection on trains."

Ms Christian said that survivors and bereaved people would meet transport minister Lord Macdonald tomorrow morning to press for the introduction of ATP rather than TPWS.

"We cannot believe this government is pleading the interests of cost when it comes to train safety," she said.

The news conference was held a couple of hours before the start of closing submissions by various parties to the inquiry, which has heard 47 days of evidence from 332 witnesses.

Submissions are expected to finish tomorrow but the inquiry will not formerly end until September.

On September 13 the inquiry will hear about a cost-benefit analysis report into fitting ATP, which was commissioned by Thames Trains.

Part two of the inquiry will take place after the Southall and Ladbroke Grove Joint Inquiry into train protection systems which begins on September 18. Part two of the inquiry is expected to last at least until the end of October.

webTitle: Web watch

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Net numbers | US views
fields.body:
Net numbers
Bango.net, a start-up in Cambridge, thinks the web would be easier to use if sites had numbers instead of words for addresses - and for people using mobile phones and other primitive devices, or foreign languages, this could well be true. Bango is giving a million numbers away at www.bango.net. However, you have to hand over a valid email address, and the number link must be used at least once a month.

US views
America's PBS public broadcasting network has a new site with a thematic approach: American Photography: A Century of Images. Kodak sponsorship has enabled PBS to build a bigger site than usual but the pictures are still too small. Other new PBS sites continue the theme of presenting the American Experience Online. These include Coney Island and Mr Miami Beach, produced with WGBH in Boston.

Ask OJ
You've asked Jeeves and perhaps beseeched the Internet Oracle: now Ask OJ, for a price. The former American football star found not guilty of murdering his wife Nicole Brown Simpson and restaurant waiter Ron Goldman is scheduled to hold his first live session online today. The website, run by the company behind the all-female VoyeurDorm, charges $7.95 for access or $9.95 on the day of this "Historic Event".

War diary
What happened day by day during four critical months in 1940? The answer is now being revealed on the Battle of Britain History site, where the RAF is publishing the complete Fighter Command Operational Diaries for the first time. The site also includes background information and a regrettably small picture gallery from which the plane above is taken.

World beat
The World Entertainment Network is webcasting the Womad USA world music festival from Seattle (July 28-30). A trailer promoting some of the artists involved is at Wen's site, www.wen.com.

Pilger online
John Pilger will be chatting on the web on Monday to mark the expansion and relaunch of the Carlton TV website devoted to his work. The site offers about 100 video clips and all the award-winning reporter's recent articles: www.carlton.com/pilger.

Spot on
The Spot On controller lets you put together sequences of sites and navigate them with a VCR-style on-screen controller. If you regularly trawl through a series of sites, Spot On preloads pages automatically, so pressing the forward button is as quick as pressing the back button. The control software for Microsoft Windows and Internet Explorer can be found at www.spoton.com.

The X factor
Virgin.Net has opened an official website for X-Men at www.virgin.net/x-men, the Twentieth Century Fox film which will be released in the UK on August 18. The site has interviews with Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellan, and the creator of the original comic, Stan Lee. While Virgin's mutant design may have usability problems, it is a lot less horrible than the official American site at www.x-men-the-movie.com.

New and noted
Britain's championship-winning coxless rowers, preparing for the Sydney Olympics, now have a website at www.coxless4.com. Marie Stopes International reckons its redesigned site is the first where visitors can book an abortion online. Timotei, the shampoo, is being promoted with a "viral marketing campaign based on e-cards at www.timotei-naturebursts.co.uk.

Mensa International, the society for people who can pass IQ tests, has opened "the world's first global ideas factory" for inventors and entrepreneurs at www.mensaiqcapital.com.

Wap watch
By Victor Keegan
To use your Wap (wireless application protocol) phone to locate the nearest off licence or filling station try http://offramp.co.uk

Job searching is a natural for Wap, and http://mmm.closecom.com specialises in telecommunications jobs.

Now http://wap.foxkids.co.uk has news and entertainment for kids on the move - with interactivity promised later.

Frustrated with not being able to connect to Wap sites? The online bible at http://wap.mobible.org/may give the solace needed.

Six of the best Free stuff

UK phone calls
www.pc2call.com
SMS messages
www.breathe.com
Faxes
www.efax.com
Voicemail
www.voizmail.com
Computer games
www.freeloader.com
Music files
www.mp3.com

 Sites suggested by Computeractive magazine.

webTitle: DoCoMo and AOL plan to attack Wap challenge

fields.headline: DoCoMo and AOL plan to attack Wap challenge
fields.trailText: America Online, the world's biggest internet service provider, is believed to be in talks with NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, about jointly developing a global internet access service for mobile phones.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts in Tokyo and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
America Online, the world's biggest internet service provider, is believed to be in talks with NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, about jointly developing a global internet access service for mobile phones.

The two are understood to be talking about an alliance to wrest control of the fast growing mobile internet business from a rival standard being promoted by European companies. Both refused to comment yesterday but reports said that a deal could be struck next month.

AOL, the world's most popular web portal, with 23m subscribers, has built its empire around the personal computer market, but it has been slow to respond to the expansion of wireless methods of accessing the net such as cellular phones and palmtop devices.

A deal with NTT DoCoMo, which could result in the Japanese company taking a stake in AOL Japan, could improve its technological offering and fill a gap in the US group's global strategy.

The company unveiled a series of agreements with mobile phone companies in the US and Europe earlier this year and last month, it joined Carphone Warehouse to offer a new internet portal in Britain and continental Europe.

DoCoMo's success has been largely built on i-mode, its cheap and simple mobile internet system that has attracted 8m Japanese subscribers in a year and half.

According to Japanese media, DoCoMo will provide AOL with the operational know-how and wireless technology used in i-mode, which offers a 24-hour link to the net. In return, AOL can offer a huge range of web content, which is seen as the key to deciding which format proves most popular with consumers.

DoCoMo confirmed that it was in talks with a number of global internet firms but refused to comment on AOL.

The move would fit with DoCoMo's aggressive strategy to take i-mode, still available only in Japan, worldwide.

The company has a ¥2 trillion (£12.5bn) war chest to buy stakes in overseas telecomunication and internet companies. By the end of the year, it is expected to launch i-mode in Britain, where it would challenge wireless access protocol (Wap) services.

DoCoMo will be the first to offer Wideband Code Division Multiple Access (WCDMA) services, which will provide transmission speeds suitable for moving images and music.

A deal could also include the use of services provided by Time Warner, the media group set to merge with AOL. Executives from both US companies were due to appear before US regulators to discuss their proposed merger today.

webTitle: May your privacy RIP

fields.headline: May your privacy RIP
fields.standfirst: The 'snoopers' charter' is now ready to become law, allowing the government unprecedented powers to pry into business and personal electronic communication. But, says Online editor Victor Keegan, it's the nature of the electronic beast to find ways of escape
fields.trailText: The 'snoopers' charter' is now ready to become law, allowing the government unprecedented powers to pry into industrial and personal electronic communication. But, says Online editor Victor Keegan, it's the nature of the electronic beast to find ways of escape.
fields.body:
Britain won't be quite the same again now that the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill (RIP) has competed its passage through parliament. Although a number of welcome amendments and safeguards have been forced through by the Lords, the essentials of the bill still stand.

It will leave Britain as the only Western industrialised country with a law enabling the government to demand encryption keys from individuals and corporations.

It remains to be seen whether this becomes a major turn-off for companies deciding where to locate their activities or whether the principle of opposite effect operates - and the bad effects of the bill are offset by the creation of innovative ways of getting around it which make life even harder for the snoops.

Defenders of civil liberties owe a big debt to Caspar Bowden's Foundation for Information Policy Research which relentlessly stalked the government. It won major revisions to key parts of the bill, including the assumption that people claiming to have lost their encryption codes are innocent until proved guilty, and in the clauses that would have enabled local authorities to browse through our emails without a warrant.

But it still remains a draconian bill. It will authorise the installation of "black boxes" to snoop on internet service providers (admittedly needing a warrant before MI5 can demand access) and will also enable government to monitor the pattern of our emails (where they are going to and who they are from) without it knowing what is inside them and without warrants.

For the first time, GCHQ, Cheltenham, which hitherto has needed a ministerial warrant to intercept domestic communications only if there was suspicion of terrorist activity, will be able to trawl much more easily through domestic mail.

It is expected the bill will spawn a whole new industry selling to companies ways of avoiding surveillance that could actually make it more difficult for the governmental bodies to snoop than beforehand.

Some of the ways people and companies can protect themselves are discussed on the FIPR's site here.

webTitle: Marcel Varnel: Oh, Mr Porter!

fields.headline: Marcel Varnel: Oh, Mr Porter!
fields.trailText: One of the biggest successes at the Paris Cinémathèque in the late 80s was a retrospective of British comedy curated by Bertrand Tavernier. Among the discoveries for the French was Will Hay, who, with his henchmen Graham Moffatt (the fat boy) and Moore Marriott (the wizened old codger), perfectly represented a certain type of bumbling British humour. One of the best of their films was Oh, Mr Porter! - and the French were pleased to find that it was directed by Paris-born Marcel Varnel. One of the great directors of British comedy in the 30s, Varnel considered Oh, Mr Porter! his best work
fields.body:
It's easier to make the British laugh than to make the French even smile. Yet, one of the biggest successes at the Paris Cinémathèque in the late 80s was a retrospective of British comedy curated by Bertrand Tavernier. Among the discoveries for the French was Will Hay, who, with his henchmen Graham Moffatt (the fat boy) and Moore Marriott (the wizened old codger), perfectly represented a certain type of bumbling British humour. One of the best of their films was Oh, Mr Porter! - and the French were pleased to find that it was directed by Paris-born Marcel Varnel. One of the great directors of British comedy in the 30s, Varnel considered Oh, Mr Porter! his best work.

Will Hay often used to play - in the music halls, on radio and on film - a pompous schoolmaster, permanently sniffing and wiping his nose, who invariably got himself into difficulties of his own making but managed to get out of them by luck rather than judgment. Moffatt was equally incompetent, while Marriott seemed the epitome of virtually senile density. In Convict 99, Marriott appeared as a long-term prisoner who spent years digging a tunnel, only to find that it opened in the warden's office. I seem to recall that all he said was "Damnation!" as he attempted to scuttle back down again.

In Oh, Mr Porter! Hay plays a railway porter with ambitions of becoming a stationmaster. Somehow he gets himself appointed to the virtually derelict station of Buggleskelly in Ireland, where Albert (Moffatt) and old Jeremiah Harbottle (Marriott) are his assistants. Desperate to justify himself, Hay organises a day excursion but gets mixed up with gun runners. He fortuitously captures them after a long locomotive chase and, once again, becomes a hero despite himself. There is a wonderful windmill sequence that has everyone hanging on for grim life but never quite falling off.

Varnel pursues this daft but very funny story with vigour, timing the gags to perfection and watching closely as Hay, Moffatt and Marriott spit out their famous routines. The script was written for them by Val Guest but often taken directly from the music hall, and it mocks a dozen or so sacred cows of the day, from the police to imperialism.

Hay's films were made between 1934 and 1943 and helped to lay the ground for the post-war Ealing comedies, which may have been richer in cinematic invention and characterisation but were seldom as sharp about Britain. His characters were oblivious to irony: serious-minded nincompoops, they escaped from calamity by sheer good fortune and then claimed they had known how to do so all along.

He, Moffatt and Marriott made a superbly foolish trio which, though now largely forgotten, has never been beaten. Like George Formby, Old Mother Riley and her daughter Kitty (Arthur Lucan and Kitty McShane), they formed part of a flourishing British comedy scene that became part of everybody's consciousness. They were so popular, in fact, that they frequently beat big Hollywood attractions at the box office. They made me laugh as a boy. And they still do now.

Credits

Director: Marcel Varnel

Writers: Val Guest, Marriot Edgar

Starring: Will Hay, Graham Moffat, Moore Marriott

UK, 1937, 85 minutes

webTitle: Crunch day for NHS as National Plan unveiled

fields.headline: Crunch day for NHS as National Plan unveiled
fields.standfirst: The full NHS plan
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's long awaited National Plan for radically overhauling the health service - billed as the biggest shake-up the NHS has seen since it was founded in 1948 - was published by the government today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's long awaited National Plan for radically overhauling the health service - billed as the biggest shake-up the NHS has seen since it was founded in 1948 - was published by the government today.

The prime minister today announced in the Commons massive changes in the way the NHS is structured, managed and staffed. The blueprint, designed to modernise the NHS over the next 10 years, has been drawn up by six committees made up of government ministers, doctors' leaders, patients' groups and other experts. Mr Blair, who believes Labour's record on the health service will be a key battleground in the next election, has also been closely involved in the formulation of the plan.

The National Plan was announced after the budget this year when spending on the health service received a £19bn boost for the next four years. The government wants to bring spending on health up to EU levels by 2005 - but has warned that huge cash injections must be matched by fundamental reform of the way the NHS is run.

A report commissioned by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, from consultants at Virgin Group highlighted problems of poor management, disillusioned staff, dirty hospitals and massive bureaucracy.

Details of the plan have been widely leaked in recent weeks. Key changes were expected to include:

&#149 Waiting lists: Any NHS patient whose operation is cancelled for non-medical reasons will be guaranteed surgery within 28 days, even if it means sending them to a private hospital. By 2005, 90% of patients will wait less than three months for non-urgent hospital care, and no one should be waiting longer than six months.

Special centres dedicated to particular operations such as cataract surgery or hip replacements could work 24 hours a day to reduce hospital queues.

&#149 Doctors: There is to be a huge increase in the number of medical school placements and changes in the way junior doctors are selected and trained.

Because these new doctors will take years to be trained and filtered through the system, a massive recruitment drive will be launched to attract qualified doctors from the US, Australia and Europe to boost UK numbers. Doctors from developing countries will not be poached to avoid accusations of depriving poorer countries of their much-needed workforce.

&#149 Nurses: Big increases in the numbers of nurses are also expected under the National Plan.

Nurses will also be given extra powers to prescribe drugs, treat patients in casualty departments and carry out minor routine surgery in a bid to improve their status and end the traditional "rigid demarcations" between doctors and nurses.

&#149 Hospitals: New standards to clean up filthy wards and hospitals will be laid down and bosses will have to work to ensure there are enough beds to cope with winter pressures and other problems. Hospitals will be set a range of performance targets and those that fail to meet them will be deprived of extra cash.

&#149 Patients: The crux of the National Plan is to make the health service more "consumer-friendly" for patients. Every hospital will have a "patients' champion" - a patient, advocacy and liaison service which will handle complaints from patients and their relatives on anything from dirty wards and hospital food to disputes with doctors, and have the power to demand action.

&#149 The elderly: The National Plan will also include the government's long awaited response to the proposal by the Royal Commission on Long Term Care of the Elderly, which recommended that all personal and nursing care for old people should be free. The government is expected to incur the wrath of the elderly by saying that nursing care will be paid for by the NHS but that personal care (including changing dressings and catheters, among other things) will have to be paid for by individuals.
