webTitle: NHS reforms: full details from the government

fields.headline: NHS reforms: full details from the government
fields.standfirst: Full text of the plan
fields.trailText: The Government has released the following press release about the NHS reforms Ð unusually, before the Prime Minister has started his announcements. Full text follows:
fields.body:
The Government has released the following press release about the NHS reforms Ð unusually, before the Prime Minister has started his announcements. Full text follows:

"The NHS Plan: A Plan for Investment. A Plan for Reform" published by Health Secretary Alan Milburn

"The most fundamental and far-reaching programme of reform in the history of the NHS was published today by Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

The NHS Plan: A Plan for Investment. A Plan for Reform will create an NHS in which the patient is the most important person. In the future, care and treatment will be redesigned around their needs, at their convenience. Mr Milburn said:

"This is the most fundamental and far-reaching reform programme. For the first time the Government has faced up to the breadth and depth of problems in the NHS and has addressed them all in turn. From the state of the wards to the doctor's contract, not one issue has been ducked. By being honest in our analysis of the problems we have been able to produce the most radical of reforms."

The major areas of reform in the NHS Plan are as follows:

 investment in NHS facilities including 7,000 extra beds and 100 new hospital schemes between 2000 and 2010, to be funded by the historic extra resources announced in the Budget (6.3% annual real terms growth);

 investment in NHS staff including 7,500 more consultants, 2,000 new GPs, 20,000 more nurses and over 6,500 extra health professionals;

 changed systems for the NHS including a new NHS Modernisation Agency and a National Performance Fund worth £500 million by 2003/4. Also a National Independent Panel to advise on major hospital changes;

 changes between health and social services including an extra £900 million investment in intermediate care by 2003/4, and New Care Trusts, combining health and social services;

 changes for NHS doctors including new consultants contract, and new quality based contracts for GPs;

 changes for NHS nurses, midwives, therapists and other NHS staff including new roles and responsibilities for nurses and new senior sisters, and better training;

 changes for patients including greater choice and new protection. From 2002 if an operation is cancelled on the day of surgery for non-clinical reasons the hospital will have to offer another binding date within 28 days or fund surgery elsewhere. Patient representatives on Trust boards for the first time;

 changes in the relationship between the NHS and the private sector including a concordat between the NHS and private providers;

 cutting waiting times for treatment including by the end of 2005 the maximum waiting time for outpatients will be three months and the maximum waiting time for inpatients will be six months. New One-Stop out-of-hours service by 2004;

 improving health and reducing inequality including every child in nursery, and those aged four to six in infant schools to receive a free piece of fruit each school day. Increased resources for deprived areas;

 clinical priorities including expansion in the cancer screening programmes and waiting times for cardiac surgery to be cut;

 dignity, security and independence in old age including higher standards of care for older people, a free NHS retirement health check, and a new Care Direct Service.

Mr Milburn continued:

"For fifty or more years the NHS has been part and parcel of what it means to be British. We are all deeply proud of the NHS - not out of dogma but out of conviction - we have a fair and efficient model of healthcare. Decades of under-investment and run-down services are now being reversed and now the NHS can focus on reforming itself and providing the best for patients. We have forged a new national alliance behind a modernised NHS which gives us a once in a lifetime opportunity to achieve these reforms."

webTitle: Government leaks

fields.headline: Government leaks
fields.standfirst:
Another two memos have leaked out of Downing Street. Julian Glover explains what lies behind all the New Labour red faces

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Another two memos have leaked out of Downing Street. We explain what lies behind all the New Labour red faces.
fields.body:
What's happened this time?
More memos have leaked from Downing Street and appeared in the press. The latest documents to emerge were written by Tony Blair and his polling expert Philip Gould. They concern the government's stance on the European single currency. They were written late last year and are less embarrassing for the government than previous leaks.

Downing Street says the prime minister's memo shows a leader who backs the official line on the euro, even in private. But the leak is embarrassing, as these bring the total number of memos leaked this year from the heart of the government to six. Someone seems to have it in for Mr Blair.

So leaks always happen. Why get worried now?
It's true that revelations from the heart of government are common and the fine line between leaking and briefing is uncertain. "Leaking is what you do; briefing is what I do," as former prime minister Jim Callaghan once put it.

But the prime minister's inner circle is usually immune. Since June, however, two emails sent by Mr Gould revealed that he warned the prime minister that his speech to the Women's Institute would prove unpopular. And on July 15, the Guardian printed emails sent by the prime minister's private secretary, Anji Hunter, about her management of the BBC's fly-on-the-wall documentary on Downing Street.

On July 17, a memo written by Mr Blair appeared in the press. Leaks such as these make life very difficult No 10, .which like the rest of us, depends upon computers and emails. It will be hard for Mr Blair to maintain trust in his personal staff.

What about the last leak?
Written by Mr Gould, the memo described the government's unpopularity on a number of key issues and concludes that "the New Labour brand has become seriously contaminated". It spoilt what should have been a good day for the government, overshadowing the chancellor's announcement of big public spending increases.

So who's the leaker?
The people who know - Trevor Kavanagh, the political editor of the Sun, and Andrew Pierce, of the Times, aren't saying. The rest of us, including Mr Blair, just have to guess.

Downing Street has hinted that the Conservative party might have had something to do with it but haven't offered any evidence so far. There's no evidence that the leaks have all come from the same person, although this is possible.

One current theory is that the documents come from Benji the Binman - Benjamin Pell, who drives around London collecting rubbish from addresses of prominent people and companies and attempts to pass documents he finds on to journalists. Mr Pell denies that he has been involved.

What other theories are there?
Some think that a computer hacker - or perhaps someone working on the Downing Street website - found the documents on the government computer system and passed them to the Conservative party.

Since one of the leaks appears to be of a fax, this seems unlikely. In the past, civil servants such as Clive Ponting (over the sinking of the Belgrano) and Sarah Tisdall (over the siting of US missiles) leaked because they had access to documents on major policy decisions which they believed to be morally wrong. But very few civil servants will have seen the Downing Street memos - and anyway, they mostly concern the trivia of government rather than policy.

Is leaking illegal?
Almost certainly, if you are a civil servant who has signed the official secrets act. Mr Ponting was tried for sending documents to MPs, although the jury failed to convict him. Tisdall was sentenced to six months' imprisonment and served four.

The position for MPs is less clear. When they join the Privy Council senior parliamentarians swear to "keep secret all matters committed and revealed", but they are hardly expected to uphold this in practice. It's almost unthinkable for a politician to be prosecuted for leaking; but the prime minister can, of course, end the political career of anyone in his party he deems to be guilty.

webTitle: Water voles

fields.headline: Water voles
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about arvicola terrestris, and why he needs a helping paw
fields.trailText: All you need to know about arvicola terrestris, and why he needs a helping paw
fields.body:
1. Ten more water voles have been released into the wild, or at any rate the Oxfordshire countryside, as part of a project by the environment agency.

2. Ten may not sound a lot but it's a big deal for the water voles. Twenty years ago they were ubiquitous but the population has plummeted by 90%.

3. The calamitous decline of arvicola terrestris is even faster than that of the otter. There are fears that the poor little chaps face extinction.

4. The water vole's main enemies are stoats and mink and, of course, us.

5. Their habitat is under remorseless attack by development and projects to shore up riverbanks from erosion caused by boats.

6. Saving the water vole is now a priority of organisations such as English Nature and the Mammal Society.

7. The latter is organising a day out with water voles at the end of September. But you'll have to be sharp-eyed to spot one.

8. There are also schemes in other parts, notably in Lincolnshire, where the county's Wildlife Trust takes a keen interest.

9. The water vole is not to be confused with the water shrew, or indeed the field vole, which is probably Britain's most common mammal.

10. Nor should it be muddled up with the water rat, which doesn't exist; except of course in Kenneth Grahame's immortal The Wind in the Willows.

webTitle: July 27: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Film-mad Britain, morale-boosting on the Bridget Jones set, Tim Roth makes his mind up, Spinal Tap make internet comeback, Larry Clark to tackle bullying, and Ian Holm and Roberto Benigni on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Britain is turning into a nation of film fanatics. In the first six months of this year, 71m cinema tickets were sold - the highest 6-monthly figure for 26 years. It is thought ticket sales could have been even greater, had Euro 2000 not distracted people in June. A major reason for the high sales figures is thought to be the weather and studios are hoping that the summer will stay dismal so that warm cinemas will continue to be an attraction. The figures indicate that, by the end of the year, 145m tickets could be sold, beating the 139m snapped up in 1999. With the release in the next six months of American blockbuster X-Men and the smash hit horror spoof Scary Movie, it looks likely this figure will be met.

 The makers of the film of Bridget Jones' Diary held a mid-shoot party to erase any doubts about Texan Renee Zellweger's British accent. Ten minutes of the film were shown at the Zeta Club in Park Lane and greeted with cheers from the cast and crew. It is understood morale was low due to rumours that co-star Hugh Grant wanted to quit the film because he thought Renee would be implausible as the 30-something singleton.

 Tim Roth (picture) has finally made his mind up and committed to play one of the lead roles in the forthcoming remake of Planet of the Apes, according to Yahoo. Roth was forced to choose between the Apes' role opposite Mark Wahlberg, and the role of Professor Snape in the film version of Harry Potter because both were shooting at the same time.

 Spinal Tap are to release their comeback single exclusively on the internet today. The band, who shot to fame in the Rob Reiner 'rockumentary' This is Spinal Tap will release the song on their Tapster website. Tap's lead singer, David St Hubbins, said: "We're putting it on the internet because we want the people who really care that we're still alive to have it in their hands and their machinery and then in their ears."

 Director Larry Clark, best known for his controversial 1995 film Kids, is to direct a low-budget feature, based on a true story, called Bully. The film is about a group of teenagers in a suburban Florida town who grow tired of being picked on by the school bully and take matters into their own hands. Shooting is due to start on August 21.

 Ian Holm is to star alongside Johnny Depp in the new film about the Jack the Ripper killings. Holm will replace Nigel Hawthorne who quit earlier this year due to poor health. The film implies that Queen Victoria knew who the serial killer was and suggests that there was a cover up. Sir Ian is thought to be playing a member of the Royal household responsible for the vicious murders. An insider told PA News: "Everyone is terribly sad Nigel won't be with us but Ian, as everyone knows, is absolutely superb. You couldn't wish for a better replacement."

 Oscar-winning Roberto Benigni is to play Pinocchio in a new film which features the Life is Beautiful winning team of Benigni, his wife Nicoletta Braschi and his longtime writing collaborator Vincenzo Cerami. Apparently it is a role Benigni has wanted to play for a very long time. "It's been 20 years, or maybe ever since I was born, that I had a desire that my nose would grow long," he told an Italian news agency.

webTitle: Julia Roberts tops the Hot List

fields.headline: Julia Roberts tops the Hot List
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts is the hottest star in Hollywood according to a new book by a veteran industry analyst
fields.body:
Julia Roberts is the hottest star in Hollywood according to a new book by a veteran industry analyst.

James Ulmer's Hollywood Hot List: The Complete Guide to Star Power puts the Notting Hill star top of a list of the 200 'hottest' actors and actresses in the business. It's quite a coup for an industry that still pays the majority of its female actors considerably less than its male ones, but a further look sees Meg Ryan as the only other woman to make the top 20 - she comes in at number eight. Roberts shot to fame in 1990 when she played a prostitute opposite Richard Gere in Pretty Woman. Previously dismissed as just another Hollywood bimbo, this year she received critical acclaim for her portrayal of Erin Brockovich in the eponymous film.

Tom Hanks came in at number two on the list, followed by Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson, Bruce Willis, John Travolta and Brad Pitt with Leonardo DiCaprio and Will Smith at number nine and ten. Included in the bottom ten were Helena Bonham-Carter, Andy Garcia, Elisabeth Shue and Steven Seagal.

Film-makers are excluded from the Hollywood Hot List, in which Ulmer rates stars according to factors such as bankability, professionalism, career management, willingness to travel and promote, acting talent, and acting range. The list is a spin-off of the author's The Hot List, an annual industry index that measures the commercial clout of nearly 2,000 movie stars and directors.

Previously dismissed as just another Hollywood bimbo, this year she received critical acclaim for her portrayal of Erin Brockovich in the eponymous film. Tom Hanks came in at number two on the list, followed by Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson, Bruce Willis, John Travolta and Brad Pitt with Leonardo DiCaprio and Will Smith at number nine and ten. Included in the bottom ten were Helena Bonham-Carter, Andy Garcia, Elisabeth Shue and Steven Seagal. Film-makers are excluded from the Hollywood Hot List, in which Ulmer rates stars according to factors such as bankability, professionalism, career management, willingness to travel and promote, acting talent, and acting range. The list is a spin-off of the author's The Hot List, an annual industry index that measures the commercial clout of nearly 2,000 movie stars and directors.

webTitle: Law to star in Kubrick's A.I.

fields.headline: Law to star in Kubrick's A.I.
fields.trailText: Jude Law is to fly to the States next month to take the lead in Stanley Kubrick's unfinished film A.I. The Talented Mr Ripley star is to work with the film's new director, Steven Spielberg, who took over the project after Kubrick died last year
fields.body:
Jude Law is to fly to the States next month to take the lead in Stanley Kubrick's unfinished film A.I. The Talented Mr Ripley star is to work with the film's new director, Steven Spielberg, who took over the project after Kubrick died last year.

Law will play the leading role of Gigolo Joe in the film, which is set in a time after the polar ice caps have melted and artificially intelligent robots run the earth. Filming, however, is understood to be taking place in two of the world's hottest spots, Los Angeles and the Caribbean.

Twelve-year-old Haley Joe Osment, who played the ghost-seeing little boy in the Sixth Sense, will also star (on a salary rumoured to be $2m), playing a robot-boy who embarks on an 'emotional journey'.

Mansfield Park actress Frances O'Connor is also confirmed to star although it is not yet known in which role.

Law's publicist believes that the cast and crew are optimistic that Spielberg will continue Kubrick's vision for the project: "Spielberg has a tremendous visual imagination. He'll do a fantastic job of this movie."

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours covered with batter, thrown in the deep fat fryer and served with haggis.
fields.trailText: Celtic manager Martin O'Neill wants to sign Manchester United goalkeeper Mark Bosnich on loan reports a back page exclusive in the Daily Mail. Apparently United have turned down a permanent move but Celtic are still waiting to see whether Sir Alex Ferguson will allow Bosnich to sign a three-month loan agreement.
fields.body:
Celtic manager Martin O'Neill wants to sign Manchester United goalkeeper Mark Bosnich on loan reports a back page exclusive in the Daily Mail. Apparently United have turned down a permanent move but Celtic are still waiting to see whether Sir Alex Ferguson will allow Bosnich to sign a three-month loan agreement.

Meanwhile Neil Lennon will decide today whether to join the Bhoys in a £6.5m deal. The 28 year-old Northern Ireland international said: "Leicester have made me a fantastic offer to stay but I still need to think things through. I would love to join Celtic and it's no longer about money." Sounds like he's on his way

Martin O'Neill should also complete the £3.5m signing of Joos Valgaeren today. The Belgian international has flown to Glasgow and will undergo a medical this afternoon.

Rangers haven't been so lucky in their attempts to strengthen their squad. In today's Daily Record chairman David Murray admits he agreed a fee with Juventus for striker Darko Kovacevic - but the deal fell through because of the Yugoslav's massive wage demands. Murray told the paper: "We had agreed with Juventus on a lower fee of around £12m but the deal collapsed because of the players wage demands. He wanted £34,000-a-week net and that would have shattered our wage structure. We are not prepared. We have to be prudent in the way we go about our business."

Murray also revealed how he agreed personal terms with Schalke forward Emile Mpenza, but the deal fell through because the German side rejected his £8m offer. "I know that Mpenza had his heart set on joining us, but there is nothing more we can do," Murray admitted. "We worked hard on this and I thought we were winning, but in business you have to take the good with the bad."

Benito Carbone looks set to rejoin former club Reggina reports Planet Football. But they say the Italian team may face late opposition from Bayern Munich, who have "made a late entrance into the race to sign the skilful star."

Arsenal winger Marc Overmars has denied reports that he has already signed a pre-contract agreement to join Barcelona. "I've done no such thing and frankly I find such a hilarious lie ridiculous." claimed the Dutch winger. His agent Karel Jansen was quick to support him: "It is complete rubbish to suggest Marc has signed an agreement with anybody. There has been no contact from Barcelona with us about Marc."

Sheffield Wednesday are eyeing Blackburn winger Keith Gillespie and Grimsby right-back Danny Butterfield reports the Express

webTitle: Dear Anna

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Just the ticket?

It would be an interesting business if supermarkets demanded an entrance fee before shoppers could purchase their goods. Yet theatre sales lines often charge exorbitantly for the privilege of purchasing tickets and get away with it. Two seats from Ticketmaster cost me £7 on top of the ticket price when I booked them last month - a sum that could have paid for a third seat in the gods. RW Witton of the Wirral complains that he was obliged to pay a £1 booking fee per ticket and a £1.50 surcharge when he booked seats through a ticket agency. When he asked where the money went he was given three different answers: that the booking fee was levied by the presentation company; that it was levied by the theatre and that it was a charge to cover the cost of the ticket agency and credit card commission charges - the same purpose, apparently as the surcharge.

"There seems to be at the very least a suspicion of double-charging," he says. "I don't see why I should have to pay for the administration costs of an 'extensive' ticket agency when all I want to do is phone the theatre as I used to and collect my tickets from the box office."

"Our charges are very low," says Ticketmaster defensively when I enquire about my £7 fee. "People want to pay for the service."

Do they indeed? As far as I know I was put through to Ticketmaster without choice or warning when I called the number listed for the theatre. Ah but, says our spokesman, although I'd have saved my seven quid had I got through to the box office I wouldn't have been able to book tickets at 3am had I wanted to, nor benefited from the range of information about performances I wasn't interested in seeing, which privileges Ticketmaster is uniquely positioned to bestow.

According to the Society of Ticket Agents and Retailers agencies can charge what they like because the Tories revoked a previous maximum of 25% to encourage competition. "There's no industry more open than ours because we declare our charges whereas train companies and supermarkets, etc incorporate them in the price," says a spokesman. "The rule is to try the box office first and work your way down the numbers listed to get the best deal."

Waving our magic wand

Caroline Wilding of Knutsford found wizardry was at work when she ordered the latest Harry Potter adventure from Waterstone's Online. "Chapter 1," she writes. "I receive a newsletter offering free delivery of all orders placed between March 10 and 13 and a chance to pre-order the new Potter book at a special price. I took advantage of both offers.

"Chapter 2: I receive a confirmation notice which gave a total of £5.50 due for the book.

"Chapter 3: The book arrives with a delivery note confirming the price at £5.50 but adding a delivery charge of £2.45 despite the free offer.

"Chapter 4: I receive a new demand in which the price of the book has magically gone up to £7.50 and my visa is debited for £9.95.

"Chapter 5: I point out the change in price and request a refund but hear nothing."

Consumer, of course, is well practiced in working magic. Shortly after Waterstones agrees to investigate, Wilding receives a call apologising for the mix up and promising a refund plus a book token by way of amends. "We have received a substantial number of orders at our website for this title," explains a spokeswoman. "Unfortunately, Caroline Wilding's order was mistakenly included as a standard price order."

webTitle: Concorde crash investigation focuses on black box

fields.headline: Concorde crash investigation focuses on black box
fields.trailText: Investigators were today continuing to study black box data from the Concorde disaster in a bid to establish any link between last-minute repairs to the doomed aircaft's engines and its devastating crash near Paris.
fields.body:
Investigators were today continuing to study black box data from the Concorde disaster in a bid to establish any link between last-minute repairs to the doomed aircaft's engines and its devastating crash near Paris.

The engine that failed was the same one which had undergone repairs before the supersonic jetliner took off, Air France has revealed.

Thirty minutes of repair work was needed on the left-hand side number two engine because of a reverse thruster problem.

Less than a minute after the plane took off, flames were seen coming out of the New York-bound plane.

The Concorde's short flight was captured on a piece of harrowing amateur video footage taken from a vehicle moving down a nearby motorway.

It shows the plane trailing a flame twice its length as it banks away from view. The nose of the airliner is raised slightly above the body but the underbelly is clearly descending towards the earth. Behind the craft, corkscrew-shaped clouds of thick black smoke emerge from the plane's trail of yellow flame.

Moments after the Concorde disappears from view, a huge cloud of black smoke billows up from the ground.

Prosecutor Elisabeth Senot, who is in charge of the judicial investigation into Tuesday's tragedy which killed 113 people, said the control tower had alerted the crew about the flames. She said that the pilot had replied that he was having trouble with the number two engine. It was as the crew tried to reach Le Bourget airport that the plane - full of German tourists - crashed into a hotel near the French capital.

In a dramatic account of the tragedy, 21-year-old Alice Brooking, from Tonbridge, Kent, told how she was "grateful to be alive" after leaping from the first floor of the hotel as it burst into flames. "There were flames everywhere ... so I jumped," the Cambridge University student said.

Air France said a fault with the reverse thruster - which helps slow the plane down on landing - had been reported as the aircraft had earlier returned to Paris from New York.

The plane could have left France without repairs being made, but the captain had insisted on the work being done. No spare part was available, so one had to be cannibalised from another Concorde.

French investigators, who have been joined by members of the British Air Accidents Investigation Branch, will want to study a May 1991 Lauda Air Boeing 767 crash in Thailand which was caused by a thrust reverser deploying in flight rather than on the ground. All 223 people on board died in the accident.

Some BA pilots said today they believed their colleagues might have been able to save the Concorde if the engine failure and fire had been the only problem.

They also wondered why the crew did not raise the undercarriage immediately there was a fault as that would have made the aircraft more controllable. "We can't understand why they didn't get the gear up. Maybe they were distracted or there was a major problem other than the flaming engine," said one pilot, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

He added: "I have spoken to some of our Concorde pilots and they believe they might have been able to save the plane if the flaming engine was the only fault. But the undercarriage would have to have been raised."

However, aviation experts said that had the aircraft suffered catastrophic, rapid and enormous damage, it would have been very difficult for the crew to control the plane.

Kieran Daly, editor of internet news service Air Transport Intelligence, said: "Clearly, engine trouble seems to have been the problem. The question is whether it was controllable and did the crew respond adequately?

"If there was catastrophic damage to an engine that was so rapid and enormous, then the aircraft could not be saved. It's impossible at this stage to say if the aircraft was still controllable."

The French president, Jacques Chirac, comforted about 200 German relatives as they visited the crash site yesterday, and he joined them for a moving service of remembrance.

webTitle: Five wickets in an over - and better

fields.headline: Five wickets in an over - and better
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: In a recent match between Range High School Staff and Year 12 students I took five wickets (WW4WWW), and finished up with 1-0-4-5. The students slumped from 53 for 5 to 57 all out in one over. Has anyone done better than this? asks Rod McGreevy
fields.body:
In a recent match between Range High School Staff and Year 12 students I took five wickets (WW4WWW), and finished up with 1-0-4-5. The students slumped from 53 for 5 to 57 all out in one over. Has anyone done better than this? asks Rod McGreevy

There are quite a few instances of a bowler taking six wickets in a six-ball over, so I'm afraid it's not quite a record, although it is a remarkable performance and must have been fun. It certainly should have impressed the students! The record for all cricket is believed to be nine wickets in consecutive balls, which has been reported twice - by a P Hugo in a club match in Johannesburg in 1930-31, and Stephen Fleming in a school match in New Zealand in 1967-68 (no, not the current New Zealand captain: he wasn't born until 1973). In first-class cricket three bowlers - Derbyshire's Bill Copson (1937), WA Henderson of NE Transvaal (1937-38) and Surrey's Pat Pocock (1972) - have taken five wickets in six balls. Charlie Parker, the Gloucestershire slow left-arm bowler who won one England cap, hit the stumps with five successive deliveries during his benefit match against Yorkshire at Bristol in 1922 ... unfortunately the second one was a no-ball.

What do you think is the greatest record - the most unbreakable one? asks Alex Roberts

Until a few years ago I'd have said that Hanif Mohammad's innings of 499 would never be exceeded, but Brian Lara knocked that off in 1994. Equally it's hard to see anyone bettering Jim Laker's 19 for 90 in a Test, but it is possible. But two marks which surely will never be broken are the aggregate records - Jack Hobbs's 61,237 runs and Wilfred Rhodes's 4187 wickets in first-class cricket. The seasonal marks of Denis Compton (3816 runs) and Tich Freeman (304 wickets) are also safe. There just aren't enough first-class matches these days for anyone to approach any of these. In Test cricket, however, the opposite is true: so much is played these days that all the aggregate records are held by current or recently retired players.

With which county did Ian Botham start his first-class career? asks Peter Darling

Botham joined Somerset after a spell on the MCC cricket staff at Lord's, and made his debut for them in 1974, three years before the first of his 102 Test appearances. After objecting to Somerset's decision to release Viv Richards and Joel Garner, Beefy moved to Worcestershire in 1987 then, in a move he later regretted, he played for Durham in 1992 and 1993, their first two years as a first-class county.

I am the great-great-great-grandson of Tom Armitage, the Yorkshire cricketer who played in the first Test of all in Australia in 1876-77. What information do you have about him? asks Lindsay Toulson

Tom Armitage was born in Walkley, Sheffield, on April 25, 1848. He was primarily a batsman, but also had some success as a bowler, often with underarm lobs - he took 13 for 46 with them in the match for Yorkshire v Surrey at Sheffield in 1876, a few months before he played in the first two Test matches, at Melbourne in March 1877. He didn't take a wicket, and had scores of 9 and 3 in the first Test (which Australia won) and 21 as England won the second game. In all first-class matches (1872-79) he scored 1122 runs at an average of 13.35, and took 119 wickets (14.27). He later moved to America, to do some cricket coaching, and died in Chicago on Sept 21, 1922.

Is it possible to access the Laws of Cricket on the web? asks Jo Clark

The Laws have just been redrafted by MCC, and you can access the new code on the Lord's website by clicking here

Is there any record of a player named Kris Padman having played for India, or any first-class cricket in India? I can't find him, so thought I'd ask the experts, says Jason Keane

No-one of that exact name has played in Tests or one-dayers for India. It might just be a gentleman called Karumanaseri Narayanaiyer Ananthapadmanabhan, a right-hand batsman and legspinner who plays for Kerala. I expect their scorer uses a shortened version of his name!

What's the name of that cartoon duck which appears when a player makes 0 in Australia? asks Steve Hewitt

The cartoon character who waddles across the bottom of the screen on Australia's Channel 9 when a batsman makes 0 is called "Daddles the Duck".

I recently bought the 2000 Wisden Almanack (which I'm greatly enjoying), and in it I've come across several glowing references to the "centenary" Almanack of 1963. How should I go about obtaining a copy? asks John Rawlinson

You might well be able to track down a copy on the internet, using one of the searchable book sites like amazon.co.uk or Barnes & Noble. I looked just now and found one on Amazon for £40 and one on bn.com for $65 (it's an American site!). Alternatively you could contact a specialist cricket-book dealer, a list of which appears in Wisden each year - in the 2000 book it's on page 1565. You should try two or three of them to find the best price.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous column, The first of the pinch-hitters?,click here

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

webTitle: UK firm linked to Burma slavery

fields.headline: UK firm linked to Burma slavery
fields.standfirst: The generals: Exclusive interview with Burma's 12-year--old rebel leaders
fields.trailText: A British company, Premier Oil, went ahead with a £500m project to pipe gas through Burma despite warnings that its partner, the Burmese military, was using slave labour  - including children - on the pipeline, according to an internal report obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
A British company, Premier Oil, went ahead with a £500m project to pipe gas through Burma despite warnings that its partner, the Burmese military, was using slave labour - including children - on the pipeline, according to an internal report obtained by the Guardian.

Premier's American partner, Texaco, has since pulled out of Burma. But despite the British government taking the unprecedented step in April of asking Premier to leave, the oil company has refused.

The Burmese have been accused of using "security" issues in the pipeline area of Tanasserim to drive ethnic Karen people from the land. There are now 120,000 Karen living in refugee camps and human rights groups say at least 30,000 Karen have been killed. The army's tactics include rape and summary executions.

The report says the army was extorting money from local people and using children and forced unpaid labour - described by the special UN rapporteur to Burma as a modern form of slavery - to build military barracks.

"The harsh conditions of those carrying out the labour, including young children and the testimony of local people, belies the government claim that such work is voluntary," said the report.

Mr Jamieson, Premier Oil's chief executive, said he was unaware of any military barracks constructed in the area and that he would have to check the location.

Premier said it was aware of the contents of the report but had not been in charge of the pipeline - just a member of the consortium - when the abuses took place. The company said it reported any abuses it encountered to the "relevant authorities".

Burma's democratic leader and the Nobel peace prizewinner, Aung San Syu Kyi, held under house arrest for the last 10 years, has said Premier "should be ashamed of itself" for continuing to give moral and financial support to the military government.

Wilfred Wong of the Jubilee Campaign, the Westminster-based human rights organisation, said: "It is nonsense for Premier to say it reports abuses to the 'relevant authorities'. The relevant authorities are the Burmese military. Premier should admit they are working with mass murderers."

Since its takeover of the pipeline from Texaco in 1997, Mr Jamieson insists that Premier has ensured that the work was carried out according to the highest "international employment standards".

People who worked on the pipeline told Earth Rights International that the "Englishmen" (a name the Karen use for white foreigners) were aware of what was going on. A 15-year-old girl interviewed by Earth Rights said: "I had to clear bushes and other things. While we were working, there were two English guys watching us. On the first two days the English came and gave us 200 kyt (£1.04) for a day. On the third day the soldiers came back again and said, 'Your work yesterday was not good enough'. We didn't see any English and we didn't get paid."

Texaco pulled out of Burma in 1997 after pressure from the US government and Royal Dutch Shell's chief executive said recently that it would not consider working in Burma "with the current situation."

webTitle: Denmark pops crucial question again

fields.headline: Denmark pops crucial question again
fields.standfirst:
This time, the euro referendum might not have the cataclysmic effects of 1992
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: On September 28 Denmark's voters go to the polls to decide whether or not their country should sign up for the single currency. The contest will be keenly fought within Denmark and closely watched elsewhere, not least by Britain's eurosceptics.
fields.body:
On September 28 Denmark's voters go to the polls to decide whether or not their country should sign up for the single currency. The contest will be keenly fought within Denmark and closely watched elsewhere, not least by Britain's eurosceptics.

Little wonder. The outcome could help shape the debate on the single currency issue in the two other European Union countries yet to sign up: Sweden and Britain. Opponents of the single currency hope a "no" vote will damage the euro project. Certainly it would hardly help its search for credibility.

Those with long memories have an additional reason for paying close attention. Danish referendums on matters European can produce spectacular results.

Remember the summer of 1992? Then, project single currency looked in good shape. The Maastricht treaty had laid down the terms on which countries would be allowed to join. The exchange rate mechanism, within which currencies fluctuated between pre-set levels, appeared to be functioning without stress. The last realignment was more than five years in the past.

Poor substitute

On June 2, the Danes went to the polls to vote on the Maastricht treaty. A narrow majority - 50.7% - decided it did not like what was on offer. The rest of Europe woke the following day to find the Danes had voted "no".

Suddenly the currency markets realised progress towards a single currency was far from being the smooth ride it had seemed. Political will was seen as a poor substitute for economic convergence, a convergence which looked a distant prospect in the light of the very obvious domestic preoccupation and orientation of the EU's biggest economy, Germany.

By mid September, with the French vote on Maastricht looking an increasingly close call, tension within the ERM reached breaking point. Amid a flurry of speculative attacks Britain and Italy were forced out of the system; Spain, Portugal and Ireland devalued. Finland, Sweden and Norway abandoned pegs to the ecu. At least in the short run the Danes paid a hefty price for voting "no". The Danish central bank, determined to hold its currency, the krone, within its ERM band jacked up short term interest rates. By late November money market rates hit 15%. That saved the currency but did little for the competitiveness of Danish industry which faced higher borrowing costs and competitors benefiting from the effects of currency devaluations.

In December the Danes came to the Edinburgh summit asking for a new deal, complete with a series of "opt-outs", which was endorsed by the voters in May 1993.

So could Denmark and the rest of the EU face a rerun if, as the trend in the opinion polls appears to suggest, Denmark's voters are likely to give the euro the thumbs-down?

"Yes and no," says Jorgen Christensen, chief economist at Den Danske Bank. Widespread turmoil looks unlikely because the situation in Europe and in the financial markets is very different from that in 1992.

Where Mr Christensen does perceive a risk is the impact of a "no" vote on the international investment sentiment towards Denmark."If we do have currency turmoil it will be much more isolated around the krone."

Some DKr400bn - around a third of Denmark's debt - is held by foreign investors. "If they begin to be worried about the situation in Denmark we could have a reaction in the bond market.

"The Danish central bank will be quick to tighten monetary policy if they think there is pressure on the krone. They will do almost anything in terms of interest rates in order to maintain the link between the krone and the euro."

The signs are that Danish voters are more concerned about conceding power to Brussels than about maintaining Danish welfare standards. The events of 1992 appear remote. Many in the "no" camp reckon the Danish economy is robust enough to ride out any consequences of a rebuff for the single currency.

It is not a view that finds favour with supporters of Denmark joining the euro. Klaus Norskov at the Confederation of Danish Industry argues that if the Danes vote "no" the country will confront a new challenge, rather than being able to carry on as normal. "The consequences of a 'no' vote will be a highly uncertain situation."

Expecting ECB help

Unsurprisingly, "no" campaigners disagree. Anders Andersen, an adviser to the Socialist People's Party, argues that the economic situtation is completely different from that in 1992. "The countries being hit in 1992 were countries which had serious problems with their inflation rates compared to others [in the ERM]. In Denmark today the economic conditions are quite good, better than in most of the [euro zone] countries."

This time round a "no" vote is unlikely to be the shock it proved in the first Maastricht referendum - even though, then as now the polls put the two sides neck and neck.

Ironically, if a "no" does unsettle the currency markets even those Danes who rejected the idea of signing up for the single currency will still expect the European Central Bank to help out in any support operation for the krone.

One key question which would be raised by a "no" vote will be whether the government will accept the voters' verdict or seek to overturn the result. If it did press ahead with the campaign for single currency membership it might not find it so easy to win a rerun. As Juli Collins-Thompson, market economist at BNP Paribas in London, notes: "I don't think we would see a replay of 1992-93 where we had a new referendum less than a year later."

Or as one Danish observer put it: "There won't be any D'Artagnan effect this time. In 1992 the other members of the EU had a vested interest in keeping Denmark on board. This time they don't need to do that. The single currency is already up and running."

webTitle: Row over Tory role in Danish euro vote

fields.headline: Row over Tory role in Danish euro vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: William Hague came under fire yesterday when the former Conservative cabinet minister and European commissioner Leon Brittan rounded on the Tory leader for allowing frontbenchers to campaign for a "no" vote in the Danish referendum on the single currency.
fields.body:
William Hague came under fire yesterday when the former Conservative cabinet minister and European commissioner Leon Brittan rounded on the Tory leader for allowing frontbenchers to campaign for a "no" vote in the Danish referendum on the single currency.

Alarmed by reports that a shadow cabinet minister had appeared on a "no" platform in Denmark, Lord Brittan warned Mr Hague that it was "unwise and counterproductive" for Conservatives to interfere in the internal affairs of another country.

Lord Brittan fired off his letter to Mr Hague after the Tories confirmed that the shadow trade and industry secretary, Angela Browning, travelled to Copenhagen earlier this year to urge Danish no campaigners to change their slogan from "nej" to "keep the kroner".

The Conservative Euro-MP Daniel Hannan is also masterminding an appeal to help the no campaign which has raised at least £100,000.

Mr Hannan denies that he is intervening in the internal affairs of another country, insisting that he is merely planning to place advertisements in Danish newspapers explaining why his supporters will be voting no when a referendum is held in Britain. An appeal for his campaign - issued on the Eurosceptic Congress for Democracy website - asks for money to "assist our Danish allies".

In his letter yesterday, Lord Brittan called on Mr Hague to make clear in public that he was opposed to public intervention by members of the shadow cabinet. "It is both unwise and counterproductive for Conservatives to participate in the Danish referendum in the way that has been alleged," he told Mr Hague. "It is counterproductive because in my experience Danes, like other citizens of EU member states, resent being told what to do by outsiders."

Lord Brittan also warned Mr Hague that Tory campaigning for a no vote also pitted British Conservatives against their sister party, the Danish Conservative party, which favours the euro.

In another attempt to distance himself from Mr Hague, Lord Brittan reassured Danish pro-Europeans that many Tories favoured British membership of the euro. Lord Brittan said: "I want to make it clear that there are many British Conservatives who favour the United Kingdom's membership of the euro and believe that it is for the people of Denmark to make up their minds on this issue."

A spokesman for Mr Hague declined to respond to Lord Brittan's remarks.

webTitle: Britain swayed US over missile delay

fields.headline: Britain swayed US over missile delay
fields.trailText: Pressure from the British government played a part in delaying the decision on deployment of a proposed national missile defence (NMD) system until after the American election, according to US defence secretary William Cohen.
fields.body:
Pressure from the British government played a part in delaying the decision on deployment of a proposed national missile defence (NMD) system until after the American election, according to US defence secretary William Cohen.

He said on Tuesday that one reason for the likely delay is the degree of opposition from the government and other European capitals, which means that the $60bn deployment might not be able to take place until after the target date of 2005.

Tony Blair and foreign secretary Robin Cook have been pressing the US, in the words of one minister, not to indulge "in gung-ho unilateralism".

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain has told the US state department the British government will come under intense political pressure if deployment goes ahead.

Behind the scenes, Britain has been urging the US to keep talking to the Russians, fearing that unilateral deployment by the US would breach of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty and trigger a new arms race. Foreign Office sources said Bill Clinton and Tony Blair had been impressed by first hand reports from Vladimir Putin that North Korea wants to avoid confrontation with the US.

North Korea, Libya, Iraq and Iran have been cited by advocates of NMD as rogue states from which the US needs a new nuclear missile shield.

Mr Cohen told the US senate the decision on whether to deploy the system would be left to President Clinton's successor because testing was not far enough advanced. The only decision Mr Clinton would have to take was whether to start building a radar for it.

Mr Cohen said, according to the latest legal advice, clearing ground for the radar site on Shemya Island off the Alaska would not violate the 1972 treaty with Moscow. But a British minister said this legal interpretation was sailing pretty close to the wind. The Pentagon has projected that it would take five years to complete the construction of an anti-missile shield capable of defending the US.

webTitle: Blair agrees curb on special advisers

fields.headline: Blair agrees curb on special advisers
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday bowed to criticism from Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, and committed the government to limiting the number of special advisers, which have doubled under Labour.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday bowed to criticism from Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, and committed the government to limiting the number of special advisers, which have doubled under Labour.

The prime minister also announced a new code of conduct for special advisers and accepted a toughening of the code of conduct for ministers.

But he ruled out requiring ministers or civil servants to release to the public - as in the United States - the basic details of meetings they hold with lobbyists, outside interest groups or big companies.

Since Labour came to power, the number of special advisers appointed by the government has risen to 74, compared to 38 at the beginning of 1997.

The government said in its response that it accepted that "an overall limit on the number of special advisers should be included in civil service legislation". There is no date for introducing the legislation. The government also accepted the committee's recommendations that there should be a separate code for special advisers, "and that it should include a duty on all advisers to respect the political impartiality of the civil service".

The code will also include a section on the direct media contacts of advisers. Mr Blair has also accepted that the prime minister's code of conduct for ministers should be changed to make it absolutely clear that individual ministers must take personal responsibility for deciding whether they have a "conflict of inter est" with their private business or personal life. They will no longer be able to shelter behind advice they may have sought from their permanent secretary.

The government also accepted tougher rules for the growing sponsorship of government conferences and campaigns by private companies following criticism from Lord Neill.

A new code published yesterday bans departments from becoming totally dependent on private industry for projects and bans any sponsorship which will give overt commercial advantage to a company - by enabling it to sell directly sell products or brands as part of a deal with government.

Lord Neill yesterday called the response "very positive". He said: "Nearly all of the committee's recommendations (covering a wide range of topics) have been accepted in full."

 The large number of Labour supporters appointed by ministers to influential posts was confirmed by the office of the commissioner for public appointments yesterday.

The office's annual report showed 14.7% of those appointed to chair public bodies - which includes the boards of NHS trusts, nationalised industries and government advisory bodies - were Labour activists. Only 3.4% were Conservatives and 0.9% were Liberal Democrats, while others did not declare any political activity.

The report also found 8.9% of appointees were from ethnic minorities - slightly up on the previous year although none were given posts paying £20,000 a year or more.

It showed that 39% of appointments were women, the same as in the previous two years.

webTitle: Teen gang guilty of Reservoir Dogs murder

fields.headline: Teen gang guilty of Reservoir Dogs murder
fields.trailText: Three teenagers were found guilty yesterday of the torture and murder of a 15-year-old boy during which they re-enacted a scene from the film Reservoir Dogs.
fields.body:
Three teenagers were found guilty yesterday of the torture and murder of a 15-year-old boy during which they re-enacted a scene from the film Reservoir Dogs.

Allan Bentley, Mark Mc-Keefrey, and Graham Neary, all 16, were detained at her majesty's pleasure for killing Michael Moss, from Merseyside, whose naked body with more than 100 injuries was found last November on playing fields in Litherland, outside Liverpool.

The three subjected their victim to "sustained and appalling violence", Mr Justice Penry-Davey said at Liverpool crown court. "You, Bentley and McKeefrey, lured Michael Moss out that night, stripped him naked and in due course the three of you killed him. Having attacked and injured him so he was unable to move, you left him and later the three of you went to the scene where the appalling violence continued. webTitle: Carmen Martín Gaite

fields.headline: Carmen Martín Gaite
fields.standfirst: After the dismal Franco years she helped transform the face of Spanish literature
fields.trailText: The novelist Carmen Martín Gaite, who has died aged 74, was one of the generation that had to make their way in the dismal Spain of the post-civil war years, a country particularly hostile to independent women. In doing so, she helped change the face of Spanish literature and lay the basis for the resurgence in the 1970s of a new generation of readers.
fields.body:
The novelist Carmen Martín Gaite, who has died aged 74, was one of the generation that had to make their way in the dismal Spain of the post-civil war years, a country particularly hostile to independent women. In doing so, she helped change the face of Spanish literature and lay the basis for the resurgence in the 1970s of a new generation of readers.

To the reforming realist generation of the 1950s, including such writers as her ex-husband Rafael Sánchez Ferlosio and Ignacio Aldecoa, Martín Gaite added a particular sense of psychological depth. Included in this loose group of Madrid writers were two women, Josefina Aldecoa and Ana María Matute, who became her lifelong intimate friends.

The daughter of an affluent, liberal family, Martín Gaite was born in Salamanca, and graduated in romance philology from Madrid University when very few women were able to do so - at her death, she was one of only two women members of the Spanish Royal Academy. She became known for her short novel, the nightmarish El balneario (The Spa), in 1954, and won the Nadal Prize in 1957 for Entre visillos (Among Anti-macassars), in which she showed a characteristic domination of colloquial language. In both 1978 and 1994 she won the National Literature Prize, and in 1988 the Prince of Asturias Prize.

Indeed, as the young writer Belén Gopegui observed, she won every possible prize in Spanish literature except those which were fixed - in which she refused to participate. For Martín Gaite was a writer of rare principle. She was not someone to shout her opinions in a literary world full of loud voices, but discreetly showed who she was in deeds - agreeing to speak at a public library threatened by closure or refusing to lend her name to establishment institutions.

She was also a voracious reader, who never refused to help other writers. Juan José Millas, Marcos Giralt, Soledad Puértolas and Belén Gopegui are just some of the younger novelists whose careers were pushed forward by Martín Gaite's acute criticism and generosity. As well as a dozen novels, Martín Gaite wrote short stories, historical essays, literary criticism, social commentary - such as a famous 1987 book on Usos amorosos de la post-guerra española (Post-war Love Customs) - and translations.

Two novels have been published in English, Variable Cloud (1995) and The Farewell Angel (1999). The former, commonly thought the finest of her later books, added massive sales to her literary renown. Indeed, her three novels of the 1990s each sold over 300,000 copies.

Variable Cloud is the story of two childhood friends who had lost their friendship by a divergence of paths, exacerbated by sexual rivalry, but in middle-age crisis meet by chance at a party. Both are stimulated by the reunion to write down their stories, one in letters, the other in a journal. The novel is a paean to the curative effect of explaining the present by writing down the past, and not just secretly, but for another: literature as friendship. Gradually both women find solace in writing. Their troubles are not diminished, nor swept away, but held at bay by the triumphant renewal of their friendship.

Martín Gaite explores meticulously the inner lives of her protagonists, making few concessions to her readers: the themes are complex and the inner monologue abundant. Yet this long novel is very readable because of the smoothness and beauty of her style - not for nothing was she translator into Spanish of Madame Bovary - and a number of vivid secondary characters who bring wit and act as a chorus on the plights of the two women.

Martín Gaite wrote psychological novels, but always strongly pinned by a realist social context. Friendship was not just the theme of Martín Gaite's novels, but the passion, along with literature, of her life. Constantly active, unafraid to talk unguardedly, endowed with the gift of friendship, her open personality became a model for younger women of how to face life and take from it everything it has to give by herself giving generously.

And, despite early success, she was not pampered by ease and privilege: her long struggles in her career under Franco - she was already 50 when he died - were added to by the failure of her marriage and the death of her only child, her daughter Marta, in 1985. She dedicated her novel Lo raro es vivir (How Strange It Is To Live) to a friend who "always poked her head out among ruins and mistakes with her smile of light".

Martín Gaite's frank stare and open smile of light - in her art and her life - taught her readers how to understand their own ruins and mistakes. She had been working right up to her death from a cancer diagnosed only in June.

webTitle: Movie star seeks Old Vic revival

fields.headline: Movie star seeks Old Vic revival
fields.standfirst: Oscar winner invests £100,000 in theatre project offering investors tax breaks
fields.trailText: The actor Kevin Spacey yesterday promised to bring back the glory days to the Cinderella of London theatres by sinking more than £100,000 of his own money and the full weight of his celebrity into reviving the Old Vic.
fields.body:
The actor Kevin Spacey yesterday promised to bring back the glory days to the Cinderella of London theatres by sinking more than £100,000 of his own money and the full weight of his celebrity into reviving the Old Vic.

He has pledged to perform at the venue in Waterloo, south London, and said that fellow actors John Malkovich and Willem Dafoe would follow him across the Atlantic.

"I want to use myself as a magnet to attract great writers, actors and directors back to this theatre that has kind of been lost," he said yesterday at the launch of Old Vic Productions.

Spacey, the Oscar-winning star of American Beauty, who won an Olivier for his performance in The Iceman Cometh at the Old Vic, said his dream would be to play alongside another Old Vic legend Peter O'Toole.

"I've got four films to do first but as soon as I finish them I want to get my butt back on that stage where it belongs. My parents brought me there first when I was five. It made a big impact on me, I still have the programme. I don't know what it was, the grand scale with the intimacy, but it continues to be the favourite theatre I've probably ever played in. Within 30 seconds of stepping on that stage I knew it was it. There's a lot of people I'd love to act alongside. I'd love to do a comedy too with Sam Mendes directing it."

Today Spacey, who gave up his 41st birthday to fly to London, will try to sell to the City his vision of a theatre company in which investors can take advantage of generous tax breaks.

"There is no better present for me than to have money come to the Old Vic. We need at least £1m but I do not see why we won't get £3m. We are not going cap in hand for subsidies. Even if we lose all your money, which I assure you, you won't, you'll get half of it back in tax relief."

Its chief executive, the impresario Sally Greene, who also heads the Old Vic Trust which saved the building by buying it for £3.5m, has assembled a board of directors including Dame Judi Dench, Jeremy Irons, Lord Attenborough and David Suchet. Spacey will act as a consultant.

They have also forged an alliance with the dance company Adventures In Motion Pictures, which is about to take up residence at the Old Vic with a new show, The Car Man. The Almeida is also staging its production of Lulu starring Anna Friel at the Old Vic.

Spacey said they hoped to succeed where Sir Peter Hall failed by assembling a dedicated company of actors by 2002 which was likely to be headed by Stephen Daldry, the former artistic director of the Royal Court, who is also on the Old Vic board.

Greene - the producer be hind such hits as The Weir, the American run of The Blue Room starring Nicole Kidman, and Speed The Plow - said the new company wanted to revolutionise the way theatre was funded.

"We invest in a range of productions - we'll be co-producing The Car Man for instance - so that our risk is spread.

"At the moment angels put their money in one production and if it goes they lose their money. The company is separate from the trust so the building will always be safe."

Minimum stakes in the company are £2,000. Greene said investors who put in £5,000 or more would be invited to first nights, readings, parties and dinners with the stars.

webTitle: Cuba winning cancer race

fields.headline: Cuba winning cancer race
fields.standfirst: Economic isolation and a passion for healthcare yield a world lead in genetically engineered medicine
fields.trailText: Clinical trials of a cancer therapy genetically engineered by the Cuban biotechnology industry are due to begin in London next month. It may prove to be a landmark both for medicine's struggle with the disease and Fidel Castro's attempts to break out of Cuba's US-imposed isolation.
fields.body:
Clinical trials of a cancer therapy genetically engineered by the Cuban biotechnology industry are due to begin in London next month. It may prove to be a landmark both for medicine's struggle with the disease and Fidel Castro's attempts to break out of Cuba's US-imposed isolation.

Despite a stark lack of resources, laboratories in the impoverished suburbs of the capital Havana have made startling strides in developing revolutionary vaccines and antibodies against meningitis, hepatitis, and lung, breast, head and neck cancers.

But their use in other parts of the world has been hindered up to now by the Helms-Burton Act, the US measure which penalising foreign companies for dealing with Cuba.

That hitherto impenetrable wall is now beginning to crumble in the more general thaw in US-Cuban relations, and western investors have found that Cuban scientists, subsisting on scarcely £10 a month, are ahead in some fields of their colleagues in the US and western Europe in the race to produce genetically engineered medicines.

After months of intensive lobbying, the British pharmaceutical company Smith Kline Beecham succeeded a year ago in persuading Washington to give it an exemption from the act, allowing it to develop and market a Cuban vaccine against the child-killing disease, meningitis B. It is the only such vaccine in the world, and is undergoing trials prior to being launched in Europe.

In the past few weeks, as international investors have grown less afraid of US retaliation, a Canadian venture capital firm, York Medical, has secured funds for clinical trials of Cuban cancer vaccines and antibodies.

Its director, David Allan, said that trials of a cancer vaccine would begin in Britain "in the next few weeks" on cancer patients who were not responding to conventional treatment. The hospitals involved cannot be named for contractual reasons.

"We already know it is effective," Mr Allan said. "What we are doing is confirming clinical trials. We all know the answer."

The vaccine does not prevent cancer in a healthy person, but it prevents existing tumours spreading. It works by provoking the immune system into making antibodies against epidermal growth factor (EGF), a naturally occurring protein which plays an important role in childhood development but seems to have no function in adults other than nourishing tumours.

The problem in reducing its supply was to find a way to provoke the immune system into fighting a substance normally found in the body.

The Cubans found a way by bonding EGF with a bacterial protein known as P64k, which promotes an immune response to both and thus mops up the supply of EGF.

York Medical says that the vaccine has already produced impressive results in Cuban tests, increasing the average survival time by 200%.

"There's a certain degree of inventiveness in Cuba, of thinking outside the box," Mr Allan said."We all learn the same words, the same things in medical school, but the Cubans are not bound by what has been in the past."

They have also developed an antibody which could provide a second line of attack against certain tumours. It works by blocking EGF receptors on cancer cells and prevents them connecting with and being nourished by the protein.

The strategy, first laid out by a Cuban scientist, Rolando Perez, in a scientific paper in 1984, not only stops the tumour growing but weakens the cancer, making it far more vulnerable to chemo- and radio-therapy.

To Cuba the success of these trials is essential. In the last 10 years, President Castro has ploughed an estimated $1bn into its cluster of biotech institutes, capitalising on a long-term investment in medical expertise which has given Cuba more doctors per capita than any other country in the world.

Mark Rasenick, a University of Illinois physiology professor who watches Cuba's progress, said: "Because they have a surfeit of physicians, they are able to allow the best and the brightest to engage in work which supports a system of biomedical research. It's considered a national priority."

The investment also represents, in the words of a diplomat in Havana, "Fidel's moon-shot" - a bid for national greatness and an impudent challenge to the US monolith in the great scientific race of the era.

But Jose Suarez, whose job it is to find foreigners to invest in Cuban scientific discoveries, points out that the country's achievements save lives. It is not national vanity, he argues, but "a national necessity".

"The world is not interested in paying to cure the diseases of poor countries," he said in his office in the Finlay Institute. "The existing cholera vaccine is for tourists. It works for 30 days, but if you live in a poor country there is no vaccine for you. We are testing a cholera vaccine for people who live in the Third World."

The meningitis B vaccine was developed as an emergency response to an epidemic in the 1970's. The government gave 15 researchers the task of finding a solution in a hurry. They tested the prototypes on their own bodies, and finally came up with a vaccine that was 84% effective.

By 1990 meningitis was no longer a serious threat in Cuba. In blocking its international use until last year, Mr Suarez said, Washington was striking at Cuba but harming the world's poor and young.

The licence given to Smith Kline Beecham last July is the only one of its kind, and it is hedged with restrictions which deny Cuba the right to cash royalties but allow it limited amounts of US medicines as a barter payment. It is a grudging exemption.

Mr Allan thinks that if the cancer trials prove successful it will be politically impossible for Washington to suppress the Cuban vaccines.

Two months ago, York Medical was on a knife-edge. It had bought the rights to the Cuban vaccines and antibodies but potential investors were wary of putting money into a project that would be ultimately strangled by Washington's embargo. The funds for trials, mostly from British and European investors, have only come in in the last few weeks.

Mr Allan believes that investors have drawn the same conclusion he has: that the US embargo is "headed for the ash-can where it belongs".

The measure which is currently before the US Congress does not kill the Helms-Burton legislation but will leave it vulnerable. And it is almost unthinkable that the American public will continue to tolerate the act if it becomes a barrier to importing effective cancer treatments.

Mr Rasenick believes that Cuban biotechnology will help to bring down the sanctions. "As a scientist, I would never continue the same failed experiment for 38 years," he said.

The government gave 15 researchers the task of finding a solution in a hurry. They tested the prototypes on their own bodies, and finally came up with a vaccine that was 84% effective. By 1990 meningitis was no longer a serious threat in Cuba. In blocking its international use until last year, Mr Suarez said, Washington was striking at Cuba but harming the world's poor and young. The licence given to Smith Kline Beecham last July is the only one of its kind, and it is hedged with restrictions which deny Cuba the right to cash royalties but allow it limited amounts of US medicines as a barter payment. It is a grudging exemption. Mr Allan thinks that if the cancer trials prove successful it will be politically impossible for Washington to suppress the Cuban vaccines. Two months ago, York Medical was on a knife-edge. It had bought the rights to the Cuban vaccines and antibodies but potential investors were wary of putting money into a project that would be ultimately strangled by Washington's embargo. The funds for trials, mostly from British and European investors, have only come in in the last few weeks. Mr Allan believes that investors have drawn the same conclusion he has: that the US embargo is "headed for the ash-can where it belongs". The measure which is currently before the US Congress does not kill the Helms-Burton legislation but will leave it vulnerable. And it is almost unthinkable that the American public will continue to tolerate the act if it becomes a barrier to importing effective cancer treatments. Mr Rasenick believes that Cuban biotechnology will help to bring down the sanctions. "As a scientist, I would never continue the same failed experiment for 38 years," he said.

webTitle: Gould's memo: Euro opposition makes Tories more electable

fields.headline: Gould's memo: Euro opposition makes Tories more electable
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Extracts of Philip Gould's memo of October 4, Strategic Choices On Europe:
fields.body:
Extracts of Philip Gould's memo of October 4, Strategic Choices On Europe:

Great divide in Britain: The great obstacle to building a sustainable majority for the euro is the fundamental divide that runs through the country on Europe. One will never create anything like a national consensus on the euro, except perhaps after joing in the single currency. Opponents of the euro can get major traction by emphasising the threat to sovereignty and British control of its own future.

Conservative opportunity: For the Conservatives, the Europe issue is a life preserver. They have fallen to 24% of the vote, and William Hague has failed to win the public's confidence. But by grasping hold of Europe, the Tories can make themselves relevant and more electable. If Labour attempts to marginalise the Tories by attacking their position as extreme - in effect, a brand of Thatcherism that is hostile to Europe - Labour loses the argument. More voters at this point are inclined to believe the opposite charge: that Labour is extreme, determined to abandon the pound and create a European superstate.

webTitle: Third leak from No10 strikes at Blair

fields.headline: Third leak from No10 strikes at Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has told his cabinet colleagues that they must take on the Conservative party over the euro or else look weak, according to the latest leaked memo from inside the Downing Street machine.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has told his cabinet colleagues that they must take on the Conservative party over the euro or else look weak, according to the latest leaked memo from inside the Downing Street machine.

It is the third dramatic leak direct from the prime minister's office and suggests the government is still exposed to an organised and unprecedented attempt to destroy its business.

Privately, ministers admit they are prey to a form of paralysis until the source of the leaks is identified. Mr Blair's aides claimed the memo revealed nothing he had not said already in public.

The memo, leaked like the others to the Sun and the Times, quoted Mr Blair as saying the government needed to be "firmer, more certain, clearer" on the euro, but stressed that the economic conditions had to be right first.

However, Mr Blair's pollster, Philip Gould, has also warned the prime minister that if he attempts to portray William Hague and his anti-Europeanism as extremist he will lose the argument.

The latest leaked memo was timed to distract attention from the government's National Plan for Health, to be unveiled today.

Downing Street last night recognised the damage of the memo but claimed voters would begin to realise that leaks were part of a coordinated attempt to distract attention from major long-term policy announcements.

Senior executives at News International, which owns the Sun and Times, insisted they were not complicit in a conspiracy to reveal leaks at a time designed to distract attention from the government's big spending announcements.

The previous damaging leaks were published immediately before and after the government annnouncements of big spending increases for public services.

The Guardian yesterday quoted reliable sources alleging that the publicist Max Clifford was the go-between in a series of leaks of memos from Mr Blair and Mr Gould. It said that he was responsible for the placing of the leaks after the documents were recovered by Benjamin Pell, nicknamed Benji the Binman because of his habit of rummaging through the waste bins of the rich and famous.

The same sources also told the Guardian on Tuesday that a further leak was likely to be printed in the Sun and the Times today to deflect media attention from the announcement of the government's NHS reform plans.

The health plan will be published today and is expected to include tough controls on consultant's contracts, especially new consultants.

In the latest leaked memo, Mr Gould says any attempt to portray the Tories as extreme will backfire. "If Labour attempts to marginalise the Tories by attacking their position as extreme - in effect a brand of Thatcherism - Labour loses the argument. More voters are inclined to believe the opposite charge - that Labour is extreme, determined to abandon the pound and create a European superstate."

The memo will increase pressure on Mr Gould to be despatched from the Blairite inner circle as a pernicious rightwing influence. His defenders will argue that he simply faithfully and vividly conveys the opinions of swing voters.

In the leaked memo Mr Gould says: "The decision to join the single currency at some future point raises significant challenges for the Labour party in the upcoming election and in any future referendum". But he also warns the "Labour stance may well energise the Tories and provide them with a credible position in the upcoming elections and a vehicle for ending Labour support. A credible performance by the Tories in 2001 using the euro issue makes a referendum that much more difficult."

Mr Gould admits in his memo what all public opinion polls have been saying, namely no section of society wishes to join the euro at moment. In a memo originally dated October 4 last year he says: "More troubling is the lack of movement towards the euro or Europe since a pro-europe government assumed office in Britain. Economic circumstances can create a majority for joining - but that majority will always be in jeopardy. One will never create anything like a national consensus for on the euro except perhaps after joining a single currency. The great obstacle to building a sustainable majority for the euro is the fundamental divide that runs through the country on Europe. A majority of the country does not identify with Europe."

webTitle: GMC checks on complaints against sacked surgeon

fields.headline: GMC checks on complaints against sacked surgeon
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council has launched another potentially damaging investigation into a sacked surgeon facing a dossier of complaints.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council has launched another potentially damaging investigation into a sacked surgeon facing a dossier of complaints.

The day after disgraced gynaecologist Richard Neale was struck from the medical register, officials travelled to West Yorkshire as it was revealed surgeon Christopher Ingoldby had been dismissed by Pinderfields and Pontefract Hospitals NHS trust.

The sacking came on Tuesday evening after the trust met to consider the report of an inquiry into his work. There have been 84 complaints brought against the surgeon, of which 30 have been settled. The GMC is to consider bringing disciplinary action which could lead to him being banned from practising as a doctor.

Yesterday former patients said they felt vindicated by Mr Ingoldby's sacking.The trust suspended Mr Ingoldby from his NHS job in January 1998. He continued to practice in a Bupa private hospital for some months afterwards. Lawyers for former patients say more decisive action would have ensured he lost his job and his NHS salary long ago.

A statement from David Russell, the Wakefield solicitor representing 60 families said: "The families considered it utterly disgraceful that it had taken the trust three years to face up to and deal with Mr Ingoldby." Public expenditure on his salary and the costs of investigations probably exceed £5m, he said.

Evidence against Mr Ingoldby started to flood in following the death of Brian McDermott, 64, in October 1997 after having his stomach and spleen removed. A verdict of misadventure was returned at an inquest.

Mr Ingoldby was sent on leave and suspended a few months later. Complaints against the general surgeon went back to 1992.

He denies the accusations against him.
