webTitle: The devil's bargain that brings disaster home

fields.headline: The devil's bargain that brings disaster home
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The plane came down on a piece of that dreary flatland typical of northern France. The building it demolished, and everything close by, was modern and functional, typical of the area round any airport but which the French seem to make even more featureless than anyone else.
fields.body:
The plane came down on a piece of that dreary flatland typical of northern France. The building it demolished, and everything close by, was modern and functional, typical of the area round any airport but which the French seem to make even more featureless than anyone else.

But you only have to walk half a mile back from the crash site - for a Concorde pilot, almost literally the blink of an eye - and you are in the centre of old Gonesse. And this is a typical small French town, with its bars and boulangeries, pantiles and peeling shutters.

Whether it was luck or the pilot's skill, no one can yet know. But Gonesse, unlike most places the day after a disaster, was in part relishing its escape. Concorde's normal flight path, when it takes off from runway two as this one did, goes over the old town and the hospital. "It was a catastrophe, yes," said a man in the Bar Boule D'Or, "but it was also a miracle."

For Gonesse, the crash was at once terrifyingly close, yet strangely distant. This is not an especially rich town and the chances are that its people not only never went on Concorde but never knew anyone who did. Anyway, the travel agent has closed down. Even two of those killed on the ground were Polish and brought forth only shrugs from the locals.

Enthusiasm for Concorde and its attendant hint of la gloire seem muted or faded here. They have seen and heard it twice a day since Charles de Gaulle airport opened down the road at Roissy a quarter of a century ago, and, for some, familiarity has bred contempt. It's a subject on which everyone at least has an opinion, though. "It's too noisy, I've always hated it," said Gilbert Lejeune, a Metro worker. "I love Concorde and this is so sad," said Francoise Hoareau, a nurse. "Whenever it comes by I look up and marvel."

Now there is a new opinion: "It's beautiful," said housewife Wanda Szawan, "but it's dangerous, isn't it?"

"Gonesse. Ville Calme," says the sign as you enter. "Respectez les limitations de vitesse." But it stopped being a calm town when the airport came. The mayor of Gonesse, Jean-Pierre Blazy, yesterday called for a ban on all Concordes and demanded a new Paris airport. Most of his speech was drowned out by aircraft noise.

The deputy mayor, Gre goire Gerard, was far more militant. He fought against the airport in the first place, campaigning for it to be 15 miles further out of town; he fought against the new runway, now being built. "The airport was always a nuisance. But now everyone can see there is another problem, and it could be a particularly tragic one. I had always feared something like this might happen."

The police were doing their best to shelter Gonesse from its celebrity. By dawn, their cordon had been pushed down the hill towards the town forcing the television anchormen to pose pointlessly in front of a flyover.

It was possible some of the time for the professionally curious (and the ordinarily curious) to avoid the police line by creeping through a muddy wood on to a hillside. There one could glimpse helmeted firemen carrying stretchers amid the debris. The smell of fuel and smoke had gone. It was a curiously compressed scene, the wreckage not strewn at random for miles around as in many plane crashes but mostly contained in an area about half the size of a football pitch. Most of it, however, was blackened beyond recognition. Had you not known it was once an aeroplane, you might not have guessed.

A few locals joined the media outside the makeshift morgue to gawp as President Jacques Chirac and about 200 of the mourners came by. The mourners were brought in discreetly in three buses with darkened windows to a local hall where an interdenominational service was held. Most townspeople carried on as normal.

For 3,000 of Gonesse's 25,000 inhabitants, that means work at the airport.

Gerard complains that his people only get menial jobs. They drive the buses and pour the coffee at Charles de Gaulle but they can't be blamed when planes fall out of the sky - they aren't given the jobs that could make a difference. He wants a new college in the area to teach engineering skills.

For the world beyond Gonesse, and Germany, the resonance of this crash stems from the plane itself. Great theories are already being spun, likening this crash to that of the Hindenburg, the Challenger space rocket and quite likely the Titanic. Supposedly, illusions have been lost and an era is ending.

What we forget is that the illusions about Concorde disappeared decades ago. It was thought to represent the future; in fact, it was a dead end, as Britain realised as it tried unsuccessfully to wriggle out of the contract before the plane was built.

But it became loved because it failed. It was so rare and exotic that for most of us to see it - never mind ride it - was really something.

But for Gonesse, Concorde was more of an everyday fact, and perhaps will be again. There is a devil's bargain here, familiar to every town that relies on any kind of dangerous, polluting or unsustainable factory for its livelihood. "I hear the noise every day," said a woman in the Boule D'Or, "and I hate it. But my grandson works at the airport. That's his income I hear overhead."

webTitle: Feedback

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
E-shopping
Sanjida O'Connell is right, of course (Why shoppers shy away from the net, Online, July 20). For many who are comparatively "old hands" at surfing the net and who are "just ordinary" folks, any attempt at window shopping on the net is not only frustrating, but boring. It can also be costly, and very time wasting. For the house bound, and those who just cannot afford the time to go "supermarketing" and of course, the initially curious, some level of business will establish itself.

But human beings need stimulation, including getting to and returning from centres of commercial interest. All sorts of things can happen and all sorts of people can be met. Not so on the net. Long live lovely, wonderful human individuality and choice.
Robert Davis
robarb@pisle5.freeserve.co.uk.

Jenni's first
Contrary to the assertion in Web Watch, www.jennycam.com is not by any means a classic. It is a rip-off of the name of the real classic www.jennicam.com. There are many variations on the name in attempts to cash in the fame of the original. Almost any recognisable distortion will produce a derivative web site, but most of them are commercial and sleazy.
John R Batts
johnbatts@banbury19.freeserve.co.uk

Opera lover
Stephen Dunn writes about how annoying it is for web developers that Opera impersonates other browsers. (Online, July 20) . But it is only because of sloppy, lazy web developers who don't understand that the web is designed to run across a variety of browsers from Lynx to Netscape and insist on coding for Internet Exploiter only that Opera has to resort to this tactic. Anthony Cunningham
tjc@tardis.ed.ac.uk

Water works
John Eason's interesting commentary on urban myths (Weblife, July 20) poses the question "Is there any truth to the legend that water swirls down the plughole counter- clockwise in Australia?" The answer, surely, is yes. I recall that in the 1960s the journal Nature reported the findings of an experiment using a carefully engineered vibration-free temperature-controlled bowl. In the southern hemisphere, as may be expected, water did indeed swirl counter-clockwise. Stan Brown
brownfarthings@aol.com

Picture law
Whatever the international situation, the copyright problem raised by Guy Clapperton does seem to be covered under English Law, specifically by the Copyright Act and by the House of Lords Report on Digital Imaging. The concept is that of an original from which copies can be made. The author, in this case the photographer, holds copyright in the original and has the right to make copies and to charge anyone else who wishes to do so.

The original is, in traditional photography, the negative or transparency which results from processing the film after exposure to light. It may be copied in various ways, including scanning, but the original, with its copyright, still exists and any copies produced from the digital file are still copies of the original.

A different situation arises when the digital file is produced directly using a digital camera. The House of Lords says that a digital file can never be an original because it can only be copied digitally. If there is no original there can be no copyright. Thus, in the Sygma case, some authors may be entitled to copying fees, others not, depending on whether or not the digital file came from a copyright original.
George Kitchin
george@gkphoto.freeserve.co.uk

1996 The Operators, James Rennie (army)

1998 The Irish War, Tony Geraghty (army)

1999 Defending the Realm, Mark Hollingsworth and Nick Fielding (MI5)

2001? Stella Rimington (MI5)

Britain's securocracy - Whitehall spymasters, backed up by government lawyers, engaged in the increasingly thankless task of preserving state secrets - are faced with an intriguing conundrum. What do they do when the bulwark they have been relying on for so long to protect their secrets crumbles before their eyes?

The 1989 Official Secrets Act was designed to deter civil servants and other state employees from disclosing information without authority, in particular to silence former members of the security and intelligence services.

In the case of David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, and of Richard Tomlinson, currently trying to escape the clutches of British police in Italy, not to mention a string of books by former SAS soldiers, it patently has not worked.

The new issue of Punch, in which Shayler describes how GCHQ monitored an IRA active service unit before the 1993 Bishopsgate bombing, is just the latest example.

Last week's appeal court judgment dismissing attempts by the police special branch and state prosecutors to seize any emails and notes the Guardian and Observer newspapers may have had relating to Shayler sounded the Official Secrets Act's death knell.

The act was passed after a series of prosecutions and acquittals made the catch-all provisions of the previous secrets act untenable. The 1989 act applies to what it misleadingly calls "more limited classes of official information".

Section 1 prevents members or former members of the security and intelligence agencies from revealing any information about their work. There is no public interest defence - the act imposes a life-long duty of confidentiality. Under section 5, journalists and others commit a criminal offence if they make "damaging" disclosures about the activities of the security and intelligence agencies.

The act also covers information relating to defence and "international relations". In this last category the mere fact that a document is stamped confidential could be enough for the state to claim damage.

The act is essentially a discretionary statute but with a significant political ingredient - the consent of the attorney general is needed before prosecution. Thus the present attorney, Lord Williams, dropped secrets charges against Tony Geraghty, the journalist and author of The Irish War, which reveals details about the army's surveil lance systems in Northern Ireland, but not against his alleged source, Nigel Wylde, a former senior army officer.

The securocracy is in a quandary over both the Wylde and the Shayler cases. The defence will argue that section 1 of the act breaches the Human Rights Act which comes into force on October 2 and establishes a right to freedom of expression and guarantees the right to a fair trial.

Privately, government lawyers recognise the incompatibility of the two acts. However, the last thing the Home Office wants to do is to reform or repeal the Official Secrets Act, certainly not this side of a general election.

They have thought up a clever wheeze. They hope that, even though section 1 does not provide a public interest defence, the prosecution and the trial judge will allow the defence to argue that their clients acted in the public interest. Thus Whitehall will be able to argue that even though, on the face of it, the act does not allow a public interest defence, in practice - through judge-made case law - it does. Therefore it is compatible with the Human Rights Act.

Perversely, last week's appeal court judgment could also help those in Whitehall who want to put off any change in the Official Secrets Act. In finding for the two newspapers, Lord Justice Judge virtually dismissed the Human Rights Act as an irrelevance. The duty of silence imposed on former spooks, and by extension journalists publishing their disclosures, was a flagrant abuse of English common law, he suggested.

He quoted a 1981 high court ruling in which Mr Justice Watkins stated: "I am concerned with the fundamental freedom which this country has prided itself on maintaining, and for which much blood has been spilt over the centuries, namely freedom of speech".

Lord Justice Judge went further. True or false, he said, Shayler's allegations about MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy were inevitably damaging to Britain's security and intelligence agencies. Yet, whether true or false, said the judge, "unless there are compelling reasons of national security the public is entitled to know the facts, and as the eyes and ears of the public, journalists are entitled to investigate and report the facts ... without prejudgment or selectivity".

These words are as incompatible with the Official Secrets Act as they are compatible with the Human Rights Act. But Whitehall is seizing on them to argue that everything is fine. The government is relying on the judges to enable them to bottle out of reforming or repealing the Official Secrets Act, at least for now.

The determination of Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, to publish her memoirs, and the prospect of a mature, independent and open vetting system covering books by former spooks provide further ammunition against the outdated act.

There is another twist. While the Official Secrets Act is dying, the long-delayed Freedom of Information Act is in danger of being stillborn. It exempts from disclosure, on the say-so of ministers, information which has been supplied by security and intelligence agencies. It also exempts information which "in the reasonable opinion of a qualified person ... would prejudice the effective conduct of public affairs".

Ministers will also be able to veto any recommendations from the proposed information commissioner, Elizabeth France, that papers should be released in the public interest.

Back to square one.

 Richard Norton-Taylor is the Guardian's security affairs editor

webTitle: Victorian laws repealed in review of sexual offences

fields.headline: Victorian laws repealed in review of sexual offences
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Victorian laws under which thousands of gay men have been prosecuted are to be repealed as part of an overhaul of Britain's sexual offences laws proposed by the Home Office yesterday.
fields.body:
Victorian laws under which thousands of gay men have been prosecuted are to be repealed as part of an overhaul of Britain's sexual offences laws proposed by the Home Office yesterday.

The official review set up two years ago by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to develop a new code of sex offences proposes changes not only to the laws on gay sex but also creating new offences of persistent child abuse, voyeurism and trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation.

The proposals are also laced with recommendations for much tougher sentences for transgressors.

But while the review group recommended radical change in the gay sex laws it is more cautious in its approach to the rape laws. The report, Setting the Boundaries, rejects suggestions that it should be made easier to prosecute alleged rapists by reversing the burden of proof or introducing a lesser offence of "date rape".

However, it is the proposals to remove remaining discrimination against gay men by abolishing the offences of buggery, gross indecency and soliciting by men which are likely to prove contentious. Home Office ministers are said to be nervous about the political impact of any such action.

The review group, which proposes legalising all consensual sexual activity between adults in private which cause no harm, says the time when the criminal law could be used to discriminate against homosexuals should be long gone.

webTitle: The 'aviation anorak' who took the now famous photo

fields.headline: The 'aviation anorak' who took the now famous photo
fields.standfirst:
Hungarian misses out on a fortune

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The amateur photograph that was splashed across yesterday's newspaper front pages and television bulletins is already being acclaimed as the news picture of the year.
fields.body:
The amateur photograph that was splashed across yesterday's newspaper front pages and television bulletins is already being acclaimed as the news picture of the year.

But to the Hungarian student who took it it is just the most famous of the many aircraft photos in his collection.

Andras Kisgergely, 20, a self-confessed aviation "anorak", took the picture moments after the passenger jet took off from Charles de Gaulle airport on Tuesday. While the photo is focused on the foreground, it shows the full plume of flames billowing from the aircraft's left wing. Experts yesterday said the photo was probably taken using compact auto-focusing camera with a small, built-in zoom lens.

Within hours Reuters news agency had had the picture developed and wired it across the globe. The image is likely to be shown thousands of times in the coming months.

While most tourists in Paris on Tuesday were focusing their lenses on the Eiffel tower, Notre Dame and the Champs-Elysées, Andras Kisgergely and his fellow spotter Szabolcs Szalmasi, 22, spurned the conventional sights in favour of Charles de Gaulle airport, just one stop on their annual tour of Europe's runways.

The two, who are studying engineering at the Hungarian Technical University in Budapest, cannot afford to travel by plane themselves. Instead they spend two or three weeks a year driving to airports in pursuit of their hobby and have amassed an archive of thousand of aircraft shots.

A spokesman for Reuters said the company would not discuss how much Mr Kisgergely was paid for his photograph but the agency's usual flat-rate fee for contributors is said to be £300.

Jean-Marc Smaja, managing director of Corbis Sigma picture agency in France said that had the student negotiated a percentage fee on the open market the image could have fetched him up to a 60% cut of $100,000-$150,000 (£66,000-£99,000) in takings for the first three weeks. Copyright may yet revert to Mr Kisgergely for later syndication when Reuters' week-long control of the picture expires.

Tuesday was not the first occasion on which Mr Kisgergely had witnessed an air disaster, Mr Szalmasi said. Last year he had watched a Hawk military jet crash at an air show in Slovakia.

"Wherever he goes there is a crash," Mr Szalmasi said. "I won't fly with him."

Both men hope to find work in the aviation industry when they graduate.

webTitle: Insurance firms face total payout of more than £230m

fields.headline: Insurance firms face total payout of more than £230m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The Air France crash will cost insurance firms in excess of £230m, brokers predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
The Air France crash will cost insurance firms in excess of £230m, brokers predicted yesterday.

The greatest cost is expected to come from liabilities for ground damage, including the demolished two-star, 40-room Hotelissimo hotel, and crew and passenger claims.

Families of victims are likely to receive upfront payments of around £13,000 each from Air France within the next 15 days, under EU regulations.

The International Air Transport Association (Iata) in Geneva said this was a "gesture of kindness".

The airline has also begun to meet relatives' costs for visiting the crash scene, including travel, accommodation and counselling.

An Iata spokeswoman said Air France was then obliged under EU regulations to compensate each family by up to around £85,000, regardless of the cause of the crash and without having to wait for a complete investigation. Under the conditions of an international compensation agreement signed by Air France in 1996, relatives need not prove negligence.

The association said Air France must calculate the compensation payments as soon as possible. This requires an assessment of each victim's income, future earning potential, home and family situation.

Most of the cost of the crash will be met by the French insurance consortium, Reunion Aerienne. The Concorde was insured for around £30m in the French market. But, as a standard damage limitation exercise, reinsurance was distributed across companies worldwide, including in Britain.

Lloyds of London will absorb 15% of the liability. A Lloyds spokesman said this was a "small amount and not significant".

Stewart Wilson, chief operating officer for brokers Heath Lambert Reinsurance, who handled London reinsurance of the Concorde, said: "The cost to the London market may be tens of millions of pounds. The London market will take this very much in its stride."

webTitle: Concorde fleet will fly on, says BA

fields.headline: Concorde fleet will fly on, says BA
fields.standfirst:
Travel industry has faith in financial future of remaining 12 aircraft

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: British Airways and the travel industry last night moved to quash doubts about the commercial future of the Concorde fleet following the Paris crash.
fields.body:
British Airways and the travel industry last night moved to quash doubts about the commercial future of the Concorde fleet following the Paris crash.

They maintained that the aircraft remains financially viable in the long term despite the crash that left 113 people dead and the plane's reputation compromised for the first time in its 30-year history. The 12 remaining aircraft in service are scheduled to operate until 2015.

Around 125,000 passengers use BA's seven-strong flagship fleet annually. BA said the fleet operated at a healthy profit, and it was confident passenger numbers would not drop despite the failure of the Air France plane.

At any one time four aircraft are in use on the New York-London route, one is undergoing maintenance checks, another is "spare", and the seventh is used for charter flights.

Around 50% of supersonic passengers are business people or what BA terms "high wealth" passengers, paying around £6,290 for a return flight to New York.

The remainder are leisure passengers on package trips or charter flights. Package operators charge a supplement to passengers wishing to start or end their holiday in style. The German tourists who died on Tuesday afternoon were one such group.

British Airways Holidays, a division of BA, said a typical supplement cost around £5,750 for the New York trip. A spokeswoman said that while it was too early to gauge passenger reaction to the disaster they expected Concorde's allure to remain strong.

Passengers already booked on Concorde flights departing before August 4 were being offered the chance to cancel without any penalty or transfer to subsonic flights with a full refund.

For the charter operator Goodwood Travel, Concorde is its core business. Its joint managing director, Colin Mitchell, said: "We were worried about the future of the business on Tuesday evening, but we have had no more than 12 cancellations and we have even had some bookings. People have been calling to offer sympathy and support. It is an indication of the way people feel about the aircraft."

Goodwood Travel began chartering Concorde in 1983 and has flown some 100,000 passengers to more than 50 destinations. A New York charter costs £250,000.

"At those prices it's a full commitment when we take on the plane but for the passengers it's something they will never forget," said Mr Mitchell. "This tragedy was devastating to us because it hit close to home. The group of Germans could easily have been one of our groups."

Among those booked on the 10.30am Concorde flight to New York yesterday morning there were mixed feelings about boarding so soon after the Paris crash. Out of 78 passengers, 29 decided not to go.

Brian Pople, 60, an electrical contractor, had no qualms: "Lightning doesn't strike twice. From what I can see on the news it was probably something that happened on the ground. There was nothing wrong with its design... If I thought it wasn't safe I wouldn't be going."

However, the president of US television network CNBC told how he could not face the emotional ordeal of a flight back to New York on Concorde. Bill Bolster, 56, transferred to a subsonic flight: "This is nothing to do with anything other than an emotional response," he said. "I have total confidence in the engineers and pilot of this Concorde but I just can't face it."

The mood among pilots at Heathrow was sombre. "We're all desperately upset that Concorde has gone down," said one senior pilot with more than 20 years experience.

"It's a magnificent looking aircraft - whenever I see one taxi past I tell my passengers it's the best looking bird at Heathrow - but what happened could have happened to any aircraft. There has been a huge overreaction in the media because it's Concorde."

webTitle: Hunt for the ideal search engine

fields.headline: Hunt for the ideal search engine
fields.standfirst: Suffering from information overload?  Danny Sullivan, a search 	engine guru, has some top tips
fields.trailText: Suffering from information overload? Danny Sullivan, a search engine guru, has some top tips
fields.body:
They call it the information superhighway, but it seems more like Spaghetti Junction when you're trying to navigate it. Popular search engines such as Yahoo and AltaVista are fine for locating web pages on a general subject, but for more specific material like news, music and pictures, you need a specialist search tool.

News junkies have a number of good news search engines to choose from. My current favourite is Moreover. It gathers headlines from more than 1,500 sources and groups them into 300-odd subjects. You can scan current stories at the site or sign up to have headlines emailed to you on particular subjects on a daily or weekly basis.

Also worth visiting is News Index. It allows you to search for current news stories appearing on more than 300 news sites. The search engine checks back with these sites several times a day to keep abreast of developments. You can even set up custom searches and have results emailed to you each day.

At NewsNow, headlines are organised into six categories. You click on a category for more specific topics. Usefully, topics are grouped according to how many minutes or hours old they are and UK stories are flagged with a union flag.

If it's music you want, there is a swath of tools for tracking down MP3 files. The controversial Napster software is fantastic for locating and retrieving music files from other users' hard disks (although of course, it may violate copyright laws). Web-based MP3 search engines Gnutella and SpinFrenzy are not as effective at locating files but do not require you to download software. Alternatively, the Lycos MP3 search engine or the CNet Music Centre lets you check multiple MP3 search engines at once.

If you're hunting for pictures, you need an image search engine that displays thumbnail pictures in its results, rather than just telling you about them in words. Both Ditto.com and AltaVista scour the web to find the images they present. AltaVista also provides matches from professional collections, which can be used royalty free, for some purposes.

Remember, while these tools make finding images easier, that doesn't grant you an automatic right to use the files you find in your own web documents. Always check with site owners about using pictures that you discover.

If you've got a Wap (wireless application protocol) phone that actually works, then a Wap search engine will locate pages designed for your mobile's small screen. Fast's Wap Search gathers its listings from the web, Waply uses human editors to categorise Wap-friendly sites, while WAPAW.com uses a combination of the two. Also be sure to visit Google, which will automatically translate any page you find from its results into a format for your phone. In addition, it will keep on translating as you view additional pages, giving you access to the entire web.

Somewherenear is a location search engine helpful to both those with Wap phones and ordinary searchers alike. Tell Somewherenear what type of business you are after, such as a pub or cinema, then tell it where you are, and it will return matching businesses in the UK.

Sometimes it can be useful to discover what people are talking about on the internet. RemarQ lets you scan messages posted to newsgroups. You can even sign up for an account that will let you post without needing newsgroup software.

Meanwhile, a new service called eNow enables you to search through live discussions on the internet. The service is down temporarily, but its operators promise it will be back up shortly.

Subject search engines narrow your search to sites covering a particular topic, rather than the entire web. Click your way down into any area of interest, then use the search box at the top of the page to search just within that subject.

For example, to perform a DIY search, you would click "Home", then "Do-It-Yourself". On the page that appears, there are some excellent DIY web sites listed. Then, if you use the search box, you can scan all the pages that Google has found from these sites - and only these sites. As a result, looking for "windows" brings up pages related to DIY and windows, and not the Windows operating system.

webTitle: The floor shook, flames burst across the room and she fled

fields.headline: The floor shook, flames burst across the room and she fled
fields.standfirst:
The survivor British tour guide tells of escape from hotel inferno
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: A British student yesterday described how she leapt from the first floor window of a blazing hotel and ran barefoot over fields and a motorway to escape the devastation caused by the crash of the Air France Concorde outside Paris on Tuesday. The woman was one of the few survivors after the plane crashed into the hotel where she had been staying.
fields.body:
A British student yesterday described how she leapt from the first floor window of a blazing hotel and ran barefoot over fields and a motorway to escape the devastation caused by the crash of the Air France Concorde outside Paris on Tuesday. The woman was one of the few survivors after the plane crashed into the hotel where she had been staying.

Alice Brooking, 21, from Tonbridge, Kent, had been in the Hotelissimo in Gonesse for just half an hour when the plane crashed. A summer tour guide, she had been waiting for a party of English music students to check in and was on the phone chatting to her sister in London.

Having escaped with burn injuries to her arms, she said yesterday: "I heard something like a plane taking off then it got louder and louder and louder until it really was deafening - until the whole floor started to tremble, at which point I realised something was up. I rushed straight for the door, and saw flames and smoke pouring from the stairs.

"I just left my sister dangling on the phone and ran straight to the window because it was the only way I could get out. The flames leapt across the room and across the bed and the receptionist who was in the car park beneath me shouted 'you have to jump'."

"I landed straight on top of him and he cushioned my fall. I did not have time to thank him. I just jumped and ran."

Ms Brooking, a student at Selwyn College in Cambridge where she studies modern languages, had not realised that there had been a plane crash or that the hotel had been flattened.

She said she looked back to see a wall of flame and did not understand what had happened until a lorry driver shouted "it's Concorde". She was spared the sight of bodies strewn from the wreckage or among the debris of the hotel. Ms Brooking said: "I didn't see anything to do with the plane. By the time I was out of the hotel, it was all in flames, and you couldn't see anything, so I really didn't have anything bad or terrible to have to cope with."

The student, who had been working with the tour company Club Europe since June, added that she did not know what had happened to the hotel until she was told later. Then she realised how lucky she had been - one of 12 survivors from the hotel. Four died there.

She said she did not want to portray herself as a heroine or "someone who has survived by a miracle because I'm not".

She said: "I did what had to be done and I was very, very lucky. All I can say is how sorry I am for those who weren't as lucky as me."

Earlier, Ms Brooking described how there had been "a big, big field kind of in the middle of nowhere".

She said: "So I ran, barefoot across the fields, as I'd left my shoes in my room, but didn't have time to think about anything - then tried calling the attention of the car drivers, and then basically got myself away, that was my first concern.

"Luckily, there weren't that many people in the hotel at the time, I don't know what they were doing. I know there were a lot of staff in there. I'd only been in the hotel half an hour myself."

Ms Brooking had been chatting on the telephone to her sister Nathalie who was at work in London when she heard a loud explosion. She shouted: "Oh my God, what's that?" before the phone went dead.

Ms Brooking's sister phoned her parents. Her father, Hugh, said: "We were frantic when Nathalie phoned us to say the line had gone dead and then we started seeing what had happened on TV". Ms Brooking managed to borrow a mobile phone from a firefighter at the scene to call her parents to let them know she was safe.

Her father said: "She was screaming I'm alive, I'm alive'."

webTitle: Skilled pilot 'did his best'

fields.headline: Skilled pilot 'did his best'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Christian Marty, the Concorde pilot who steered his doomed aircraft away from the busy streets of Gonesse, was an experienced Air France captain and a keen sportsman who 20 years ago became the first Frenchman to windsurf across the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Christian Marty, the Concorde pilot who steered his doomed aircraft away from the busy streets of Gonesse, was an experienced Air France captain and a keen sportsman who 20 years ago became the first Frenchman to windsurf across the Atlantic.

"He was an exceptionally competent man, admired and liked by everyone at Air France who knew him," said Bernard Pedamon, a fellow Airbus pilot and friend. "He flew his first plane in 1969 and had over 10,000 flying hours behind him. He will have done absolutely everything he could."

Marty, who leaves a widow, was born in the southern town of Saint Laurent du Var. Aged 54, he qualified as a Concorde captain just over a year ago. He died at the controls of his plane as it plunged into a hotel on the outskirts of the small town, east of Charles de Gaulle airport.

"For me, the pilot is a hero," said Jean-Marie Alexandre, a Gonesse delivery driver who watched the plane come down. "He made a big swing to the left to avoid crashing onto Gonesse or the N17 autoroute. He knew what was happening and tried to avoid any more deaths."

Another pilot, Eric Derivry, said Marty was "a great sportsman, very sharp mentally and physically - he was at the very highest level". He said the dead pilot was an active sportsman known for taking his mountain bike with him on long-haul flights to while away the turnaround hours.

Pierre-Jean Loisel, another Air France captain, said Marty had been the captain on an Airbus 340 for many years before moving on to Concorde flights. "He was a humble man and a very, very professional one," he said. "I'll always remember him as a calm, committed pilot who was also a sportsman at heart."

webTitle: Last minute repairs may be key to Concorde crash

fields.headline: Last minute repairs may be key to Concorde crash
fields.standfirst:
Work by two mechanics at centre of disaster inquiry
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The engine of the Air France Concorde which erupted into flames and exploded, bringing the aircraft crashing to earth at a cost of 113 lives, was being worked on only minutes before takeoff, it emerged last night.
fields.byline: Jon Henley, David Hearst and Jason Burke in Paris
fields.body:
The engine of the Air France Concorde which erupted into flames and exploded, bringing the aircraft crashing to earth at a cost of 113 lives, was being worked on only minutes before takeoff, it emerged last night.

Two mechanics who carried out repairs on the left number two engine - an operation that took 30 minutes - are at the centre of inquiries by air crash investigators.

The repairs were reportedly carried out at the insistence of the captain, although Air France said yesterday the manufacturers had declared the supersonic craft safe to travel.

The plane crashed two minutes after takeoff on Tuesday after the pilot fought in vain to make an emergency landing.

The first details of the communication between the pilot and air traffic control show that the engine was on fire before the jet had reached the end of the runway. By that point, it was too late for the pilot to abort takeoff.

An hour and a half earlier, although he was technically allowed to to take off in a plane which had been reported defective on a flight from New York the previous day, the pilot, Christian Marty, 54, demanded that a replacement part be found for a malfunctioning reverse thruster.

He insisted that as the plane was full, and therefore heavy, the reverse thruster - which slows the plane on landing - must work properly. The part could not be found, and a backup Concorde was cannibalised to provide it.

As accident investigators combed the charred remains of the aircraft and the hotel on the outskirts of Gonesse into which it ploughed, the public prosecutor in charge of one of three French crash inquiries, Elisabeth Senot, released information from the cockpit voice recorder, which has been recovered from the wreckage.

Only 56 seconds after the pilot switched his engines to maximum thrust, the control tower warned him that flames were spouting from the rear of the aircraft. Seconds after, an unidentified voice in the cockpit reported tersely: "Breakdown in engine number two." The tower replied that the flames were spreading.

Marty, said by fellow pilots to be a dedicated pilot with more than 30 years of experience, then told the air traffic controllers that it was too late to abort takeoff, because he was already going too fast.

"At that moment, he suggested heading for Le Bourget airport, rather than trying to return to the Roissy runway," said Ms Senot. "In order to do that he embarked on a turning manoeuvre and it was during that manoeuvre that he crashed."

British Airways, the only other operator of Concorde, yesterday resumed flights, saying it had complete confidence in its aircraft. But the French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, ordered Air France's six Concordes to be grounded indefinitely.

He said that the two flight recorders on the plane had been read, but not interpreted. Their results would be released today. If they did not reveal the cause of the disaster, he would consider demanding that the planes' engines be recertified.

The crash of the Concorde, which for 31 years was in the vanguard of French aviation, has come as a huge psychological shock to a nation which has always believed in the superiority of its technology. Several commentators suggested the future of the aircraft was now in doubt.

As pale-faced relatives of the passengers, most of whom were German, arrived at Charles De Gaulle's T9 charter terminal to be greeted by 50 psychologists, the German transport minister Reinhard Klimmt told reporters they should respect the privacy of grief. "I have spoken to some of the relatives. They are in shock," he said. "My conversation with them is private."

Ninety-six of the passengers were from Germany, including 13 from the town of Mönchengladbach. All were killed as the Concorde exploded in a huge fireball.

By late afternoon 105 of the 113 victims had been recovered from the crash site. The authorities in Gonesse said the task of retrieving the corpses had been complicated by the violence of the explosion.

In Germany, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder led mourners at a televised memorial service in Hanover. "Germany is shaken and Germany is speechless," he said, struggling to find his words. The French president, Jacques Chirac, attended a similar service in Gonesse last night.

Meanwhile, a British student who was staying at the hotel in Gonesse last night told of her extraordinary escape from the inferno: "I was talking to my sister on the phone, when we both heard this enormous bang," said Alice Brooking, a Cambridge University student who was working for the summer as a tour guide in France.

"I ran to the door, but the landing was covered in flames. I just jumped [from a first floor window] and ran and ran and ran as far away from the hotel as I could get."

webTitle: Games reviews

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: MoHo | In Cold Blood | Dead or Alive 2
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Andy Bodle and Steven Poole
fields.body:
Convicts roll out a new idea

MoHo

Sony PlayStation £29.99 Take 2

Originality isn't an overly common commodity in the PlayStation market but, for their first title since leaving Bullfrog, Lost Toys have developed an inventively different game.

Move quickly past the wafer-thin plot - future criminals lose legs, gain ball and become freedom-seeking gladiators - and choose from a list of curiously unlovable characters. Then it's into the action which is best described as mixing Marble Madness, skateboarding and future sport. Fans of those genres will enjoy the accurate rolling and movement, but it is the rippling landscape that impresses most.

Caused by explosions and other seismic activity, this is a remarkable graphical effect on a machine already drawing its pension, and enables you to surf past baddies and obstacles alike. The game is split up into numerous arenas made up from one of seven basic elements - race, tag, pursuit etc - but all involve time trials or tricky challenges.

Successful arena qualification opens up further levels and there is certainly a lot to do before your spherical-limbed convict tastes freedom. But frustration can set in with a steep learning curve for first-timers. Just getting used to the physics and control takes time and it's likely that MoHo's charms will remain hidden to all but the most committed and patient gamer. Or, perhaps, to those who fondly recall the days when games were hair-wrenchingly tough and Fifa was a little known acronym. Flawed, yes, but in these days of sequels and licenses, MoHo is a breath of fresh air. (GH)

Great game, shame about the console

In Cold Blood

Revolution Software/ Sony PlayStation

Developing a game for the PlayStation these days is like launching a space shuttle with an elastic band: however good the design, it's never going to get off the ground.

In Cold Blood has good design coming out of its ears. A tight, twisting plot, challenging puzzles, intricate visuals, and an interface that remains intuitive without wasting a button on the controller. Sadly, these noble efforts are thwarted at every turn by the limitations of the console.

In theory, the animations and backgrounds are rich and detailed. In practice, on the PlayStation's ageing processor, it's like watching the cast of Thunderbirds wandering round the set of Scooby-Doo.

In theory, the ubiquitous shadows add atmosphere; in practice, unless you're playing on a multiplex cinema screen, it's impossible to tell good guys from bad, or which way your character is facing (a hitch in a third-person stealth adventure).

The nine huge levels, split Resident Evil-style into dozens of smaller zones, ought to give relentlessly nail-biting gameplay; but with the PlayStation's feature-length load times, you'd better have some knitting handy. Revolution must take its share of the blame. It's way too easy to die: three bullets and you're dead, and you can't draw your gun without triggering world war three. There are also believability problems: guards shoot you if you so much as show your face, while their technician colleagues treat you like a long-lost brother.

Then there's the sort of carelessness that would leave Homer Simpson's forehead sore. The first guy you meet, for example, helps you out by chatting with the guards outside a mine so that you can sneak in. But once you've hacked into the mine's computer, you discover that the entry under your pal's name reads "shoot to kill".

It's almost as if the developers, having sweated blood over the core of the game, gave up when they found out it was PlayStation-bound. On the other hand, if this is a test run for something sensational on the PS2, I can't wait. (AB)

No sex please, we're killers

Dead or Alive 2

Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Tecmo/Sega

Acclaim's poster campaign for this game - featuring a reclining digital woman with the legend "Are you hard enough?" -is a pitiable example of the kind of drooling teenage sexism that still infects the videogame industry. Which is stupid, because underneath the soft-porn trappings of heaving breasts and flashing knickers, Dead or Alive 2 boasts some highly refined beat-'em-up mechanics.

Most games in the Tekken or Street Fighter mould require you to learn head-frazzling strings of button-presses to execute special moves, but DOA2 is different.

Punches and kicks flow together with beautiful freedom, while an intuitive system of grapples and reversals explodes the tedious old "I'll attack while you guard and then you attack while I guard" paradigm.

The gorgeously modelled 3D arenas include a church with stained-glass windows and a verdant mountain pass with a splashing stream, as well as the usual hi-tech rooms of steel and glass.

Their topography demands strategic thinking: fighters can be hurled through windows, slammed up against walls, or thrown off the edge of a platform to land painfully 100 feet below.

fields.bodyText: Convicts roll out a new idea MoHo Sony PlayStation £29.99 Take 2 Originality isn't an overly common commodity in the PlayStation market but, for their first title since leaving Bullfrog, Lost Toys have developed an inventively different game. Move quickly past the wafer-thin plot - future criminals lose legs, gain ball and become freedom-seeking gladiators - and choose from a list of curiously unlovable characters. Then it's into the action which is best described as mixing Marble Madness, skateboarding and future sport. Fans of those genres will enjoy the accurate rolling and movement, but it is the rippling landscape that impresses most. Caused by explosions and other seismic activity, this is a remarkable graphical effect on a machine already drawing its pension, and enables you to surf past baddies and obstacles alike. Just getting used to the physics and control takes time and it's likely that MoHo's charms will remain hidden to all but the most committed and patient gamer. DOA2 can't match that masterpiece for sheer eye candy or long-term solo interest, but its two-player contests, especially in the excellent tag mode, are fascinatingly tense, and it is possibly the more sophisticated game design. webTitle: Germany struggles with its grief

fields.headline: Germany struggles with its grief
fields.standfirst:
The mourners 'God, where were you in Paris?' asks bishop
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Inexorably yesterday, the dimensions of the tragedy sank in among Germans. Filtered by respect for the families of the dead and the country's strict privacy laws, the identities of some victims nevertheless trickled out, putting names and faces to the statistics.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Mönchengladbach and John Hooper  in Berlin
fields.body:
Inexorably yesterday, the dimensions of the tragedy sank in among Germans. Filtered by respect for the families of the dead and the country's strict privacy laws, the identities of some victims nevertheless trickled out, putting names and faces to the statistics.

In Mönchengladbach, businesses remained closed as the Rhineland city struggled to cope with the shock. Thirteen people from Mönchengladbach were among those who died, a bigger toll than any other city. All 13 belonged to a group of wealthy businessmen and entrepreneurs who often travelled together on foreign cruise liners.

"We are utterly devastated," said Christian Sattrop of the Clemens travel agency in the suburb of Rheydt where the group had booked the tour. "All of them had been regular customers with us for years and they were really looking forward to this trip."

Among the dead were Mar garete and Werner Tellmann, owners of a furniture business. Their store in Rheydt shopping precinct remained closed yesterday; "For family reasons we will not be opening today," read a sign scribbled on paper behind the glass doors.

"We don't know how to react," said a shop assistant, Monika Dierhahn. "The Tellmanns built the business up over 30 years. They never took holidays until recently and then it was only once a year. This was to be their chance to see the world."

Other crash victims included Kurt Kahle, the director of a private business school, his wife Marion and son Michael. "It is very difficult," one of Mr Kahle's friends told local radio. "We saw them off on Friday with a barbecue at our house and had wished them well."

The town's mayoress, Monika Bartsch, appealed to journalists to leave relatives in peace. "They must be allowed their right to privacy," she said.

The Social Democrat prime minister of North Rhine-Westfalia, Wolfgang Clement, ordered flags throughout Germany's most populous state to be flown at half-mast. Forty-nine of the victims came from the state.

Mönchengladbach plans a memorial service on Saturday. The city's football team cancelled a lavish anniversary celebration on Saturday.

Most of the relatives of the dead flew to Paris yesterday. The French authorities were said to have dropped objections about the bereaved going directly to the scene of the crash.

Four Mönchengladbach residents who had booked on the tour escaped death because there were no seats left on the flight. The four, including a Conservative Christian Democrat politician, Renate Zimmermanns, flew to New York on a regular Lufthansa flight on Tuesday.

Mrs Zimmermanns's son Stefan said he had called his mother at 2am. "She is shattered. They were sitting aboard the cruise liner waiting for the others to arrive but her friends just didn't show up," he said.

Elsewhere in Germany, the tragedy left a trail of lives destroyed. The car manufacturer BMW disclosed that an entire family had been killed. Staff at the company's Munich headquarters confirmed that an engineer, Christian Eich, 57, his 36-year-old wife, their 10-year-old son and seven-year-old daughter, and his wife's parents were killed.

Television viewers saw a cabinet minister reduced to tears. Karl-Heinz Funke, an agriculture minister in Gerhard Schröder's coalition, said: "My wife gave me a call and told me that the daughter of a good friend was on the plane as a stewardess."

Mr Funke was leaving a service for the victims in Hanover, attended by the chancellor and all the available members of his government. "Germany is shaken and Germany is speechless," Mr Schröder told the congregation.

"God, where were you in Paris?" asked the Roman Catholic bishop of Hildesheim, Josef Homeyer, his voice cracking with emotion. "Why have you deserted us?"

All but four of the 100 passengers who died were Germans. Another was thought to be an Austrian living in Germany.

They had booked for a cruise starting today aboard the MS Deutschland. From New York, the vessel was to make its way down the eastern seaboard, through the Panama canal to Ecuador where many of the passengers were to disembark.

Others are thought to have been booked in for the onward passage to Sydney where the MS Deutschland is to provide the official premises for the German national olympic committee during the games.

The cruise is to go ahead. The owner of the vessel, Peter Deilmann, said from his firm's headquarters in Neudstadt that all 410 remaining passengers had been offered a refund if they cancelled. "No one took up the offer. So it is our duty to carry on."

webTitle: Comment: Promises of cuts in road traffic are being broken by Prescott

fields.headline: The young will take to the trees
fields.standfirst:
Promises of cuts in road traffic are being broken by Prescott

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Promises of cuts in road traffic are being broken by Prescott.
fields.body:
John Prescott's pledge was unequivocal. "I will have failed," he wrote in June 1997, "if in five years' time there are not many more people using public transport and far fewer journeys by car. It's a tall order, but I urge you to hold me to it."

Well Mr Prescott, I hold you to it and I assert that you have failed. You have failed now, and you will fail five years, 10 years and 15 years after your promise was made. Your transport plans, for all the fanfare with which they were launched, are a disaster.

How can I state this with such confidence? Because your own projections show it. I refer you to one of the documents you published on Thursday - Transport 2010: the background analysis. Figure 13, chapter three shows that, even if your 10-year plan is fully implemented, between 2000 and 2010 traffic volumes will increase by 17%.

We shouldn't be surprised to find that your promise and the others that the Labour party has made (before the election, for example, it told us that it would "reduce and then reverse traffic growth"), will be comprehensively broken. Studies dating back to 1938 show that road building generates traffic: new roads fill up until congestion persuades drivers to find a different way to travel. As one of your transport ministers commented in 1998, "the fact of the matter is that we cannot tackle our traffic problems by building new roads".

If you don't believe him, look at what has happened in Newbury. According to a report by West Berkshire Council, following the construction of the new bypass "there is no consistent pattern of traffic change over the Newbury network as a whole". As the inevitable "infill" development between the bypass and the town generates its own traffic, the long-term impact on the town centre could turn out to be deeply negative.

Even your 10-year plan acknowledges that "simply building more and bigger roads is not the answer: we need a more strategic approach". But a more strategic approach is precisely what you have failed to deliver. You have announced that 100 bypasses will be built and 360 miles of roads widened before these schemes have been identified, or the need for them has been established. In other words, you have decided to build first, ask questions later.

You surely know better than anyone else that people will not leave their cars behind until there are both incentives to take alternative forms of transport, and disincentives to drive. Instead, you have offered both new incentives to take the train and, through new road building, new incentives to take the car.

You promised an integrated transport system, but you have delivered instead a formula for self-destruction - one half of your scheme neatly undermines the other.

So why are you doing this? The Confederation of British Industry has kindly provided us with a clue. Your plan, it announced, is "a monumental victory for the business community". The CBI's lobbyists demanded a transport package worth £180m, and this is, to the pound, what you gave them. The primary purpose of most large-scale construction is to provide contracts for developers. You have given a struggling construction industry everything it wanted.

The only logical concomitant of a massive investment in public transport is not the £21bn road building programme you have announced, but a £21bn road closure programme. If you are to honour your promises, you must gradually reduce the amount of available road space, rather than increasing it. A long-term, carefully phased road closure plan would show that you genuinely want to make ours a healthier, more cohesive, more inclusive society, governed not by corporations and a handful of target voters, but by the best interests of all of its people. You could start to achieve all the things your "integrated" department claims it stands for: less air pollution, more peace and quiet, more space - as land is released - for playing fields, housing and conservation. And your "public transport revolution" would be an unquestionable and irreversible success.

Instead, Mr Prescott, you have lost faith in your own objectives. You have already broken your promise, made before the election, not to build the Birmingham Northern Relief Road. You will break your promise not to build the Salisbury bypass. You have broken your promises to reduce the amount of traffic on our roads. Soon, young people all over Britain will take to the trees and the tunnels once more, in an effort to force you to keep the promises you made in order to attract our votes. And you will call them undemocratic.

webTitle: Engine fault crippled plane on takeoff

fields.headline: Engine fault crippled plane on takeoff
fields.standfirst: Air France details captain's insistence on fitting of spare part
fields.trailText: Air France yesterday took the highly unusual step of issuing a detailed statement explaining exactly what happened in the minutes leading up to the crash of its ill-fated Concorde.
fields.byline: Jon Henley  and  David Hearst  in Paris  Jason Burke  in Gonesse and Keith Harper  in London
fields.body:
Air France yesterday took the highly unusual step of issuing a detailed statement explaining exactly what happened in the minutes leading up to the crash of its ill-fated Concorde.

At 2.30pm an airline spokesman handed a single sheet of paper to the media waiting at the company headquarters in Roissy, part of the Charles de Gaulle airport complex. It gave two reasons for "the delay" of flight AF4590.

Air France said the first reason for the delay was that the 100 passengers "on this very special flight" had very short connection times at the Paris airport. Because of the late arrival of their luggage from Frankfurt, flight AF4590 was delayed.

But the sheet of paper also revealed that during a flight from John F. Kennedy airport in New York arriving back last Monday, the captain of the aircraft had reported that the system that reverses the thrust of the engine was not working.

The release said that the spare part for the reverse thrusters was not immediately available from the "parts warehouse" in Paris.

The statement went on: "Given the technical tolerance authorised by the manufacturer, the aircraft could take off again without being repaired ..."

This information was presented to the captain of flight AF4590, who decided to overrule the advice and have the spare part installed.

The part was immediately obtained from another Concorde, Air France said, and the repairs took 30 minutes to carry out.

Under aviation rules, which apply to all airlines, the captain has the ultimate responsibility for control of an aircraft. If he thinks there is a problem, he is bound to ignore any commercial pressures placed on him to take off.

Speaking on Channel 4 News, Bill Tench, Britain's former chief air accident investigator, suggested last night that the mechanics would have been under great pressure to complete the work in order to meet the flight's departure slot.

"It's possible that in their hurry to change the component, a panel was not completely replaced. Consequently when the pilot opened the throttle, I'm pretty sure the suction would pull the panel out and break the compressor [in the engine] into pieces," he said.

Sources among emergency services at the airport yesterday told the Guardian that the Concorde had developed problems as it attempted to take off.

The airport's emergency services had been scrambled as the plane began to take off and problems with the number two engine became apparent. As the plane left the ground, airport staff said flames were clearly visible streaming from the affected engine.

The conversation taped on the cockpit voice recorder between the pilot, Christian Marty, and air traffic controllers reveals that 56 seconds into the run the rear of the aircraft was belching flames. The runway was too short to allow the pilot to abort the takeoff.

'Bits of metal'

This is confirmed by a witness from an aircraft waiting to take off behind the doomed Concorde. She said she noticed smoke coming from one of the engines and "bits of metal on the runway under the wing."

Airport sources also confirm that the pilot contacted air traffic controllers to request permission to make an emergency landing after takeoff. But the plane did not have sufficient power to gain enough altitude to turn back safely.

They said that the pilot, by now at about 300ft, was forced to take action to avoid crashing into the nearby town of Gonesse. In doing so, he lost control of the plane and hit the ground.

The deputy public prosecutor, Elisabeth Senot, said: "The pilot reported a failure in number two motor and it seems he was no longer able to brake, given that the thrust was too great."

Ms Senot, who is leading a judicial investigation, said she was quoting from transcripts from the plane's cockpit voice recorder, retrieved at the crash scene.

The Air France Concorde, which had flown for 12,000 flying hours, had last been serviced four days before the crash. It had received a major overhaul, involving the stripping down of all flying services last September.

Air France has invested £30m in a programme to give each aircraft "a large technical overhaul every nine months." The aircraft is completely dismantled on each occasion, with the objective of prolonging its working life till 2010.

Bernard Pedamon, an executive member of the French union of pilots said: "Pilots are trained to cope with an engine fire after takeoff. But there is a combination of factors which can contribute to it."

Mr Pedamon said the pilot would have known that he would not have been able to stop the aircraft. The last communication from the pilot was that there was an engine breakdown not a fire.

He added: "At this stage, the pilot would have been extremely busy with the takeoff and in this case with emergency procedures. It is extremely difficult to manage and communications are cut to a minimum."

The events in Paris were relayed to British Airways which yesterday resumed flights to New York when the BA001 Concorde took off half full at 10.30am. It landed at New York, three and a half hours later.

BA would not divulge the Air France communication "because there is a chance of legal proceedings." But it stressed that it had acted on the information and that its own Concorde was subjected to a thorough inspection before being allowed to leave.

Mike Street, BA's director of operations, said: "We have complete confidence in our own Concorde aircraft. We have liaised closely with the relevant air safety authorities and the aircraft and engine manufacturers."

He said: "We believe there is no technical, safety or operational evidence to suggest that Concorde should not operate safely into the future. We have had no information from Air France or the British and French authorities which leads us to believe that we should ground our Concorde fleet."

BA briefed its passengers on its flight plans and offered them the opportunity to switch to subsonic aircraft. Most of them decided to remain with Concorde.

The aircraft is completely dismantled on each occasion, with the objective of prolonging its working life till 2010. Bernard Pedamon, an executive member of the French union of pilots said: "Pilots are trained to cope with an engine fire after takeoff. But there is a combination of factors which can contribute to it." Mr Pedamon said the pilot would have known that he would not have been able to stop the aircraft. The last communication from the pilot was that there was an engine breakdown not a fire. He added: "At this stage, the pilot would have been extremely busy with the takeoff and in this case with emergency procedures. It is extremely difficult to manage and communications are cut to a minimum." The events in Paris were relayed to British Airways which yesterday resumed flights to New York when the BA001 Concorde took off half full at 10.30am. It landed at New York, three and a half hours later. BA would not divulge the Air France communication "because there is a chance of legal proceedings." But it stressed that it had acted on the information and that its own Concorde was subjected to a thorough inspection before being allowed to leave. Mike Street, BA's director of operations, said: "We have complete confidence in our own Concorde aircraft. We have liaised closely with the relevant air safety authorities and the aircraft and engine manufacturers." He said: "We believe there is no technical, safety or operational evidence to suggest that Concorde should not operate safely into the future. We have had no information from Air France or the British and French authorities which leads us to believe that we should ground our Concorde fleet." BA briefed its passengers on its flight plans and offered them the opportunity to switch to subsonic aircraft. Most of them decided to remain with Concorde.

webTitle: 'Eight-year term' for Norfolk farmer who shot burglar, 16

fields.headline: 'Eight-year term' for Norfolk farmer who shot burglar, 16
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Tony Martin case
fields.trailText: Tony Martin, the Norfolk famer serving life for the murder of a burglar aged 16, may spend only eight years in prison.
fields.body:
Tony Martin, the Norfolk famer serving life for the murder of a burglar aged 16, may spend only eight years in prison.

The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, who recommends how long convicted murderers should serve, has suggested that Martin be incarcerated for a minimum of eight years.

According to a leaked document obtained by ITV's Tonight with Trevor MacDonald, the trial judge, Mr Justice Owen, who jailed Martin for life for the murder of Fred Barras when the teenager was caught raiding his farmhouse, had recommended a nine-year minimum term, or tariff.

But Lord Woolf believes there are "mitigating circumstances" which mean Martin should be considered for a lesser tariff.

Martin is appealing against his conviction. Jurors at Norwich crown court found him guilty of murder by a 10-2 majority after hearing how he shot Barras at Emneth Hungate, Norfolk.

According to the programme, Mr Justice Owen made his nine-year recommendation in a report to the home secretary, Jack Straw, who will set the final tariff. However, the copy sent to Mr Straw contained hand-written notes on the case apparently from Lord Woolf.

These said: "I note he initially considered fixing the tariff figure at eight years and, on the facts described, that is the figure I would have selected, rather than the nine years on which the judge decided."

A spokesman for the lord chief justice would not confirm that the writing was Lord Woolf's, adding: "He is saying 'No comment', full stop."

Any increase in the tariff beyond the judge's recommendation could well be successfully challenged by Martin under the Human Rights Act, which comes into force in October.

A figure of eight or nine years indicates that the judges regard Martin's murder as less serious than most. A more usual tariff is around 12 years.

A memo by Tony Blair, leaked last week, said ministers' re sponse to the case had made the government seem out of touch with the public. He suggested that a senior judge might look at whether the mandatory life sentence should be retained for all murders.

Mr Blair's comment echoed Mr Justice Owen's report, which talked about public sympathy for Martin, who has had a £60,000 contract placed on his life since the killing.

Martin "was a man without convictions, whose home was broken into, and had it not been for the burglars he would not have committed his crimes," the report said.

"However, much of that sympathy is based on very inadequate accounts of the evidence. I believe the burglars did not know Martin was there until the very last moment. They were given no chance to escape, and Martin was not acting in reasonable self-defence. He fired intending really serious injury and certainly risked the lives of each of the burglars."

Mr Justice Owen concluded: "He is never likely to reoffend, but he deserves punishment."

webTitle: Games watch

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.standfirst: Lara V | Dream Bleem!
fields.trailText:
Lara V
It will begin with Lara's funeral and feature the usual clutch of new costumes, new weapons and new enemies. Lara will appear as a 16 year old as well as in her mature form. The first preview of TR5 is expected to appear in Official PlayStation Magazine next month. Meanwhile, PSM magazine reckons that TR6 will feature Lara but will drop the Tomb Raiding bit in order to explore new situations. Theresa Jenne's unofficial Tomb Raiders website is tracking developments.
fields.body:
Lara V
It will begin with Lara's funeral and feature the usual clutch of new costumes, new weapons and new enemies. Lara will appear as a 16 year old as well as in her mature form. The first preview of TR5 is expected to appear in Official PlayStation Magazine next month. Meanwhile, PSM magazine reckons that TR6 will feature Lara but will drop the Tomb Raiding bit in order to explore new situations. Theresa Jenne's unofficial Tomb Raiders website is tracking developments.

Dream Bleem!
Bleem, best known for its Sony PlayStation emulator for the PC, plans to launch an emulator that will play PlayStation games on a Sega Dreamcast console. Bleem says there will be four $19.99 "bleempaks", each of which will support 100 PlayStation titles. Games will run at 640 by 480 pixels (VGA) instead of the usual 320 by 240 pixels. On its website see www.bleem.com, Bleem concedes that its emulator will play copies of original games: "We can't prevent it since the technology that verifies that a disc is an original PSX title is patented by Sony, and if we used it, we would be in violation of that." However, Bleem says: "It's ridiculous to blame the makers of a program that simply PLAYS recorded media. It would make more sense to go after the devices that make the copies in the first place - the company that created the CD format (Sony), makes the recorders (Sony), and sells the media (you guessed it, Sony)."

Tour de force
Konami, one of Japan's leading games developers, has signed a deal to develop a game based on one of Europe's leading sports events, the Tour de France. It may be out in time for next year's tour, but don't bet on it. Konami also says it plans to publish at least 10 games for the PlayStation 2. The five titles being prepared for the UK hardware launch include the great soccer sim, International Superstar Soccer. Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty will appear next year.

PSone TV
In Japan, Sony has started a TV advertising campaign for the dinky PSone version of the PlayStation. The ads are online in RealPlayer format, so try www.scei.co.jp/news/puki/ram/000717.ram if you have a fast internet connection. For more Sony TV clips, including PS2 ads, see www.scei.co.jp/news/puki/puki_02.html. Jack Schofield

webTitle: 'The first you know of a fire is a loud bell. Then a red light comes on'

fields.headline: 'The first you know of a fire is a loud bell. Then a red light comes on'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The crew of the doomed Concorde were well into their emergency routine when it crashed, according to a former Concorde pilot who helped devise safety procedures for the aircraft.
fields.body:
The crew of the doomed Concorde were well into their emergency routine when it crashed, according to a former Concorde pilot who helped devise safety procedures for the aircraft.

Captain John Cook, 66, joined the Concorde development team in 1974 as a technical adviser representing the Pilots' Association, and went on to fly 6,300 hours in 12 years as a Concorde captain.

He believes that the crew of the plane were aware that there had been a serious engine failure and were taking steps to deal with it.

"You can see from the final picture of the plane that the nose wheel is up - the main landing gear is still down - but the front wheel is up which indicates the pilot was attempting to gain as much speed as possible," he said.

"When you have an engine fire during takeoff that's the first thing you do, try and gain speed not height, so in case the fire spreads to another engine and you're down to two you've still got enough spit to get you off the ground. Pulling the wheels up helps because it reduces drag.

"The first you know of a fire is a loud bell that rings. At the same time a red light comes on on what's called the fire stick. You push a button to shut the bell off because it's very distracting, and then the engineer pulls the fire handle. That shuts down the engine and should, in ordinary circumstances, control the fire.

"After that you would run through a series of checks to make sure that everything was shut down - fuel supply, hydraulics - then have a look to dump fuel and request an emergency landing. Having just taken off you would be too heavy to land with a full fuel load."

Cpt Cook said that he had twice lost an engine while flying Concorde but the problems had been contained.

"In 12 years I never really had anything other than routine flights. I've had to close down an engine because the intakes have gone wrong, but I only had one engine that broke up on me. That wasn't a problem because it contained itself in its own cell.

"The engines are designed so that if there is a fire or an explosion it should be contained in its own cell. You can't have engine fires going into other engines or ripping through the fuselage."

Concorde is a more refined aircraft to fly than subsonic passenger planes said Cpt Cook, but the skills required are the same.

"It's different in its way of flying but it's not difficult. It has very responsive controls. It's very smart, very sharp like a fighter plane as opposed to a normal aircraft. The main thing to get used to is the speed of approach when landing which is 30 knots faster than a 747. Frankly Mach 2, the cruising speed, doesn't come into it."

Cpt Cook said his first reaction on hearing of the accident was "great grief".

"It's a great shame, the worst of nightmares. We never expected this one to go, it's so well built.

"All of us who were involved in developing Concorde feel a very great affinity with the aircraft. We fought to make it the great success it has been."

webTitle: Mandelson to release Docklands bomber

fields.headline: Mandelson to release Docklands bomber
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, used the royal prerogative of mercy yesterday to order the release from the Maze prison tomorrow of the London Docklands bomber, James McArdle.
fields.body:
Unionists were enraged last night as tomorrow's release of 80 convicted terrorists threw up a new controversy after the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, used the royal prerogative to allow the Docklands bomber, James McArdle, to join them.

They were incensed the Queen had to sign the papers to release McArdle, 31, eight months early. Under the early release scheme of the Good Friday agreement he was due to remain in jail until March.

McArdle, from Crossmaglen, south Armagh, would have been the only high profile IRA prisoner left in the Maze after tomorrow's exodus. Only 15 prisoners will remain in a jail which housed 1,700 inmates at the height of the troubles.

McArdle was serving 25 years for conspiracy to murder in connection with the IRA's bombing of Canary Wharf in London in February 1996, ending the IRA's first ceasefire.

McArdle was jailed in Belfast in March 1999 with three other members of the IRA's south Armagh sniper team, thought responsible for the murders of 12 security force members.

McArdle was jailed for 50 years for conspiracy to murder and possession of weapons. Together, the four men received three life sentences and jail terms totalling 640 years.

But, unlike his co-defendants, McArdle was a convicted prisoner when he came to the trial, and, under the release scheme, his time in custody did not count as time on remand. The rules stipulate two years must be served.

They explain why Irish National Liberation Army prisoner Crip McWilliams, who murdered Loyalist Volunteer Force leader Billy Wright in the Maze in December 1997, will remain in prison until October, two years after his conviction. He was already serving a life sentence for murder.

The Inla is considering a legal challenge to secure the release of McWilliams and his two accomplices. They too were already convicted.

Sammy Wilson, a Democratic Unionist assembly member and lord mayor of Belfast, said: "How often have we been told that the agreement was written in stone and that it was impossible to cherry-pick aspects of it? Here we have the secretary of state doing just that, and we must ask why."

Two LVF members among the handful remaining in the Maze are Stephen McClean and Noel McCready, who murdered a Catholic man and his Protestant friend in Poyntzpass, Co Armagh, in March 1998, five weeks before the qualifying date. But they were allegedly involved in an attack on a member of the Ulster Volunteer Force while on pre-release parole last month
