webTitle: Comment: Excessive media coverage of the Concorde exposes our voyeurism

fields.headline: The ghoulish crowds
fields.standfirst:
Excessive media coverage of the Concorde crash tells us little, but exposes our voyeurism

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Excessive media coverage of the Concorde crash tells us little, but exposes our voyeurism.
fields.body:
Concorde's crash drew crowds who came to gawp at the smoking ruins and the scurrying of the emergency services. They were driven by our common instinct to gather round disaster: the instinct which has us shift our eyes off the road as we pass the scene of an accident, and the instinct which has us pricking our ears up in the office to eavesdrop on a good row. There's an appetite for catastrophe and over the last 24 hours, the mass media have sought to satiate it.

The Independent clears its entire front page, and all the papers devoted yards of coverage, relegating other major stories (such as collapse of the Middle East peace talks) to a few paragraphs; the BBC Today programme even flies one of its presenters to the Paris scene.

But the fact is that there is very little to say about an air crash. This was painfully obvious if you persisted through more than a few minutes of the BBC news. It became agonising as you heard reporters desperately trying to spin out what they had, or listened to someone who had seen something (a plume of smoke, a flame) or heard one of the few pundits who suddenly popped up everywhere. The elderly gentleman who had been a test pilot on Concorde 30 years ago was wheeled out of retirement: he had as little to say as the rest of us.

The saturation coverage of Concorde's nemesis is not driven by our desire for knowledge, because there is not much to be had. Tragically, a large number of people have been killed, but there is only a bald figure, 113. The relatives understandably want privacy. As for the plane, everyone wants to know why it crashed, but it will be some time before there's an answer. By then, we may all have lost interest.

No, the extent of the coverage is partly because we have created a global media industry. There are thousands of hours of rolling news to fill. This giant maw is insatiable; it needs stories - the bigger the better - to justify its existence. And the reporters need to justify their personal sense of importance: they breathlessly recount the big story as if it were a moment of huge historical significance - the fall of Berlin or Pearl Harbour. Their job is to inject dramatic immediacy; no one wants them to have a sense of proportion.

The media is supplying what millions of consumers want. This blanket coverage meets many human needs: voyeurism, for a start. We are no different from the crowds of suburban Parisians staring at the fire engines. Voyeurism stimulates powerful emotions: schadenfreude, the desire to be in the know (however awful), the desire for drama to break the routine. And fear. The fear is not assuaged by reading how the plane exploded. On the contrary, it is exercised by being given a clear focus and an imagined scenario (what was it like in Concorde in those last few seconds?). It is a comparable process to people enjoying horror movies or rollercoasters. The fact that the Concorde's disaster is very close to our own experience makes this crash all the more powerful a scenario. Most people have a deep rooted fear of flying (however well they control it), and many of them are preparing to set off for their annual summer holidays in the next couple of weeks.

We like being emotionally stimulated - even when the emotions are unpleasant ones such as fear or hate. We want to know that, like the strings of a musical instrument, we resonate with the appropriate feeling. It makes us feel alive - unlike those who have died - because we feel. Quite literally, our hearts beat faster. We can feel our blood circulating.

The coverage also helps expiate our collective sense of shock. On Tuesday, many people said they instinctively reached for the phone to talk to a friend about the disaster.

The mass media are a conversation writ large. We want to acclimatise ourselves to this new fact: that Concorde, the emblem like no other of the power of technology - has failed us. We need to mull this over, consider it from every angle in the process of coming to terms with it. We need the repetition of information in order to absorb it. We need to be armed with scraps of information for the chat round the office coffee machine.

Yet shock used to trigger not talk, but silence - we use phrases such as "struck dumb". When children are shocked, they fall silent. Silence is traditionally how we mark tragedy - the silent minute at the Cenotaph on Remembrance Day. Stoics placed great virtue on silence as did many generations of westerners inspired by their message of emotional self-control. But not 21st century adults. Shock and tragedy are treated, as every other emotional state, with talking. We go into the equivalent of national counselling sessions for post-traumatic stress syndrome, and the mass media take on the role of both voicing and interpreting our emotions to ourselves.

The danger is that these crude levers to attract our attention in the end exhaust us. We simply cannot meet the emotional demands news makes of us. We don't want to feel the fear, the pain, the despair: it's a form of emotional over-stimulation so we switch over, and bin the paper.

Shock and tragedy are treated, as every other emotional state, with talking. We go into the equivalent of national counselling sessions for post-traumatic stress syndrome, and the mass media take on the role of both voicing and interpreting our emotions to ourselves. The danger is that these crude levers to attract our attention in the end exhaust us. We simply cannot meet the emotional demands news makes of us. We don't want to feel the fear, the pain, the despair: it's a form of emotional over-stimulation so we switch over, and bin the paper. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

webTitle: Napster

fields.headline: Napster
fields.standfirst: A US judge has ordered that Napster's internet music clearing house be shut down pending trial for copyright breaches. Gwyn Topham explains
fields.trailText: A US judge has ordered that Napster's internet music clearing house be shut down pending trial for copyright breaches. Gwyn Topham explains
fields.body:
What is Napster?
Napster allows computer users to find and download music for free over the net.

How does it work?
Computer users can record CDs as high-quality MP3 files to listen to on their computer or on MP3 players. At napster.com you can download software that allows you to make a library of your music files and connect your own personal collection to the outside world. Users can browse through other people's collections and copy tunes that they like, or simply search for a track that they want. Effectively, Napster has created a directory of the best MP3s on the net.

Do many people use it?
Made freely available in January this year, by March five million people had downloaded the software. Napster claims its user base grows between 5% and 25% daily: 70 million people were expected to be using Napster by the end of this year. By February, 60% of available bandwidth at the university of Indiana was taken by students leaving Napster on all the time. Several US campuses have now blocked the service. Earlier today it was estimated 1,400 songs were being downloaded each minute via Napster's software.

Why is it controversial?
Napster embodies the sharing, community-based ethos of the internet pioneers or operates theft on a massive scale, depending on your point of view. The music industry claims most of the songs traded are pirated, and that song-swapping via Napster has cost them more than $300m (£200m) in lost sales.

How did the court case come about?
The Recording Industry Association of America sued Napster for 'contributory copyright infringement' last December, accusing it of encouraging an unrestrained, illegal, online bazaar. Rock group Metallica also sued, claiming that more than 300,000 Napster users had traded its songs online. Napster reacted by blocking more than 30,000 people from its service, but new users carried on swapping Metallica's music.

What is happening now?
A judge has granted a preliminary injunction ordering that Napster's service be suspended from midnight on Friday, July 28, pending the trial.

What is Napster's case?
Napster say that trying to eliminate trading in copyrighted music would inevitably result in blocking legally traded songs as well; that personal copying of music is protected by federal law; and that its service should be considered a non-infringing use. They point to a precedent in the Sony Betamax case, when the film industry tried unsuccessfully to block the production of VCRs, claiming they would be used primarily to make illegal copies of copyrighted movies. Napster argues it doesn't actually hold any files, it just allows people to trace files for download and is essentially powerless to stop users trading copyrighted material.

Does it affect record sales?
Some research has suggested Napster may actually promote interest in buying music. A study of more than 2,200 online music fans by Jupiter Communications found users of music-sharing programs to be 45% more likely buy more music than other fans.

Will the Napster case end online swapping of copyright material?
The music industry certainly hopes so. But other file-sharing sites, such as Gnutella, exist and their technical status makes them a more difficult legal target. Meanwhile, the film and music industries are launching another action against Scour.com, who help users search the net and exchange not only MP3s but copyrighted films and images too.

webTitle: Comment: Labour must dictate the terms of battle - and soon

fields.headline: Labour must dictate the terms of battle - and soon
fields.standfirst:
The Tories are at their weakest. The government should make use of that

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Tories are at their weakest. The government should make use of that.
fields.body:
The defining vice of New Labour, as the political season closes, is not arrogance but its opposite. The government is often accused, here among other places, of being overmighty. It makes plenty of decisions without attention to what other people think. But what Labour knows it deeply lacks is historic self-confidence.

It still believes, somewhere in its head, that Tories are born to rule, or are at any rate unable to rid themselves of that fixation. That's a strange misperception, but it's matched on the other side. Together these parties have produced in the past two months the distorted images of reality the country is left with now. Both leave voters - at any rate, those voters who are interested in such matters - groping for bearings.

The panic at the heart of government could not be missed by any reader of the recently leaked Blair-Gould memos. Though these dated from the spring, they remain an extraordinary replication of a state of mind. The government seems fearful for its very acceptance as leader by right.

Top Labour people are steeped in the belief that the Tories are fundamentally stronger, that they have all the best press, that William Hague inherits through his ancestral juices a mentality that doesn't just oppose but abominates Labour ever being in power. The cry of the underdog whinges out of Labour's psychic hinterland.

From this dismal platform, the party sees enemies all around. It is not confident of beating them. Though it despises everything Hague stands for, it can't shake off the suspicion that the Tories remain strong. To Tony Blair, winning a second full term is a prize of almost unimaginable richness.

Clement Attlee ran out of steam after a single term, Harold Wilson only got going in his second. Each could tack barely a year on to their one full span. Labour history is full of aborted progress. Plenty of Labour people, right and left, still talk as though this is written in the stars.

Such is the source of today's paranoid anxieties. It's as if the present majority of 179 did not exist, by comparison with the future majority that may never be. Labour really does believe that the tricks of the Tory leader, the unscrupulousness of his methods, and the insidious support of newspapers that long since abandoned their transient backing for Mr Blair, add up to an enemy that Labour's real friends, including this newspaper, cruelly underestimate.

For their part, the Tories peddle an equal and opposite misperception. They too see their enemy as insufferably strong - but this time in a way they can exploit rather than submit to. They've found a mantra to express it. Mr Blair, they say 10 times a day, is out of touch. Every time he fails, he proves it.

It's a very useful mantra, which has been seized on, as it happens, by the rightwing opponents of several social democratic governments in Europe. Not only can every bad statistic about hospitals, schools and crime, earnestly promised for reform by these parties of the left, be laid at the door of absent touch. The defect implies a more general want of character, a certain haughty grandeur on the part of Mr Blair. A rabid press daily gives this charge some traction.

It has little truth. The Blair government is no more out of touch than any other. It does suffer from hauteur, specifically in its attitude to parliament. It makes mistakes, but out-of-touchness is seldom the reason. Personally, I wish it dared to be more out of touch with some of the short-term populist prejudices it takes such care to check out.

But the charge has become a substitute for opposition policy-making. In a sense, it's the natural follow-on for a politics based, in the modern way, less on conviction than on the claim to be doing what the people want. In that climate, not being in touch can be made to sound more lethal than not being true to your beliefs. Thrashing round to disprove it, Labour has begun to look like a destabilised government.

Stability, however, is now returning. The political summer ends better than it began. Mr Blair's declaration that he will see out a second term if he wins - in effect, that he will fight a third election - clears the air of Brownite turbulence. The suspicion that Gordon Brown might be preparing to take over excited his phony friends in the Sun and Mail, with their paeans to his superior gravitas, his professional creativity and his Euro-scepticism.

We rediscover, if we ever forgot, that Mr Blair is in politics for serious reasons, and has the taste for struggle in pursuit of them. Driven by such passion for a second term, he would hardly be likely to surrender it half way through. His statement banishes a source of insidious rumour-mongering: one small step away from hysteria.

Another was taken by Robin Cook and Peter Mandelson, each explicitly reaffirming in recent days support for the Brown position on the euro. This doesn't represent a climb-down. We do not forget where they stand. As the euro-zone economies accelerate, and one set of arguments against the single currency disappears into oblivion, the Cook-Mandelson analysis gains in strength. But they do not now need to repeat it. Mr Blair seems to have successfully reminded them that there's nothing to be gained from whetting the appetite of the other side for cabinet splits that do not fundamentally exist.

These are the beginnings of realism. The next venture into it, I imagine, will be a greater national awakening to what the Conservative party these days amounts to. The neurotic summer has allowed this to become obscured. Far from being superhumanly powerful, the Tories are at their lowest point. They have never, in my memory, been less interested in constructive politics, or more dependent on gimcrack populism unencumbered by even the smallest offering of remedies for the perceived discontents. Their response to Labour's public spending programme for the next three years would have insulted the intelligence of every Tory chancellor since Mrs Thatcher came to power.

Their whole appeal, moreover, remains targeted on their most reliable supporters - but with an exception. Mr Hague, having begun by seeming to pitch for voters in the un-Thatcherite centre, soon directed himself back towards the hard right to solidify his personal position. The best measure of his continuing lack of confidence is his failure to break out from that defensive strategy. Yet, while cultivating his heartland, he has lost touch with his business support, through his bull-headed rejection of the euro. Has a party of the right, anywhere in the world, so spectacularly ceased to be the party of big business - at the same time neglecting to fill the gap with any alternative constituency?

In the autumn, this should become more apparent. The contest between the heavyweight and the lightweight ought to be seen for what it is. But that requires Labour to dictate the terms of battle, with all the specific gravity at its command. It has plenty available. If it cannot pulverise the demons of history now, it never will.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Invensys confirmed yesterday it would take over the troubled Dutch software firm Baan for 762m (£476m) and shed 1,000 jobs at both firms.
fields.body:
Invensys will buy Baan

Invensys confirmed yesterday it would take over the troubled Dutch software firm Baan for €762m (£476m) and shed 1,000 jobs at both firms.

The British automation conglomerate said it would go ahead with the acquisition at €2.85 a share, even though it managed to purchase only 75% of Baan equity. Nevertheless, Invensys extended its deadline for shareholders to sell to August 1 in an attempt to come closer to its 95% target.

Invensys assumes all of Baan's assets and liabilities as part of the deal.

Debut values RTL at £16.5bn

RTL, the pan-European television group, joined the London stock market yesterday with a valuation of £16.5bn and a promise to use its shares to pursue further acquisitions. But it made a muted debut with the shares ending at €170, from €190 earlier.

RTL is the combination of the television assets of Pearson with those of Germany's Bertelsmann and Belgium's Audiofina. It has 22 television channels, including a majority stake in Channel 5, and 18 radio stations.

ABN Amro offered an "undervalued" recommendation on the stock. Its market value places it well above the three ITV companies, the largest of which is Granada Media, valued at £8.8bn.

RTL has been named as a possible bidder for Lord Hollick's United News & Media but is thought to be most interested in the company's 35% holding in Channel 5.

Microsoft asks for appeal move

Microsoft has asked the US supreme court not to grant the justice department's request for an immediate transfer of the anti-trust case to the high court.

Instead, Microsoft requested that an appeals court first hear the company's appeal.

Microsoft said the antitrust case would be an "extraordinary burden on the supreme court", given the "morass of procedural and substantive issues that can be resolved only through a painstaking review of a lengthy and technologically complex trial record".

Microsoft asked that the court of appeals for the District of Columbia hear the case. In 1998, Microsoft won a victory in that court.

Billiton gains CVRD stake

The metals and mining conglomerate Billiton said yesterday it had acquired a minority stake in Brazil's Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world's largest iron ore producer.

Billiton, which has been seeking a stake in CVRD for some time, agreed to acquire a 67% holding in Sweet River Investments for $327.3m. Sweet River holds just under 12% of Valepar, CVRD's controlling shareholder. This gives the former South African mining operator a 2.1% stake in the Brazilian company. Billiton paid the equivalent of $40 each for its CVRD shares which were trading at around $26 in Sao Paulo on Tuesday.

webTitle: Judge in Lloyds TSB case sells embarrassing shares

fields.headline: Judge in Lloyds TSB case sells embarrassing shares
fields.trailText: A nine-year-old dispute between Lloyds TSB and a couple who lost their business came close to farcical collapse in the high court yesterday after a discovery by the judge hearing the case that he was a Lloyds shareholder.
fields.body:
A nine-year-old dispute between Lloyds TSB and a couple who lost their business came close to farcical collapse in the high court yesterday after a discovery by the judge hearing the case that he was a Lloyds shareholder.

Mr Justice Wright, who is hearing allegations of fraud by the bank, apologised to the court and said that after consultations with the Lord Chief Justice he had immediately disposed of the shares.

He told the court on Tuesday he had "divested myself of any involvement with Lloyds TSB that could possibly involve even the most theoretical conflict of interest".

However, the couple who have brought the case, Eddy and Brenda Weatherill, were unhappy about his decision to continue hearing it. Yesterday they went to the Court of Appeal to ask for the judge to be taken off the case and for the matter to be reheard, but their application was refused.

The case will continue today, when it is due to finish, and Mr Justice Wright is expected to give his judgment in a few weeks. The hearing is the culmination of a nine-year dispute involving the Weatherills, of Somersham, near St Ives, Cambridgeshire, and the high-street bank.

The couple have accused the bank of fraud and are claiming damages, compensation and costs of more than £1m. The bank denies the allegations.

The case began on July 3 and had reached closing submissions this week when on Tuesday morning the judge told the court that after arriving home on Friday he received a report from his stockbroker. "I discovered to my intense embarrassment that until yesterday [Monday] I was the holder of a thankfully extremely small shareholding in Lloyds TSB," he said.

"... I am very sorry. It is my own fault for not checking before the case started but I must confess it never even occurred to me that that might be the situation and I do apologise."

The judge asked Mr Weatherill to accept his assurance that, "having been wholly unaware of it until now, it has never affected my mind in the slightest so far as the case itself is concerned".

Mr Weatherill yesterday, on legal advice, went before the Court of Appeal with an application to discharge the judge from further consideration of the matter on the grounds that holding the shares during the hearing amounted to a conflict of interest, but this was refused.

The couple have told the court that their business collapsed and they face losing their home after their Lloyds bank manager encouraged them to remortgage their house to raise capital for their interiors company.

Last legal curbs on homosexuals to go as paedophiles face harsher punishments, but some changes will disappoint women's groups

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Last legal curbs on homosexuals to go as paedophiles face harsher punishments, but some changes will disappoint women's groups
fields.byline: Alan Travis, home affairs editor and Clare Dyer, legal correspondent
fields.body:
The proposal to repeal laws criminalising gay sex by consenting adults in private rests on the belief that the law's view of homosexuality as "unnatural" legitimises prejudice and contributes to homophobia.

"The criminal law should not treat people differently on the basis of their sexual orientation. It should offer protection from all non-consensual sexual activity. Consensual sexual activity between adults in private that causes no harm should not be criminal," concludes the official review chaired by a Home Office civil servant, Betty Moxon.

The review report published yesterday, Setting the Boundaries, recommended sweeping away the offences of gross indecency, buggery and soliciting by men which is sometimes called "cottaging" or "cruising". At present the offence of gross indecency makes it illegal for homosexual acts to take place where there are more than two people taking part or are present and in a public lavatory.

Ministers believe it is this recommendation which will prove politically the most difficult, as it will legalise group gay sex in private as it is a victimless crime. It will remain an offence to engage in gay sex in a public toilet, but instances will be prosecuted under a general public order offence involving inappropriate sexual behaviour in public rather than a specific anti-gay crime.

The review said the offence of buggery was fundamentally flawed, as it equated anal intercourse with bestiality and was an unpleasant and offensive term. Separate provision is to be made for the protection of children and animals.

It also said that the law that had been used to prosecute thousands of men for cottaging or cruising should be scrapped. The most commonly used offences against men who seek sexual partners in or around toilets are importuning and gross indecency. The report said that similar behaviour, if between men and women, would be seen as no more than "chatting up" and such approaches to women were not criminal. Instead it proposed if cottaging happened on such a scale to cause distress to local residents, it should be dealt with under laws for street prostitution.

The report made clear, for example, that two men or two women should be able to hold hands or kiss in public.

The review proposed a much tougher line on "flashers" and "peeping toms". The offence of indecent exposure should be reformed, it said, to one where a man exposes himself knowing he might cause alarm or distress, and the penalties be doubled to six months for a first offence. A new offence of voyeurism would criminalise those who installed cameras in public changing areas, and protect anybody spied on inside a building who had an expectation of privacy.

Alan Travis

Child abuse and rape

Abuse or exploitation of children and other vulnerable people is at the heart of a review of the gamut of sex offences unveiled by ministers. But the independent review's recommendations for the crime of rape will disappoint women's groups who wanted changes to increase the 9% conviction rate for reported cases.

There are to be new offences covering the commercial sexual exploitation of children up to 18, including using child prostitutes or making child pornography. The maximum would be life imprisonment where the child was under 13, and 10 years for children between 13 and 18; using a prostitute aged 16 to 18 would carry a five year sentence. Adults using the internet to incite children to have sex would also be covered.

A new offence of trafficking, transporting someonefor the purpose of selling sexual services, would attract a maximum of 14 years.

Abusers could face a new charge of persistent sexual abuse of a child, allowing courts to assume a course of conduct from a small number of specimen charges, and carrying a maximum of 14 years in prison to reflect the long-term nature of the abuse.

The ancient crime of incest would be replaced by an offence of familial sexual abuse, reflecting "the looser structure of modern families". Adoptive parents will be treated the same as natural parents, and sex between adoptive siblings will be illegal until age 18.

Step-parents and foster parents will also be covered by the new offence, and if the relationship ends the ban will stay until the child is 18. Any per son living in the household who holds a position of trust or authority over the child will also be banned from sex with a child under 18.

The review's steering group, made up of civil servants, lawyers and victims' groups, was "deeply saddened" by what they heard about abuse of people with disabilities. The chairman, Betty Moxon, said the law at present was designed to stop vulnerable people having sex; a more modern law would strike a balance allowing those capable of consenting to have a private life, while protecting vulnerable people from exploitative sex.

The group recommended the offence of "sexual intercourse with a defective", with a maximum of two years, be replaced by "sexual activity with a person with severe mental incapacity", punishable by life imprisonment.

The proposals on rape will not affect the burden of proof or the presumption of inno cence. It would still be for the prosecution to prove that the woman did not consent to sex, if the defendant said she did.

The review rejected two proposals strongly urged on them: creation of a separate, lesser offence of date rape to improve conviction statistics; and, more controversially, preventing an acquittal if the jury accepted a man honestly believed, however unreasonably, the woman had consented.

Women's groups and some academics wanted the man to have to prove his belief was reasonable. The review team recommended that, as in Canada, a man should not be able to rely on an "honest but mistaken" belief of consent if he was reckless, drunk or did not take all reasonable steps to make sure she freely agreed.

The offence of rape will change to include oral penetration as well as vaginal and anal penetration.

Clare Dyer

Main points

 Scrap offences of buggery, gross indecency and soliciting by men

 New public order offence of sexual behaviour in a public place

 New offence of voyeurism

 New crime of persistent child abuse

 Incest replaced by sex abuse in the family to cover adoptive and step-parents

 Definition of rape extended to forced oral sex

 New crime: sexual touching

 Seven years' jail instead of two for many offences

webTitle: No flowers, by request, as Unigate ditches its old name

fields.headline: No flowers, by request, as Unigate ditches its old name
fields.trailText: Unigate, the food group which recently sold its dairy operations to Dairy Crest, is changing its name to Uniq.
fields.body:
Unigate, the food group which recently sold its dairy operations to Dairy Crest, is changing its name to Uniq.

The new name, which was sneaked out in a shareholders' circular last month, was approved at a low-key shareholders' meeting yesterday.

Finance director John Worby explained that it retained part of the group's orig inal name, while adding a "q" for "quality".

The rebranding is part of the group's reinvention as a focused manufacturer of convenience foods. Chairman Ian Martin yesterday announced that in a further attempt to slim down, the group was planning a £400m demerger of its Wincanton logistics arm.

Mr Worby said Uniq was agreed upon without outside advice, at a boardroom brain storming session: "The Unigate name is synonymous with milk. Dairy Crest has the right to use it, so it was clearly appropriate to change our corporate name."

Uniq is already the name of one of the group's smaller food-manufacturing subsidiaries. The choice attracted acidic comment from some industry observers - analyst John Parker of Deutsche Bank said: "Well, it really is inspira tional isn't it? I find it very, very moving."

Mr Worby rejected criticism that the new name was conservative, pointing out that more radical changes by other companies had often been unsuccessful. "Beauty is in the eye of the beholder," he said. "I don't recall the world being ecstatic at the creation of Diageo."

Unigate's origins go back to the second world war, when a group of west country milk suppliers formed Wiltshire United Dairies, to send milk to London during the blitz. The company merged with a rival, Cow & Gate, in 1959 to form Unigate.

The group now comprises Wincanton logistics, a pig-trading business called Malton and a convenience foods operation making frozen foods, sandwiches, pizzas and spreads.

Wincanton, which made profits of £34.9m last year, dis tributes food to supermarket chains and designs automated warehouses for industrial corporations. Mr Worby said Wincanton had grown substantially in recent years, and the time had come to spin it off.

However, some analysts were unimpressed. One said: "Instead of one medium-sized company, they're creating two small-cap companies. That tends to mean a diminution of shareholder value."

webTitle: Prodi hacks away EU's dead wood

fields.headline: Prodi hacks away EU's dead wood
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Six hundred Eurocrats are being offered early retirement in an overhaul of the European Union's executive arm, and a much-maligned private food shop where European commission officials can buy their favourite national delicacies is to be shut.
fields.body:
Six hundred Eurocrats are being offered early retirement in an overhaul of the European Union's executive arm, and a much-maligned private food shop where European commission officials can buy their favourite national delicacies is to be shut.

Romano Prodi, the president of the commission, and Neil Kinnock, his British deputy, announced yesterday that long-overdue internal reforms would help the 18,000-strong commission to close the widening gap between tasks and resources.

Having concluded that 1,250 jobs needed to be filled, the commissioners decided to ask for 375 new recruits and make up the shortfall by a combination of efficiency gains and redeployment of staff. The measures include non-compulsory early retirements.

Personnel changes are a key element of the reform process launched last year after the resignation of Jacques Santer's discredited commission following allegations of mismanagement, fraud, sleaze and cronyism at the heart of the EU.

"The commission has made major efforts to modernise and improve internal procedures," Mr Prodi said. "We are going to have to squeeze a lot out of our staff."

Personnel are to be redeployed to understaffed areas where the role of Brussels has expanded in recent years.

Some 300 will go to external relations, where Britain's second EU commissioner, Chris Patten, has pledged to improve delivery of the community's £5.7bn aid programme, the world's largest.

Other officials are being sent to work on food safety, the environment and new areas of justice and home affairs, such as fighting crime.

More financial managers, lawyers, personnel managers and IT experts are also needed.

Mr Kinnock said that he could no longer justify the existence of the shop, the Economat, which was opened in the 1960s to allow homesick Italian functionaries to buy olive oil, and Britons their marmalade and breakfast tea.

Although it is neither subsidised nor secret, the shop featured regularly in stories with an anti-EU agenda, often combined with details of the tax-free perks and allowances which have made Eurocrats a byword for feather-bedding.

"I couldn't justify the continued maintenance of shopkeeping as one of the roles of the European Commission," Mr Kinnock said.

The unions are expected to react badly to the staffing reforms. They claimed earlier this week that they had not been adequately consulted.

Mr Kinnock, the former Labour party leader and one of the few survivors of the Santer commission, pledged earlier this year to build the "best multinational administration in the world". But he acknowledged last week that the process was moving slowly.

Most of the 15 EU member states want to see changes to ensure efficiency, accountability, transparency and public faith restored in the scandal-battered commission.

Recent appointments have been made on merit rather than according to informal national quotas, as in the past, though the French are annoyed that several key jobs have been given to talented British candidates.

One British official, Jonathan Faull, was confirmed yesterday as the commission's chief spokesman after the removal of an Italian ex-journalist and confidant of Mr Prodi who was felt to be ineffective.

webTitle: Muckraker who feeds off bins of the famous

fields.headline: Muckraker who feeds off bins of the famous
fields.standfirst:
Rummaging through rubbish of prominent people is all in a night's work for man linked to No 10 leaks
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Rummaging through rubbish of prominent people is all in a night's work for man linked to No 10 leaks
fields.body:
Benji the Binman may not yet have fulfilled his wish to be famous but his brush with Downing Street has certainly raised his profile.

Benjamin Pell, a professional muckraker who makes a decent living going through rubbish, specialises in stealing waste.

Dressed in overalls and a fluorescent jacket, he drives around London emptying bins and black plastic bags into the back of his van. Addresses of prominent people and firms are targeted and it is collected ritually according to precise timings, mainly at night.

To avoid detection after a series of scrapes with the law, Pell even recycles old rubbish so householders and office staff are not left wondering where it all went.

He believes he is a social necessity, not a social menace. Nor does he accept he is breaking the law; the culprits are individuals such as Labour pollster Philip Gould and firms carelessly disposing of confidential documents.

Pell, 36, has been diagnosed as suffering from a very severe form of obsessive-compulsive disorder. As well as filling the family home with papers, his daily routine involves repeated checks of doors, locks, lights and other possessions.

The illness is thought to have started in his early teens after an older brother died in a car crash. Around the age of 14 he became known as the "bag boy", carrying around half a dozen bags stuffed with papers and books.

He started a law course at University College, London, but unexpectedly failed his law exams in 1986. Ashamed, Pell did not tell his parents and for eight months pretended he was a lawyer until they found out.

After a further ill-fated stab at joining the legal profession, he started work for a cleaning company and then started his own cleaning firm.

That set him off down the road that led him to being named as the source of the leaked Downing Street memos that rocked the government.

His contempt for the the lawyers who refused to embrace him as one of their own and growing interest in rubbish saw him raiding the bins of solicitors and barristers. He took the waste home to sift through the dregs of everyday life in search of notes, letters, credit card details and bank statements of the rich and famous.

Pell initially dealt directly with newspapers but, after feeling he had been ripped off, struck up a relationship with publicist Max Clifford who could use his formidable contacts to supply the documents and guarantee payment.

"It's not about money for Benji," said Mr Clifford yesterday. "It's about the thrill. In the past, I've had large cheques from News International for Benji and he's left them lying around the office for months."

A News International invoice shows Pell was paid £3,375 at the end of April last year for stories on Jonathan Aitken, James Hewitt and allegations of ballot-rigging in Hackney, east London.

Another invoice, from Mirror Group Newspapers, detailed £1,435 paid during July last year ranging from £15 for a tale about TV presenter Clive Anderson to £400 for a story about ex-Spice Girl Geri Halliwell.

He accepts commissions, regularly visiting addresses that newspapers and others such as private investigators want targeted. Mr Gould and Lord Levy, the millionaire Labour fund raiser who saw his low tax bill splashed across the Sunday Times last month, were on a list handed to him earlier this year by a non-News International contact.

Security sources yesterday said MI5 had even "warned off" certain journalists and editors after Pell was accused of taking the waste of some of their own.

Pell is well known to the police and was fined £20 in London last November on five counts of "stealing documentary waste".

The court was told he had been seen loading rubbish into his van outside a firm of Harley Street solicitors that represented Jonathan Aitken and James Hewitt.

When he was searched in Marylebone police station officers discovered a £2,500 cheque from News International. A search of his home uncovered at least 200,000 documents in his garden shed.

Earlier this year, Pell was alleged to be involved in a £10,000 deal to supply Mohamed Al Fayed with papers suggesting the questions he might face in his libel battle with former Tory minister Neil Hamilton.

Readers of virtually every national newspaper will at some point have read a scoop inspired or informed by his rumagings.

From the Sun and the Mirror via the Express, Daily Mail, Mail on Sunday, the Times, Independent, Guardian (though this paper has never bought documents from Pell), Sunday Times and Sunday Telegraph - to name but a few - his handiwork has appeared in print.

Benji the Binman may yet achieve that fame he craves.

webTitle: Runaway boy speaks of life with cult

fields.headline: Runaway boy speaks of life with cult
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The official solicitor yesterday renewed his call for a runaway teenager to contact him after he spoke on BBC radio about the religious cult he has joined.
fields.body:
The official solicitor yesterday renewed his call for a runaway teenager to contact him after he spoke on BBC radio about the religious cult he has joined.

Bobby Kelly, 16, who ran away from his home in Romford, Essex, a month ago and has been made a ward of court, insisted that he was not being held against his will but admitted being homesick and missing his relatives.

The six-minute interview was broadcast on the Today programme, 10 days after it was recorded, after a high court judge lifted an injunction against it, taken out by Bobby's family.

Bobby said making him a ward of court to prevent the cult, the Jesus Christians, from taking him abroad was an overreaction. Sounding confused and admitting that a cult member had accompanied him to a public telephone box from which he called the BBC, Bobby said he had joined the Jesus Christians because "they got right down to the nitty-gritty of the Bible ... and they don't miss anything out".

He said: "If the [ward of court] decision gets scrapped then obviously I'm going to stay with these people, although obviously I will see my nan - like see her a few times throughout the year to reassure her ... That means I can't live my life for God then, doesn't it, if I live with my nan.

"They [the cult] are normal, exactly like everyone else, except that they believe in Jesus and try to commit their life to his teachings. They don't burn babies and eat them or anything nasty like that."

Asked if he missed his friends and relatives, he replied: "Yeah, I'm very homesick actually. I miss my mum and my nan and my sister and other friends quite a lot actually, but it basically says in the Bible that I have to give everything up to work for God."

webTitle: Judge declares end to 11-year search for Hillsborough blame

fields.headline: Judge declares end to 11-year search for Hillsborough blame
fields.trailText: There will be no retrial of the senior police officer who was in charge of crowd control on the day of the Hillsborough football disaster, a judge has ruled.
fields.body:
There will be no retrial of the senior police officer who was in charge of crowd control on the day of the Hillsborough football disaster, a judge has ruled.

For the families of the 96 Liverpool fans who died, the ruling represents the end of an 11-year campaign for what they saw as justice.

Earlier this week, a jury at Leeds crown court was unable to agree a verdict on former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, who was accused of two specimen charges of manslaughter, to which he pleaded not guilty. The trial judge, Mr Justice Hooper, was asked by solicitors representing the families whether a second trial could take place. Yesterday he ordered a stay on proceedings against Mr Duckenfield. He will outline the reasons for his decision tomorrow.

The Hillsborough Family Support Group, which had brought the private prosecution against the officer, and another officer who was earlier acquitted, announced that it would take no further legal action. Each day for six weeks the group's members had packed the public gallery at court number five, and had waited while the jury deliberated for more than 24 hours over five days in Mr Duckenfield's case. All wanted verdicts that would suggest that someone was to blame for the deaths. They did not get them.

Shortly before lunch on Monday, the jury sent a note to the judge saying they were unable to reach a verdict against Mr Duckenfield.

He had denied charges concerning two fans, John Anderson, 62, and James Aspinall, 18, crushed to death on the terraces at Sheffield Wednesday's ground during Liverpool's FA cup semi-final against Nottingham Forest in April 1989.

Former superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, who was Mr Duckenfield's deputy, was cleared of the same charges last Friday. Several families wept as they left court.

Yesterday Alun Jones QC, representing the families, told Mr Justice Hooper that he was seeking a retrial against Mr Duckenfield. William Clegg QC, counsel for Mr Duckenfield, argued that a new trial would put unfair pressure on the officer and his family.

During the trial, the families' counsel had claimed the two officers were responsible for the fans' deaths, having ordered the opening of an exit gate to relieve the crush outside the turnstiles without taking steps to block off a tunnel leading to the overcrowded Leppings Lane terraces.

It emerged that Mr Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, in Dorset, did not give evidence because he was suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. As he left the court yesterday, several people shouted abuse. His solicitor, Simon Eastwood, said: "As a husband and father he has every sympathy with the victims' families."

Inevitably, the families were disappointed. Trevor Hicks, chairman of the support group, said: "The conduct of the core of the trial, we felt, was satisfactory. But what we objected strongly to was the summing-up and the directions from the judge in the last few days."

Margaret Aspinall, whose son was named in the charges, said she was angry and upset: "The police can't always be exonerated. Somebody has to be accountable."

The judge ordered that the majority of the prosecution and defence costs, estimated at £4m, should be paid from public funds.

The outcome was welcomed by Peter Gammon, president of the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales, since it had been "a travesty" for two former senior officers to have been in the dock for a decision they had taken so many years ago.

"The decision to open the gate was taken because lives were endangered outside the ground," he said. "They could never have predicted that death would result."

webTitle: Scientists create greedy mouse that stays thin

fields.headline: Scientists create greedy mouse that stays thin
fields.trailText: Scientists have fitted mice with a human gene that allows them to eat gargantuan meals yet remain thin, and say that an "eat fat, stay thin" pill for people could be the outcome.
fields.body:
Scientists have fitted mice with a human gene that allows them to eat gargantuan meals yet remain thin, and say that an "eat fat, stay thin" pill for people could be the outcome.

Researchers at the pharmaceutical company SmithKline Beecham, led by John Clapham, together with scientists in Cambridge, created the greedy skinny mouse with a human gene that secretes excess amounts of a protein, UCP-3, in its muscles.

The effect was dramatic. The mice ate up to 54% more than ordinary mice in the experiments, yet the proportion of fat in their bodies was reduced by up to 57%.

In the journal Nature today, the researchers say that if the secretion of UCP-3 in humans, which occurs naturally, could be stepped up it would be a "promising approach" to the treatment of obesity.

"If this gene is overexpressed you get the ideal anti-obesity phenotype," said Martin Brand, of the MRC-Dunn human nutrition unit in Cambridge. "Slim mice that eat as much as they like without getting fat."

He said an effective diet pill developed in the US in the 1930s, dinitophenell, which caused tens of thousands of people to shed kilos before it was withdrawn because of side effects, had worked on a similar principle. Unlike UCP-3, however, that drug had to suffuse throughout the body before reaching its target. UCP-3 was active only in muscle.

A successful anti-obesity pill would set a river of money flowing to the company that patented it. In the US 23% of adults are clinically obese and 55% are overweight; in Britain one in five women and one in six men are obese, twice as many as a decade ago.

A report from a Washington think tank this year said the US health care system spent £60bn a year on the consequences of obesity, and a further £20bn was spent on diet drugs. Each year more than 400,000 Americans have fat moved through liposuction.

Yet there would be strong ethical concerns among regulators if a drug were developed that had the same effect in humans as the UCP-3 gene in mice.

The transgenic mice are not only skinny but hyperphagic: stimulated to eat much more than usual. UCP-3 makes the body less efficient: food turns to heat instead of energy or fat.

Dr Brand admitted that obe sity could be treated by getting people to eat less, but said this ignored the compulsive eating patterns of humankind.

There are powerful nerve circuits in place to encourage eating; it's as bad as opium addiction," he said. "It makes people miserable if they don't get enough food ... saying obese people should eat less is a bit like saying to an opium addict: 'It's just availability and lack of willpower'."

Matthew Grainger, of Oxfam, said: "It's obscene to think that valuable research and development money could be spent on a drug that will enable us all to look like Posh Spice."

webTitle: Keep talking, Jordan urges

fields.headline: Keep talking, Jordan urges
fields.standfirst:
Little credit in Arab world for Israeli leader
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Arab commentators agreed, almost universally, yesterday that Israel was to blame for the collapse of the summit between Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister.
fields.body:
Arab commentators agreed, almost universally, yesterday that Israel was to blame for the collapse of the summit between Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister.

"Israel, driven by its notion that muscle power will always succeed, eclipsed an opportunity to ensure peace for the generations to come," the United Arab Emirates newspaper Gulf Today said in an editorial. It urged the Palestinians to go ahead and de clare independent statehood unilaterally.

Jerusalem - the main stumbling block at Camp David - is seen as a pan-Arab and Islamic issue, in large part because of the holy sites in the Old City. Though Israel moved further during the summit than ever before, its proposals still fell far short of Arab, as well as Palestinian, demands.

After stopping in Egypt to brief some of its leaders yesterday, Mr Arafat is expected to tour other Arab states to try - as he has been doing for much of his life - to build a united approach to any future negotiations.

The Egyptian foreign minister, Amr Moussa, said that Camp David was not the last chance for peace but he stressed the importance of Jerusalem.

His Jordanian counterpart, Abdullah al-Khatib, voiced hopes that the peace process would continue: "It is clear that a number of concepts between the two sides were developed and that the gap that divides them on a number of issues has narrowed."

An editorial in the Jordan Times said the failure of Camp David was not surprising: "Given that Israel has, over the near decade of peacemaking, been unable to sway itself from the false premise on which it bases its claim for the Holy City, we could expect little more. The best we could hope for was an honourable Arab stand. And this was achieved."

Syria - which, unlike Egypt and Jordan, has not made a separate peace with Israel - urged the United States to adopt a more even-handed role. The official daily, al-Ba'ath, warned that the alternative to a just and comprehensive peace was a Palestinian uprising, "language that Barak might understand".

The Saudi newspaper al- Jazeerah also suggested there could be renewed violence after the militant Islamic group Hamas urged Mr Arafat to return to the armed struggle. "This throws the future of peace in the Middle East to the winds and subjects the whole region to renewed violence," the paper said.

Ali Mustafa, who last month took over from George Habash as leader of the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, also foresaw some trouble ahead. "I think a flare-up is the most likely possibility as a result of the failure of the talks," he said.

webTitle: Eads tries to persuade investors it is one big, happy family

fields.headline: Eads tries to persuade investors it is one big, happy family
fields.trailText: "This is probably the most incestuous industry in the whole world," said Jean-Louis Gergorin. The head of strategy at the European Aeronautic Defence and Space company (Eads), was referring to the myriad alliances and cross-holdings among the biggest aerospace and defence contractors.
fields.body:
"This is probably the most incestuous industry in the whole world," said Jean-Louis Gergorin.

The head of strategy at the European Aeronautic Defence and Space company (Eads), was referring to the myriad alliances and cross-holdings among the biggest aerospace and defence contractors. His remark raised a laugh at a weekend seminar in Keble College, Oxford, but many serious analysts believe the incestuous nature of Eads itself will tear its family apart.

Despite the announcement at the Farnborough Air Show of the first firm orders for Airbus' A3XX super-jumbo, Eads is dogged by investors' doubts.

Eads was formed last autumn from the merger of France's Aérospatiale Matra, Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace (Dasa) and Spain's Casa, and has developed strong links with Italy's Alenia.

It looks like a good bet for investors through its controlling stake in Airbus. Executives went out of their way at the Oxford seminar to stress that, now Airbus is on course to become Airbus Integrated Company, they call the shots and Britain's BAE, as a 20% shareholder with limited veto rights, is a minority player.

But BAE, less than a year after its merger with GEC's Marconi defence arm, is increasingly rated a strong buy while Eads is, at best, rated neutral by analysts. Since the 30.65% float at €19 a share on July 10, the price has stuck below that.

One reason is the structure of Eads: two headquarters (Paris and Munich), two chief executives, Philippe Camus and Rainer Hertrich, legal incorporation in Amsterdam and a centre in Madrid. Rivals insist it is inherently unstable.

But in Oxford Mr Camus, a Frenchman who is a long-standing ally of Jean-Luc Lagardère, Eads co-chairman, and Mr Hertrich, a German with many years' experience at Dasa, put on an engaging double act to argue that three business cultures can be integrated. The two talk for at least half an hour a day on a video-conference link between Paris and Munich and spend at least two days a week together in France and Germany.

All the French directors report to Mr Hertrich and the Germans to Mr Camus; the Spanish report to both. But Mr Camus insisted that a three- strong integration team would make Eads one corporate culture within two years, and help realise the promised €500m annual synergies by 2004.

Another source of investor unrest is the sheer cost - £7bn - of the A3XX project and fear of overruns allied to doubts about market potential. Farnborough has dispelled some of these worries.

Andreas Sperl, Airbus chief financial officer, said AIC needed to sell 230 to make the project profitable - out of an expected market of 780 stretched jumbos by 2021. The group has targeted Asia and believes the initial orders will create what Dr Sperl calls a domino effect.

Airbus accounts for more than 50% of Eads business, but analysts are worried that Eads is over-exposed to a commercial aerospace market on the brink of cyclical downturn and under-exposed in the defence field where BAE is on the upturn.

Airbus is due to contribute half of Eads' annual cost savings and Dr Sperl insisted AIC could meet that target and raise its margins.

The deepest fear among investors is the stake held by the French (and Spanish) governments and the fact that the Pentagon can block alliances between Eads and US contractors. France is on the so-called C list while Britain and BAE are on the A list of approved contractors. Mr Gergorin said there was a strong will at industrial and political levels in the US for developing links with European players.

Mr Hertrich said Chrysler, the US arm of the German-American parent, was lobbying hard to improve France's approval rating. "Let's face it, you can't split Nato into an Anglo-Saxon part and a continental European part and so the US will want to talk to Eads."

But in the end it is potential for earnings growth that will lock in investors and that means the Camus-Hertrich double-act must deliver and remain intact.

webTitle: Polluter firms face tougher fines

fields.headline: Polluter firms face tougher fines
fields.trailText: Big companies were warned yesterday they could soon face huge fines for polluting the environment as the government urged magistrates to stop imposing "derisory" penalties.
fields.body:
Big companies were warned yesterday they could soon face huge fines for polluting the environment as the government urged magistrates to stop imposing "derisory" penalties.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said he wanted "six-figure" sums levied in serious cases and hinted he would press for punishments ranging up to 10% of annual turnover unless courts made fuller use of their powers.

The environment agency, responsible for prosecuting most offenders in England and Wales said some punishments amounted to "not even a mosquito bite". They effectively encouraged companies to break the law rather than invest in anti-pollution measures and failed to reflect the long term damage caused in pollution incidents.

The agency, which yesterday named and shamed the worst pollution offenders prosecuted during 1999, said the average level of fines was far too low - £4,750 per offence, or only £3,500 if the £750,000 penalty imposed on Milford Haven port authority for the 1996 Sea Empress disaster, was removed from the list.

This is well under the £20,000 or six months imprisonment that can be imposed by magistrates or the unlimited fine and two years imprisonment possible at crown courts. Both Mr Meacher and the agency were disappointed last year when the appeal court reduced the original Milford Haven penalty from £4m.

Mr Meacher said: "Fines up to now have in some cases been derisory. They have failed clearly to match the seriousness with which society now regards pollution. I absolutely take the view that figures of £2,000, £5,000 and £10,000 are quite ineffective. For a significant company one is talk ing about a six-figure fine if it is going to have a deterrent impact."

He said he had asked the Home Office to request its sentencing advisory panel to look at the problem and the Magistrates' Association was now giving guidance to courts.

He also said that new utilities legislation gave regulators power to fine companies up to 10% of their annual turnover for breaking competition rules.

John Harmon, chairman of the agency, said: "We are deeply concerned that it can still be cheaper for a business or individual to commit an environmental crime than it is to comply with the law.

"The fines are still derisory compared to the state of corporate finance. It is simply not enough. It is not a deterrent. It is not even a mosquito bite."

More than 500 businesses and individuals were prosecuted last year.

The agency also praised some companies including AES Drax power station, Selby, North Yorkshire, Associated Octel, Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, and BP Chemicals in Hull for big reductions in pollutant emissions.

Thames Water, which has an annual turnover of nearly £1.5bn, topped the prosecutions table, with eight resulting in fines totalling £79.000.

A Thames Water spokeswoman said: "We regret our position in the league table but it is only one measure of our environmental performance. It takes no account of the fact we are the largest water and sewerage company and we serve about 25% of the population of England and Wales."

This is well under the £20,000 or six months imprisonment that can be imposed by magistrates or the unlimited fine and two years imprisonment possible at crown courts. Both Mr Meacher and the agency were disappointed last year when the appeal court reduced the original Milford Haven penalty from £4m. Mr Meacher said: "Fines up to now have in some cases been derisory. They have failed clearly to match the seriousness with which society now regards pollution. I absolutely take the view that figures of £2,000, £5,000 and £10,000 are quite ineffective. For a significant company one is talk ing about a six-figure fine if it is going to have a deterrent impact." He said he had asked the Home Office to request its sentencing advisory panel to look at the problem and the Magistrates' Association was now giving guidance to courts. He also said that new utilities legislation gave regulators power to fine companies up to 10% of their annual turnover for breaking competition rules. John Harmon, chairman of the agency, said: "We are deeply concerned that it can still be cheaper for a business or individual to commit an environmental crime than it is to comply with the law. "The fines are still derisory compared to the state of corporate finance. It is simply not enough. It is not a deterrent. It is not even a mosquito bite." More than 500 businesses and individuals were prosecuted last year. The agency also praised some companies including AES Drax power station, Selby, North Yorkshire, Associated Octel, Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, and BP Chemicals in Hull for big reductions in pollutant emissions. Thames Water, which has an annual turnover of nearly £1.5bn, topped the prosecutions table, with eight resulting in fines totalling £79.000. A Thames Water spokeswoman said: "We regret our position in the league table but it is only one measure of our environmental performance. It takes no account of the fact we are the largest water and sewerage company and we serve about 25% of the population of England and Wales."

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Commandos fail drugs tests

A group of Royal Marine commandos has been sent home from Kosovo after testing positive for drugs, the navy said yesterday.

The six marines and two soldiers from the Commando Logistic Regiment were tested in a random drugs sampling before they left for Kosovo. Traces of ecstasy and cannabis are believed to have been found. All eight are based at Chivenor, north Devon.

Victims' families to get £10,000

Families of Ulster's "disappeared" - murdered by terrorists and secretly buried - are each to be given up to £10,000 compensation, the government said yesterday.

Web shopping to double

The number of consumers buying on-line is set to double globally in the near future, according to a worldwide study of a consumers and internet users published yesterday.

The report by market analysts Taylor Nelson Sofres Interactive said the industry still needed to overcome shoppers' scepticism.

Shipman ruling accepted

Health secretary Alan Milburn yesterday said he would not be appealing against a high court judgment which overturned his decision to hold the inquiry into the case of serial killer GP Harold Shipman in private.

Officials will consult the families of Shipman's victims to decide how the inquiry will be run.

Stop badger cull says Cornwall

Cornwall county council is calling on the government to scrap its badger culling programme.

Parts of Cornwall are among 10 areas of Britain being used for scientific trials to establish whether badgers are the main cause of tuberculosis in cattle. Geoffrey Gibbs

Robin Oakley joins CNN

Robin Oakley, the outgoing political editor of BBC News, is to join the US news organisation CNN. Oakley, 58, becomes European political editor for CNN.com, the cable network's website. Matt Wells

Aid workers kidnapped

Aid workers have been offered evacuation from the Somali capital, Mogadishu, after gunmen kidnapped two from their compound yesterday, the Foreign Office said.

The British man and French woman were seized in what appeared to be a botched robbery. They were said to be unharmed. John Ezard

Post Office complaints up

Complaints by customers against the Post Office have doubled over the past year to more than 10,000, and are expected to continue increasing, the Post Office Users' National Council revealed yesterday.

webTitle: Digital stacks up the figures for Murdoch

fields.headline: Digital stacks up the figures for Murdoch
fields.standfirst: Forget snobbery this is class stuff
fields.trailText: Telephony geeks will tell you that there is a point in any mobile phone market when, after years of laboured growth, the graph charting the percentage of the population carrying handsets suddenly erupts.
fields.body:
Telephony geeks will tell you that there is a point in any mobile phone market when, after years of laboured growth, the graph charting the percentage of the population carrying handsets suddenly erupts. It happened in Britain and has happened in virtually every mature cellular market.

The theory is that take-up gains its own momentum once the product wins a certain ubiquity and people without phones start feeling left behind.

There is a view that the same could now be happening in pay television. It has always been assumed that the market for multi-channel television would reach a plateau and for the past few years BSkyB has struggled to lift subscriber numbers above the 3.5m mark.

But digital TV, which once seemed a difficult concept to explain to consumers, has clearly caught the public's imagination and underpinned rapid growth for Rupert Murdoch's business, BSkyB. Taking cable and ONdigital into account, one in three households in Britain now has access to Sky channels including Sky One and Sky Sports. In homes with access to SkyDigital almost 19% audience share is taken by Sky-branded channels - just below BBC1.

Just as there was a key point at which mobiles went from being the reviled tool of the yuppie to a commodity item, so we could be witnessing the change in character of pay-TV from council estate eyesore to a "must-have" service.

BSkyB's cause will only be aided by new technology. ADSL, which upgrades the old copper wire telephone network for broadcasting TV, will mean those recalcitrant snobs can stop worrying about the satellite dish.

Another telling statistic aired by BSkyB in a presentation yesterday was the shift in customer type. The old analogue system, it seems, attracted 46% ABC1s while the digital audience is 52% ABC1. The argument goes that digital TV is not just about the rather downmarket proposition of consumers wanting more television but is also about home shopping, interactive services and the internet.

If BSkyB has done an impressive job in building its place in British television however, it must also recognise its debt to the cable companies. Without their extraordinary inability to get digital operational it might have been one of BSkyB's rivals heralding the step change in our viewing habits.

Spain catches up

Plagued by allegations of insider dealing, and having fallen out with the Spanish prime minister, Juan Villalonga is finally resigning as chief executive of Telefonica, the state-owned phone business which he had turned into a new-economy heavyweight. The world of Spanish business will be a less colourful place. This is the man who left his wife 18 months ago and then tried to move Telefonica's operational headquarters to Miami so he could spend more time with his new love, a former Miss Mexico.

The pace and style of deal-making by this former investment banker had also made the group's big international shareholders increasingly nervous.

But his departure will be cushioned by a pay-off estimated at £15m, together with a glowing tribute from the Telefonica board. This is quite extraordinary. The man is deemed by Spain's major institutions to be unfit to run the business.

There was a time when most big Spanish firms were run by political cronies. It is progress, perhaps, that important management changes are now dictated by the owners of the business instead. But it is difficult to avoid the thought that Spanish business has some serious catching up to do in the field of corporate governance if it is to be taken seriously elsewhere in the world.

Banking dearth

It is the banks' half-time reporting season, but no one wants the shares; Abbey National, Halifax and Alliance & Leicester were pummelled yesterday.

A placing in A&L shares was partly to blame, but evidence of the pressure on Abbey's margins, despite a surprisingly up-beat presentation, did not help. Abbey's net interest spread - the difference between the rate of interest it pays out and receives - has shrunk from 2.18% to 2.06% in six months and will hit 2% soon.

This is an indicator of competitive pressures in the retail banking market, but if the fall in banks' shares is just about competition they have probably fallen too far.

For instance, Abbey has historically operated in an environment where the net interest spread has been as low as 1.75% and as high as 2.25%, but at current levels the shares appear to be pre-empting a precipitous decline in profitability from here.

Other factors, like government intervention, are also clearly worrying investors. Bid speculation in the sector also seems to have disappeared for now. So stand by for some nervous presentations from Abbey's rivals over the coming days.

webTitle: Rural jobless 'should get grant for car'

fields.headline: Rural jobless 'should get grant for car'
fields.standfirst: Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Unemployed people trapped in the countryside without access to bus and train services should be offered government grants to buy a car, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
Unemployed people trapped in the countryside without access to bus and train services should be offered government grants to buy a car, according to a study published today.

Means tested help towards the costs of road tax and vehicle insurance should also be offered as additional inducements to find work, it says.

Researchers funded by the influential Joseph Rowntree Foundation call for a radical reappraisal of government policy to address the "hidden and dispersed nature of poverty" outside cities and towns. They argue that the hundreds of millions collected from fuel duties in the countryside should go into a special rural fund to subsidise car buying schemes, keep open village shops and schools, and underpin bus and taxi services.

The government's country side agency added its weight to the study by calling for a bold initiative from ministers. "For many rural people access to a car is a necessity," it said.

Professor Mark Shucksmith, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundations's rural areas research programme, identifies transport - either the lack of buses, or the rising cost of motoring-- as a major barrier to improving the lives of many country dwellers.

He said there was "a fundamental contradiction" when fuel taxation and other policies designed to reduce car use and ownership "serve to exacerbate rural exclusion and intensify barriers to employment". The study argues that public transport is unable to provide a comprehensive so lution to accessibility in the countryside. "Cars are essential," it says.

webTitle: Chocolate sales falling in UK

fields.headline: Meltdown
fields.standfirst: Falling chocolate sales force Cadbury to go shopping
fields.trailText: Britons are losing their appetite for chocolate, according to the confectionery company Cadbury Schweppes, which is considering acquisitions in other "impulse" food and drinks products.
fields.body:
Britons are losing their appetite for chocolate, according to the confectionery company Cadbury Schweppes, which is considering acquisitions in other "impulse" food and drinks products.

The group announced yesterday that interim pre-tax profits rose 17% to £295m but chief operating officer John Brock warned that the domestic market for sweets and snacks was "subdued".

He blamed a slump in the number of traditional family-run corner shops and competition among supermarkets, due to the arrival of the American discount retailer Wal-Mart.

Supermarkets were shrinking the space devoted to its products to make room for higher-margin non-food items such as clothes.

The group's sales in Britain and Ireland slipped by £1m to £456m during the first half, although savings helped push profits up 5% to £81m. This was offset by a strong performance in America from soft drinks, particularly Seven Up and Dr Pepper.

Chief executive, John Sunderland said: "We would prefer to develop our core businesses of beverages and confectionery but we are prepared to consider going into related markets if the strategic benefits are clear."

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Anyone faintly mystified as to why Mr Tony Blair brought Alun Michael into his cabinet and later imposed him as assembly leader on a reluctant Wales may find news of a family wedding instructive. Alun's daughter Bethan is to be wed in September, in a small evangelical church in Cardiff, and the wedding invitations say that all present "will be received by the bride and groom and their parents in the church hall, and offered a buffet lunch of tea/coffee/squash and finger foods _ 4.30pm: all to take their seats in the marquee, for the speeches. There will be no 'toasts' - and you may like to know in advance that no alcohol will be served during the day." It sounds an absolute riot, and close students of New Labour will be reminded that Mr T banned all booze from Euan's 16th birthday party. Anyone planning to attend the wedding may apply to the Diary for a full list of British retailers who stock hip flasks.

It sounds an absolute riot, and close students of New Labour will be reminded that Mr T banned all booze from Euan's 16th birthday party. Anyone planning to attend the wedding may apply to the Diary for a full list of British retailers who stock hip flasks.

Second from the left in a Daily Mail photo of seven former Bond girls, I am thrilled to note, is Valerie Leon. She is not best known to Diary readers, of course, for appearances in Never Say Never Again and The Spy Who Loved Me, but as the shop assistant who erected Charles Hawtrey's tent in Carry On Camping - and, indeed, as the most fearsome PR known to this column. A feeling in my water suggests we will be carrying news of the Hungarian Cultural Centre, a client of hers, very shortly.

One-time Arthur Daley of New Labour turned advertising magnate Dolly Draper becomes ever more expert at precisely targeting his projects at the correct media outlet. Dolly has just written to Boris the Jackal Johnson asking him to watch two short films "highlighting the current events being organised to bring asylum seekers and local communities together". How perfectly tailored for the Jackal's Spectator. Good on Dolly for taking on so worthwhile a cause, but next time he writes to the editor of a very rightwing publication, it might be wise not to address the package to the Observer.

Although Gerald Kaufman Month does not begin officially until next week, please start sending in your entries to the competition now. To remind you: in no more than a dozen words, finish the sentence that begins: "I love Gerald Kaufman because ..." First prize is Big Mouth Billy Bass, the singing, lip-synching fish that has been bringing such mirth and merriment into the life of Mr Tony. In truth, it is quite funny once or twice (the only people I know of who have found it hilarious time after time are the PM and a three-year-old boy of my acquaintance). Entries must arrive by noon on August 17, with champagne to the three runners-up.

Tomorrow will bring sensational news tying in Gerald Kaufman Month with the forthcoming loan of the Rolls-Royce Corniche, RR1. Definitely not to be missed.

In today's extract from Under No Illusion, by Paul Daniels, we find the conjuror footloose after his first marriage broke up. "A blinding awareness had come in the middle of making love to a girl in the back of car," Paul remembers. "I had realised I wasn't actually enjoying it; I was just doing it for the sake of it. I remember I actually apologised to the girl and drove her home." What a gent he is. "A few years later on a train journey, I started to doodle the names of the girls I had made love to in my 'mad' years." And the the tally? "I got past 300 and gave up." Yes, but how many did he drive home?

Surprising crime figure news from Italy. The tiny town of San Marino has closed its jail after 27 years for no better reason than its failure ever once to hold a prisoner. "We will use it as a community centre," says mayor Fabio DeAngelis. "Our police chief doubles as a stray-dog catcher and coroner when he isn't running his florist shop."

webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Nationwide under attack

Rebel Nationwide building society member Andrew Muir - who stood unsuccessfully for election to the board on a windfalls ticket two years ago - told the annual meeting yesterday that he would relaunch his campaign for the society to turn itself into a bank.

The Nationwide said that it does not have to accept a conversion resolution at next year's meeting. The earliest the challengers could bring a resolution forward would be November 2001.

L&G examines free estate

Legal & General said yesterday it is examining ways to release its £2.3bn free estate to shareholders and policyholders after reporting operating profits up 19% to £231m from £194m in the half year to June 30.

Pre-tax profits slipped to £287m from £290m, but L&G says the figures were distorted by the impact of stockmarket movements on its life fund.

Group chief executive David Prosser ruled out joining the bidding battle for Equitable Life.

EU agrees to Syngenta

AstraZeneca and Novartis have got the green light from regulators to merge their agrichemicals businesses, as long as they sell crop protection products with total annual sales of $340m.

The ruling, from the European commission yesterday, means the £9bn deal is likely to be completed in the fourth quarter. The combined company, called Syngenta, will be the world's biggest agribusiness company and a leading producer of genetically modified food.

Abbey sees 5% increase

Abbey National reported a 5% rise in profits in the first six months of the year of £922m.

Its new internet bank, Cahoot, lost £31m and has 31,000 customers after turning away a similar number which failed the credit scoring criteria. Abbey will pay an interim dividend of 15.15p, up 13%.
