webTitle: Land Rover cuts prices and improves specification

fields.headline: Land Rover cuts prices and improves specification
fields.trailText: Land Rover, under its new Ford management, has given way to customer pressure and cut the price of its models by up to 14% and is increasing the equipment fitted as standard.
fields.body:
Land Rover, under its new Ford management, has given way to customer pressure and cut the price of its models by up to 14% and is increasing the equipment fitted as standard.

The move follows a dramatic fall over the past year in the prices which customers are prepared to pay for multi-purpose vehicles such as Land Rovers. The monthly survey of forecourt transaction prices by the Alliance & Leicester, published yesterday, showed customers paying 17% less for MPVs than a year previously.

Its June survey showed the real cost to consumers of new cars 4.6% lower than in June last year. But despite lower prices, car sales fell 10%.

webTitle: Mugabe sued for role in farm invasions

fields.headline: Mugabe sued for role in farm invasions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: A lawsuit accusing Zimbabwe's president of being directly responsible for the breakdown of law in the country was lodged yesterday by the country's white farmers.
fields.body:
A lawsuit accusing Zimbabwe's president of being directly responsible for the breakdown of law in the country was lodged yesterday by the country's white farmers.

Robert Mugabe, the suit alleges, played "a material role in the persistence of the farm invasions", which has seen more than 1,400 farms occupied by supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party.

The action was filed by the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents 4,200 white- owned farms in the country.

There has been "a major resurgence of farm invasions" since the June parliamentary elections, the suit says, and more than 50 farmers have been threatened with death. Numerous farmers, it alleges, have been ordered to leave their properties immediately, though the Zanu-PF supporters have "no legal authority" to issue such eviction notices.

"Death threats are being issued with such vehemence and conviction that it would be foolhardy for anyone to ignore them," the CFU alleges. "The whole situation is greatly aggravated by totally inadequate police reaction."

The lawsuit also names the country's police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, and the leader of the war veterans' group that has taken a leading role in the farm occupations, Chenjerai Hunzvi.

The courts twice ruled that the occupations were illegal, but Mr Mugabe ordered the police to take no action to end the squatting on the farms.

The farmers' union says it will drop the legal proceedings against the president if he takes immediate action to end the occupations and restore law and order. The production of tobacco, maize, wheat and other key crops has been disrupted. Tobacco is the country's key export commodity.

In the northern Karoi area, 230 white-owned farms have closed in protest at the farm invasions. Most of the shops in Karoi have also shut to show solidarity with the white farmers. A Karoi farmer, David Brand, was beaten unconscious on Tuesday by war veterans and was recovering yesterday.

The opposition Movement for Democratic Change went ahead yesterday with its legal challenge to 28 parliamentary seats won by Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the June 24 and 25 elections.

Zanu-PF won 62 of the 120 elected seats, and the MDC won 57. But because Mr Mugabe can appoint 30 MPs, his party has ended up holding 92 of the 150 parliamentary seats.

Large-scale electoral irregularities were being alleged yesterday in the Mazowe East constituency, where officials were investigating the voting papers. Lawyers for the MDC claim that many people voted twice, and in some cases the dead cast ballots.

The MDC is hoping not only to overturn several results but to have some Zanu-PF candidates barred from office.

The government raised the price of regular petrol by almost 26% yesterday. It also raised the price of kerosene - used by the poor for lighting and cooking - by 128%. With inflation already at 70% and unemployment at 50%, the increases are bound to raise hostility to the government.

webTitle: Fury as envoys vote for military secrecy

fields.headline: Fury as envoys vote for military secrecy
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: European Union governments are letting Nato's culture of secrecy in through the back door, an MEP complained yesterday..
fields.body:
European Union governments are letting Nato's culture of secrecy in through the back door, an MEP complained yesterday as the permanent representatives in Brussels of the 15 EU states acted to block public access to documents about security and defence.

Protests erupted after the ambassadors approved a plan by Javier Solana, the union's defence and foreign policy chief, to drastically curtail the relatively open approach to official papers.

The plan puts a block exemption on documents about military and crisis-management planning which are likely to be accessible under current rules.

The Netherlands, Finland and Sweden voted against the plan. One official involved protested furiously that it amounted to a "military coup".

The row highlights a sharp clash of cultures as the EU develops its own defence structures, which require close cooperation with Nato and its strict security procedures.

Mr Solana, a former Nato secretary-general, is moving cautiously to avoid alarming Eurosceptics and Americans who are afraid that Nato will be weakened if the EU gets the military muscle to match its economic weight.

"He's got to find a way that denies the right of automatic access to documents that are given to him, otherwise he'd never get the information he needs from the member states," one national official insisted.

Mr Solana wants to block not only military documents but also documents about non-military crisis management activities, such as the proposed EU police force to operate after a Kosovo-type conflict. It is feared that the ban might be extended to sensitive areas such as police and judicial cooperation.

The freedom of information watchdog Statewatch said the approach undermined the commitment in the 1997 Amsterdam treaty to the public's right of access to documents.

The plan infuriated MEPs, who have just started discussing a commission proposal for a code of access to meet the Amsterdam pledge. .

"Solana is trying to introduce Nato's secretive methods into the EU through the backdoor," Heidi Hautala, the Finnish co-president of the Green group in the EU parliament, said.

webTitle: Crowds out for Arafat, daggers out for Barak

fields.headline: Crowds out for Arafat, daggers out for Barak
fields.standfirst:
Homecoming Palestinians like firm stance at summit, but Israel's leader is in political peril for discussing Jerusalem
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Homecoming Palestinians like firm stance at summit, but Israel's leader is in political peril for discussing Jerusalem
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak returned to two very different homecomings yesterday after the collapse of their summit at Camp David - the Palestinian leader to whoops of delight, and his Israeli counterpart to the sound of knives being sharpened.

In choreographed demonstrations in the West Bank and Gaza, thousands of Palestinians gave a conqueror's welcome to Mr Arafat, hailing his courage for refusing to yield their claim to the ancient walled city of Jerusalem. This was the breaking point of the summit.

In the West Bank city of Ramallah, Nimeh Rashadieh, a mother of 10 children, ululated with joy. She was unconcerned by predictions that a new cycle of violence could begin between Arab and Jew, should Mr Arafat declare a state without Israel's acquiesence later this year.

"It's a war," she said yesterday, clutching a poster of Mr Arafat to the embroidered bodice of her dress. "Soon the blood will be knee-deep. Yes, I want another war and another intifada if that is what it takes to get our country back."

From the US, Hillary Clinton - seeking to shore up her pro-Israel credentials as she wages a tough campaign in New York for the US Senate - chimed in with a statement declaring that a unilateral declaration of statehood by Mr Arafat "should be met with a cutoff of US assistance".

The Camp David summit saw an Israeli leader for the first time putting the future of Jerusalem up for negotiation; and the meeting galvanised opponents of the peace process on both sides.

In Gaza, loudspeakers ordered people to line the streets leading to Mr Arafat's headquarters. He landed with a wave, and a smile, saying: "Jerusalem is the capital of the Palestinian state, like it or not. Whoever does not like it can go and drink from the sea." Even so, the Palestinian leader will soon be taking soundings around the region on whether to settle for some form of control short of sovereignty in Arab neighbourhoods of East Jerusalem. The Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat, announced yesterday that discussions would resume in the region on Sunday.

In Tel Aviv a few hours later, it was a very different reception for the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, who re turned without a government, and with left and right lining up to criticise him. Hardliners had not wanted him to go to the summit at all.

Though the red carpet was laid out and the military honour guard assembled at Ben Gurion airport, the display of pomp offered scant assurance for Mr Barak.

The second person to greet him after he stepped off the plane was David Levy, the foreign minister who refused to accompany him to Camp David, and who courted rightwing Jewish protesters in the prime minister's absence. Far from the conquering hero, Mr Barak appealed to his people for understanding of his decision to discuss Jerusalem only to fail to reach a deal.

"I left knowing full well that there would not be peace at any price, but that there could not be peace without paying a price that may be heart-wrenching and difficult to accept," he said.

"I return today from Camp David with millions of eyes looking at me, and I have to say with anguish we did not succeed. We did not succeed because our Palestine neighbours have not yet accepted that for genuine peace you have to give up part of your dream."

The Israeli leader spent his 12-hour flight telephoning potential allies to try to rebuild the coalition that fractured on the eve of his departure for Camp David two weeks ago.

If he fails here too, he could face elections in the autumn, or be saddled with a national unity government including the rightwing Likud party. That would almost certainly put the lid on peace efforts in the immediate future.

Mr Arafat faces no such challenges. On the streets of Ramallah, there is little faith in negotiations that have dragged on for seven years, and few see the summit's failure as a missed opportunity.

Instead, they say Mr Arafat has redeemed their honour by asserting his claim to a city that is sacred to all Muslims.

At the al-Quds butcher shop, named in honour of "the holy", the name the Arabs use for the divided city of Jerusalem, Khalid Hamad said Camp David was a fool's enterprise.

"It is like churning water to get butter. It will never work. That is what these negotiations are like," he said as Koranic verses wafted out of a cassette player beside his meat grinder. "I believe we cannot get our land back peacefully. We have to use force."

In Jewish settlements in the West Bank - likely confrontation points if violence erupts - they were inclined to agree with the predictions of doom.

"I think we will probably be killing each other in a few weeks," said Paul Ross, who lives in Rimonim, an isolated settlement on a hilltop. "Camp David just spared us a little time before the axe starts falling."

webTitle: Labour agrees curb on special advisers

fields.headline: Labour agrees curb on special advisers
fields.standfirst:
Standards watchdog applauds 'positive' response
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday bowed to criticism from Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, and committed the government to limiting the number of special advisers, which have doubled under Labour.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday bowed to criticism from Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, and committed the government to limiting the number of special advisers, which have doubled under Labour.

The prime minister also announced a new code of conduct for special advisers and accepted a toughening of the code of conduct for ministers.

But he ruled out requiring ministers or civil servants to release to the public - as in the United States - the basic details of meetings they hold with lobbyists, outside interest groups or big companies.

Since Labour came to power, the number of special advisers appointed by the government has risen to 74 - at a cost of £3.9m to the taxpayer - compared to 38 at the beginning of 1997. The government said in its response that it accepted that "an overall limit on the number of special advisers should be included in civil service legislation". There is no date for introducing the legislation. The government also accepted the committee's recommendations that there should be a separate code for special advisers, "and that it should include a duty on all advisers to respect the political impartiality of the civil service". The code will also include a section on the direct media contacts of advisers.

Mr Blair has also accepted that the prime minister's code of conduct for ministers should be changed to make it absolutely clear that individual ministers must take personal responsibility for deciding whether they have a "conflict of interest" with their private business or personal life. They will no longer be able to shelter behind advice they may have sought from their permanent secretary.

The government also accepted tougher rules for the growing sponsorship of government conferences and campaigns by private companies following criticism from Lord Neill.

Lord Neill yesterday called the response "very positive". He said: "Nearly all of the committee's recommendations (covering a wide range of topics) have been accepted in full."

 The large number of Labour supporters appointed by ministers to influential posts was confirmed by the office of the commissioner for public appointments yesterday.

The office's annual report showed 14.7% of those appointed to chair public bodies - which includes the boards of NHS trusts, nationalised industries and government advisory bodies - were Labour activists. Only 3.4% were Conservatives and 0.9% were Liberal Democrats, while others did not declare any political activity.

The report also found 8.9% of appointees were from ethnic minorities - slightly up on the previous year although none were give posts paying £20,000 a year or more. It showed 39% of appointments were women, the same as in the previous two years.

webTitle: Camp David peace talks

fields.headline: Forbidden issues aired at last
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The breakdown of the Camp David talks should not obscure the fact that after years of a "peace process" that prevented negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis on the most important issues, a rational discussion of the previously taboo topics of refugees and Jerusalem has at last begun in Israel and elsewhere.
fields.body:
The breakdown of the Camp David talks should not obscure the fact that after years of a "peace process" that prevented negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis on the most important issues, a rational discussion of the previously taboo topics of refugees and Jerusalem has at last begun in Israel and elsewhere.

This is not to say that the Israeli proposals leaked during the talks were in any way sufficient as a basis for resolving these issues.

On refugees, the proposals apparently involved a refusal to accept any Israeli responsibility for the creation of this problem, a refusal to accept the right of return (except for a mere 5,000 a year, spread over two decades), and the brazen suggestion that others pay any compensation on offer.

On Jerusalem, the offer seems to have involved no Arab or shared sovereignty over the Old City or - outside the walls, the Mount of Olives, the districts of Silwan and Sheikh Jarrah, or the Saladin Street business area - the core of Arab Jerusalem. And while giving the Palestinians formal control of outlying neighbourhoods they already largely control, the proposal sought to keep most of the city under exclusive Israeli sovereignty.

Nevertheless, after 33 years of stubbornly repeating the mantra that Jerusalem is Israel's "eternal and undivided capital", some Israeli politicians are finally realising they face a choice.

They can keep the 230,000 Arabs of Jerusalem - the largest Arab city in the West Bank - under their exclusive sovereignty, with the certainty that this will prevent Palestinian and Arab acceptance of a peace accord. Or they can give the Palestinians some form of sovereign authority in Jerusalem, and full municipal control over the Arab part of the city, and obtain a lasting peace.

Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, presumably recoiled from the full political implications of this choice. But a shift has begun in Israel away from the mindless repetition of an unreal and unrealisable slogan, and towards accepting the need to share the Holy City.

Less progress has been made on refugees. This is in spite of all that Israeli new historians, educators, and journalists have done to replace the mythology of Israel's virgin birth in 1948 with an appreciation of the suffering and loss inflicted on the Palestinians as a precondition for creating a Jewish state in a place with a two-thirds Arab majority that owned over 90% of the land.

But even here, the subject is finally on the table, and the property and residence rights of the 750,000 Palestinians who were driven out in 1948 can no longer be ignored.

Israel argued that these negotiations had to result in a binding end to the conflict. This is an admirable objective. It cannot be achieved, however, without addressing the taboo issues which Israel has long succeeded in per suading its American friends to exclude from the negotiations, and indeed from rational discussion.

If this conflict is to be ended, its root causes, in particular the issues of refugees and Jerusalem, must finally be faced squarely.

This means that there must be a fair formula for the sharing of Jerusalem, and that Israel must accept its responsibility for the wrongs done to the refugees, and offer redress.

This redress should be in the form of return for a proportion of them - certainly those with families living in the 100 Arab villages remaining in Israel - combined with restitution of, or compensation for, property lost.

None of this will be easy, nor will it happen soon. But for it to happen will require a genuine public debate in Israel. This is a process which the failed Camp David talks have belatedly begun.

 Professor Rashid Khalidi teaches history at the University of Chicago and is the author of Palestinian Identity. He was an adviser to the Palestinian delegation in the peace process from 1991-93

webTitle: Telefonica chief's reign ends

fields.headline: Telefonica chief's reign ends
fields.trailText: Juan Villalonga, flamboyant chairman and chief executive of Telefonica, Spain's telecoms multinational, resigned last night, victim of his fraught relationship with the country's centre right government.
fields.body:
Juan Villalonga, flamboyant chairman and chief executive of Telefonica, Spain's telecoms multinational, resigned last night, victim of his fraught relationship with the country's centre right government.

He is due to be replaced by the chairman and chief executive of the Franco-Spanish tobacco company Altadis, Cesar Alierta, who is a member of Telefonica's board. Several board members close to Mr Villalonga are also expected to go.

Mr Alierta may be only a temporary replacement and the roles of chief executive and chairman could be split.

Mr Villalonga is believed to have negotiated a pay-off of about 4bn pesetas (£14.4m) and guarantees that an inquiry into allegations of insider trading will go no further.

Telefonica said last night: "The appropriate time has come for a change in the company's leadership." That follows months of speculation about Mr Villalonga's survival at the company he privatised and then made a global player.

Shares in Telefonica, and the Terra internet company two-thirds owned by Telefonica, rose yesterday following reports that the resignation was close. "There is a sense of relief that the destabilising battles of the past months are over," one analyst said.

Mr Villalonga was appointed soon after Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, came to power in 1996. The two had been at Madrid's elite Pilar school together.

No one reflected Mr Aznar's desire to put Spain on the global economic map better than his friend. He made Telefonica the biggest telecoms operator in Latin America and carved out mobile phone, internet and television interests around the world.

But the friendship turned sour after Mr Aznar asked him to renounce huge stock option payments which became an embarrassing issue during the election campaign earlier this year. Mr Villalonga refused.

He also clashed with the government over a proposed merger with the Dutch telecoms company KPN and infuriated Spaniards by conducting much Telefonica business from Miami where he moved after leaving his wife, a close friend of Mrs Aznar, to live with a former Miss Mexico.

webTitle: Backing for 2006 analogue switch-off

fields.headline: Backing for 2006 analogue switch-off
fields.trailText: BSkyB believes analogue television signals can be switched off within six years unlike the Independent Television Commission.
fields.body:
BSkyB believes analogue television signals can be switched off within six years unlike the Independent Television Commission.

Yesterday, Sky executives declared the government's plan to switch off the analogue TV services as early as 2006 attainable after announcing plans to end its own analogue transmission in June 2001, some 18 months earlier than originally planned.

The ITC recently said the 2006 timetable was unrealistic.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, has said he hopes to complete the analogue switch-off by 2010 but has cautioned that it will happen only when new digital services are "universally available and affordable". The switch-off is a potentially explosive political issue because it will force people on lower incomes who do not want to sign up to the likes of BSkyB or ONdigital to fork out for new digital television sets.

The satellite TV company yesterday said the unexpectedly rapid take-up meant 80% of BSkyB customers were receiving a digital service. The early switch-off will save the company £20m in dual transmission costs. Tony Ball, BSkyB chief executive, said the company's experience added grist to Mr Smith's proposed timetable.

"That date is probably achievable and we are a great help to the government," Mr Ball said. "A free dish and set top box means that old lady in the Hebrides can switch to digital easily," he said.

webTitle: BSkyB targets 7m viewers

fields.headline: BSkyB targets 7m viewers
fields.trailText: BSkyB yesterday turned up the heat on its rivals in the pay television market when it published a new target of 7m subscribers by the end of 2003.
fields.body:
BSkyB yesterday turned up the heat on its rivals in the pay television market when it published a new target of 7m subscribers by the end of 2003.

The goal was outlined as the company boasted of a now yawning gap between itself and the cable companies which has been built by BSkyB's early deployment of digital technology. Digital, which allows better quality pictures, more channels and interactive services, has proved a huge catalyst for growth.

"We were stuck at around 3.5m subscribers for quite some time and it is the launch of digital which has really set us growing," claimed BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball.

The company said talks were under way to develop a joint venture with British Telecom to use its network for a broadcasting service. Both are running pilots with other partners.

BSkyB's subscriber base reached 4.5m in the year to June 30 of which some 80% are now on SkyDigital. The numbers reflected a gain of more than 1m subscribers during the year, a period which Mr Ball said was the company's best performance since 1996 - the year BSkyB began broadcasting Premiership football.

"The cable companies are still at the back of the queue when it comes to launching digital services. In our fourth quarter alone we added 345,000 - in recent years we would have been happy if that was the number for the full 12 months," he said.

Almost 9m homes now receive Sky channels through the BSkyB service, cable or ONdigital.

The cable companies' launch of digital services has been plagued by delays and technical problems. Last week Telewest, the smaller of the two main remaining players said it was suspending the marketing of its digital service, which launched in parts of the country last autumn, owing to a shortage of the set top boxes needed to unscramble the signal.

Shares in Telewest lost another 8% yesterday to settle on 193p and are at their lowest level for 18 months. They have tumbled from a peak of 569p in March.

NTL, Britain's largest cable company after acquiring Cable & Wireless, wants 500,000 customers to be using its digital service by the end of the year.

The accelerated take-up at BSkyB was not without its price however as the cost of paying for set-top boxes and rising investment in programming kept the company in the red. Pre-tax losses for the year were £262.7m, including £120m of exceptional costs against losses of £388m in the previous 12 months. Revenues were £1.9bn, an increase of 20%.

The cost of programming including sports rights acquisitions reached £946m while marketing, including the cost of the set-top box giveaway grew from £215m to £381m.

Mr Ball said the renewal of BSkyB's contract to screen the Premiership matches had "derisked" the business.

As well as growing subscriber numbers Mr Ball said the company's aim was to develop interactive services to lift the average revenue from £287. Digital customers spend an average £300 with the company against analogue of £275.

He also added that no conversations are being held with ITV over its refusal to be carried on SkyDigital but added that BSkyB was not being hurt.

webTitle: Indonesia to try former dictator for corruption

fields.headline: Indonesia to try former dictator for corruption
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Indonesian government prosecutors have compiled enough evidence to charge the country's ailing former dictator, Suharto, with corruption. The trial will probably begin within three weeks.
fields.body:
Indonesian government prosecutors have compiled enough evidence to charge the country's ailing former dictator, Suharto, with corruption. The trial will probably begin within three weeks.

A spokesman at the attorney general's office, Yushar Yahya, said yesterday that a letter detailing the charges would be submitted to a court early next month. Under Indonesian law a suspect is formally charged on the first day of a trial, which must begin within two weeks of the letter being submitted.

"The letter states that he is charged with the criminal act of corruption," Mr Yahya said. "It will definitely be submitted before August 10 [the date Mr Suharto's house arrest order expires]".

It is widely alleged that the retired general amassed a fortune worth tens of billions of pounds during his 32-year reign until May 1998. Indonesia's current president, Abdurrahman Wahid, announced last month that he believed Mr Suharto had stolen about £30bn while in office and had allowed his family and cronies to rake off billions as well.

The announcement came shortly after Mr Suharto, 79, lost a libel suit against the American news magazine Time, which claimed that the one-time strongman was worth about £27bn.

Mr Wahid has repeatedly promised to pardon Mr Suharto if he returns at least £25bn.

The attorney general's investigation is focusing on how seven charitable foundations controlled by Mr Suharto acquired tens of millions of dollars, and to whom the money was disbursed. "We chose to focus on the foundations first because it is easier to obtain evidence about them," Mr Yahya said. "We will see how this prosecution goes before we move on to anything else."

Last week, the prosecutors seized a 12-storey office building in central Jakarta owned by the foundations and confiscated a mansion belonging to a Suharto crony, Zahid Husein, the former treasurer of one of the charities.

One of Mr Suharto's lawyers, Juan Felix Tampubolon, said yesterday that the prosecutors had no firm evidence, and that their actions were politically motivated. "The attorney-general has violated Suharto's human rights," he said. "He has pursued this case for political purposes."

President Wahid and the attorney general, Marzuki Darusman, have come under intense pressure to prosecute Mr Suharto quickly. There are demonstrations about the slow pace of the investigation on most days in Jakarta.

Mr Tampubolon reiterated that Mr Suharto was not well enough to stand trial."He's an old man in failing health who should be left to spend his remaining days in peace."

He suffered a further public humiliation this week when the central bank announced that banknotes depicting his face would no longer be legal tender after August 21.

webTitle: Space station gets all mod cons

fields.headline: Space station gets all mod cons
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Astronauts' living quarters were finally connected to the international space station yesterday in a series of highly complex space manoeuvres 220 miles above the earth which took the project another step towards completion.
fields.body:
Astronauts' living quarters were finally connected to the international space station yesterday in a series of highly complex space manoeuvres 220 miles above the earth which took the project another step towards completion.

The successful docking of the unmanned Zvezda module was greeted triumphantly by representatives of the Russian space agency, who have been bitterly criticised by their international colleagues for long delays caused by Russia's financial crises and technical problems.

The project is two years late and $3bn (£2bn) over budget as a result of the setbacks to the Russian-built craft.

Zvezda's safe arrival clears the way for the first team of scientists to be sent to the station in the autumn to begin work on the most ambitious and most expensive international science project in history.

Now that there is somewhere to sleep, the first three astronauts from the US and Russia can be lifted into orbit in October. The station, which is being built jointly by Russia, the US, Japan and Europe at a cost of about $60bn, is not due to be finished until 2005.

Zvezda, the size of a large bus, contains sleeping quarters for three, facilities for washing in zero gravity and a kitchen with an exercise bicycle and treadmill. It cost $340m and was launched from a cosmodrome in Kazakhstan two weeks ago.

Early yesterday as it crossed central Asia at 0.5mph, Russian engineers on the ground eased it by remote control into contact with the two partner modules which have been in orbit for the last two years.

"This is an astonishing achievement - something we've been waiting for quite some time," said Robert Castle of Nasa, who was watching the link-up with Russian officials at the mission control headquarters in Korolyov.

The head of the Russian space agency, Yury Koptev, said that more government funding was needed to build on yesterday's success. "This event shows that Russia is still strong and developing as a superpower, and the government should support us."

Scientific research is not due to begin until the US-built Destiny module arrives in January. When the station is finished a crew of seven will work in six laboratories on projects in physics, gravitational biology, ecology, and earth and space science.

webTitle: Leader: Report published on the reform of sex offence laws

fields.headline: Law for a liberal age
fields.standfirst:
Recipe for more coherence on sex offences
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A government under attack for failing to defend family values must have blenched when it received the report published yesterday on the reform of sex offences.
fields.body:
A government under attack for failing to defend family values must have blenched when it received the report published yesterday on the reform of sex offences. How will the tabloids - and reborn Tories - respond to a report calling for the abolition of the offences of buggery and of gross indecency, and the cottaging laws? It is going to be easy to maliciously misrepresent this sane and sensible report, so it is important for progressives to set out clearly why it is so urgently needed. Our current laws are in a mess: illogical, discriminatory and incoherent. This is the most comprehensive review since the present patchwork - a mixture of statutes dating back to 1861 and common law cases even earlier - evolved. The 30-strong committee has produced a new framework, based on two principles: the need for stronger and more coherent laws to protect children and vulnerable people from non-consensual sex; but no interference with sexual activities between consenting adults in private.

It would sweep away the discriminatory laws on buggery and gross indecency in a bid to make our laws gender neutral. Men could not be prosecuted for chatting each other up - even in a public lavatory - but there would be a new offence against engaging in sex in a public place, to protect people from offence or alarm. In this new liberal age, gay men would have even less reason to go to public lavatories to find partners.

On rape and the shamefully low proportion of cases leading to a conviction (a miserable 9%), the report refuses to reverse the burden of proof on the issue of consent. Campaigners will be unhappy, but reversing the proof would be ruled out by the European Convention on Human Rights. Instead the report spells out a much clearer definition of consent and proposes that the law should include a list of examples where consent is not present: such as being deceived, drunk, or unable to resist from fear. This should make it easier for juries. It also proposes to lift the sentence for using drugs to stupefy victims from two up to seven years.

A new and more serious offence of persistent abuse would catch child abusers within families and staff in residential homes or schools. The law of incest would be extended to include adoptive, foster and step relatives. There will be no legislation this side of the election - consultation will continue until March - but yesterday Home Office ministers were encouragingly bullish.

webTitle: Fiji coup leader is arrested amid fears of new unrest

fields.headline: Fiji coup leader is arrested amid fears of new unrest
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: George Speight, the leader of the Fiji coup which sparked a 56-day hostage crisis, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of arms offences and threats to the president.
fields.body:
George Speight, the leader of the Fiji coup which sparked a 56-day hostage crisis, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of arms offences and threats to the president.

Mr Speight, who stormed the parliament in May and took most of the cabinet captive, was stopped at a bridge checkpoint in Kolabu, 12 miles east of Suva, where scores of his supporters have gathered.

"There's a number of allegations that were being brought to us about the carriage of arms in and around Suva by Speight and his bodyguards, and about threats to the head of state," a military spokesman, Lieutenant Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said.

There were no details about the alleged threats to Fiji's head of state, ailing 79-year-old President Ratu Josefa Iloilo.

Col Tarakinikini said that an amnesty granted to Mr Speight as part of the deal to secure the release of the hostages would only come into effect once all his weapons had been returned. A total of 18 M-16 rifles and pistols taken from military arsenals had still not been handed back, so the amnesty did not yet apply, he said in a statement.

"We cannot have private militias operating around the country," Col Tarakinikini told a local radio station.

The military earlier deployed troops across the racially-split country, fearing renewed civil unrest when a new government and possibly a new prime minister are named today.

Mr Speight had threatened new unrest if his nationalist candidate for prime minister, a 60-year-old diplomat, Adi Samanunu Cakobau, was not accepted in place of the military-backed caretaker prime minister, Laisenia Qarase. "The people could react," Mr Speight had warned.

Col Tarakinikini said that five warning shots were fired before Mr Speight was arrested along with his legal adviser, Tevita Bukaru, his media adviser, Jo Nata, and a bodyguard, Ireli Cakau.

He said that Mr Speight and his supporters would be held inside the Queen Elizabeth military barracks on a hilltop overlooking Suva.

Mr Speight and his gunmen stormed parliament on May 19 to demand more rights for indigenous Fijians. The rebels held Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, and most of his cabinet hostage for eight weeks before releasing them on July 13.

Mr Speight won widespread support among Fijian nationalists in his bid to limit the political power of Fiji's Indian community, which makes up 44% of the islands' 800,000 population and dominates the tourism and sugar-based economy which has been hit hard by the political crisis.

Sporadic violence flared around Suva and other parts of the country in the wake of Mr Speight's coup, and the military declared martial law on May 29 in an attempt to restore order.

There was no immediate response from President Iloilo or Mr Qarase about Mr Speight's arrest or future government plans.

Local media reports said yesterday that the new government would be sworn in on Friday with Mr Qarase at its head. A presidential aide, Joe Brown, gave no indication of who would head the government.

International concern over Fiji's protracted political crisis grew yesterday, with Australia suggesting that there could be a role for the United Nations. Australian trades unions called for direct UN intervention.

New Zealand welcomed Mr Speight's arrest but warned it was too early to say whether calm would return.

The rebels held Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, and most of his cabinet hostage for eight weeks before releasing them on July 13. Mr Speight won widespread support among Fijian nationalists in his bid to limit the political power of Fiji's Indian community, which makes up 44% of the islands' 800,000 population and dominates the tourism and sugar-based economy which has been hit hard by the political crisis. Sporadic violence flared around Suva and other parts of the country in the wake of Mr Speight's coup, and the military declared martial law on May 29 in an attempt to restore order. There was no immediate response from President Iloilo or Mr Qarase about Mr Speight's arrest or future government plans. Local media reports said yesterday that the new government would be sworn in on Friday with Mr Qarase at its head. A presidential aide, Joe Brown, gave no indication of who would head the government. International concern over Fiji's protracted political crisis grew yesterday, with Australia suggesting that there could be a role for the United Nations. Australian trades unions called for direct UN intervention. New Zealand welcomed Mr Speight's arrest but warned it was too early to say whether calm would return. Reuters

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents/Internet Dreamers
fields.body:
There is, apparently, no easy way to translate "think tank" into Khalkha, the language of Outer Mongolia. So the female network established there a decade ago to introduce post-Communist democracy to a society which had never known it, has been dubbed "The Liberal Women's Brain Pool". Tim Whewell discovers in Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) how its members are getting on. He finds that one of their advantages in this nomadic culture is that women have long been accepted as group decision-makers.

As you browse through your daily emails, spare a thought for Joseph Carl Robnett Licklider. Joseph who? He was the behavioural psychologist at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology who originated the idea of an internet way back in 1962. Even in Tim Marlow's three-part history of Internet Dreamers (8.0pm, Radio 4) he gets little more than a passing nod. Yet he has probably had as great an impact on his age as Einstein.

webTitle: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play Mick Jagger in a film about his life?
fields.trailText: Who will play Mick Jagger in a film about his life?
fields.body:
Jude Law .......................1-4

Jim Carrey .....................4-1

Dexter Fletcher ..............5-1

Mick Jagger .................. 6-1

James Ferris ............... 10-1

Boasting a script about the rock'n'roll industry written by Mick Jagger himself, the second project from Jagged Films, the production company headed up by the Rolling Stones frontman, definitely has the smell of autobiography about it. But who will they get to play old rubber lips?

"When God made Mick Jagger he threw away the mould, and then sold it later to the producers of Spitting Image," says Ladbrokes' analytical guru Ed Nicholson. How then, Ed, can a real version play this extraordinary person? Could the lips be added as prosthetics?

"Mick Jagger has rubber lips, but Jim Carrey has a complete rubber face," says Ed. "He achieved critical mass through films like The Mask, and critical acclaim in The Truman Show. But the big glitch is that Jim is American.

"There have been reports that Mick wants Jude Law to play him. The Oscar-nominated actor mixes tension, grace and danger," says Ed. "And those are certainly three characteristics you'd need to play Jagger."

There's a slim chance that Mick could play himself. He's already taken the role of a drug-addled, feral young icon in the psychedelic 70s film Performance. "But quite what they'd do for the early years is anyone's guess," says Ed. "I don't think this is likely to happen."

Of course there's always an option for the rock'n'roll flick to go spoof-style. That's when James Ferris, a well known Mick Jagger lookalike, could step into the role. "But with all the parties, meet and greets and concerts, he's probably busier than Mick Jagger is."

Ed reckons on another lookalike. "An outsider - Dexter Fletcher. He could have been a Jagger lovechild - the facial similarities are amazing." But what are the odds on Jagger having a lovechild? "We could ask Mick himself, but I'm sure he'll be keeping those lips tightly shut."

webTitle: Birds of a feather

fields.headline: Birds of a feather
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Andrew Gilchrist
fields.trailText: Phobias/Celebrity Rehab
fields.body:
Jacqueline Kelly is so terrified of birds she once abandoned her three-year-old daughter on a Tenerife beach when a pigeon landed nearby. Did I say nearby? Actually, it was 100 yards away, but that was enough to send the Manchester mother, who is even petrified of feathers, screaming back to the hotel.

Spliced with sudden shots of swooping birds and screechy Hitchcockian music, Jacqueline's story was the highlight of Phobias (BBC1), an enjoyably light look at everyday people we're glad we're not like. This was no mean feat given that case study number two was Christine Keeler (great name!), a chef from Norfolk who, we learned, developed a mice phobia after her mother accidentally baked one in a pie.

The programme followed Christine and Jacqueline (whose fear derived from wit nessing, 35 years ago, the crazed flappings of a bird trapped in her granny's house) on their occasionally hilarious search for salvation. Jacqueline turned to local hynotherapist Costa Lambrias who, beneath a giant poster of a sun-drenched, palm-strewn beach, tried to "recondition her subconscious" by making her think nice thoughts about nice places. It seemed to work. They went outside and watched a magpie alight on a chimney. Barely a quiver from Jacqueline. Then a pigeon appeared and it was back to Costa's soft furnishings for a sob.

Meanwhile, to give the programme scientific depth, Christine was popped into a giant brain scanner and shown mice pictures. Terms like "a surge of blood in the hippocampus" were bandied about. This was in marked contrast to the language used later by Dr Roger Callahan, a Californian therapist who charged $3,000 for "thought field therapy". Looking like he'd just come in from the Jerry Springer Show, and living in a mansion that wouldn't have been out of place in Costa's beach poster, Dr Rog promised to cure Christine over the phone - by having her tap two fingers against her skin, just below her right eye, while thinking about mice.

It was meant to trigger an acupuncture point but didn't work. "This", said Dr Rog, as I braced myself for a complicated scientific explanation, "is what we call... a very complex phobia." Next, Christine was told to drape herself in a towel, since Dr Rog, despite being 6,000 miles away, had detected that her T-shirt was toxic and interfering with the treatment.

Jacqueline and Christine were eventually cured through some straightforward exposure therapy on the black leather sofas of the medically qualified. Within 45 minutes Jacqueline was stroking a feather and, to celebrate, went off to feed ducks with her daughter. Christine wrote the word mouse 24,720 times (previously impossible even once) and ended up giving one a big smacker on the lips.

This gently sympathetic programme ended on an appropriately bizarre note. Christine got her back tattooed with a cartoon mouse sporting a buck-toothed grin.

Celebrity Rehab (Channel 4) had plenty of rehab but was somewhat short on the celebrity front, unless John Reid, ex-manager of Elton John, is your idea of an A-list pin-up. Clarissa Dickson Wright, Marc Almond, Jim Davidson and Chris Difford (he was in Squeeze, a pop group) were wheeled out to offer such staggering insights on the fine art of going cold turkey as: "It's quite tough."

Featuring much clunky visual padding - an out-of-focus reconstruction of people actually drinking beer in a bar was particularly unmemorable - Celebrity Rehab was a sad reminder that stars are generally lots more fun when they're on a drug-fuelled bender than when they're trying to get off one. Nevertheless, there were some gems, such as Jim Davidson recalling his flight from a clinic: he ran at the pond, swore at the ducks, then dashed off to hide in the woods, covering himself with leaves. No one came looking.

The most telling testimony came not from a celebrity but from Lesley Lloyd, widow of Kevin, the alcoholic who played Tosh Lines in The Bill. She used to stock the fridge up with every type of booze imaginable so that maybe, just maybe, Kevin would be there for family lunch on Sundays. She deserved an Oscar, she said, for all the acting she'd had to do.

webTitle: The rat race

fields.headline: The rat race
fields.standfirst: A weekly look at the state of play in the Big Brother house
fields.trailText: A weekly look at the state of play in the Big Brother house
fields.body:
On Tuesday evening as the clocks were striking 6.05pm, Big Brother collated the one-on-one diary-room confidences of the sealed house and informed his charges that the public must choose either hippy Sada or the shockingly lip-lined Caroline for expulsion. During tomorrow night's live show (8.30pm, C4), the results of the phone vote will be announced, and the first outcast will take tentative steps back into civilised society via a post mortem on Davina McCall's follow-up programme.

While most of us reel at the fact that no one voted against toxic Nicholas, it's becoming increasingly clear that, contrary to the stern pronouncements on the credits and billboards, we're not going to decide at all. According to the Big Brother website - vague about its sources - Nicholas's quasi-racism struck a jarring chord with right-minded Channel 4 viewers, earning him instant villain status that should have seen him evicted with dizzying speed.

No such luck. And the ugly scenes of celebration he instigated in the boys' bedroom following the announcement of the proposed outcasts merely confirmed our worst suspicions. But given that Big Brother - human interest revolving around emotional masochism - will snare more female than male viewers, such behaviour should guarantee Nicholas's swift removal when his time comes, which surely it must.

And even though Ladbrokes have Melanie as 5-2 favourite to win, clever money should go on an inoffensive boy, free of the guiles and lap-perching tendencies that will inevitably grate against a wised-up audience. Someone whose faintly silly, psychotically upbeat manner will help him win friends and influence people within the house.

Craig, for example. The ineffectual builder who carries a whiff of J from 5ive with him. Whack your hard-earned dollar on him.

webTitle: A family affair

fields.headline: A family affair
fields.standfirst: Frank Zappa said they were better than the Beatles. But they only managed to make one album before fading into obscurity.  Bob Stanley thinks we just weren't ready for the Shaggs - until now
fields.trailText: Frank Zappa said they were better than the Beatles. But they only managed to make one album before fading into obscurity. Bob Stanley thinks we just weren't ready for the Shaggs - until now
fields.body:
The all-singin', all-dancin', all-family pop group has long been a fertile breeding ground for great drama and unintentional comedic moments. Sure, there have been some roaring successes - the Jacksons (give or take the odd breakdown) and a slew of imitators like the Osmonds and the Sylvers - but the other end of the spectrum is something of a freak show. The usual ingredients for a sibling pop group are Shirley Temple wholesomeness, cute falsettos and a domineering parent. Britain's answer to Donny and Little Jimmy were the strange, cuddly-rodent-like James Boys, whose mum proudly told the BBC: "People in the business must take over the boys and exploit them - I have a house to run." Yet even the James Boys in full chipmunk regalia couldn't outweird the Wiggin sisters, better known as the Shaggs.

The Shaggs released one LP, Philosophy Of The World, in 1970, then sat back and waited for the world to catch up. Legendarily rare, a copy was picked up by WCBN-FM in Boston and championed by Keith Spring, of obscure but adventurous band NRBQ, who secured a re-issue on Rounder in 1980. Reactions were extreme - the New York Times called it "the best worst rock album ever made". Most thought it was an elaborate hoax. The singing is flat, the guitars are out of tune, and only once on the whole album does the drummer hit the beat (on the intro to the tortured Why Do I Feel). Philosophy Of The World is awful by any musical definition, but is so obviously innocent and heartfelt (songs about pets and parents, titles like My Companion) that it exists and succeeds in a dimension all of its own. The original sleevenote said succinctly: "You know they are pure, what more can you ask?"

Dorothy, Betty and Helen Wiggin grew up in a small New Hampshire town called Fremont, a place obscure enough, according to their liner notes, that it "encouraged them to develop their music unaffected by outside influences". In spite of this spartan isolation, their dad, Austin Wiggin Jr, played a jew's-harp and had the radio on permanently - the girls dug Herman's Hermits and Dino Desi And Billy. Little Helen had a soft spot for Ricky Nelson. Austin Jr had always wanted music lessons as a kid and actively encouraged his daughters. Betty and Dot took guitar and voice lessons for a year, Helen was the drummer. At high school they carried on taking lessons through the mail and, by 1969, Austin Jr thought they were ready to cut a record. "I want to get them while they're hot," he told the engineer. Nobody else thought they were ready, least of all the girls: "We didn't feel we knew that much about music. [Dad] gave us a lot of support. He backed us up all the way."

Austin Jr naively trusted a local entrepreneur to release the album on a label called Third World, but after receiving one box of records the label and its owner disappeared with the Wiggins' money. You could say that a father's love is unconditional or you could call Austin Wiggin a visionary. Philosophy Of The World is one of the most honest and expressive records ever made. It's completely free of pretension and self-awareness. Obviously this sets the artists up for all manner of cynical abuse, but the recent rediscovery of similarly untarnished soulmates like English folk singer Vashti Bunyan and American harmony group the Free Design (sample songtitles: Kites Are Fun, My Brother Woody) indicates that there's a substantial, non-ironic audience for the Shaggs.

Which couldn't be said in 1980 when Philosophy Of The World got its first large-scale release. Frank Zappa said the Shaggs were "better than the Beatles", which was stupid. Worse, the album inspired a wave of faux-naive groups like the execrable Beat Happening - students singing like horses hardly equated to the love and spirit behind Philosophy Of The World. Jonathan Richman, genuine naif if ever there was one, says: "The Shaggs convince me that they're the real thing when they sing."

With the Shaggs so easily misunderstood, you fear for what Hollywood could make of them. There was a rumour a few years back that closet 60s pop aficionado Tom Cruise had bought the rights to the Wiggin sisters' story. Suddenly the film is back on the agenda - Katherine (A Good Baby) Dieckmann is set to direct. A biopic of the group Lester Bangs once called "the anti-power trio" could be as risible as Oliver Stone's The Doors. Or it could be the best film about naive art since Tony Hancock's The Rebel. Here's hoping.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: In Search Of History: The Mysterious Howard Hughes/ All That Jazz/Playing God/The English Patient
fields.body:
In Search Of History: The Mysterious Howard Hughes

12noon, History Channel

Hughes was a daring aviator, film-maker and inventor blessed with matinée idol looks - even after his famous plane crash which broke every bone in his body. He died without leaving a will, kicking off one of America's lengthiest and more bizarre probate cases. We get no closer to solving the mysteries of his life, but if you want to hear the testimony of "experts" who know less than you do, and see the vultures who came sniffing after the dead man's lucre, then this is the show for you.

All That Jazz

(Bob Fosse, 1979)

9pm, Carlton Cinema

With Fosse, the musical celebration of the director-choreographer's work slaying 'em in the West End, this is a timely showing for his grand autobiographical movie. Giuseppe Rotunno's photography is superb and the dancing is stunning, but the meat of the movie is in Roy Scheider's performance as Joe Gideon. A hell of a testimony to Fosse's wild talent.

Playing God

(Andy Wilson, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Arresting but silly drama starring X-Files investigator David Duchovny as a drug-addled, struck-off surgeon who gets the chance to work again, courtesy of gangster Timothy Hutton, who wants someone to patch up his henchmen. Debut director Wilson barely summons the nasty edge of his small-screen Cracker, but the dialogue is snappy and in the hip cast are Angelina Jolie and Peter Stormare.

The English Patient

(Anthony Minghella, 1996)

11.40pm FilmFour

The arty tale of hot sex that mopped up nine Oscars. It has Ralph Fiennes' cerebral and detached Almasy drawn into a passionate, adulterous affair with sparkling newlywed Katharine (Kristin Scott Thomas) while on a North African mapping expedition at the start of the second world war. The action switches forward and back to Almasy, in an Italian monastery, now burnt and being cared for by nurse Juliette Binoche. Minghella's film has the beauty of pure romantic epic.

fields.standfirst: How to get a geyser to blow * Cherubs at work * Why cameras stay on one side of the pitch
fields.trailText: How to get a geyser to blow * Cherubs at work * Why cameras stay on one side of the pitch
fields.body:
I once saw a TV science programme in which the presenter encouraged a quietly steaming Icelandic geyser to dramatically "blow" a few seconds later by tipping into it a large quantity of soap bars. Can anyone explain this phenomenon?

* I have seen this done. The geyser pool is at the top of a hole in the ground, perhaps 50m or more deep, full of water, which is continuously heated from the bottom by the adjacent mass of hot rock. Just before a natural "blow" the water towards the bottom will have reached a temperature well above normal boiling point, but it is prevented from boiling by pressure from the column above. Left to itself, the water will eventually become too hot for this unstable situation to persist; steam bubbles will form, and the geyser spontaneously "blows". To please an impatient audience, a travel guide can induce premature discharge by dropping soap into the pool. Arriving near the bottom, the soap starts to dissolve; as with any other solute, its presence depresses the boiling point of water, and steam-bubbles start to form and rise. Their arrival at the top usually causes a violent spillage of some water out of the pool. This reduces the weight of the column and its pressure, causing boiling of the whole column, as in a natural eruption.

Tom Hering, Kegworth, Derby.

Just outside London's Liverpool Street station, between the tracks and the arches, there are a number of small "memorial-type" statues. What are they?

* The statues are some of the surviving decorative pieces of stone and brickwork from the old Liverpool Street station buildings that were demolished in the 1980s as part of the station redevelopment. Some of the carved stonework came from the old Hamilton House railway offices fronting Bishopsgate. Some of these show the initials GER (Great Eastern Railway), which built Liverpool Street station. There are also some examples of carved brickwork, shaped in the form of a half circle. There were originally six of these high on the wall of the building that was behind the concourse of platforms 11-18 of the old station. They depicted railway activities (signalman, porter, fireman, etc.) being undertaken by cherub-like beings. One of these has been incorporated into the new station, and at least one is in the site mentioned. The others seem to have been destroyed. The new station incorporates the carving mentioned as well as two others from the old station, one depicting a train and the other a ship. The war memorial and other memorial tablets from the old station have also survived and are on prominent display.

Nigel Bowdidge, Brentwood, Essex.

Does the human race have a future longer than its past?

* Not according to the ancient Mayan people of South America. They claim that every cycle of life has five "suns", or ages, each of which is ended by a natural disaster, be it global freezing, a great meteor or a great flood. Their highly detailed calendar, which has predicted other events (such as the first world war) with great accuracy, shows us to be now living in the fifth, and last, sun of our life on earth. Furthermore, they have predicted that the present age will come to an end on December 23, 2012, in such a way that no human life will survive it.

Hannah Rawlinson, Accra, Ghana.

* Professor Joss Hawthorne is barking up the wrong science if he seeks support for an infinite human future from Frank Tipler (Notes & Queries, July 13). Tipler envisages a finality to human evolution which negates the idea of an infinite future. Tipler's thesis is that there will come a specific point in time in the remote but finite future at which the human project will be complete. In his book, The Anthropic Cosmological Principle, Tipler and John D Barrow state that there is a logical conclusion or end-state to human progress. They state that humanity is destined to expand into the universe and gather all knowledge. When all the knowledge that it is logically possible to acquire has been gathered, the Omega Point will have been reached. This will be an omnipotent entity which will reverse time and raise the dead. The final sentence in Tipler and Barrow's book is: "And this is the end."

Peter Stockill, Berwick Hills, Middlesbrough.

Why are some countries, such as the Gambia, prefixed with "the", even when they are not plural (like the Netherlands)?

* There appear to be three rules: where countries are named after rivers or mountain ranges, for example, the Gambia, the Lebanon; where the final noun in the name is preceded by an adjective and/or "of", for example, the United Kingdom, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Czech Republic; and for the plural names of island groups, for example, the Philippines, the Grenadines (islands or archipelagos ending in -a or -ia never take "the"). Of course, the rules in other European languages are completely different - for example, la France and die Schweiz .

Alaisdair Raynham, Singapore.

* There is a perfectly logical explanation as to why the country called Ukraine used to take a definite article. Under the Russian Empire, the part of Eastern Europe that is currently Ukraine and part of eastern Poland constituted the borderlands of the Empire - in Russian "krai" ("edge"). The Russian preposition "u", which is attached to the word "krai" as a prefix, means "at". This gives us the name "Ukraina", or "The Edge of the Empire/Borderland". The former use of the definite article in English (which does not exist in Russian) represented linguistic recognition of the political reality that what was then "The Ukraine" constituted the western limits of the Russian, and later the Soviet, empire. Since Ukraine became an independent country it has become a requirement in politically correct English to drop the article in deference to the fact that Ukraine, as an independent state, can no longer be considered a borderland territory of Russia.

Brian Keegan, Paris.

* To question Jim Burfield's assertion (Notes & Queries, July 6) that The Hague is the only town on earth whose English name takes "The", a quick look in my atlas gives The Bight in the Bahamas, The Dalles in the USA, The Pas in Canada and The Rock and The Twins in Australia.

Mike Rayner, Pity Me, Durham.

* In Welsh we have Y Wyddfa for The Snowdon and Yr Albion for The Scotland among others.

Bryn Gwyndaf Jones, Welwyn

Garden City, Herts.

When a football match is televised, why is the camera always on only one side of the pitch?

* In film and television production a principle exists called the 180 degree rule: that two cameras should not face each other when filming the same subject. The reason for this is to stop the audience from becoming confused and disorientated. When you are watching from the stadium, you will sit on one side of the pitch, looking from one direction. When you watch the match on TV, you will watch the game from several angles thanks to the multi-camera set up.

If the director was following a player with a camera on, say, the north side of the stadium then cut to another camera on the south side, the player on the screen will suddenly have appeared to change direction. If the second camera is on the same side of the pitch the player will continue in the same direction on the screen - this is called a "match on action". The same principle is used in most sports.

Mike Harris, Colerne, Wilts.

Why do cigarette packets in vending machines have only 16 fags in them?

* For many years I worked in an American restaurant in London which had a machine dispensing packets containing 16 cigarettes. It was not possible to add the cost of the cigarettes to the restaurant bill, but as a courtesy the waiters would take the customers' change, get the cigarettes and return them to the table. On one occasion, an elderly American couple called me over to the table. "I'm sorry to have to report this", the husband said, "but your waiter has stolen four of my cigarettes!" No amount of explanation seemed to convince him otherwise. Needless to say, US cigarette vending machines dispense packs of 20.

Russell Norman, London NW6.

Any answers?

I was brought up to believe that British subjects had certain freedoms - freedom of movement, assembly, speech etc, trial by jury, presumption of innocence, habeas corpus and so on. Do these rights still exist in full, or have they been curtailed by legislation?

Matthew Lagden, London N16.

A man was recently arrested for singing whilst riding a bike through the City of London at night. The arrest was apparently because an unrepealed 17th-century law exists forbidding song in the square mile at night. Why was such a law ever made?

Liz Finney, London W4.

As the 20th century apparently only lasted 99 years, is the Queen Mother really 101?

Steve Parish, Warrington.

My student son lives on beans, wholemeal toast and oranges in term time. He claims this gives him all the nutrients he requires. Is he right?

Rosalind Lloyd, Acton, London W3

The past 50 years have seen a vast increase in consumption of canned carbonated drinks and lager-type beers which are pressurised using carbon dioxide. Does this use of gas contribute to global warming?

Martin King, Hastings, East Sussex.

Which was the first book to include review quotes on its cover (as opposed to the back panel)? And is there any evidence that this disfiguring practice actually increases sales?

Paul Bowes, Caersws, Powys.

Why is it that to express disapproval we boo, whereas most other people whistle?

Frank Silverman, London SW2.

webTitle: US 'needs allies in defence'

fields.headline: US 'needs allies in defence'
fields.standfirst: British radar site is vital
fields.trailText: Washington's plans for a national missile defence system against "rogue states" cannot succeed without the approval of its Nato allies.
fields.body:
Washington's plans for a national missile defence system against "rogue states" cannot succeed without the approval of its Nato allies, including Britain, the US defence secretary, William Cohen, has told the Senate armed forces committee.

It relied on radar stations abroad, he said: a reference to the early warning bases at Fylingdales in north Yorkshire and Thule in Greenland, which belongs to Denmark.

Without X-band radars overseas, he said, "You can't see the missiles coming. Therefore, your interceptors really are not worth very much."

In his evidence, reported yesterday, he said the failure of a missile interceptor in a test on July 8 "called into question the realism" of having a system in place by the current target of 2005, though that date should remain the goal for a limited shield.

President Bill Clinton was expected to decide next month whether to start work on a radar station in Alaska next spring, Mr Cohen said.

He played down cooperative overtures by Kim Jong-il of North Korea, and the Korean summit last month, saying: "One summit doesn't change a tiger into a domestic cat."

webTitle: Talking dirty

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
"If I could reinvent myself, I'd put the mind I have today in the head of the beautiful young actress who was seduced by James Bond"
Former Bond girl Madeline Smith, 50, Daily Mail

"Rather than spend 20 minutes at an audition convincing people you're more than just tits and arse, you say you've got a degree from Cambridge and it's amazing how it cuts through the crap"
Thandie Newton, Mirror

"Witnessing the female staff cooing over the male models who slouched through the door, I was left thinking that, for any woman to find you attractive, you had to have bulging muscles and a smug, one-sided grin. A few years later I realised I'd been labouring under a misconception. Women look at shirtless Diet Coke men in the same way I look at a Ferrari - very exciting but a bugger to run"
Damon Syson on his time working on a women's magazine, Express

"Hollywood doesn't understand how to make films with women. Even the women now in power don't understand how to create good, character-driven films for women. The executives, regardless of their sex, are interested in films that can make $20 million the first weekend. That usually means one thing if it involves a big female part: something with Julia Roberts and seven men"
Shirley MacLaine, Hello!

"Feminists who say they don't need men are cooking up trouble for themselves because it's a message some men like to hear. It means they can be irresponsible and feckless. When men are told they are not needed, they don't go off and form a little commune somewhere. They become - well, I don't say it is the cause of football hooliganism but it is a factor"
Anthony Clare, Evening Standard

webTitle: Battlefield falls without a fight

fields.headline: Battlefield falls without a fight
fields.standfirst: The Scots are building houses on the site of William Wallace's victory over the English.  Maxton Walker, a local, is not impressed
fields.trailText: The Scots are building houses on the site of William Wallace's victory over the English. Maxton Walker, a local, is not impressed.
fields.body:
I have fond memories of the Bannockburn heritage centre just outside Stirling. I learned to do handbrake turns in my dad's car in the car park there one icy morning in the late 80s. The heritage centre stands near the field where the Scottish flag was raised on the day that Robert the Bruce thrashed Edward I's English army in 1314. Next to the heritage centre is my parents' local, a pub called the 1314 Inn. It's the ugliest building I've ever seen - a concrete box squatting next to a main road.

The 1314 Inn always worried me when I was growing up. Did Scotland's tourism bosses really think that people who had traipsed halfway around the world to see where Robert the Bruce had defeated the English army in 1314 might fancy a warm pint in a shabby concrete boozer afterwards? But it illustrates the way many people in Stirling regard their national heritage. Sometimes I think that if the Taj Mahal had been built in Bannockburn it would now be a Post Office depot.

So I was hardly surprised at the news earlier this week that the local council in Stirling has given the go-ahead for houses to be built on another site on the battlefield. They have always been alarmingly relaxed about the national heritage under their stewardship. Their priorities are more "progressive" than that. You can never have too many pubs, after all.

The present heritage centre at Bannockburn is hardly a world-beater. There's always been something tangibly desolate about the place - a windswept field on the edge of a housing estate with a concrete sculpture, a flagpole and a statue of Robert the Bruce. And we're lucky to have even that. Thirty years ago it too almost fell victim to the property developers until a benefactor saved it for the nation. But instead of a monument to the legendary warriors who gave Scotland a sense of national pride and identity, it feels vaguely tawdry.

Perhaps it's because people are too apathetic to care. But that seems unlikely. Scottish schoolchildren have the significance of these events mercilessly drummed into them. Some of my most vivid memories from my time at Wallace High School (named after William "Braveheart" Wallace) are the history lessons about the 700-year-old battles for independence. Even at that age, the delicious sense of nonconformism wasn't lost on us. Here were our teachers openly imbuing us with tales of rebellion. And it only enriched the experience for me that I was sitting on the very ground where the English blood had been spilt.

So why do these attempts to erase our past continue? Stirling is, admittedly, something of a special case. It's groaning under the weight of history. The place is littered with ancient buildings: a medieval cathedral, an ancient abbey and the best old-town walls in Scotland. The authorities must feel there's a law of diminishing returns. With so much else for tourists to see, a field doesn't seem so important. And, of course, there's always the visitor centre. Do we really need another one?

Aside from the obvious ethical concerns, the issue also betrays a woeful complacency. The leaders of many towns would kill for Stirling's tourist business. But if tourists start to feel short-changed, there are plenty of other countries with ruins on offer.

Ultimately, though, the current state of affairs in Stirling is unforgivable. And it seems to be part of a national malaise. When it comes to packaging ancient history, the English can be inspired in their torpor-inducing initiatives. The Stonehenge visitor centre, for one, is a national disgrace. But one could argue that the standing stones are too old to be a cultural reference point for the nation. Stirling's tourist attractions deal with the defining moments of Scotland's history. They're not only historically important but - as the country flirts with independence - symbolically significant.

Possibly, though, I'm being too hard on Stirling. It is still a magical place, and the authorities aren't totally ignorant of the need to bring these historical events to life (although perhaps we should draw a veil over the plan to erect a William Wallace statue with Mel Gibson's face on it). One can only hope that it will stay that way in the years to come - despite the authorities' worst efforts.

Of course, you may disagree. We need to move with the times, after all. So I'd be quite happy to talk it over. The only proviso is that we do it over a pint in the 1314 Inn. I don't expect many takers.
