webTitle: Shock of the new

fields.headline: Shock of the new
fields.standfirst: The Victoria and Albert Museum is finally trying to drag itself into the 21st century. But why are so many people determined to stop it?  Jonathan Glancey  reports
fields.trailText: The Victoria and Albert Museum is finally trying to drag itself into the 21st century. But why are so many people determined to stop it?
fields.body:
Unlike Tate Modern or the Science Museum or any other gallery or museum with a clear-cut purpose and collection, the Victoria and Albert Museum is a hybrid - or, as the art critic Brian Sewell puts it, "a dog's dinner". Its 12 acres of buildings house 1.5m objects - furniture, fashion and musical instruments, ironwork, glassware, prints, drawings and pots - as well as 1m-plus books. Turnover is £40m; staff number 800. It is the sort of place where one expects to unlock a panelled door and stumble across a long-dead curator, quill in hand, who never quite finished a catalogue entry on the neo-Etruscan escutcheon plates of north Staffordshire, 1776-7.

The museum boasts an all but forgotten collection of British paintings tucked away in the Henry Cole Wing, and has just become home to the Royal Institute of British Architects' drawings collection. In 2001 it will open the British Galleries, £30m of quietly interactive displays and British decorative art and design to the present day.

Yet the V&A can never be all things to all men and women. Visitor numbers are falling, from a peak of 1.8m per year in the late 80s, when admission was free, to under 1m today, when tickets cost £5. And whenever it attempts to be vaguely hip and modern, it only brings out the worst in the traditionalists who believe it should do nothing but conserve the contents of its mighty "handbag", as Sir Roy Strong, a former director, describes it.

Richard Dorment, art critic of the Daily Telegraph, is certainly not impressed. He described the current exhibition of Ron Arad's contempo rary furniture in the medieval galleries as an "abomination" - like "a heavy metal band playing at top volume during a performance of Guillaume de Machaut's Messe de Notre Dame". The comparison is snobbish, hysterical - and depressingly predictable.

Even more unsettling to traditionalists is that the museum seems bent on spending money it hasn't even got on a dramatic £80m extension, the Spiral, designed by Daniel Libeskind, architect of the haunting Jewish Museum in Berlin. With one broadsheet journalist comparing Libeskind's revolutionary design to "the Guggenheim in Bilbao turned on its side and then beaten senseless with a hammer" (it is nothing of the sort) stick-in-the-muds will feel all the more justified in their belief that the V&A will be, as Dorment puts it, "visually raped".

It is at times like this that decisive management is most needed. Instead, the V&A offers confusion. On the one hand, it has a director, Alan Borg. On the other, it doesn't, because Borg is due to leave in some 18 months. The trustees themselves have been dismissed as "a second-rate bunch of uneducated political placemen and women" by Stephen Bayley, design consultant and one-time director of the Boilerhouse Project, the V&A's shortlived forerunner of the Design Museum. They are indeed a mixed bunch, although six new trustees are to be appointed this autumn.

Sadly, the way the V&A has set about looking for a new director damns the new appointee from the start. The trustees have insisted that Borg's replacement be both creative director and chief executive - a role too big for one person. Like the British Museum, the V&A would do better to split the job in two. Those in the running for the job are the usual suspects - Charles Saumarez Smith of the National Portrait Gallery, Simon Thurley of the Museum of London (who has told his staff he doesn't want the job) and Timothy Clifford of the National Galleries of Scotland, who was pipped to the post in 1995. There are others who have protested in private they would never apply for such a job but in reality will be unable to keep their CVs at bay.

Some of these are avowed traditionalists. Others, like some of the museum's trustees, doubt the wisdom of building the Spiral, which is planned as a gallery of contemporary design that will have a knock-on effect throughout the museum. It is here that the confusion is greatest. The Spiral, progressing towards construction under the direction of Gwyn Miles, the V&A's unflappable head of major developments, is intended to be not a separate gallery, but a focal point for ideas, events and exhibi tions in the museum as a whole. It will be as different from the conservative Design Museum in south London as can be imagined. Research for the project is at an advanced stage, and ideas have been garnered from around the world as well as from within the V&A. I know this because I have been working as an unpaid advisor to the project.

To reshape itself as the proactive, questioning, controversial arena of design, arts and architecture that it was always meant to be, the V&A needs to sort out its structure and administration. It needs to do what it does well as it learns to change - pursuing, for example, an art deco exhibition after the successful current art nouveau show. It needs to avoid being fey or quirky as it brings the contemporary design world further into its heart. It needs fresh faces to work alongside the best existing curators. It needs the support of the Department of Culture as it reinvents itself. It needs to ride out the storms of adverse publicity.

If - and this is a big if - the V&A decides to be safe and cosy and imagines itself solely as the custodian of old treasures, if it is unable to lead but merely reflects on past glories to the tune of de Machaut's Messe de Notre Dame, it will fall into a long and dusty decline. But this would be an insult to both the museum's staff and those of us who have come here since childhood looking for inspiration to fire the imagination - not to have it doused by fogeys.

webTitle: Sounds divine

fields.headline: Sounds divine
fields.standfirst: The ondes martenot, the synth's ugly older brother, is coming to the Proms.  Stuart Jeffries  rejoices
fields.trailText: The ondes martenot, the synth's ugly older brother, is coming to the Proms. Stuart Jeffries rejoices.
fields.body:
The first electronic musical instruments were hardly beautiful objects. The theremin, for instance, was a four-legged lump of a cabinet topped by an aerial and a looped antenna. It was invented in 1917 by a Russian emigre called Lev Termen and was played in a strange way: the player's hands move close to the antennae but do not touch them. It has a spooky, cosmic-violin sound that must have appealed to Lenin because he asked for lessons and commissioned 600 to be made.

The ondes martenot is even uglier: the instrument's keyboard stands free from the speaker, on top of which is a diffuser that looks like a bishop's mitre. And yet it is one of the most beautiful-sounding and, in Britain at least, unrecognised instruments invented in the last century.

The theremin and the ondes martenot were precursors of the synthesiser, and radical musicians in the early 20th century seized on them hungrily. The French composer Edgard Varèse, for example, was a particular fan. He first used it as a substitute for sirens in a performance of his Amériques in 1929.

Varèse was so taken with the instrument that he re-wrote his 1933-4 choral work Ecuatorial, replacing the original two theremins with two ondes martenots - the version that will be performed tonight in a Prom given by the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group.

"Varèse had really been waiting for the ondes martenot to be invented so he could express himself as he had wanted," says Valérie Hartmann-Claverie, one of the ondistes who will be performing Ecuatorial tonight. "He re-scored the piece for the ondes martenot because it has the right nuances and pitches."

But while the theremin became trapped in a repertoire of kitsch and cheesy effects, the ondes martenot has had a more distinguished, and very French, history. It was invented by Maurice Martenot - pianist, cellist, composer, and part-time electrician, who presented it to the public at a concert in 1928.

The ondes martenot demands unusual dexterity from the performer. The keyboard controls the frequency of a variable oscillator and the signal is radiated as sound from a loudspeaker. The right hand plays the keyboard, and each key is capable of slight lateral movement, microtonally shifting the pitch and enabling the performer to create a vibrato. So far, so much like the theremin: composers such as Varèse thrilled to the new possibilities these instruments gave, not least the opportunity to abandon the chromatic scale and write microtonal intervals.

But the ondes martenot can be played another way. The player attaches a finger ring to a ribbon and then sweeps the ribbon across a conducting strip that runs parallel to the keyboard. The left hand is used to control potentionmeters, which change the timbre and degree of amplification. This enables wide glissando sweeps and expressive portamentos undreamt of by Termen.

"It is an extremely difficult instrument to play. It's extraordinarily sensitive," says Hartmann-Claverie, who started playing the instrument at the age of 12. "For me, when I studied the instrument at the conservatoire in Paris, it was very much the instrument of our days."

She is typical of the many French musicians who have been captivated by the ondes martenot. Pierre Boulez briefly became a performer in the 40s and wrote an ondes martenot quartet just after the war. But arguably the greatest roles for the instruments were written by Messiaen. He wrote for six ondes martenot in F tes des Belles Eaux, and for one - to extraordinarily dramatic effect -in the Turangalla Symphony. He even put a gong in the diffuser, creating sounds that he described as "strange, mysterious and unreal when they are soft, or cruel, lacerating and terrifying when forceful". A wonderfully expressive instrument, then, well suited to a work about the divine action upon the cosmos, about love, life and death.

But isn't the ondes martenot now just a museum piece that has been replaced by more sophisticated electronic instruments? "Not at all," says Hartmann-Claverie. "There is a repertoire of more than 1,200 pieces. All the time we ask composers to write for us - and they do. The instrument has a bright future. I am sure of it."

The Birmingham Contemporary Music Group performs Varèse's Ecuatorial and Gerald Barry's Wiener Blut at the Albert Hall, London SW7 (020-7589 8212), tonight.

webTitle: Oh, for big shoulders and just-so hair

fields.headline: Oh, for big shoulders and just-so hair
fields.standfirst: Is Joan Collins right when she says inside every dowdy woman is a glamour girl longing to break out? Louisa Young  reports
fields.trailText: Is Joan Collins right when she says inside every dowdy woman is a glamour girl longing to break out? Louisa Young  reports.
fields.body:
Darling, gorgeous, beautiful Joan Collins has been having a go. Joan thinks that women today are not well-dressed and not well-groomed. She blames TV. Ah, Joan, you can lecture us on glamour any day. I'm sorry we disappoint you, you who, with your stockings and your shoulderpads and your hair just so, have cheered us up through so many movies and TV and magazine appearances.

Joan reportedly believes that "a lot of women would like to be" more glamorous but "the average woman doesn't know how". I suspect really she knows why we are not as glamorous as her. But in case she doesn't, I'll run through it - in a spirit more of explanation than of excuse.

Glamour is a form of bondage. Of course, unsmudged lipstick and tidy hair are not in the same league as bound feet and faintingly tight corsets, but they have the same origin. A woman who is glamorous cannot "do" anything other than be glamorous. She cannot run for the bus in her four-inch heels, she cannot type her masterpiece, wash up her children's tea, carve her great work, play her fabulous sonata or her winning serve with long, long nails. She can hardly walk in the tight skirt; she can't bend over without her bosoms falling out of the low-cut blouse. She can't go out in the rain because she will be flooded with gunk off her hair, which will give her the appearance of a less than glamorous drowned rat. All this is fine if she doesn't want or have to do anything. But we do. Plenty.

Glamour is time-consuming. Maintaining glamour is a full-time job, as Jilly Cooper pointed out in her novel Octavia: as soon as beautiful Octavia got a job, her looks went because she couldn't spend all day washing her hair, oiling her limbs, being massaged and buying lovely new clothes. Most of us have lives to live that take up our time and painting our toenails simply has to take its turn behind earning a living, running a home, having friends and/or family and/or fun and/or a lovelife ... Joan herself mentioned recently that she spent most of her time between takes on Dynasty wondering what to wear next. It's hard work, I can see that.

Glamour is expensive, too. I am currently considering looking glamorous for the glamorous Mayfair launch party of my novel, but the expense involved in looking glamorous even for one night is startling. Massage 40 quid, leg-wax 20 quid, pedicure 15, hairdresser 100, exotic facial (with seaweed) 60, new outfit, say, 200 (and I'm not looking at huge extravagance here, I'm not planning on going to Bond Street). Sixty quid for delightful new shoes. A tenner for a pair of sleek tights. Were I to be starting from scratch on make-up and skincare, that could easily be another couple of hundred. Twenty quid handcreams, 30 quid liposome gunk, 12 quid stay-put lipstick in Joan Collins red. Then taxis everywhere and all that dry-cleaning, only champagne to drink ...

In many ways it sounds fabulous, of course it does, but there's this thing, this real-life thing, that just gets in the way. In the old days, I suppose, we had servants and ladies' maids and dressers, and they did half the work for us. Unless of course we were servants or ladies' maids or dressers, in which case glamour - for goodness sake, girl, what are you thinking - would have been above our station. In fact, the more I think about it, the more I realise that the only suitable job for a woman who really wants to be glamorous is to be a film star.

Glamour can be embarrassing. I don't like crossing over to my limousine looking like a million dollars and passing a woman wearing an old sleeping bag and a piece of last season's cardboard. In these scary days, plenty of people want the security of looking like each other and if that means the unglamorous lowest common denominator, so be it.

But then there's that other glamour - glamour as Shakespeare used the word, the natural magical aura, the enchanting glamour, that some people, male or female, just have and everybody else wants either to have or, well, to have. That glamour, there is nothing you can do about. Marilyn Monroe, they say, could switch it on or off, but generally either you have it or you don't.

Joan Collins, of course, has it in buckets. As they used to say in the old days, gazing up in awe at the screen goddesses: "She could wear a sack and she'd look lovely, that one."

fields.headline: No: 1686
fields.standfirst: A Geordie
fields.trailText: A Geordie
fields.body:
Hoy, pet. How's it gannin' like? I'm very well, thank you for asking.

Why aye! So, aah hear ye want to find oot aboot Geordies? Actually, yes. The thing is, the Arts and Humanities Research Board has just received a grant of almost £1m to carry out a study of the north-east and its inhabitants.

Champion! Broons aal roond! What are they ganna gandie at like? Apparently they want to examine the region's historical, cultural, religious and sporting influences in an effort to pinpoint the true Geordie identity.

Canny! Aah'd hev thowt the'll want to knaa aboot the accent, then? Why yes, the origins of the local dialect will be one aspect of the study, as will the composition of the stottie cake and Newcastle Brown Ale.

Why, tha Toon broon! Indeed. Oh, and the researchers also intend to analyse Newcastle United FC and the impact on the area of its mixed fortunes over recent years.

Howay the Lads! Toon Army! Toon Army ! The very same.

Hadaway, man. Worraboot wor Captain Marvel? Ah yes, Alan Shearer. Well, the study will be taking the effect of his celebrity into account, alongside that of fellow natives such as Paul Gascoigne . . .

Why aye, wor Gazza! ... Sting, Bryan Ferry, Steve Cram and Brendan Foster.

Haad on a min't, man! Worraboot Donna Air? Ant 'n' Dec? Viz? Worraboot Jimmy Nail, pride o' tha Tyne? Don't worry old chap, I'm sure they'll be involved too.

Howay! Ah really divven't see tha point in this, hinny. Well, the basic idea is to try to dispel that old stereotype.

What ye talkin' aboot, man? You know, that old chestnut about Geordies only being interested in beer and football, always spoiling for a fight, and talking in an accent that's largely incomprehensible to anyone born south of Durham.

Ah, reet. That aad rubbish. (Silence.) Um, well, it's been champion talking ta ye and that, but ah'm gannin' hyem. Yes, OK. And a jolly old cheerio to you too!

Hadaway, man. Worraboot wor Captain Marvel? Ah yes, Alan Shearer. Well, the study will be taking the effect of his celebrity into account, alongside that of fellow natives such as Paul Gascoigne . . . Why aye, wor Gazza! ... Sting, Bryan Ferry, Steve Cram and Brendan Foster. Haad on a min't, man! Worraboot Donna Air? Ant 'n' Dec? Viz? Worraboot Jimmy Nail, pride o' tha Tyne? Don't worry old chap, I'm sure they'll be involved too. Howay! Ah really divven't see tha point in this, hinny. Well, the basic idea is to try to dispel that old stereotype. What ye talkin' aboot, man? You know, that old chestnut about Geordies only being interested in beer and football, always spoiling for a fight, and talking in an accent that's largely incomprehensible to anyone born south of Durham. Ah, reet. That aad rubbish. (Silence.) Um, well, it's been champion talking ta ye and that, but ah'm gannin' hyem. Yes, OK. And a jolly old cheerio to you too!

webTitle: Cesare Valletti

fields.headline: Cesare Valletti
fields.standfirst: Italian tenor excelling in opera's lyrical roles
fields.trailText: In the early post-war era, two tenors dominated the scene where the lighter, lyrical roles were concerned. One was Ferruccio Tagliavini, he of the honeyed tone; the other was the more stylish, sober Cesare Valletti, who has died aged 77.
fields.body:
In the early post-war era, two tenors dominated the scene where the lighter, lyrical roles were concerned. One was Ferruccio Tagliavini, he of the honeyed tone; the other was the more stylish, sober Cesare Valletti, who has died aged 77.

His compact, slightly reedy tone and effortless technique were ideal for the tenor parts in Mozart, Rossini and Donizetti, and in those he was considered the true successor to the legendary Tito Schipa: Valletti matched his great predecessor in terms of fastidious style as exemplified in well-nigh faultless phrasing.

His gifts were revealed to London's operatic public when he sang Fenton in Falstaff with the company of La Scala on its visit to Covent Garden in 1950. Here was the sweet, plangent tone and airy manner the role calls for, and some gift for acting. Unfortunately, he did not appear at the Royal Opera House again until 1958, when he was an impassioned Alfredo to Callas's legendary Violetta.

By then his voice had strengthened while losing little of its old beauty of timbre, so that he was able to sing Alfredo's denunciation of Violetta in Act Two with the requisite strength; in the Act One and Act Three duets his style and tone were as appealing as ever.

In the early 1960s, at the end of his foreshortened career, he gave a series of recitals at the Wigmore Hall of French and Italian repertory, which displayed his ease of manner and intelligence in a non-operatic context. His account of Pizzetti's I Pastori, a setting of a D'Annunzio poem about a shepherd longing for home, with its subtle inflections, still lingers in my mind, the very epitome of a certain kind of Italianate singing now seemingly lost. It is preserved on one of his RCA recital discs, which have become collectors' items. By then, unlike so many Italian tenors, he had become an accomplished recitalist.

The main part of Valletti's international career was at New York's Metropolitan, with whom he appeared, at the home house or on tour, 113 times, from his admired debut as an elegant and much-praised Don Ottavio in Don Giovanni in 1953 through until 1959, when he left in a huff after a row with the dictatorial director, Rudolf Bing. He was particularly feted for his Almaviva (The Barber of Seville) and Ernesto (Don Pasquale), but he also essayed the heavier parts of Pinkerton and Werther with appreciable success.

Valletti was born in Rome and studied privately until making his debut, as Alfredo, at Bari in 1947. He came to prominence when he sang Don Narcisco in Il turco in Italia, with Callas and Mariano Stabile also in the cast, at Rome in 1950. He was soon in demand in the major houses in Italy, and began to record for the Italian company Cetra.

Among several complete roles he adorned with his gracefully accomplished singing were Nemorino in Donizetti's L'elisir d'amore, Don Ramiro in Rossini's Cenerentola, and Lindor in the same composer's L'Italiana in Algeri. In all these roles he was sure-voiced, effortless in his fioriture and poised in his phrasing.

Later, in the 1950s, he was heard as Alfredo in a rewarding set of Traviata under Monteux for RCA, for whom he also recorded his Pinkerton. He also committed to disc extracts from two of his best parts in French opera, Massenet's Werther and Des Grieux. In all these his cleanly produced voice, innate musicality, clear diction, clean vowels and rare sense of style are to the fore and, of course, those qualities also informed his appearances on stage.

Valletti also appeared at the Vienna State Opera, at the Colón in Buenos Aires, and at Amsterdam and Paris. He sang Don Ottavio for Karajan at the 1960 Salzburg Festival. After a vocal crisis in 1967, he decided to retire and became a successful businessman in the pasta-making business of his second wife's father. He made one further appearance, in 1968, at the Caramoor Festival in the US as Nero in L'incoronazione di Poppea.

Cesare Valletti, Italian tenor, born December 18 1922; died May 14 2000

webTitle: Neuma Goncalves da Silva

fields.headline: Neuma Goncalves da Silva
fields.standfirst: First lady of samba with a mission to help Rio's shantytown children
fields.trailText: Neuma Goncalves da Silva, who has died aged 78, was a leading light in one of Rio's most famous samba "schools", Mangueira.
fields.body:
Neuma Goncalves da Silva, who has died aged 78, was a leading light in one of Rio's most famous samba "schools", Mangueira.

Her father helped to found the school in 1928, and from the age of seven she danced in the annual carnival parade, when the schools, in reality community clubs located in different shantytowns, compete for the title of champion.

Mangueira, a favela, or shantytown, located on a steep hillside beside a railway in a shabby part of Rio, became one of the most famous samba schools, at a time when Brazilian music was dominated by samba rhythms and the songs of a generation of brilliant composers like Noel Rosa, Cartola and Nelson Cavaquinho. Neuma's intense devotion to Mangueira and a newspaper headline about a visit to the school by Maria Teresa Goulart, Brazil's first lady during the 1962-64 presidency of her husband Joao, led to Neuma becoming known as "Dona Neuma de Mangueira", the first lady of samba.

In the days before organised crime had cast its shadow over the favelas, the annual carnival parade was the highlight of the year. Dona Neuma used to tell the story of what happened in 1938, when Mangueira's participation was threatened by the needlewoman who refused to hand over the new flag she had embroidered for the parade because they did not have enough money to pay her. So Neuma and other girls formed groups and ran up and down the steep alleyways holding out old flags for people to throw their contributions into. "It was the bread money, the milk money, but that's how we managed to pay for the new flag and take part in the parade," she remembered.

Today Mangueira, like most of the other Rio shantytowns, has been infiltrated by drug gangs. Dona Neuma recently observed: "It's the law of the trigger. As soon as you begin to climb up the hill men appear to ask you whether you're after black [marijuana] or white [cocaine]." Dona Neuma was notorious for her frankness and her generous use of four-letter words, but she was also an extremely maternal woman who loved children, and fostered 23 besides her own three daughters.

A friend said: "For any child who appeared at her house she always had a plate of food and a warm word. She saw many die after getting involved with the bandits who used the shantytowns." This led her to begin a project to provide an alternative through education, sport and vocational courses. At the foot of the shantytown there is now a large concrete building called the Mangueira Olympic Village, where sports, samba rehearsals and classes all take place. More than 5,000 children attend courses there.

Dona Neuma asked that, when she died, her wake would not be held in the samba centre, because it was a place of joy and celebration, not sadness. Her wish was respected, but the presence of many of Rio's most illustrious samba composers and singers turned her funeral into a party.

Fireworks exploded as drummers picked their way among the tombs of the Caju cemetery, beating out her favourite tunes: after her coffin, crammed with pink gladioli and green foliage, the colours of Mangueira, had been lowered into the grave and covered with a stone, a white haired sambista danced on the tombstone, and hundreds of children from the shantytown projects Dona Neuma helped to start sang old carnival songs. She is survived by her daughters, four grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and 18 of her foster children.

Neuma Goncalves da Silva ('Dona Neuma de Mangueira'), samba dancer, born May 8 1922; died July 17 2000

webTitle: Leader: Parliamentary criticism over military sales to Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Policing the arms trade
fields.standfirst:
The rules remain too permissive
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The parliamentary criticism levelled at the government over recent military sales to Zimbabwe has once again demonstrated the difficulty of reconciling support for international human rights and democratic values with the commercial priorities of Britain's powerful arms export industry.
fields.body:
The parliamentary criticism levelled at the government over recent military sales to Zimbabwe has once again demonstrated the difficulty of reconciling support for international human rights and democratic values with the commercial priorities of Britain's powerful arms export industry. In this specific instance, the broadside delivered jointly by four Commons select committees is a trifle harsh. There certainly was confusion and disagreement between Downing Street and the Foreign Office over the supply to Robert Mugabe's regime of seven spare parts for two serviceable Hawk aircraft. But in the event, the licences were rightly revoked.

In another recent case, that of Pakistan, the government began well by imposing an arms embargo after last October's coup. But then the DTI outflanked the FCO to secure a relaxation of the ban. It is a mixed record that has been re-played again and again since Labour, holding pledges to support business in one hand and high-minded mission statements in the other, took office. Sales of military aero-engines to China highlight legitimate, unanswered questions about Beijing's rights abuses (and its strategic ambitions). Sales to Indonesia, when set against Jakarta's repressive policies in Timor, are at first defended, then delayed. Whether the recipients of British hardware are the haughty autocrats of the house of Saud or boy soldiers in indebted Sierra Leone, accusations of hypocrisy fly, Whitehall squabbles, and Tories taunt the foreign secretary Robin Cook with his now notorious 1997 proclamation of an "ethical" foreign policy.

In introducing considerations of principle into a lucrative, hard-nosed business on which thousands of UK jobs supposedly depend, Mr Cook always faced an uphill struggle, with the industry it self, with a two-faced Opposition, and indeed with some colleagues. But at least he has made the attempt. And in truth, some worthwhile steps have been taken.

Guidelines have been imposed barring sales of equipment that could be used for internal repression or external aggression. Britain has led the the bid to proscribe landmines and restrict proliferation of small arms. Labour has introduced an annual report on arms exports and has this year provided more details of equipment sold. Peter Hain, the FCO minister, does not rule out the committees' suggestion that military licences be subjected to prior scrutiny by MPs, if commercial confidentiality can be maintained. And it was Britain which was a prime mover in creating the EU's code of conduct on arms exports in 1998.

But far more needs to be done. Greater accountability to parliament is indeed necessary, as is greater transparency in terms of information publicly available about the end users, the volume and the value of arms exports. The voluntary EU code should be given teeth, perhaps through the creation of an EU watchdog agency working in tandem with Europe's new defence procurement arm. Labour's manifesto pledge to develop a defence diversification agency should be honoured. And proposed legislation covering UK-run arms brokering and trafficking (including a brokers' register) must go forward in the Queen's Speech. Indeed, far from being dropped, as recently hinted, the bill should be expanded to create a new, overall regulatory framework for arms exports, a long-overdue reform championed by Sir Richard Scott in his watershed 1996 report. Until such time as Britain is ready to forego a leading role in the arms trade, ethical dilemmas cannot be avoided. But their causes and effects can be tackled more vigorously.

webTitle: Cecil Merritt VC

fields.headline: Cecil Merritt VC
fields.standfirst: Canadian who set a daring example in Dieppe raid
fields.trailText: On August 19 1942, Lieutenant-Colonel Cecil Merritt, who has died aged 91, was commanding officer of the South Saskatchewan Regiment, part of the nearly 5,000-strong 2nd Canadian Infantry Division which was involved in Operation Jubilee, the disastrous attack on the French port of Dieppe.
fields.body:
On August 19 1942, Lieutenant-Colonel Cecil Merritt, who has died aged 91, was commanding officer of the South Saskatchewan Regiment, part of the nearly 5,000-strong 2nd Canadian Infantry Division which, with 1,000 British commandos and 50 United States rangers, comprised the ground forces for Operation Jubilee, the disastrous attack on the French port of Dieppe. For the Canadians, in particular, few of whom had any battle experience, the Dieppe carnage was a baptism of fire which left a lasting legacy.

Some claim Jubilee was a useless slaughter, others maintain it was a necessary, if costly, rehearsal for the Normandy landings two years later. The military purpose behind Dieppe was to gain experience of an opposed landing and capture of a continental port, and the lessons learned were closely studied by the D-Day planners.

The attack called for assaults at five different points over a 15-mile front. Merritt's South Saskatchewan Regiment was assigned to Green Beach on the right flank and its objective was Pourville and the cliffs above.

Landing in one wave in the early dawn, they were virtually unopposed until heavy firing broke out from German gun emplacements as they scaled the sea wall and advanced towards Pourville. Unfortunately, instead of landing astride the estuary of the river Scie, the Navy had put the battalion down too far west, on the wrong bank. This meant those companies assigned to take the high ground above the village had first to cross a bridge - which the Germans raked with heavy mortar and machine-gun fire. With the bridge covered with dead and wounded, the advance halted.

Aware of the need to regain the initiative, Merritt stood up, took off his helmet and, waving it in his hand, walked on to the bridge shouting at his men: "Come over! There's nothing to worry about here." Inspired by their CO's example, the men raced across in small groups while others swam the river making for the high ground and the enemy pillboxes. Merritt personally led survivors of at least four parties in turn across the bridge.

With increasing casualties among his commanders, progress slowed, but Merritt led the remaining men forward and succeeded in clearing the pillboxes. Merritt himself silenced one post by throwing in grenades. Having lost most of his runners, he kept contact with his positions by moving from one to the other under heavy fire. Although twice wounded, and with his battalion reduced to fewer than 300 men, Merritt managed to hold on to the improvised perimeter.

Just after 9am orders came through to withdraw, and the remaining troops pulled back to the beach. Here Merritt, collecting up every spare weapon he could find, set up a rearguard position in a small bandstand to cover the evacuation of the Canadian 6th Brigade. By 1.30pm, out of ammunition and with no chance of evacuation, but not willing to raise a white flag, Merritt sent a German prisoner forward to invite the enemy to take his surrender. The South Saskatchewans left 84 dead on the beach and 89 more, including Merritt and eight other officers, were taken prisoner. Of the 4,963 Canadians who embarked for the operation, only 2,210, including many wounded, returned to England. There were 3,367 casualties, including 1,946 taken prisoner; 907 Canadians were killed.

The announcement of the award of the Victoria Cross to Merritt, published in The London Gazette of October 2, 1942, spoke of his "matchless gallantry and inspiring leadership" and concluded with these words: "To this commanding officer's personal daring, the success of his unit's operations and the safe re-embarkation of a large portion of it were chiefly due." Merritt's VC was the first to a Canadian soldier in the second world war.

Throughout his three years in prison camp, Merritt made life as difficult as possible for his captors, and he was eventually sent to Colditz. Following his release in 1945, he was mentioned in despatches for his leadership while in captivity.

Merritt was born in Vancouver, British Columbia; his father, Major Cecil Merritt, was killed in the First World War at Ypres. Educated at University School, Victoria, he graduated from the Royal Military College, Ontario, in 1929 and, after studying law, was called to the British Columbian Bar in 1932. He had joined the Canadian Militia during the 1930s, being commissioned into the Seaforth Highlanders of Canada. Mobilised in 1939 and promoted major, he held a number of staff appointments in England. In March, 1942, Merritt was promoted to command the South Saskatchewan Regiment.

On his return to Canada in 1945, Merritt won the seat for the Vancouver-Burrard constituency as a Conservative. Following the re-election of the Liberals in 1949, Merritt, who had not greatly enjoyed being a back-bench MP, happily returned to his legal practice and rejoined the militia, commanding his original regiment, the Seaforth Highlanders of Canada.

Merritt's wife predeceased him; he had two sons and a daughter. With his death, the number of living recipients of the VC is reduced to 24, of whom only one is Canadian.

Cecil Charles Ingersoll Merritt, soldier, lawyer, politician, born November 10 1908; died July 12 2000

Educated at University School, Victoria, he graduated from the Royal Military College, Ontario, in 1929 and, after studying law, was called to the British Columbian Bar in 1932. He had joined the Canadian Militia during the 1930s, being commissioned into the Seaforth Highlanders of Canada. Mobilised in 1939 and promoted major, he held a number of staff appointments in England. In March, 1942, Merritt was promoted to command the South Saskatchewan Regiment. On his return to Canada in 1945, Merritt won the seat for the Vancouver-Burrard constituency as a Conservative. Following the re-election of the Liberals in 1949, Merritt, who had not greatly enjoyed being a back-bench MP, happily returned to his legal practice and rejoined the militia, commanding his original regiment, the Seaforth Highlanders of Canada. Merritt's wife predeceased him; he had two sons and a daughter. With his death, the number of living recipients of the VC is reduced to 24, of whom only one is Canadian. Cecil Charles Ingersoll Merritt, soldier, lawyer, politician, born November 10 1908; died July 12 2000

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: As president of the British Council of Churches during his archbishopric of Canterbury, Robert Runcie (obituary July 13) invariably presided over at least one session of the BCC's biannual assemblies.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Salter writes:
As president of the British Council of Churches during his archbishopric of Canterbury, Robert Runcie (obituary July 13) invariably presided over at least one session of the BCC's biannual assemblies.

He showed as much commitment to the wider ecumenical fellowship as he did to his relationship with the Roman Catholic hierarchy. As moderator of one of the BCC's five divisions (and the only woman of the five), I found him unfailingly supportive, quick to grasp the core arguments in debate, and full of wisdom in his leadership.

An incident, which is now part of ecumenical history, illustrates his lack of pomposity. At the start of the Vancouver assembly of the World Council of Churches, in 1983, at which he was a Church of England delegate, he stood in line waiting to register. "No one by the name of Runcie on the list," said the official at the desk. A colleague was called, and asked: "What do I do about this man?" "He's the Archbishop of Canterbury," hissed the embarrassed official. "Well, he should have said so." Robert Runcie - as well as the delegates - was highly amused.

WS Heath writes:
I read the first paragraph of your obituary of Ganju Lama (July 20) with incredulity. I have reason to remember March 17 1944 extremely clearly. My unit had by then relocated from Jamu to take up position in Imphal, which your contributor claims was held by the Japanese. It was not.

And the division was not an advancing force, it was one in retreat and only managed to avoid isolation and surrender by the skin of its teeth. But in no way would I wish to lessen the tribute to a very brave man. I had some contact with Gurkhas under fire and have admiration for them.

fields.headline: Back door influence
fields.trailText: Well done, Stephen Bates, for taking on the Christian Institute (Work of the devil, July 26). For many of us, it is not only the astute campaigning, the glossy materials, nor even the origins of their financial resources that raise concern.
fields.body:
Well done, Stephen Bates, for taking on the Christian Institute (Work of the devil, July 26). For many of us, it is not only the astute campaigning, the glossy materials, nor even the origins of their financial resources that raise concern. The CI's power and influence on government is deeply disturbing. On just about every issue that might be controversial, they have gained access to the ears of ministers, including over the European employment directive.

Their tactics are not new. Many of their arguments over the employment directive have been rehearsed in the debates around the Human Rights Act, the equalisation of the age of consent for gay men, the learning and skills bill and many others. The CI has already pitched its sights on the proposed reforms of sex offences legislation, whipping up steam amongst some of its kindred fundamentalist groups. When some of the current arguments were aired around the Human Rights Act, safeguarding amendments were put in place, either in the act itself or in other legislation such as the school standards and framework bill.

The CI's scaremongering now is no more valid than it was then. Their wrecking tactics must be seen as what they really are: an all-out assault on civil liberties and human rights. The employment directive and other UK domestic legislation, rather than being watered down, will have to be consistent with the European Convention on Human Rights. Having failed to wreck human rights legislation in 1998, the CI is now trying to do it by the back door.

Martin Pendergast
Chair, Christians for Human Rights
martin@lymegrove.cablenet.co.uk

fields.headline: A No vote on euro tactics
fields.trailText: Julia Langdon is eager to defend Robert Worcester (Few Britons are keen on Europe, July 25) from the charge of cynicism.
fields.body:
Julia Langdon is eager to defend Robert Worcester (Few Britons are keen on Europe, July 25) from the charge of cynicism. But the real criticism of his prescription for winning a referendum on the euro is not so much that it is cynical, as that it is unlikely to work. If, as he recommends, the government avoids talking about the euro until it is safely re-elected, and then suddenly announces the date of a referendum, its prospects of winning would be slight indeed.

The government has said it will only hold a referendum when it believes joining would be in Britain's economic interest. Any government going through an election campaign saying it is unsure whether Britain should join the euro and then immediately after re-election saying it has suddenly made up its mind, would face an insuperable credibility problem. The comparison with the 1975 referendum is misleading. In a euro referendum, the major opposition party, supported by great swathes of the popular press, will be against the government's recommendation. In 1975 the overwhelming majority of the political and media establishment was with the government.

Julia Langdon is right that party political considerations have polluted the European debate. The effect has been to induce among pro-Europeans a timidity and procrastination which have left a vacuum for the Eurosceptics to fill. Trying to postpone the debate on the euro until after the next election will only postpone yet further the date on which a referendum can be held and won.

Brendan Donnelly
Deputy leader,Pro Euro Conservative Party
brendan.d@btclick.com

Unless ministers rule out a referendum altogether, a failure to have a clear answer on the euro will expose Labour to ridicule throughout the election campaign. Labour's "don't ask, don't tell" policy is unsustainable. If it doesn't become more explicit (and soon) the Tories will have a field day.

Anand Shukla
London

So "we are far and away the least enthusiastic member state, according to any statistic that you care to measure". How about the Eurobarometer poll? This shows that 38% of Swedes (compared with 24% of us) think the EU is a bad thing, a net 4% more than those thinking it a good thing (1% more of us think it is a good than a bad thing). If we look at who thinks their country hasn't benefited from EU membership, this applies to 56% of Swedes, 48% of Austrians and 44% of Finns, not to mention 49% of east Germans and 42% of all Germans (compared with 44% of us). A greater percentage of Danes (47%) and Swedes (53%) tend not to trust the commission than us (40%).

Trust and support for the EU has been slowly going down in all countries. The particularly bad looking figures for the UK are largely due to the inclusion of people who don't know, or who expressed a neutral opinion, a much larger section than in continental Europe. Instead of bemoaning our Euroscepticism, you should spend more time telling us about the reality of Europe so that we can make our own minds up.

Stuart Thompson
Durham

It would be interesting to know to what extent the US puts pressure on the British media, especially that owned by Rupert Murdoch and Conrad Black, to persuade the public that joining the euro would not be in Britain's interest. An EU with a common currency, foreign and defence policy, plus a larger GNP than the US, would push the Americans into second place in terms of world influence. It may well be that both the Conservative and Labour parties are being similarly influenced.

Cllr Anthony Baker
(Lib Dem) Shepway council

fields.headline: Arts discord
fields.trailText: It is wonderful that Alan Howarth acknowledges the Aldeburgh Festival as exemplary (Letters, July 15), and that both the minister and the secretary of state for culture, media and sport chose to attend this year's Aldeburgh Festival.
fields.body:
It is wonderful that Alan Howarth acknowledges the Aldeburgh Festival as exemplary (Letters, July 15), and that both the minister and the secretary of state for culture, media and sport chose to attend this year's Aldeburgh Festival.

Sadly, the government's commitment to "accessible" culture has not extended to our organisation and our public funding has fallen in real terms. A committed management and board have taken risks and found considerable private support to provide well over nine-tenths of the funding we need to present work of such quality. Though delighted with the culture minister's recognition, we must modestly dispel the implication that our success is in any large part due to government arts policies.

We have ambitious plans and we trust that the Arts Council and Regional Arts Boards will follow the minister's lead and find support for the art itself in parallel to making it more accessible.

Thomas Ades
Jonathan Reekie
Aldeburgh Festival

fields.headline: Act on arms
fields.trailText: It is unsurprising that the government was confused earlier this year over whether or not it should allow the export of spare parts for the Hawk jets previously supplied to Zimbabwe (Parliament demands power to vet arms sales, July 25).
fields.body:
It is unsurprising that the government was confused earlier this year over whether or not it should allow the export of spare parts for the Hawk jets previously supplied to Zimbabwe (Parliament demands power to vet arms sales, July 25). Despite its good intentions, the government's attempts to patch-up an arms export control system that dates back to the second world war has not and cannot create the kind of clear cut rules on arms exports that are needed.

What is really required are not piecemeal measures, but tough new legislation that will indisputably deliver on Labour's 1997 manifesto promise to stop arms exports that may fuel internal repression or external aggression.

Kate Allen
Amnesty International UK

fields.trailText: Last week a plane crashed in northern India, killing many people, which you only gave marginal coverage to. When the Air France Concorde crashed yesterday you gave three pages to it. Don't third world plane crashes count as much as western ones?

Last week a plane crashed in northern India, killing many people, which you only gave marginal coverage to. When the Air France Concorde crashed yesterday you gave three pages to it. Don't third world plane crashes count as much as western ones?

Spiros Papaglimis
York

As one of Simon Hoggart's "little old ladies" (Letters, July 22), I am not too concerned about this label. What really bothers me is a growing tendency to separate the elderly from adults, eg on a recently prescribed medication: "Usual dose adults and elderly, 2 tablets." When I achieved grown-up status at the age of 21, nobody told me there was an upper age limit.

Lorna Judd
Milton Keynes, Bucks

Re Tesco's return to imperial measures (Letters, July 20): our newest granddaughter, Lucy, was born on Monday weighing 6lbs 12ozs. If her weight had been expressed in kilograms, it would have been completely meaningless to us.

Geoffrey Walter
Bromley, Kent

Perhaps Mr Branson (Letters, July 26) should have arranged to meet Ms Amery on any of his West Coast Mainline services. He would then have had plenty of time to sit, or stand as the case may be.

Philip Duffy
Stockport, Cheshire

Surely the News of the World will not be certain its policy of naming and shaming paedophiles is a success until profits show an increase (Letters, July 25).

Henry Robertson
London

Please could you publish the name, address and photograph of the editor of the News of the World together with an appeal not to resort to vigilante justice.

Tony Fry
Southampton

webTitle: Judges endorse refusal of citizenship to Fayed

fields.headline: Judges endorse refusal of citizenship to Fayed
fields.trailText: Three appeal court judges yesterday endorsed the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to turn down Mohamed Al Fayed's application for British citizenship and to refuse him a passport.
fields.body:
Three appeal court judges yesterday endorsed the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to turn down Mohamed Al Fayed's application for British citizenship and to refuse him a passport.

The most senior of the three, Lord Justice Nourse, said the Harrods owner's failure to stop a break-in to a safe deposit box belonging to his business rival on three occasions represented a "gross betrayal of trust", and agreed with Mr Straw that Mr Fayed, having lived in Britain for many years, ought to have known that making secret payments to MPs was improper and unethical. The judges ruled these two factors meant Mr Straw was not unreasonable when he decided that Mr Fayed had "a general defect in his character" and refused him citizenship.

Michael Beloff QC, representing Mr Fayed, had told the appeal court that Mr Straw had not treated his client's application for citizenship "with an open mind".

Lord Justice Nourse said the "grave allegation" that the home secretary had prejudged the decision rested on a Sunday Express article, in which it was claimed that Mr Straw "had told friends" he could not see how Mr Fayed could have citizenship if he paid MPs. The judge said there was no satisfactory evidence to establish that the home secretary had said the words quoted or, if he had, that they showed he had prejudged the issue.

Lords Justice Kennedy and Rix also dismissed the appeal. Lord Justice Kennedy said the case was "simply the application of a foreign national for British citizenship, and the more one looks at the material the more obvious it seems to me that the conclusion of the home secretary as to the character [of Mr Fayed] is a rational conclusion with which this court should not interfere".

An application to appeal further was rejected.

webTitle: Cancelling debt the best way to health

fields.headline: Cancelling debt the best way to health
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association is extremely disappointed that world leaders at the Okinawa G8 summit did not take the opportunity to turn their promises of debt cancellation into action (Letters, July 24).
fields.body:
The British Medical Association is extremely disappointed that world leaders at the Okinawa G8 summit did not take the opportunity to turn their promises of debt cancellation into action (Letters, July 24). Although all of the major creditor governments have given assurances on debt relief during the last year, and the British government remains strongly committed on the issue, the debt relief process is still too slow and offers too little hope to the millions in developing countries where paying debt interest takes priority over health and education. We believe that while the infectious disease initiative announced last week is a valuable contribution to improving global health, debt cancellation remains a fundamental part of the process.

Almost half the population of sub-Saharan Africa lives on less than $1 a day; one-eighth of the world's population are not expected to survive to the age of 40; 29% of all children under the age of 5 are underweight. Despite these terrible facts, many of the worst-affected countries still spend more on debt repayment than on health and education combined. Developing countries are forced to divert scarce resources from health and education budgets to pay debt interest, and international financial institutions impose strict economic programmes as a condition of debt relief. Such demands cannot be reconciled with the drive to reduce poverty and improve health.

Dr Edwin Borman
British Medical Association

Noel Hannon is right to op pose the plan to make it easier for skilled workers to settle in Britain on the ground that the loss of such workers will represent a grave blow to developing nations' future growth (Letters, 25 July). The statistics are already alarming. UN figures show that by the late 1980s almost one-third of skilled African workers had emigrated - 60,000 high- and middle-ranking managers emigrating to Europe and north America between 1985 and 1990 alone. Sudan lost 45% of its surveyors, 30% of its engineers, 20% of its university lecturers and 17% of its doctors and dentists. To give an even more alarming figure from a different country, an incredible 60% of Ghanaian doctors practise abroad.

Ian Heffernan
Watford
Hertsiheff@pgen.net

webTitle: 10 years' jail for man whose meticulous rape plot failed

fields.headline: 10 years' jail for man whose meticulous rape plot failed
fields.trailText: A sex attacker who planned a rape in "chilling" detail has been jailed for 10 years.
fields.body:
A sex attacker who planned a rape in "chilling" detail has been jailed for 10 years.

Marcus Hance tried to avoid being caught by shaving all hair from his body, trimming his nails and plucking his nasal hair. He wore tights around his shoes so as not to leave footprints, wore a balaclava and carried a knife and tights to threaten and tie up his victim.

He wrote a long list of the items he would need for the attack, to be carried out on a footpath near Exeter University where he knew women students often walked alone.

webTitle: Letters

fields.headline: Caring for the NHS
fields.trailText: At last an article which does not simply focus on the search for scapegoats (be they managers, doctors or nurses) or the idealism of providing a health service to appease the social consciences of a few to the detriment of the many who rely on the NHS (Faith healing, July 24).
fields.body:
At last an article which does not simply focus on the search for scapegoats (be they managers, doctors or nurses) or the idealism of providing a health service to appease the social consciences of a few to the detriment of the many who rely on the NHS (Faith healing, July 24). This idealism is often the thing which blinds so many to the shortcomings of a large monolithic service which, despite all the rhetoric, simply cannot be flexible enough to meet the needs of local populations.

As a former director of nursing, I have seen how the system mitigates against the provision of much-needed services, as this invariably requires more staff and more resources. We cannot make genuine progress on the best way to build a modern health system in the UK until we understand the need for real local control of hospitals and healthcare. The longer we allow politicians to use the NHS as a political soap-box, the longer it will be before this country can enjoy health care that befits a so-called developed nation.

It would be wonderful to see the trust put back into the relationships of patients/clients and their carers. Trust is the one thing that invariably has been lost or destroyed. Nurses for example now no longer have the time to care because too many management gurus and consultants were drafted in over the last 10 to 15 years to lecture us on the inefficiencies of the caring relationship when compared to commercial industry. We are indeed in a mess.

Mark Darley
South Bank University
darleyma@sbu.ac.uk

Many thanks for an excellent article, which supports the dismay many of us felt at the attempt to run the NHS like a commercial organisation. However, I am sad at the use of the phrase "balance of power between patient and doctor", which suggests competition of doctor against patient, rather than of patient, doctor, nurse and many other staff together against disease.

Dr Richard Gunstone
Rugby, Warks

webTitle: Universities to be given extra funding to keep key academics in UK

fields.headline: Science gets £4m to pay for brain gain
fields.standfirst: White paper lures key academics to fix UK in hi-tech premier league
fields.trailText: Universities will be given extra money to lure the "David Beckhams" of science to Britain - or dissuade them from going abroad - in the hope that they will catalyse an explosion of local genius and a flowering of silicon and biotechnology businesses around their labs.
fields.body:
Universities will be given extra money to lure the "David Beckhams" of science to Britain - or dissuade them from going abroad - in the hope that they will catalyse an explosion of local genius and a flowering of silicon and biotechnology businesses around their labs.

"There is global competition for talent, and we have got to make sure we are in the premier league," said Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, introducing the white paper on science yesterday. "We want to get the best in the world to the UK, because we intend to be the best in the world as far as science is concerned."

University salaries have stagnated. But with money from the Wolfson Foundation, a charity, the government has a £4m package to help universities to offer salaries of up to £100,000 to key scientists and turn the brain drain into a brain gain.

"It is key individual scientists who make the difference," said Lord Sainsbury, science minister. "The assumption is they will get a normal professor's salary, whatever, and this will be on top of that ... Money to travel, or have a research assistant, is equally important."

The white paper outlines plans for a £140m fund to create better links between universities, business and industry, and help small firms to exploit state of the art research; and £50m to help regional development agencies to support clusters of science businesses - and to encourage scientists and entrepreneurs to collaborate in the regions. Hi-tech small firms will be encouraged to develop new research capacity.

The government also proposes to invest £250m of new money in 21st century fields such as genomics, e-science, nanotechnology, quantum computing and bioengineering. Optoelectronics, a new field of communication technology, has become a £30bn business. This is expected to grow in the next decade to at least £200bn. Britain's share last year was about £4bn, half of all Europe's output.

Britain has 1% of the world's population but does 4.5% of the world's science. It produces 8% of scientific papers and gets 9% of the citations - a measure of how influential such papers can be. In this respect, Britain is second only to the US. "In value for money," says the white paper, "we are second to none."

The recent spending review promised a 7% average growth in real terms in government science investment over the next three years.

But the government is clearly worried about the future of science. It wants to beef up school labs, persuade "science ambassadors" to encourage children - particularly girls - to take science more seriously, and launch a "science year" in September 2001.

Mr Byers said: "Science will be the key to creating new jobs, providing better health care, ensuring a cleaner environment and tackling crime. We must build on our existing science base, to ensure excellence in science across the UK."

 Excellence and Opportunity: a science and innovation policy for the 21st century, Stationery Office, £11.60.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: EU pays to clear Danube debris
fields.body:
EU pays to clear Danube debris

The European Commission agreed to pay up to €22m (£13.6m) yesterday to clear the Danube river of debris from bridges destroyed by Nato's bombing last year.

The action supported an earlier decision made by EU finance ministers last week to pay as much as 85% of the cost of the project, which will be restricted to opening a navigable channel by next spring.
AP, Brussels

Seven years for Serb journalist

A Serb reporter was sentenced to seven years imprisonment yesterday for writing about atrocities committed by Serb troops in Kosovo last year.

Miroslav Filipovic, a reporter for the Belgrade daily Danas, was convicted by a military court on charges of espionage and spreading false information.
AP, Nis

95 herders die in cattle battle

A dispute about livestock between two heavily armed factions of the same tribe of herders has left 95 people dead in a remote corner of north-eastern Uganda, the army said yesterday.
Reuters, Kampala

webTitle: Holocaust victims win $1.25bn

fields.headline: Holocaust victims win $1.25bn
fields.trailText: A New York judge yesterday gave his approval to a landmark $1.25bn (£833m) settlement between Swiss banks and Holocaust victims and their families whose prewar deposits were never returned.
fields.body:
A New York judge yesterday gave his approval to a landmark $1.25bn (£833m) settlement between Swiss banks and Holocaust victims and their families whose prewar deposits were never returned.

The judge, Edward Korman, is expected to approve within the next month a scheme for distributing the funds among roughly 600,000 claimants. The first payments could be made by the end of the year.

Elan Steinberg, head of the World Jewish Congress, called the judgment "a victory for justice, a victory for memory".

In issuing his verdict yesterday, Judge Korman quoted one Holocaust survivor, Ernest Lobet, as saying: "I do not say it is fair, because fairness is a relative term. No amount of money can possibly be fair under those circumstances."

A lawyer for the banks, Roger Witten, said he also welcomed the ruling, adding: "We're as anxious as anybody to get this money out." Mr Witten said that the banks had already deposited $550m into escrow accounts in anticipation of disbursements in the coming months.

In the years before the second world war, an estimated 54,000 accounts were opened by depositors who later fell victim to the Nazis.

Those who survived often had problems recovering the deposits because they lacked detailed account information. Families of those killed in the concentration camps were asked to provide death certificates, an absurd and impossible request in the circumstances.

Yesterday's settlement also covered Jewish families whose property was seized by the Nazis and wound up in Swiss vaults.

Mr Steinberg said that the ruling would speed up the payments process, which was vital if the last few survivors were to see justice done. "That is why there is some urgency," he said. "We are losing 10% to 15% of them every year."

A three-year independent investigation into the issue, led by Paul Volcker, a former chairman of the US federal reserve, cleared the banks last year of "systematic destruction of records of victims accounts". However, the report also found that there was evidence of "deceitful actions by some individual banks".

In May, the two largest Swiss banks - Credit Suisse Group AG and UBS AG - agreed to grant access to databases containing 2.1m Holocaust-era accounts to help speed up restitution. They issued a joint statement after Judge Korman's decision.

"The banks hope that those Holocaust survivors or their heirs with an entitlement to the monies from the fund will receive the amounts they are due as soon as possible," the two banks said.

The Swiss Bankers' Association will publish a list of names of holders of dormant and closed accounts from the second-world-war era "who may have been victims of the Holocaust", they said.

webTitle: Only tomb can tell

fields.headline: Only tomb can tell
fields.standfirst: Joann Fletcher on an ancient riddle: is it a pharaoh's tomb or royal mummy workshop?
fields.trailText: Joann Fletcher on an ancient riddle: is it a pharaoh's tomb or royal mummy workshop?
fields.body:
K V.39 has baffled Egyptologists since its discovery in 1899. The highest of all the tombs in the Valley of the Kings, it remains the most enigmatic.

Some believe it was made to house the body of the warrior pharaoh Amenhotep I (1525-1504 BC). This would make it the first royal tomb to be built in ancient Egypt's famous necropolis. Others follow Howard Carter's original belief that the king was actually buried elsewhere. But KV.39 might be where royal mummies were rewrapped after the desecration of their original tombs further down the Valley.

Amenhotep I's own mummy was actually discovered in a mass burial of pharaohs in the nearby cliffs of Deir el-Bahari. Like his illustrious companions he had been carefully rewrapped and placed inside a new coffin. Ancient dockets on the mummies show that they had been moved several times in an attempt to stay ahead of the ancient tomb robbers always on the look-out for the rich pickings adorning the bodies. But the mummies' final resting place had been well-chosen, and they remained hidden until their discovery in 1881.

They were whisked away to Cairo's Egyptian Museum where today they lie in state. Some are on display in the royal mummy room while further bodies await redisplay in a second room now being prepared. All the pharaohs were unwrapped and examined shortly after their discovery, save for the ever-elusive Amenhotep I.

Only his mummy remains as it was found, its 5ft 10in frame still hidden within its linen wrappings, the face covered with a painted burial mask and swathed in the garlands placed over him by pious hands almost 3,000 years ago.

The king had been deified after his death alongside his mother and co-ruler Queen Ahmose-Nofertari, whose own superbly preserved mummy is that of a 70 year old woman with the family's characteristic buck teeth. The couple were especially venerated at Deir el-Medina, the village they founded to house those who built the royal tombs.

So given the importance of KV.39 and its significance in the history of Egyptian burial practices, it seems all the more amazing that serious excavation only began in 1989, a full 90 years after its original discovery. Under the auspices of the American Pacific Western University and partly funded by ICI, John Rose and his team of British and Egyptian workers cleared the debris-filled tomb over five seasons.

Their recently published findings have provided an accurate plan of its unusually complex design in which the standard "corridor" arrangement had been extended later by digging out two further passages.

The large amounts of material discovered support the idea that the tomb once functioned as a macabre kind of restorer's workshop, the place chosen to repair the ravaged remains of great pharaohs such as Ramses II, Seti I and the "Napoleon of ancient Egypt" Tuthmosis III (1479-1425 BC).

Standing only 5ft tall, Tuthmosis was the greatest of Egypt's warrior kings, expanding the Empire as far as the Euphrates River. His own wonderfully decorated tomb is the one closest to KV.39, and a popular spot with the tourists who clamber up a modern iron staircase to reach it.

The electricity supply to Tuthmosis's tomb was harnessed to provide the light the team needed to work deep within the tomb in the hill above. Among piles of debris the archaeologists recovered painted coffin fragments, great quantities of mummy wrappings of various sorts and sizes and embalming materials such as resin.

They even found a large golden signet ring, which after careful cleaning and conservation revealed the word "Menkheperre", throne name of Tuthmosis III himself. While analysing the ring, team member Stephen Buckley of Bristol University discovered what appeared to be traces of natron salts of the type used to dry the body during the mummification process.

An analytical chemist specialising in mummification materials, Buckley believes that "the ring may well have come from the mummy of Tuthmosis while it was being rewrapped".

During his analysis of the resins from the tomb Buckley also identified compounds found in myrrh, a preservative and anti-bacterial ingredient used in the preparation of bodies. His findings provide further interpretation of KV.39's history.

"Although we can never be 100% certain, the nature of the material we found leads me to think that the tomb could well be the place where royal mummies were restored prior to their reburial at Deir el-Bahari. In fact, much of the material we recovered still needs looking at, and would certainly repay careful study in the years to come".

There is more to emerge. It seems somehow appropriate that of all the tombs in the Valley of the Kings, it is KV.39 which lies closest to the summit of the natural pyramid-shaped peak of the Theban hills.

It was thought to be home to the cobra goddess Meretseger, "She who loves silence". It is clear that this mysterious place has yet to give up all its secrets.

webTitle: Stranger than fiction

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst:
Within 40 years, self-transforming robots could be scaling space, writes Sanjida O'Connell
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Within 40 years, self-transforming robots could be scaling space, writes Sanjida O'Connell
fields.body:
His real drive is to try to prove that life exists on a world other than ours. "It will profoundly change the way we think; we'll look at the stars in the sky in a whole new way," says Thomas Vaneck, one of Nasa's new vanguard: scientists who have been recruited to conjure up creations from the very edge of the possible.

NIAC, the Nasa Institute for Advanced Concepts, has just held its second annual conference, of 27 US scientists who have been awarded a grant by Nasa. They met to tell each other about their projects. "Fortunately for us, we don't have to make any of these things in the next few weeks, and I think this was Nasa's plan - to allow us to be dreamers," says Steve Dubowsky.

The plans range from an elevator to whisk us into space, "astrotels" - space rockets cum hotels doing a shuttle run between Earth, moon and Mars, a spacecraft driven by a magnetic field, to a more familiar dream - the creation of a giant flawless telescope. All the ideas are intended to be realised within 40 years.

Dr Christopher Brown, from Dynamac Corporation and North Carolina State University, has a plan that on the surface seems more feasible than most. It partly relies on deciphering plant genetics, and as the whole genetic map of one species of plant is almost complete, he may have a head start. Brown's idea is a programmable plant, a sci-fi hybrid we can talk to then eat. "Eventually we'll understand enough genetics to manipulate plants in a directed manner to make plants do what we want when we want them to do it," says Brown. The plants will be a marriage of genetic engineering and nanotechnology; they'll contain devices so tiny they could fit inside the plant's cells, perhaps even within an organ inside a cell. This device could send information about the plant to us, or receive information.

"We could send that signal over long distances, from a rocket or from Earth to Mars to say, 'The crew will be there in two months, please flower', or 'Please increase output of oxygen'; well, it's a plant so you don't have to say please, but you get the picture."

Brown thinks that potentially you could have plants that could do even more than flower, increase oxygen output, mop up excess carbon dioxide, and recycle water on command. Plants could also be grown to produce chemicals such as insulin, or tomatoes and potatoes at the same time.

"The fun thing about NIAC is that you can loosen up your mind and project it into the future, but this project is definitely feasible," he adds.

Although arriving on Mars with home-grown veg already waiting is an attractive option, many planets are too hostile for humans to explore. Dr Steve Dubowsky, from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston, is developing robots that will investigate whatever is thrown at them. "One wouldn't know before one got there what would be needed to carry out the task," says Dubowsky, "so the robots would morph when they arrived."

His self-transforming robotic planetary explorers will be made out of plastic that will act like muscles with the equivalent of nerves and a distributed intelligence; in other words, each part of the robot will be a mini computer capable of communicating with every other part in the same way as the internet allows computers to network together. The robots would initially morph in three ways: firstly they could change shape by contracting muscles in the same way as a snake can become longer and thinner.

Secondly, they could radically change by physically shifting body parts around. For example, after walking along on two legs using a pair of limbs as arms, they could attach their arms in a different position, fasten on another set and scale a cliff like a spider.

Finally, groups of robots would join to construct a solar panel or dig minerals for rocket fuel. This large robot could break down into smaller units and reassemble in different configurations as required.

"In 40 years' time they'll have a high degree of autonomy. One could imagine a simple task, such as mapping or searching for water or minerals, would require them only to check in every three years."

Ultimately we will just drop CTXs - continuously transforming explorers on a planet. "We'd just ship a bag of plastic over and it would form itself into a new device," says Dubowsky.

Dr Thomas Vaneck, from Physical Sciences, in Andover, Massachusetts, is also developing robot colonisers but instead of shape-shifters, he has borrowed ideas from nature. "Nature has had a long time and an infinite budget to create critters," he explains.

What drives him is whether there are any Europans. Europa, Jupiter's second moon, has water and heat, and its oceans could have hot, chemical vents similar to those found at the bottom of earth's seas. These geothermal vents are home to up to 300 species, so we may find equivalent life forms on Europa. The idea is that robot eels will swim down to the bottom of Europa's oceans, split open and give birth to seahorses which are more efficient swimmers and can hold onto rocks with their tails if the current grows too strong.

"These creatures are going to be made from materials that don't exist today," says Vaneck. "They have to be lightweight because it costs a lot to get them to another planet, and they have to withstand tremendous pressure and in a potentially nasty environment - we don't know whether they'll be bathing in acid."

He imagines a bone structure clothed in a skin grown from carbon nanotubes. So will the eels and seahorses spot life on Europa? "Frankly I would love it if something comes up and taps on the seahorse's camera and says, 'Hi, how are you?' But I suspect that the life we'll find will be microscopic, bacteria-like."
